## INTRODUCTION {¶=manual}

[pg xxvii] The Tractate *Niddah,* which comes seventh in the Mishnah editions of the Order of Tohoroth, is placed first in the editions of the Talmud, since it is the only Tractate in this order which consists of Gemara as well as Mishnah.

The term *niddah*1  is applied in Biblical and Rabbinical literature to a woman in menstruation who, by reason of her uncleanness, is subject to certain restrictions during her periods and for a varying number of days subsequently.

The origin of these regulations is Lev. XV, 19ff, which prescribe some general rules concerning *niddah* and *zibah* (v. Glos.). These enactments have been expounded and amplified in accordance with Rabbinical methods of interpretation and tradition, and have been made still more onerous by the strict customs adopted by Jewish women themselves.

The following is a brief summary of the ten chapters of this Tractate:

CHAPTER I describes the factors that determine the length of the periods of uncleanness in various classes of women, particularly with reference to the retroactive effect of the uncleanness.

CHAPTER II states the test which establish the beginning of the menstrual period and indicates which colours of discharge are clean and which are unclean.

CHAPTER III deals with the woman in childbirth, stating under what conditions and for what length of time she is unclean, and determining the period of uncleanness in those cases where the sex of the child cannot be established either because of hermaphroditism or on account of miscarriage or abortion.

CHAPTER IV is concerned with the condition of uncleanness of non-Jewish women, such as Samaritans, Sadduceans and idolaters, and of women in protracted labour. [pg xxviii]

CHAPTER V deals with the uncleanness of a woman whose child was delivered by a Caesarean section. It indicates also the signs of puberty in both sexes, determining their symptoms and the times of their appearance.

CHAPTER VI gives further details on the signs of puberty in the female. In this connection the rule is evolved that on the appearance of a particular symptom the other are assumed to exist, whereas the converse is not true. This terse rule is illustrated by a number of diverse topics where, likewise, it is seen that one condition or fact implies another, but not *vice versa* (cf. 49a ff).

CHAPTER VII discusses the uncleanness of menstrual blood and other impurities. It also states the circumstances and to what extent Samaritans are believed in regard to uncleanness.

CHAPTERS VIII — X indicate the tests to be applied to decide whether a stain is that of menstrual blood or of some other matter; describe the symptoms of the approach of the menstrual period; and deal finally with the condition *of* uncleanness of the corpse of a menstruant.

This Tractate contains little Haggadic material. Apart from the occasional homiletical interpretations of Biblical verses the following passages are noteworthy: the view that the physical qualities and characteristics of a person are preordained before birth whereas the moral character and spiritual outlook are left to the free choice of man (16b); the remarkable experiences of Abba Saul as a grave digger (24b); and the folkloristic belief in the blissful condition of the unborn child in the mother's womb (30b).

ISRAEL W. SLOTKI

Footnotes

\[H\] (from root \[H\] or \[H\]) 'isolation', 'impurity'. A menstruant is 'isolated' from her husband and keeps away from other persons and things because, being in her 'impurity' she renders them ritually unclean if she comes into contact with them.

The Indices of this Tractate have been compiled by Dr. Judah J. Slotki, M. A.

ISIDORE EPSTEIN [pg 2a]

## CHAPTER I

***MISHNAH***. SHAMMAI RULED: FOR ALL WOMEN[^fn_2a_1] IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON\] THEIR \[PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM THE\] TIME \[OF THEIR DISCOVERING THE FLOW\].[^fn_2a_2] HILLEL RULED: \[THEIR PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS IS TO BE RECKONED RETROSPECTIVELY\] FROM THE \[PREVIOUS\] EXAMINATION TO THE \[LAST\] EXAMINATION,[^fn_2a_3] EVEN \[IF THE INTERVAL EXTENDED\] FOR MANY DAYS. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: \[THE LAW IS\] NEITHER IN AGREEMENT WITH THE OPINION OF THE FORMER[^fn_2a_4] NOR IN AGREEMENT WITH THAT OF THE LATTER,[^fn_2a_5] BUT \[THE WOMEN ARE DEEMED TO HAVE BEEN UNCLEAN\] DURING \[THE PRECEDING\] TWENTY-FOUR HOURS[^fn_2a_6] WHEN THIS[^fn_2a_7] LESSENS THE PERIOD FROM THE \[PREVIOUS\] EXAMINATION TO THE \[LAST\] EXAMINATION, AND DURING THE PERIOD FROM THE \[PREVIOUS\] EXAMINATION TO THE \[LAST\] EXAMINATION WHEN THIS[^fn_2a_8] LESSENS THE PERIOD OF TWENTY-FOUR HOURS. {¶=1.1}

FOR ANY WOMAN WHO HAS A SETTLED PERIOD IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME SHE DISCOVERS THE FLOW: AND IF A WOMAN USES TESTING-RAGS WHEN[^fn_2a_9] SHE HAS MARITAL INTERCOURSE, THIS IS INDEED[^fn_2a_10] LIKE AN EXAMINATION WHICH LESSENS EITHER THE PERIOD OF THE \[PAST\] TWENTY-FOUR HOURS OR THE PERIOD FROM THE \[PREVIOUS\] EXAMINATION TO THE \[LAST\] EXAMINATION. HOW \[IS ONE TO UNDERSTAND THE RULING THAT\][^fn_2a_11] IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME SHE DISCOVERS THE FLOW'? IF SHE WAS SITTING ON A BED AND WAS OCCUPIED WITH RITUALLY CLEAN OBJECTS[^fn_2a_12] AND, HAVING LEFT THEM, OBSERVED A FLOW, SHE IS RITUALLY UNCLEAN WHILE THE OBJECTS[^fn_2a_13] REMAIN RITUALLY CLEAN.

ALTHOUGH THEY[^fn_2a_14] HAVE LAID DOWN THAT SHE[^fn_2a_15] CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS FOR A PERIOD OF TWENTY-FOUR HOURS \[RETROSPECTIVELY\][^fn_2a_16] SHE COUNTS \[THE SEVEN DAYS OF HER MENSTRUATION\][^fn_2a_17] ONLY FROM THE TIME SHE OBSERVED THE FLOW.

***GEMARA***. What is Shammai's reason?[^fn_2a_18] — He is of the opinion that a woman[^fn_2a_19] should be presumed to enjoy[^fn_2a_20] her usual status, and the status of the woman[^fn_2a_21] was one of cleanness.[^fn_2a_22] And Hillel?[^fn_2a_23] — When is it said that an object is presumed to possess its usual status? Only when the unfavourable condition[^fn_2a_24] is not internal;[^fn_2a_25] but as regards a woman, [pg 2b]

since what she observes \[is a discharge\] from her own body, it cannot be held that she is presumed to have her usual status.

Wherein, however, does this[^fn_2b_1] essentially differ[^fn_2b_2] from that of a ritual bath of which we learnt: If a ritual bath[^fn_2b_3] was measured and found lacking, all purifications that have heretofore been effected through it, whether it was in a public[^fn_2b_4] or in a private domain,[^fn_2b_5] are regarded[^fn_2b_6] as unclean?[^fn_2b_7] According to Shammai[^fn_2b_8] the difficulty arises from 'heretofore'; while according to Hillel the difficulty arises, does it not, from the certainty; for, whereas in the case of the twenty-four hours' period[^fn_2b_9] of the menstruant \[any *terumah*[^fn_2b_10] she touched\] is only held in suspense, it being neither eaten nor burned,[^fn_2b_11] here[^fn_2b_12] the uncleanness is regarded as a certainty?[^fn_2b_13] — The reason[^fn_2b_14] there[^fn_2b_15] is that it may be postulated that the unclean person shall be regarded as being in his presumptive status[^fn_2b_16] and assumed[^fn_2b_17] not to have performed proper immersion.[^fn_2b_18] On the contrary! Why not postulate that the ritual bath shall be regarded as being in its presumptive status of validity and assume that it was not lacking?[^fn_2b_19] — Surely a lacking \[bath\] is before you. But in this case also,[^fn_2b_20] is not blood before you? — She has only just now observed it.[^fn_2b_21] In that case[^fn_2b_22] too, is it not[^fn_2b_23] lacking only just now?[^fn_2b_24] — What a comparison![^fn_2b_25] In that case[^fn_2b_22] it might well be presumed that the water was gradually diminishing,[^fn_2b_26] but can it here also be presumed that she was gradually observing the flow?[^fn_2b_27] — What an objection is this! Is it not possible that she observed the blood only when it was coming in profusion?[^fn_2b_28] — In the former case[^fn_2b_29] there are two unfavourable factors[^fn_2b_30] while in the latter[^fn_2b_31] there is only one unfavourable factor.[^fn_2b_32] Wherein, however,[^fn_2b_33] does this[^fn_2b_31] differ from the case of the jug concerning which we have learnt:[^fn_2b_34] If one tested[^fn_2b_35] a wine jug for the purpose of periodically taking from it *terumah* \[for wine kept in other jugs\][^fn_2b_36] and, subsequently,[^fn_2b_37] it was found to contain vinegar,[^fn_2b_38] all[^fn_2b_39] three days it is certain,[^fn_2b_40] and after that it is doubtful.[^fn_2b_41] Now does not this[^fn_2b_42] present an objection against Shammai?[^fn_2b_43] — The reason there[^fn_2b_44] is that it can be postulated that the *tebel*[^fn_2b_45] shall be regarded as having its presumptive status, and then it may be presumed that it had not been ritually prepared.[^fn_2b_46] On the contrary! Why not postulate that the wine be regarded as having its presumptive status[^fn_2b_47] and then it might be assumed that it had not become sour? — Surely it stands sour before you. But in that case also[^fn_2b_48] is there not blood before you? — She has only just now observed it. But in that case too[^fn_2b_49] is it not sour only just now? — What a comparison! In the latter case[^fn_2b_49] it might well be presumed that the wine turned sour by degrees,[^fn_2b_50] but can it also be said in the former case[^fn_2b_48] that she observed the flow by degrees?[^fn_2b_51] — What an objection is this! Is it not possible that she observed the blood only when it came in profusion? — In the former case[^fn_2b_49] there are two unfavourable factors[^fn_2b_52] while in the latter[^fn_2b_48] there is only one such factor.[^fn_2b_53]

An incongruity, however, was pointed out between the case of the jug[^fn_2b_54] and that of the ritual bath:[^fn_2b_55] Wherein lies the essential difference between the two[^fn_2b_56] that in the latter case[^fn_2b_57] \[the retrospective uncleanness is regarded as\] a certainty while in that of the former[^fn_2b_58] \[the uncleanness of the *terumah* is deemed\] doubtful? — R. Hanina of Sura replied: Who is the author \[of the ruling concerning the\] jug? R. Simeon, who in respect of a ritual bath also regards \[the retrospective uncleanness\] as a matter of doubt; for it was taught:[^fn_2b_59] If a ritual bath was measured and found lacking all purifications heretofore effected through it whether it was in a public or in a private domain, are regarded as unclean.[^fn_2b_60] R. Simeon ruled: In a public domain they are regarded as clean but in a private domain they are regarded as being in suspense.[^fn_2b_61] [pg 3a]

And both[^fn_3a_1] deduced it[^fn_3a_2] from no other law than that of sotah.[^fn_3a_3] The Rabbis[^fn_3a_4] hold \[that the law of the ritual bath is the same\] as that of sotah; as \[the offence of\] the sotah is a matter of doubt and is regarded as a certainty[^fn_3a_5] so here also[^fn_3a_6] \[where the uncleanness is\] a matter of doubt it is regarded as a certainty. If \[the inference, however, is made\] from the sotah might it not be argued: It is like the sotah in this respect, viz., that as the sotah is clean \[if she is suspected of an offence\] in a public domain[^fn_3a_7] so should \[all the purifications effected in\] this case also[^fn_3a_6] be regarded as clean \[if the bath was\] in a public domain? — What a comparison![^fn_3a_8] There[^fn_3a_9] the cause[^fn_3a_10] is seclusion[^fn_3a_11] but seclusion in a public domain is impossible,[^fn_3a_12] but here,[^fn_3a_6] the cause[^fn_3a_13] being the deficiency,[^fn_3a_14] what matters it whether the deficiency takes place in a public, or in a private domain?[^fn_3a_15] And should you argue: Is not every doubtful case of ritual uncleanness in a public domain regarded as clean \[it could be retorted:\] Since \[in the case of the bath\] there are two unfavourable factors[^fn_3a_16] it is regarded as certain uncleanness. R. Simeon, however, holds \[that the law of the ritual bath is the same as that of sotah \[in this respect\]: As the sotah is regarded as clean \[where she is suspected of an offence\] in a public domain so also here[^fn_3a_17] \[are all the purifications effected regarded as\] clean \[if the bath was\] In a public domain. If \[the inference, however, is made\] from the sotah, might it not be argued: It is like the sotah in this respect viz., that as the sotah \[if suspected of the offence\] in a private domain is regarded as definitely unclean so should also \[all purifications effected in this case\] be deemed to be definitely unclean \[where the bath was\] in a private domain? — What a comparison![^fn_3a_18] In that case[^fn_3a_19] there is some basis for the suspicion,[^fn_3a_20] seeing that he[^fn_3a_21] had warned her and she had secluded herself with the stranger; what basis for uncleanness,[^fn_3a_20] however, is there here?[^fn_3a_22]

And if you prefer I might say that this is R. Simeon's reason:[^fn_3a_23] He infers the law of the termination of uncleanness[^fn_3a_24] from that of the inception of uncleanness;[^fn_3a_25] as with the inception of uncleanness if it is doubtful whether an object has or has not touched an uncleanness in a public domain it is deemed to be clean, so also with the termination of uncleanness, if it is doubtful whether an object had been duly immersed or not, in a public domain it is deemed to be clean. And the Rabbis?[^fn_3a_26] — What an inference![^fn_3a_27] There,[^fn_3a_28] since the man is in the presumptive status of ritual cleanness, we cannot on account of a doubt transfer him to a state of uncleanness, but here,[^fn_3a_29] seeing that the man is in the presumptive status of uncleanness, we cannot on account of a doubt release him from his uncleanness.

Wherein, however, does this[^fn_3a_30] essentially differ[^fn_3a_31] from the case of an alley of which we learnt: If a dead creeping thing was found in an alley it causes ritual uncleanness retrospectively[^fn_3a_32] to such time as one can testify, 'I examined this alley and there was no creeping thing in it',[^fn_3a_33] or to such time as it was last swept?[^fn_3a_34] — There[^fn_3a_35] also, since there are creeping things from the alley itself and also creeping things that make their way into it from the outside world, the case is the same as one that has two unfavourable factors. And if you prefer I might reply,[^fn_3a_36] This is Shammai's reason:[^fn_3a_37] Because a woman is herself conscious \[when she suffers a flow\].[^fn_3a_38] And Hillel?[^fn_3a_39] — She might have thought that the sensation[^fn_3a_40] was that of urine. As to Shammai, is there not \[the possibility of suffering a flow while\] asleep?[^fn_3a_41] — A woman asleep too would[^fn_3a_42] awake on account of the pain,[^fn_3a_43] as is the case where one feels a discharge of urine.[^fn_3a_44] But is there not the case of an imbecile?[^fn_3a_45] — Shammai agrees[^fn_3a_46] in the case of an imbecile. But did he not state, ALL WOMEN?[^fn_3a_47] — \[He meant:\] All sensible women. Then why did he not merely state WOMEN?[^fn_3a_48] — He intended to indicate that the law is not in agreement with R. Eliezer; for R. Eliezer mentioned 'Four classes of women'[^fn_3a_49] and no more, hence he[^fn_3a_50] informed us \[that the law applies to\] ALL WOMEN. But is there not the case of stains?[^fn_3a_51] Must we then[^fn_3a_52] assume that we learnt the Mishnah about stains[^fn_3a_53] in disagreement with Shammai? — Abaye replied: Shammai agrees[^fn_3a_54] in the case of stains. What is the reason? — Since she was neither handling a slaughtered bird nor was she passing through the butchers' market, whence could that blood have come?[^fn_3a_55] And[^fn_3a_56] if you prefer I might reply, This is Shammai's reason: If in fact any blood were there[^fn_3a_57] it would have flowed out earlier.[^fn_3a_58] And Hillel?[^fn_3a_59] — The walls of the womb may have held it back.[^fn_3a_60] And Shammai?[^fn_3a_61] — The walls of the womb do not hold blood back. But what can be said for a woman[^fn_3a_62] who[^fn_3a_63] uses an absorbent in her marital intercourse?[^fn_3a_64] — Abaye replied: Shammai agrees[^fn_3a_65] in the case of one who uses an absorbent,[^fn_3a_66] Raba replied: An absorbent too \[does not affect Shammai's ruling, since\] perspiration causes it to shrink.[^fn_3a_67] Raba, however, agrees[^fn_3a_68] in the case of a tightly packed absorbent.[^fn_3a_69]

What, however, is the practical difference between the latter explanations[^fn_3a_70] and the former explanation?[^fn_3a_71] [pg 3b]

— The practical difference between them is the possibility of pointing out an incongruity \[between the ruling in our Mishnah and the rulings concerning\] the jug, the ritual bath and the alley:[^fn_3b_1] According to the former explanation such an incongruity may justifiably be pointed out[^fn_3b_1] while according to the latter explanations such an incongruity does not exist. But what practical difference is there \[in the case of the latter\] between the one and the other explanation? — According to Abaye[^fn_3b_2] there is the case of the absorbent,[^fn_3b_3] and according to Raba[^fn_3b_2] there is the case of the absorbent tightly packed.[^fn_3b_4] It was taught in agreement with that explanation that 'if in fact any blood were there it would have flowed out earlier': Hillel said to Shammai, 'Do you not agree that in the case of a basket one corner of which was used for levitically clean objects while in another corner was found[^fn_3b_5] a dead creeping thing, the objects that were formerly clean are regarded as unclean retrospectively?'[^fn_3b_6] — 'Indeed', the other replied. 'Then \[Hillel rejoined\] what is the difference between the one case and the other?'[^fn_3b_7] — 'The one[^fn_3b_8] \[Shammai replied\] has a bottom,[^fn_3b_9] the other[^fn_3b_10] has none.'[^fn_3b_11] Raba stated: Shammai's reason[^fn_3b_12] is to avoid[^fn_3b_13] neglect of marital life.[^fn_3b_14] So it was also taught: Shammai said to Hillel, 'If so,[^fn_3b_15] you cause the daughters of Israel the neglect of marital life'.[^fn_3b_16] Now according to him[^fn_3b_17] who taught this explanation[^fn_3b_18] \[it may be objected:\] Was it not taught,[^fn_3b_19] in agreement with the former explanation,[^fn_3b_18] that 'if in fact any blood were there it would have flowed out earlier'? — There[^fn_3b_19] it was Hillel who erred. He thought that Shammai's reason was that if any blood had been there it would have flowed out earlier and, therefore, he raised an objection against him from the case of the basket,[^fn_3b_20] but Shammai answered him, 'My reason is the avoidance of the neglect of marital life; and as regards your erroneous assumption too, in consequence of which you raised an objection from the case of the basket, the latter has a bottom while the former has none.[^fn_3b_21]

But according to him who taught[^fn_3b_22] the first explanation[^fn_3b_23] \[it may be objected:\] Was it not in fact taught, in agreement with the latter version, that the reason is to avoid the neglect of propagation? It is this that Hillel in fact said to Shammai, 'Even if you give as your reason that "if in fact any blood were there it would have flowed out earlier," you must nevertheless make a fence[^fn_3b_24] for your ruling, for why should this law be different from all the Torah for which a fence is made?' To this the other replied, 'If so,[^fn_3b_25] you would cause the daughters of Israel to neglect marital life'.[^fn_3b_26] And Hillel?[^fn_3b_27] — 'Do I \[he can reply\] speak of marital life?[^fn_3b_28] I only speak of levitical cleanness'. And Shammai?[^fn_3b_29] — \[Restrictions, he holds, must\] not \[be imposed\] even as regards levitical cleanness, since otherwise[^fn_3b_30] the man might have scruples[^fn_3b_31] and keep away altogether.[^fn_3b_32]

(Mnemonic:[^fn_3b_33] *Bottom examined covered in a corner*.)

It was stated: If one corner of a basket was used for levitically clean objects and a dead creeping thing was found in another corner, Hezekiah ruled that the objects that were formerly[^fn_3b_34] clean remain clean. R. Johanan ruled: The objects that were formerly[^fn_3b_35] clean are now regarded as retrospectively unclean. But do not Shammai[^fn_3b_36] and Hillel in fact agree[^fn_3b_37] in the case of a basket that the objects that were formerly clean are deemed to be retrospectively unclean?[^fn_3b_38] — Shammai and Hillel agree[^fn_3b_39] only in the case of a basket that had a bottom,[^fn_3b_40] while Hezekiah and R. Johanan differ in that of a basket that had no bottom.[^fn_3b_41] But if the basket had no bottom what could be R. Johanan's reason?[^fn_3b_42] — It had no bottom, but it had[^fn_3b_43] a rim.[^fn_3b_44] But surely, it was taught:[^fn_3b_45] 'If a man drew[^fn_3b_46] ten buckets of water one after the other[^fn_3b_47] and a creeping thing was found in one of them, this one[^fn_3b_48] is unclean and all the others[^fn_3b_49] remain clean';[^fn_3b_50] and in connection with this Resh Lakish citing R. Jannai stated, 'This[^fn_3b_51] was taught only in a case where the bucket had no rim[^fn_3b_52] but if it had a rim[^fn_3b_53] all the buckets of water are deemed to be unclean.' Now must it be assumed that Hezekiah[^fn_3b_54] does not adopt the view of R. Jannai?[^fn_3b_55] — \[No, since\] water[^fn_3b_56] glides[^fn_3b_57] while fruits[^fn_3b_58] do not glide;[^fn_3b_59] or else \[it may be replied\] one is not particular with water[^fn_3b_60] but with fruit one is particular.[^fn_3b_61] And if you prefer I might reply: Shammai and Hillel agree[^fn_3b_62] only in respect of a basket that was not \[previously\][^fn_3b_63] examined[^fn_3b_64] [pg 4a]

while Hezekiah and R. Johanan differ in the case of a basket that had been examined. One Master[^fn_4a_1] holds \[the objects to be clean because the basket\] surely had been examined,[^fn_4a_2] and the other Master[^fn_4a_3] \[holds them to be unclean, since\] it might be assumed that the creeping thing fell in just when the man[^fn_4a_4] removed his hand.[^fn_4a_5] But \[the case of the basket,\][^fn_4a_6] surely, was taught in the same manner as that of the woman,[^fn_4a_7] and is not a woman[^fn_4a_8] deemed to be duly examined?[^fn_4a_9] Since the flow of blood from her body is a regular occurrence she is regarded as unexamined.[^fn_4a_10] And if you prefer I might reply:[^fn_4a_11] Shammai and Hillel agree[^fn_4a_12] only in respect of a basket that[^fn_4a_13] is uncovered,[^fn_4a_14] while Hezekiah and R. Johanan differ in respect of a covered basket.[^fn_4a_15] 'Covered'! Then how \[could the creeping thing\][^fn_4a_16] have fallen into it? — \[This is possible when\] for instance, the way of using it was by \[opening and closing\] its cover.[^fn_4a_17] But \[the case of the basket\] surely, was taught in the same manner as that of the woman,[^fn_4a_18] and is not a woman[^fn_4a_19] in the condition of being covered?[^fn_4a_20] — Since the flow of blood from her body is a regular occurrence she is regarded as being in an uncovered condition.[^fn_4a_21] And if you prefer I might reply:[^fn_4a_22] Shammai and Hillel agree[^fn_4a_23] only in respect of the corner of a basket, while Hezekiah and R. Johanan differ in that of the corner of a room.[^fn_4a_24] But was not a 'basket' spoken of?[^fn_4a_25] — It is this that was meant:[^fn_4a_25] If a basket was used for clean objects in one corner of a room and, when it was moved into another corner,[^fn_4a_26] a creeping thing was found \[in it while it was\] in that other corner, Hezekiah holds that we do not presume the uncleanness found in one place[^fn_4a_27] to apply to another place,[^fn_4a_28] while R. Johanan holds that we do presume.[^fn_4a_29] But do we[^fn_4a_29] apply the rule of presumptive uncleanness? Have we not learnt: 'If a man touched someone in the night and he did not know whether it \[was a person who was\] alive or \[one that was\] dead, and in the morning when he got up he found him to be dead, R. Meir declares \[the man\] clean, but the Sages declare \[him\] to be unclean because all questions of uncleanness are determined by \[the condition of the objects at\] the time they are found',[^fn_4a_30] and in connection with this it was taught, 'As at the time they are found and in accordance with the place in which they are found'?[^fn_4a_31] And should you reply that this[^fn_4a_32] holds good only[^fn_4a_33] in respect of the law of burning[^fn_4a_34] but that in respect of the law of suspense it is well applied,[^fn_4a_35] have we not learnt, \[it could be retorted,\] If a needle[^fn_4a_36] was found[^fn_4a_37] full of rust or broken[^fn_4a_38] it is regarded as clean[^fn_4a_39] because all questions of uncleanness are determined by \[the condition of the objects at\] the time they are found?[^fn_4a_40] Now why should this be so?[^fn_4a_41] Why should it not rather be assumed that this needle was formerly[^fn_4a_42] in a sound condition[^fn_4a_43] and that it produced the rust just now?[^fn_4a_44] Furthermore, have we not learnt: If a burnt creeping thing was found upon olives and so also if a tattered[^fn_4a_45] rag[^fn_4a_46] was found upon them it is clean,[^fn_4a_47] because all \[questions of\] uncleanness are determined by \[the conditions of the objects at\] the time they are found?[^fn_4a_48] And should you reply that \[the uncleanness is determined\] in accordance with \[the condition of the objects at\] the time they are found, irrespective of whether the result is a relaxation[^fn_4a_49] or a restriction of the law,[^fn_4a_50] only in the place where they[^fn_4a_51] are found, but \[if the doubt arises\] in regard to the place in which they[^fn_4a_51] were not found[^fn_4a_52] the objects[^fn_4a_53] are not to be burned but are nevertheless to be held in suspense,[^fn_4a_54] was it not in fact taught,[^fn_4a_55] \[it could be retorted,\] If a loaf of bread was lying on a shelf under which[^fn_4a_56] lay an object of a minor degree of uncleanness,[^fn_4a_57] \[the loaf,\][^fn_4a_58] although if it had fallen down it would have been impossible for it not to touch the unclean object,[^fn_4a_59] is clean, because it is assumed that a clean person entered there and removed it,[^fn_4a_60] unless one can testify, 'I am certain that no one entered there',[^fn_4a_61] in connection with which R. Eleazar stated: This assumption[^fn_4a_62] was required only in the case of a sloping shelf?[^fn_4a_63] — There[^fn_4a_64] the reason[^fn_4a_65] is as stated,[^fn_4a_66] [pg 4b]

'Because it is assumed that a clean person entered there and removed it'.[^fn_4b_1] But why should it not be assumed here also[^fn_4b_2] that a raven came and dropped \[the creeping thing into the basket\]?[^fn_4b_3] — In the case of a man who acts[^fn_4b_4] with intention such an assumption[^fn_4b_5] is made, but in that of a raven which[^fn_4b_6] does not act with intention such an assumption[^fn_4b_7] is not made. But consider: The loaf[^fn_4b_8] is a case of doubtful uncleanness in a private domain. Now is not any case of doubtful uncleanness in a private domain regarded as unclean?[^fn_4b_9] — \[The loaf is deemed to be unclean\] because it is a thing that possesses no intelligence to answer questions,[^fn_4b_10] and any thing that possesses no intelligence to answer questions, irrespective of whether it was in a public or in a private domain, is in any doubtful case of uncleanness regarded as clean.[^fn_4b_11] And if you prefer I might reply: Here[^fn_4b_12] we are dealing with a Rabbinical uncleanness.[^fn_4b_13] A deduction \[from the wording\][^fn_4b_14] also supports this view, for the expression used is 'middaf'[^fn_4b_15] which is analogous to the Scriptural phrase, 'a driven \[niddaf\] leaf'.[^fn_4b_16]

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: \[THE LAW IS\] NEITHER IN AGREEMENT WITH THE OPINION OF THE FORMER NOR IN AGREEMENT WITH THAT OF THE LATTER etc. Our Rabbis taught: And the Sages ruled, \[The law is\] neither in agreement with the opinion of the former nor in agreement with that of the latter, neither \[that is\] in agreement with the opinion of Shammai who[^fn_4b_17] provided no fence for his ruling[^fn_4b_18] nor in agreement with the opinion of Hillel who[^fn_4b_19] restricted far too much,[^fn_4b_20] but \[the women are deemed to be unclean\] during the preceding twenty-four hours when this lessens the period from the \[previous\] examination to the \[last\] examination, and during the period from the \[previous\] examination to the \[last\] examination when this lessens the period of twenty-four hours. '\[The women are deemed to be unclean\] during the preceding twenty-four hours when this lessens the period from the \[previous\] examination to the \[last\] examination'. How is this to be understood? If a woman examined her body on a Sunday[^fn_4b_21] and found herself to be clean and then she spent Monday and Tuesday without holding any examination while on Wednesday she examined herself and found that she was unclean, it is not ruled that she should be deemed to be unclean retrospectively from the previous examination to the last examination but only \[that she should be deemed to be unclean\] during the preceding twenty-four hours. 'And during the period from the \[previous\] examination to the \[last\] examination when this lessens the period of twenty-four hours'. How is this to be understood? If the woman examined her body during the first hour of the day and found herself to be clean and then she spent the second and the third hour without holding any examination while in the fourth hour she examined herself and found that she was unclean, it is not ruled that she should be deemed to be unclean retrospectively for a period of twenty-four hours but only during the period from the previous examination to the last examination. But is it not obvious that, since she has examined herself during the first hour and found that she was clean, she is not to be deemed unclean retrospectively for twenty-four hours?[^fn_4b_22] — As it was taught, 'during the preceding twenty-four hours when this lessens the period from the \[previous\] examination to the \[last\] examination'[^fn_4b_23] it also stated,[^fn_4b_24] 'during the period from the \[previous\] examination to the \[last\] examination when this lessens the period of twenty-four hours'.

Rabbah stated: What is the reason of the Rabbis?[^fn_4b_25] Because a woman well feels herself.[^fn_4b_26] Said Abaye to him: If so,[^fn_4b_27] \[a period of uncleanness from\] the time of her observation of the flow should suffice![^fn_4b_28] And Rabbah?[^fn_4b_29] — He only wished to exercise Abaye's wits.[^fn_4b_30] What then is the reason of the Rabbis?[^fn_4b_31] — It is one such as that which Rab Judah gave in the name of Samuel: The Sages have ordained for the daughters of Israel that they should examine themselves in the morning and in the evening; 'in the morning', in order to verify the cleanness of objects they handled during the previous night,[^fn_4b_32] 'and in the evening' in order to verify the cleanness of objects they handled during the previous day;[^fn_4b_33] but this woman,[^fn_4b_34] since she did not \[regularly\] examine her body,[^fn_4b_35] has[^fn_4b_36] lost one 'onah.[^fn_4b_37] But what could be meant by 'one 'onah'?[^fn_4b_38] — One additional 'onah.[^fn_4b_39] Said R. Papa to Raba: But would you not sometimes find that there are three 'onahs in twenty-four hours?[^fn_4b_40] — The Sages have laid down a uniform limit[^fn_4b_41] in order that there shall be no variations in the twenty-four hours' period. And[^fn_4b_42] if you prefer I might reply:[^fn_4b_43] \[the period extends to three 'onahs\] in order that the sinner[^fn_4b_44] shall not[^fn_4b_45] be at an advantage.[^fn_4b_46] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_4b_47] — The practical difference between them is the case of a woman who was the victim of circumstances and in consequence of which she did not hold her examination.[^fn_4b_48]

FOR ANY WOMAN WHO HAS A SETTLED PERIOD etc. Must it be conceded that our Mishnah represents the view of R. Dosa and not that of the Rabbis seeing that it was taught:[^fn_4b_49] R. Eliezer ruled, For four classes of women it suffices \[to reckon the period of their uncleanness from the time they discovered the discharge,\] viz., a virgin,[^fn_4b_50] a pregnant woman, a woman that gives suck and an old woman; and R. Dosa ruled, For any woman who has a settled period it suffices \[to reckon her period of uncleanness from\] the time she discovered the discharge?[^fn_4b_51] — It may even be held \[that our Mishnah represents the view of\] the Rabbis, for the Rabbis differ from R. Dosa only \[in respect of a flow\] that did not occur at the woman's set time[^fn_4b_52] but \[in the case of one that did occur\] at her set time they might agree with him; and our Mishnah deals with a flow that occurred at the woman's set time and it, therefore, represents the view of both.[^fn_4b_53] Thus[^fn_4b_54] it follows that R. Dosa maintains his view even where a flow did not occur at the woman's set time. Who then is the author of the following which the Rabbis taught: Though a woman has a settled period her bloodstain[^fn_4b_55] is deemed to be unclean retrospectively,[^fn_4b_56] for were she to observe a flow when it is not her set time she would be unclean retrospectively for a period of twenty-four hours?[^fn_4b_57] Must it be conceded[^fn_4b_58] to be the Rabbis only and not R. Dosa?[^fn_4b_59] — It may be said to be even R. Dosa; for R. Dosa may disagree with the Rabbis only in the case where the flow occurred at the woman's set time but where it occurred when it was not her set time he agrees with them;[^fn_4b_60] and our Mishnah deals with one that occurred at her set time and it is, therefore, in agreement with the opinion of R. Dosa [pg 5a]

while the Baraitha[^fn_5a_1] is in agreement with both.[^fn_5a_2] But why should not the final assumption be[^fn_5a_3] reversed?[^fn_5a_4] — As it is possible to adopt an explanation that leads to a relaxation of the law[^fn_5a_5] and one that leads to a restriction of it[^fn_5a_6] we adopt the one that leads to the restriction.

Now it was just taught,[^fn_5a_7] 'For were she to observe a flow when it is not her set time she would be unclean retrospectively for a period of twenty-four hours' — \[If this[^fn_5a_8] is\] the reason[^fn_5a_9] \[it follows\] that only in the case of a woman who has a settled period do the Rabbis draw a distinction between her stain and her observation[^fn_5a_10] \[of a flow\],[^fn_5a_11] but in the case of the other women[^fn_5a_12] concerning whom the Sages ruled that it sufficed for them to reckon their uncleanness from the time they discovered the flow[^fn_5a_13] \[the extent of the uncleanness of\] their stains is like that of their observation of a flow.[^fn_5a_14] Now whose view is this? — It is that of R. Hanina b. Antigonus; for Rab Judah citing Samuel who had it from R. Hanina b. Antigonus stated, In the case of all women their stains cause uncleanness retrospectively but in that of the women[^fn_5a_12] concerning whom the Sages ruled that it sufficed for them to reckon their uncleanness from the time they discovered the flow \[the extent of the uncleanness of\] their stains is like that of their observation of a flow,[^fn_5a_14] the exception being a child who has not yet attained the age of the suffering of a flow of whom, though her sheets are soiled with blood,[^fn_5a_15] no notice is to be taken.[^fn_5a_16] But does R. Hanina at all uphold[^fn_5a_17] the law of the uncleanness of a stain?[^fn_5a_18] Was it not taught: In the case of all women their stains are unclean and also in the case of the women concerning whom the Sages ruled that it sufficed for them to reckon their period of uncleanness from the time they discovered the flow their stains are unclean; while R. Hanina b. Antigonus ruled, The women concerning whom the Sages ruled that it sufficed for them to reckon their uncleanness from the time they discovered the flow are not subject to the law of uncleanness of the stain? Now does not this mean that they are not subject at all to the law of uncleanness of the stain?[^fn_5a_19] — No, it means that they are not subject to the law of the uncleanness of the stain retrospectively but they are well subject to it from now[^fn_5a_20] onwards. Does this[^fn_5a_21] then imply that the first Tanna[^fn_5a_22] is of the opinion that their uncleanness is even retrospective? — Yes; it[^fn_5a_23] being the view of R. Meir who restricts the law in respect of stains. For it was taught: In the case of all women their stains are unclean retrospectively and also in the case of the women concerning whom the Sages ruled that it sufficed for them to reckon their period of uncleanness from the time they discovered the flow their stains are unclean retrospectively; so R. Meir. R. Hanina b. Antigonus ruled, In the case of the women concerning whom the Sages ruled that it sufficed for them to reckon their period of uncleanness from the time they discovered the flow \[the uncleanness of\] their stains is like that of their observation \[of their flow\]; and a child who has attained the age of suffering a flow is subject to the law of the uncleanness of the stain while one who has not attained that age is not subject to the uncleanness of a stain, and when does she attain the age of suffering a flow? When she attains her maidenhood.[^fn_5a_24]

AND IF A WOMAN USES TESTING-RAGS WHEN SHE HAS MARITAL INTERCOURSE etc. Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: A testing-rag used before[^fn_5a_25] marital intercourse does not reduce \[the doubtful period[^fn_5a_26] of retrospective uncleanness\] as an examination. What is the reason? — R. Kattina replied: Because the woman is in a hurry to do her marital duty.[^fn_5a_27] But what matters it even if she is in a hurry to do her marital duty? — Since she is in a hurry to do it she does not insert the testing-rag into depressions and folds.[^fn_5a_28]

We learnt: IF A WOMAN USES TESTING-RAGS WHEN SHE HAS MARITAL INTERCOURSE, THIS IS INDEED LIKE AN EXAMINATION. Does not this mean that she uses one before intercourse and one after it?[^fn_5a_29] — No, the one as well as the other is used after intercourse but[^fn_5a_30] one is for the man[^fn_5a_31] and the other is for her; as we learnt: It is the custom of the daughters of Israel when having marital intercourse to use two testing-rags, one for the man and the other for herself.[^fn_5a_32] What a comparison![^fn_5a_33] If you concede that one is used before intercourse and the other after it one can well understand the necessity for the ruling.[^fn_5a_34] As it might have been presumed that on account of her being in a hurry to do her marital duty she does not properly perform her test we were informed that THIS IS INDEED LIKE AN EXAMINATION. If you maintain, however, that the one testing-rag as well as the other is used after marital intercourse, is not the ruling obvious?[^fn_5a_35] — It might have been presumed \[that the test should be ineffective\][^fn_5a_36] on account of the possibility of the appearance of a drop of blood of the size of a mustard seed[^fn_5a_37] which semen might cover up,[^fn_5a_38] hence we were informed \[that such a remote possibility need not be considered\]. And if you prefer I might reply: The Rabbis required a woman to perform two tests, one before intercourse and one after it,[^fn_5a_39] and in stating 'THIS IS INDEED LIKE AN EXAMINATION' the reference is to the one after the intercourse. But was it not stated, IF A WOMAN USES etc.?[^fn_5a_40] — Read: And a woman shall use.[^fn_5a_41]

LESSENS EITHER THE PERIOD OF THE PAST TWENTY-FOUR HOURS. Now that you stated that it[^fn_5a_42] lessens THE PERIOD OF THE PAST TWENTY-FOUR HOURS[^fn_5a_43] [pg 5b]

was it also necessary to state that it lessens THE PERIOD FROM THE PREVIOUS EXAMINATION TO THE LAST EXAMINATION?[^fn_5b_1] — As it might have been presumed that only in the case of the twenty-four hours' period did the Rabbis[^fn_5b_2] take into consideration the possible loss of clean things[^fn_5b_3] but not in that of the period from the previous examination to the last examination,[^fn_5b_4] we were informed \[that both periods are equally reduced\].

HOW \[IS ONE TO UNDERSTAND THE RULING THAT\] 'IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME SHE DISCOVERS THE FLOW' etc. What need was there[^fn_5b_5] for stating, IF SHE WAS SITTING ON A BED AND WAS OCCUPIED WITH RITUALLY CLEAN OBJECTS, when it should rather have been stated,[^fn_5b_6] IF SHE WAS OCCUPIED[^fn_5b_7] WITH RITUALLY CLEAN OBJECTS AND HAVING LEFT THEM, OBSERVED A FLOW? — It is this that we were informed:[^fn_5b_8] The reason \[why the bed is regarded as clean is\] because \[in the case of that woman\][^fn_5b_9] it suffices \[for her to reckon\] her \[period of uncleanness from the\] time \[of her discovery of the flow\] but[^fn_5b_10] \[where the uncleanness extends backwards over\] twenty-four hours the bed also is regarded as unclean.[^fn_5b_11] This provides support for Ze'iri, for Ze'iri ruled: \[A woman[^fn_5b_12] during\] the twenty-four hours preceding her discovery of a menstrual flow causes bed and seat[^fn_5b_13] to convey uncleanness to a man who in turn conveys it to his clothes.[^fn_5b_14] But consider: This bed is a thing that has no sense to answer questions,[^fn_5b_15] and is not doubtful uncleanness[^fn_5b_16] in the case of an object that has no sense to answer questions regarded as clean?[^fn_5b_17] Ze'iri explained: \[This[^fn_5b_18] refers to a case\] where her friends were carrying her in the bed so that the latter may be regarded as the hand of her friends.[^fn_5b_19] Now, however, that R. Johanan ruled that in the case of doubtful uncleanness conveyed through a human agency[^fn_5b_20] the object in doubt,[^fn_5b_21] though lying on the ground, is deemed to be capable of answering questions as if it had been a human being who has the sense to answer questions[^fn_5b_22] \[this[^fn_5b_23] holds good\] even though her friends were not carrying her in the bed.

\[Reverting to\] the \[above\] text, 'R. Johanan ruled: In the case of doubtful uncleanness conveyed through a human agency the object in doubt, though lying on the ground, is deemed to be capable of answering questions as if it had been a human being who has the sense to answer questions'.[^fn_5b_24] An objection was raised: If a man was wrapping himself in his cloak while clean or unclean objects were at his side[^fn_5b_25] or above his head and it is doubtful whether there was contact[^fn_5b_26] or not, they[^fn_5b_27] are deemed to be clean,[^fn_5b_28] but if it was impossible \[for the cloak and the other objects\] not to have come in contact they[^fn_5b_29] are regarded as unclean. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: The man is told, 'Do it again'[^fn_5b_30] and he does it again.[^fn_5b_31] They,[^fn_5b_32] however, said to him: No repetition \[test[^fn_5b_33] is recognized\] in questions of cleanness.[^fn_5b_34] Now why \[should they[^fn_5b_35] be clean\][^fn_5b_36] seeing that this is a case of uncleanness that is conveyed through a human agency?[^fn_5b_37] — This is beside the point,[^fn_5b_38] for R. Hoshaia learnt: In a private domain \[such a case of\] doubtful uncleanness[^fn_5b_39] is regarded as unclean, and in a public domain it is regarded as clean.[^fn_5b_40]

\[Reverting to\] the \[above\] text, 'Ze'iri ruled: \[A woman during\] the twenty-four hours preceding her discovery of a menstrual flow causes bed and seat to convey uncleanness to a man who in turn conveys it to his clothes'.[^fn_5b_41] But, surely, this cannot be correct.[^fn_5b_42] For did not Abimi from Be Hozai[^fn_5b_43] when he came bring with him[^fn_5b_44] a Baraitha which stated, 'During the twenty-four hours preceding the discovery of her menstrual flow a woman's bed and seat are \[as unclean\] as the object she touches', which means, does it not, that as an object she touches does not convey uncleanness to a human being[^fn_5b_45] so also does not her bed convey uncleanness to a human being?[^fn_5b_46] — Raba retorted: And do you understand this ruling[^fn_5b_47] seeing that it \[may be refuted by an inference\] a minori ad majus: If an earthen vessel that was covered with a tight fitting lid, which is protected from uncleanness in a corpse's tent,[^fn_5b_48] is yet not so protected \[from the uncleanness\] of the twenty-four hours preceding the discovery of a menstrual flow,[^fn_5b_49] is it not logical that the beds and seats \[of a menstruant\], which are not protected from uncleanness in a corpse's tent, should not be protected from the uncleanness of the twenty-four hours preceding the discovery of a menstrual flow?[^fn_5b_50] — But did not Abimi of Be Hozai quote a Baraitha?[^fn_5b_51] — Read:[^fn_5b_52] A woman's bed and seat[^fn_5b_53] [pg 6a]

are \[as unclean\] as that which touches the body of the menstruant herself; just as the touching of her body causes the uncleanness of a human being who in turn causes the uncleanness of the clothes he wears[^fn_6a_1] so does the touching of her bed or seat cause the uncleanness of a human being who in turn causes the uncleanness of the clothes he wears.

It was taught in agreement with Raba: A woman who observed a bloodstain[^fn_6a_2] conveys uncleanness retrospectively.[^fn_6a_3] And what are the things to which she conveys the uncleanness?[^fn_6a_4] Foodstuffs and drinks,[^fn_6a_5] beds and seats,[^fn_6a_6] as well as any earthen vessel, even though it was covered with a tightly fitting lid,[^fn_6a_7] and her counting[^fn_6a_8] is[^fn_6a_9] disturbed,[^fn_6a_10] and she conveys[^fn_6a_11] uncleanness to the man who cohabited with her retrospectively. R. Akiba[^fn_6a_12] ruled: She conveys uncleanness to the man who cohabited with her but begins her counting[^fn_6a_13] from the time only of her observing a flow. If she observed a flow of blood,[^fn_6a_14] she conveys uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours.[^fn_6a_15] And what are the things to which she conveys uncleanness?[^fn_6a_16] Foodstuffs and drinks,[^fn_6a_17] beds and seats[^fn_6a_18] as well as any earthen vessel, though it was covered with a tightly fitting lid,[^fn_6a_19] her counting[^fn_6a_20] is not[^fn_6a_21] disturbed and she does not convey[^fn_6a_22] uncleanness to the man who cohabited with her.[^fn_6a_23] In either case, however,[^fn_6a_24] the uncleanness[^fn_6a_25] is held in suspense \[and any consecrated foodstuffs touched\] must neither be eaten nor burned.[^fn_6a_26] As to Raba, however,[^fn_6a_27] if he heard of the Baraitha,[^fn_6a_28] why did he not say \[that his ruling is derived from\] a Baraitha? And if he did not hear of the Baraitha, whence did he \[derive the law for his inference\] a minori ad majus? — The fact is that he heard of the Baraitha, but[^fn_6a_29] were he to derive his ruling from the Baraitha it could have been objected \[that the uncleanness[^fn_6a_30] is conveyed\] either to the man or to his clothes[^fn_6a_31] but not to the man as well as to the clothes he wears,[^fn_6a_32] hence he had recourse to his inference a minori ad majus.[^fn_6a_33]

R. Huna ruled: \[The retrospective uncleanness during\] the twenty-four hours \[preceding the observation\] of a menstrual flow is conveyed only to hallowed things but not to *terumah*. But if so, should not this law have been mentioned together with those of the other grades \[of sanctity\]?[^fn_6a_34] — Only cases that involve definite uncleanness are enumerated but any in which no definite uncleanness is involved[^fn_6a_35] is not mentioned.

An objection was raised: What are the things to which she conveys uncleanness? Foodstuffs and drinks.[^fn_6a_36] Does not this[^fn_6a_37] mean those that are hallowed as well as those that are *terumah*? — No, only those that are hallowed.[^fn_6a_38]

Come and hear: R. Judah ruled \[that priestly women must examine their bodies\] even after they have concluded a meal[^fn_6a_39] of *terumah*;[^fn_6a_40] and the point raised, 'Is not the consumed meal a matter of the past?'[^fn_6a_41] \[And to this\] R. Hisda replied: This[^fn_6a_42] was necessary only for the sake of ensuring the fitness of the remnants before her?[^fn_6a_43] — R. Huna reads:[^fn_6a_44] 'To burn the remnants that were in her hands',[^fn_6a_45] the examination being held immediately after[^fn_6a_46] \[the meal\].[^fn_6a_47]

Come and hear: It once happened that Rabbi acted[^fn_6a_48] in accordance with the ruling of R. Eliezer,[^fn_6a_49] and after he reminded himself[^fn_6a_50] he observed, 'R. Eliezer deserves to be relied upon [pg 6b]

in an emergency'.[^fn_6b_1] And the point was raised, What could be the meaning of 'after he reminded himself'? If it be explained, 'After he remembered that the *halachah* was not in agreement with R. Eliezer but in agreement with the Rabbis', \[the difficulty would arise:\] How could he act according to the former's ruling[^fn_6b_2] even in an emergency? Hence,[^fn_6b_3] \[it means after he recalled\] that it was not stated whether the law was in agreement with the one Master or with the other Master, and having recalled that it was not an individual that differed from him[^fn_6b_4] but that many differ from him he observed, 'R. Eliezer deserves to be relied upon in an emergency'.[^fn_6b_1] Now if it is granted \[that retrospective uncleanness applies also\] to *terumah*[^fn_6b_5] one can well understand the incident[^fn_6b_6] since *terumah* was in existence in the days of Rabbi, but if it is maintained \[that retrospective uncleanness is applicable only\] to hallowed things[^fn_6b_7] \[the objection would arise:\] Were there hallowed things in the days of Rabbi?[^fn_6b_8] — \[This may be explained\] on the lines of a statement of 'Ullah. As 'Ulla stated, 'The Associates'[^fn_6b_9] in Galilee[^fn_6b_10] keep their things[^fn_6b_11] in levitical cleanness';[^fn_6b_12] so they may have done it in the days of Rabbi.

Come and hear: It once happened that R. Gamaliel's[^fn_6b_13] maid was baking bread loaves of *terumah* and after each[^fn_6b_14] she rinsed her hands with water and held an examination. After the last one when she held the examination she found herself to be unclean and she came and asked R. Gamaliel who told her that they were all unclean.[^fn_6b_15] 'Master', she said to him, 'did I not hold an examination after each one'?[^fn_6b_14] 'If so', he told her, 'the last[^fn_6b_16] is unclean[^fn_6b_17] while all the others are clean'. At all events was it not here stated, 'bread loaves of terumah'?[^fn_6b_18] — By *terumah* was meant[^fn_6b_19] the bread loaves[^fn_6b_20] of a thanksgiving-offering.[^fn_6b_21] But how does it come about that the loaves of a thanksgiving-offering[^fn_6b_22] should require to be baked?[^fn_6b_23] This is a case where they[^fn_6b_24] were set aside[^fn_6b_25] while they were being kneaded,[^fn_6b_26] this being in line with what R. Tobi b. Kattina[^fn_6b_27] ruled: 'If a man baked the loaves of a thanksgiving-offering in four loaves[^fn_6b_28] he has performed his duty'. \[For when\] the objection was raised, 'Do we not require forty loaves',[^fn_6b_29] \[the reply was that\] this[^fn_6b_30] is just a religious requirement.[^fn_6b_31] But, surely, \[it was asked,\] is it not necessary to separate *terumah*[^fn_6b_25] from each?[^fn_6b_32] And should you reply that one might break off a piece from each[^fn_6b_33] \[it could be retorted that:\] The All Merciful said, one[^fn_6b_34] which implies that one must not break off a piece.[^fn_6b_25] \[To this\] it was replied that 'they were set aside while they were being kneaded';[^fn_6b_35] so here also[^fn_6b_36] it may be explained that they were separated while they were being kneaded.[^fn_6b_37]

Come and hear: Another incident took place when R. Gamaliel's maid was sealing wine jars with clay that after each she rinsed her hands with water and held an examination. After the last one when she held the examination and found herself to be unclean she came and asked R. Gamaliel who told her that they were all unclean. 'But, surely', she said to him, 'I held an examination after each one'. 'If so', he told her, 'the last[^fn_6b_38] is unclean while all the others are clean'. Now if it is conceded that one incident[^fn_6b_39] concerned hallowed things and the other *terumah*, it can be well understood why she asked a second time, but if it is contended that the former as well as the latter concerned hallowed things, why should she have asked him a second time? — \[Each\] incident occurred with a different maid.[^fn_6b_40]

Another version: R. Huna ruled, \[The retrospective uncleanness during\] the twenty-four hours \[preceding the observation\] of a menstrual flow is conveyed both to hallowed things and to *terumah*. Whence is this[^fn_6b_41] inferred? From its omission in the enumeration of[^fn_6b_42] the various grades \[of sanctity\].[^fn_6b_43] Said R. Nahman to him: Surely, a Tanna[^fn_6b_44] recited \[that the retrospective uncleanness\][^fn_6b_45] applies only to hallowed things and not to *terumah*. R. Samuel son of R. Isaac accepted this \[teaching\][^fn_6b_46] from him \[and explained it\] as applying to common food that was prepared under conditions of hallowed things and not to common food that was prepared in conditions of *terumah*.[^fn_6b_47]

We learnt elsewhere: If a question of doubtful uncleanness has arisen about a dough[^fn_6b_48] before it was rolled[^fn_6b_49] it may be prepared in uncleanness,[^fn_6b_50] \[but if the doubt has arisen\] after it had been rolled[^fn_6b_51] it must be prepared in cleanness.[^fn_6b_52] 'Before it was rolled it may be prepared in uncleanness', because it is common food and it is permitted to cause uncleanness to common food in Erez Israel. 'After it had been rolled it must be prepared in cleanness', because common food that is in a condition of *tebel*[^fn_6b_53] in respect of the dough-offering is regarded as dough-offering, and it is forbidden to cause uncleanness to the dough-offering. A Tanna taught: [pg 7a]

Its dough-offering[^fn_7a_1] is in a suspended condition[^fn_7a_2] and it may neither be eaten nor burned. In respect of what doubt did they[^fn_7a_3] give this ruling?[^fn_7a_4] In respect of a doubt applicable to the dough-offering.[^fn_7a_5] What is meant by 'a doubt applicable to the dough-offering'? — Both Abaye and Raba explained: That one should not assume that the ruling[^fn_7a_6] applies only to[^fn_7a_7] a case of likely uncleanness[^fn_7a_8] such as that of the two paths,[^fn_7a_9] for in that case even mere common food contracts uncleanness;[^fn_7a_10] but that it applies also in the case

actual *terumah* which is subject to the same restrictions as hallowed things where only 'leaning' might be assumed;[^fn_7a_11] for we learnt: If a *zab*[^fn_7a_12] and a clean person were unloading an ass or loading it, if the load was heavy[^fn_7a_13] \[the latter\] is unclean; if it was light[^fn_7a_14] he is clean and in either case[^fn_7a_15] he is regarded as clean[^fn_7a_16] \[even if he is\] of the members of the Synagogue[^fn_7a_17] but as unclean[^fn_7a_18] in respect of *terumah*,[^fn_7a_19] and 'unconsecrated food that is in a condition of *tebel* in respect of the dough-offering' is regarded as dough-offering.[^fn_7a_20] But have we not learnt:[^fn_7a_21] A woman who is a tebulath yom[^fn_7a_22] may[^fn_7a_23] knead her dough and cut off from it its dough-offering[^fn_7a_24] and put it on an inverted basket of palm-twigs or on a board,[^fn_7a_25] and then[^fn_7a_26] bring it close \[to the major portion of the dough\] and designate it \[as dough-offering;[^fn_7a_27] this procedure being permitted\] because the uncleanness of the dough[^fn_7a_28] is only of the third grade,[^fn_7a_29] and the third grade is regarded as clean in common food.[^fn_7a_30] Now if you were to maintain that 'common food that is in a condition of *tebel* in respect of the dough-offering is regarded as dough-offering' \[the objection would arise:\] Did she not in fact convey uncleanness to it?[^fn_7a_31] — Said Abaye: In regard to any object,[^fn_7a_32] that conveys certain uncleanness to common food, uncleanness has been imposed as a preventive measure, even in a doubtful case, where common food that is in a condition of *tebel* in respect of the dough-offering is concerned,[^fn_7a_33] but in regard to the woman who is a tebulath yom, since she does not convey certain uncleanness to common food,[^fn_7a_34] no uncleanness has been imposed as a preventive measure in a doubtful case where common food that is in a condition of *tebel* in respect of the dough-offering is concerned.[^fn_7a_33] But is there not the case of the retrospective uncleanness of the twenty-four hours \[preceding the observation\] of a menstrual flow which[^fn_7a_35] conveys certain uncleanness to common food and in connection with which, nevertheless, no uncleanness has been imposed as a preventive measure in a case of doubt[^fn_7a_36] where common food that is in a condition of *tebel* in respect of the dough-offering is concerned;[^fn_7a_33] for has not the Master said, 'R. Samuel son of R. Isaac accepted from him this \[teaching, and explained it\] as applying to common food that was prepared under conditions of hallowed things and not to common food that was prepared in conditions of terumah'?[^fn_7a_37] — In the former case[^fn_7a_38] no *terumah* is kneaded up with the common food[^fn_7a_39] but in the latter case *terumah*[^fn_7a_40] is kneaded up with the dough.[^fn_7a_41] And if you prefer I might reply: Leave out of the question the retrospective uncleanness of the twenty-four hours, since it is merely a Rabbinical measure.

***MISHNAH***. R. ELIEZER RULED: IN THE CASE OF FOUR CLASSES OF WOMEN IT SUFFICES \[FOR THEM TO RECKON\] THEIR \[PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME \[OF THEIR DISCOVERING OF THE FLOW\]: A VIRGIN,[^fn_7a_42] A WOMAN IN PREGNANCY,[^fn_7a_42] A NURSING WOMAN,[^fn_7a_42] AND AN OLD WOMAN.[^fn_7a_42] R. JOSHUA SAID: I HAVE ONLY HEARD \[THE RULING[^fn_7a_43] APPLIED TO\] A VIRGIN.[^fn_7a_44] [pg 7b] {¶=1.2}

THE *HALACHAH*, HOWEVER, IS IN AGREEMENT WITH R. ELIEZER.

WHO IS REGARDED AS 'VIRGIN'? ANY WOMAN, EVEN THOUGH SHE IS MARRIED, WHO HAS NEVER YET OBSERVED A FLOW. 'A WOMAN IN PREGNANCY'? ONE WHOSE EMBRYO CAN BE DISCERNED. 'A NURSING WOMAN'? A WOMAN BEFORE SHE HAS WEANED HER CHILD. IF SHE GAVE HER CHILD TO A NURSING WOMAN, IF SHE WEANED IT, OR IF IT DIED, R. MEIR RULED: SHE CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS RETROSPECTIVELY FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS;[^fn_7b_1] BUT THE SAGES RULED: IT SUFFICES FOR HER[^fn_7b_2] \[TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME OF HER \[OBSERVATION OF THE FLOW\]. WHO IS REGARDED AS 'AN OLD WOMAN'? ANY WOMAN OVER WHOM THREE 'ONAHS[^fn_7b_3] HAVE PASSED[^fn_7b_4] NEAR THE TIME OF HER OLD AGE.[^fn_7b_5] R. ELIEZER[^fn_7b_6] RULED: FOR ANY WOMAN[^fn_7b_7] OVER WHOM HAVE PASSED[^fn_7b_4] THREE 'ONAHS IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME OF HER \[OBSERVING OF A FLOW\]. R. JOSE RULED: FOR A WOMAN IN PREGNANCY AND A NURSING WOMAN OVER WHOM THREE 'ONAHS HAVE PASSED[^fn_7b_8] IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON THEIR PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME OF THEIR \[OBSERVATION OF THE FLOW\].[^fn_7b_9]

AND OF WHAT DID THEY[^fn_7b_10] SPEAK[^fn_7b_11] WHEN THEY LAID DOWN[^fn_7b_12] THAT 'IT SUFFICES \[FOR THEM TO RECKON\] THEIR PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM THE TIME \[OF THEIR DISCOVERING OF THE FLOW\]'? OF A FIRST OBSERVATION,[^fn_7b_13] BUT AT A SUBSEQUENT OBSERVATION[^fn_7b_14] SHE CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS RETROSPECTIVELY FOR A PERIOD OF TWENTY-FOUR HOURS. IF, HOWEVER, SHE SUFFERED THE FIRST FLOW ON ACCOUNT OF AN ACCIDENT[^fn_7b_15] IT SUFFICES FOR HER EVEN AT A SUBSEQUENT OBSERVATION \[TO RECKON HER UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME OF HER \[OBSERVING OF THE FLOW\].

***GEMARA***. It was taught: R. Eliezer said to R. Joshua, 'You have not heard[^fn_7b_16] but[^fn_7b_17] I have heard; you have only heard one tradition but I have heard many;[^fn_7b_18] people do not ask him who has not seen the new moon to come and tender evidence[^fn_7b_19] but only him who has seen it.' Throughout the lifetime of[^fn_7b_20] R. Eliezer the people acted in accordance with the ruling of R. Joshua, but after the passing away of R. Eliezer, R. Joshua re-introduced the earlier practice.[^fn_7b_21] Why did he[^fn_7b_22] not follow R. Eliezer during his lifetime? — Because R. Eliezer was a disciple of Shammai[^fn_7b_23] and he[^fn_7b_24] felt that if they[^fn_7b_25] would act in agreement with his ruling in one matter[^fn_7b_26] they[^fn_7b_25] would act in agreement with his rulings in other matters also[^fn_7b_27] and that out of respect for R. Eliezer no one could interfere[^fn_7b_28] with them; but after the passing away of R. Eliezer, when the people[^fn_7b_29] could well be interfered with, he[^fn_7b_24] re-introduced the original practice.

Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in four cases. One is that which has just been mentioned.[^fn_7b_30] The other is that about a woman who was in a hard travail[^fn_7b_31] \[concerning whom it was stated:\] For how long must she be relieved from pain[^fn_7b_32] so as to be regarded a zabah?[^fn_7b_33] Twenty-four hours;[^fn_7b_34] so R. Eliezer.[^fn_7b_35] And the *halachah* is in agreement with his view.[^fn_7b_36] And the third[^fn_7b_37] is the following: If a *zab* and a zabah[^fn_7b_38] examined themselves on the first day[^fn_7b_39] and found themselves clean and on the seventh day also[^fn_7b_40] and found themselves clean, but did not examine themselves during the other days,[^fn_7b_41] R. Eliezer ruled: Behold these[^fn_7b_42] are in a presumptive condition of cleanness,[^fn_7b_43] and R. Joshua ruled: They are entitled \[to reckon as clean\] only the first day and the seventh day,[^fn_7b_44] while R. Akiba ruled: They are entitled \[to reckon as clean\] the seventh day alone,[^fn_7b_45] and it was taught: R. Simeon and R. Jose stated, 'The view of R. Eliezer[^fn_7b_46] is more feasible than that of R. Joshua,[^fn_7b_47] while that of R. Akiba is more feasible than those of both,[^fn_7b_48] but the *halachah* agrees with that of R. Eliezer'.[^fn_7b_49] And the fourth is the following.[^fn_7b_50] For we have learnt: If the outer sides[^fn_7b_51] of vessels were rendered unclean[^fn_7b_52] by liquids,[^fn_7b_53] R. Eliezer ruled, they convey uncleanness[^fn_7b_52] to other liquids[^fn_7b_54] but they[^fn_7b_55] do not render foodstuffs unfit.[^fn_7b_56] 'They convey uncleanness to liquids' even where the latter are common, but they 'do not render foodstuffs unfit', even where the latter are *terumah*. R. Joshua ruled: They convey uncleanness to liquids and also render foodstuffs unfit.[^fn_7b_57] Said R. Joshua: This may be inferred a minori ad majus: If a tebul yom who[^fn_7b_58] does not convey uncleanness to a common liquid,[^fn_7b_59] nevertheless renders foodstuffs of *terumah* unfit how much more then should the outsides of vessels which do convey uncleanness to an unconsecrated liquid render foodstuffs of *terumah* unfit. And R. Eliezer?[^fn_7b_60] — The uncleanness of the outsides of vessels[^fn_7b_61] is only Rabbinical[^fn_7b_62] while that of a tebul yom[^fn_7b_63] is pentateuchal;[^fn_7b_64] and, where it is a question of deducing a Rabbinical from a Pentateuchal law, no inference a minori ad majus can be applied.[^fn_7b_65] For in accordance with Pentateuchal law no foodstuff conveys uncleanness to a vessel and no liquid conveys uncleanness to a vessel, and it is only the Rabbis that have ordained such uncleanness as a preventive measure against possible laxity in the case of the fluid[^fn_7b_66] of a *zab* or a zabah;[^fn_7b_67] hence it is only in the case of liquids, which are prone to contract uncleanness, that the Rabbis have enacted a preventive measure, but in that of foodstuffs, since they are not prone to contract uncleanness, the Rabbis enacted no preventive measure. What, however, is the reason for the mention of the outsides of vessels?[^fn_7b_68] — Because their restrictions are lighter.[^fn_7b_69] For we have learnt: If the outside of a vessel came in contact with unclean liquids,[^fn_7b_70] its outside becomes unclean while its inside, its hanger,[^fn_7b_71] its rim and its handles remain clean, but if its inside has become unclean all of it is unclean.[^fn_7b_72]

But what does Samuel teach us,[^fn_7b_73] seeing that in all these cases we learnt that the law \[was in agreement with R. Eliezer\]? And should you reply that he mainly informed us about the 'outsides of vessels' concerning which we did not learn \[elsewhere what the law was\], why \[it could be retorted\] did he not simply state, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in the case of the outsides of vessels'? — The fact is that it is this that he informed us:[^fn_7b_74] That the *halachah* may not be derived from a theoretical statement.[^fn_7b_75]

But are there no more \[than the four rulings\]?[^fn_7b_76] Is there not in fact another, since we have learnt: R. Eliezer ruled, [pg 8a]

'A minor[^fn_8a_1] is to be instructed[^fn_8a_2] to exercise her right of *mi'un* against him'[^fn_8a_3] and in connection with this Rab Judah citing Samuel stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer'?[^fn_8a_4] — When Samuel stated 'the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in four cases he referred to rulings in the Order of Toharoth,[^fn_8a_5] but in the other Orders there are many such rulings. This[^fn_8a_6] also stands to reason, for we learnt: R. Eliezer ruled, Also in the case of one who shovels out loaves of bread[^fn_8a_7] from an oven and puts them into a basket,[^fn_8a_8] the basket causes them to be combined in respect of their liability to the dough-offering',[^fn_8a_9] and in connection with this Rab Judah citing Samuel stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer.'[^fn_8a_10] This is conclusive. But why is the latter[^fn_8a_11] a more valid proof[^fn_8a_12] than the former?[^fn_8a_13] — Because in the former case R. Eleazar takes up the same standpoint as he,[^fn_8a_14] for we learnt: R. Eleazar ruled, The minor is to be instructed[^fn_8a_15] to exercise her right of *mi'un* against him.[^fn_8a_16] But does he[^fn_8a_17] take up the same standpoint?[^fn_8a_18] Have we not in fact shown[^fn_8a_19] that both[^fn_8a_20] were required because they are not like one another?[^fn_8a_21] — Rather say, Because R. Judah b. Baba takes up the same position as he,[^fn_8a_22] for we learnt,[^fn_8a_23] 'R. Judah b. Baba testified concerning five things: That minors are urged to exercise their right of *mi'un*,[^fn_8a_24] that a woman[^fn_8a_25] is allowed to remarry on the evidence of one witness,[^fn_8a_26] that a cock was stoned[^fn_8a_27] in Jerusalem because it had killed a person,[^fn_8a_28] that[^fn_8a_29] wine which was only forty days old[^fn_8a_30] was poured as a drink-offering upon the altar, and that[^fn_8a_29] the continual morning sacrifice was offered[^fn_8a_31] \[as late as\] at the fourth hour \[of the day\]'.[^fn_8a_32] Now does not the expression 'minors'[^fn_8a_33] imply[^fn_8a_34] the one of which R. Eleazar and the one of which R. Eliezer spoke?[^fn_8a_35] — No; by the expression[^fn_8a_36] 'minors' minors in general[^fn_8a_37] were meant.[^fn_8a_38] If so,[^fn_8a_39] should it not have been stated, in the case of the woman[^fn_8a_40] also, 'women', meaning thereby[^fn_8a_41] women in general?[^fn_8a_42] As in the latter case,[^fn_8a_43] however, it was stated 'woman',[^fn_8a_44] and in the former 'minors'[^fn_8a_45] it may be concluded that the expressions are to be taken literally.[^fn_8a_46] This is conclusive.

R. Eleazar[^fn_8a_47] also[^fn_8a_48] stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in four things'. But are there no more of such rulings?[^fn_8a_49] Have we not in fact learnt, 'R. Eliezer ruled, The minor is to be instructed to exercise her right of *mi'un* against him'[^fn_8a_50] and R. Eleazar stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer'?[^fn_8a_51] And were you to reply that when R. Eleazar stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in four things' he referred to the rulings in the Order of Toharoth, but that in the other Orders there are many more such rulings[^fn_8a_49] \[it could be retorted:\] But are there any such? Have we not in fact learnt, 'The rose, henna,[^fn_8a_52] lotus[^fn_8a_53] and balsam as well as their proceeds are subject to the laws of the Sabbatical year[^fn_8a_54] and they and their proceeds are also subject to the law of removal,'[^fn_8a_55] in connection with which R. Pedath[^fn_8a_56] is observed, 'Who taught[^fn_8a_57] that balsam is a fruit?[^fn_8a_58] R. Eliezer'; and R. Zera replied, 'I see that between[^fn_8a_59] you and your father you will cause balsam to be permitted to the world,[^fn_8a_60] since you said, "Who taught that balsam is a fruit? R. Eliezer" and your father said, "The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in four things".'[^fn_8a_61] Now, if it were so,[^fn_8a_62] why did he[^fn_8a_63] not reply to him,[^fn_8a_64] 'When my father said, "The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer in four things" he referred only to rulings in the Order of Toharoth but in other Orders there are many more'?[^fn_8a_65] — But then,[^fn_8a_66] does not the previous difficulty[^fn_8a_67] arise? — \[In the case of *mi'un*[^fn_8a_68] the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer\] because R. Eleazar \[b. Shammua'\] takes up the same standpoint as he; for we have learnt: R. Eleazar ruled, The minor is to be instructed to exercise her right of *mi'un* against him.[^fn_8a_69] But does he[^fn_8a_70] take up the same standpoint? Have we not in fact shown that both[^fn_8a_71] were required because they are not like one another?[^fn_8a_72] — Rather say: Because R. Judah b. Baba takes up the same standpoint as he.[^fn_8a_70] But are there no more such rulings?[^fn_8a_73]

Have we not in fact learnt: 'R. Akiba ruled, One says it[^fn_8a_74] as an independent benediction;[^fn_8a_75] R. Eliezer ruled, One includes it in the benediction of thanksgiving';[^fn_8a_76] and in connection with this R. Eleazar[^fn_8a_77] stated,[^fn_8a_78] 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer'? — R. Abba replied: \[The *halachah* agrees with him\] in that case because he \[may have\] said it in the name of R. Hanina b. Gamaliel, for it was taught: R. Akiba ruled, One says it[^fn_8a_79] as an independent benediction;[^fn_8a_75] R. Hanina b. Gamaliel ruled, One includes it in the benediction of thanksgiving. [pg 8b]

But was he[^fn_8b_1] not much older than he?[^fn_8b_2] — Rather say:[^fn_8b_3] Because R. Hanina b. Gamaliel took up[^fn_8b_4] the same line as he, But did he[^fn_8b_5] take it up? Was it not in fact taught: On the night of the Day of Atonement[^fn_8b_6] one recites in his prayers seven benedictions and makes confession; in the morning[^fn_8b_6] one recites seven benedictions and makes confession; during the additional prayer[^fn_8b_7] one recites seven benedictions and makes confession; in the afternoon prayer one recites seven benedictions and makes confession; In the concluding prayer[^fn_8b_8] one recites seven benedictions and makes confession, and in the evening[^fn_8b_9] one recites seven benedictions embodying the substance of the Eighteen;[^fn_8b_10] and R. Hanina b. Gamaliel in the name of his ancestors ruled: One must recite in his prayers[^fn_8b_11] all the eighteen benedictions because it is necessary to include habdalah[^fn_8b_12] in 'who favourest man with knowledge'?[^fn_8b_13] — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: He cited it[^fn_8b_14] in the name of his ancestors but he himself[^fn_8b_15] does not uphold it.

Said R. Jeremiah to R. Zera:[^fn_8b_16] But do you not yourself hold that he who taught that balsam was a fruit is R. Eliezer, seeing that we have learnt: R. Eliezer ruled, Milk curdled with the sap of *'orlah* is forbidden?[^fn_8b_17] — This[^fn_8b_18] might be said to agree even with the view of the Rabbis, since they differed from R. Eliezer only in respect of the sap of the tree but in the case of the sap of the fruit they agree with him, for we have learnt: R. Joshua stated, I have explicitly heard that milk curdled with the sap of the leaves or with the sap of the roots is permitted, but if it was curdled with the sap of unripe figs it is forbidden because the latter is regarded as a proper fruit.[^fn_8b_19] And if you prefer I might reply: The Rabbis differ from R. Eliezer only in respect of a fruit producing tree but in the case of a tree that does not produce fruit they agree that its sap is regarded as its fruit, for we have learnt: R. Simeon ruled, Balsam is not subject to the laws of the Sabbatical Year[^fn_8b_20] and the Sages ruled, Balsam is subject to the laws of the Sabbatical Year because the sap of the tree is regarded as its fruit.[^fn_8b_21] Now who are the Sages? Are they not in fact the Rabbis who differ[^fn_8b_22] from R. Eliezer?[^fn_8b_23] — Thus, a certain elder replied to him, said R. Johanan, 'Who are the "Sages"? R. Eliezer who ruled that its balsam is its fruit'. But if by the 'Sages' R. Eliezer was meant what was the point in speaking of a tree that does not produce fruit seeing that even where a tree produces fruit its sap is regarded as its fruit? — He[^fn_8b_24] spoke to them[^fn_8b_25] according to the view of the Rabbis. 'According to my view' \[he said in effect,\] 'even in the case of a fruit producing tree its sap is regarded as its fruit, but according to your view[^fn_8b_26] agree with me at least in this case of a tree that produces no fruit that its sap is its fruit. But the Rabbis told him: No difference is made.[^fn_8b_27]

WHO IS REGARDED AS A 'VIRGIN'? ANY WOMAN WHO HAS NOT YET OBSERVED etc. Our Rabbis taught: \[If a virgin\] married and observed a discharge of blood that was due to the marriage, or if when she bore a child she observed a discharge of blood that was due to the birth, she is still called a 'virgin', because the virgin of whom the Rabbis spoke is one that is a virgin as regards menstrual blood but not one who is so in regard to the blood of virginity.[^fn_8b_28] Can this, however, be correct?[^fn_8b_29] Has not R. Kahana in fact stated, 'A Tanna taught: There are three kinds of virgin, the human virgin, the soil virgin and the sycamore virgin. The "human virgin" is one that never[^fn_8b_30] had any sexual intercourse, the practical issue[^fn_8b_31] being her eligibility to marry a High Priest[^fn_8b_32] or else her claim to a *kethubah* of two hundred *zuz*;[^fn_8b_33] the "virgin soil" is one that had never[^fn_8b_30] been cultivated, the practical issue[^fn_8b_31] being its designation as "a rough valley"34 or else its legal status as regards purchase and sale;[^fn_8b_35] the "virgin sycamore" is one that has never[^fn_8b_36] been cut,[^fn_8b_37] the practical issue[^fn_8b_38] being its legal status as regards purchase and sale[^fn_8b_39] or else the permissibility to cut it[^fn_8b_37] in the Sabbatical Year, as we have learnt: A virgin sycamore may not be cut in the Sabbatical Year because such cutting is regarded as cultivation'.[^fn_8b_40] Now if this[^fn_8b_41] were correct why did he[^fn_8b_42] not mention this one also? — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: He only mentioned such as has no special[^fn_8b_43] name[^fn_8b_44] but one which bears a special[^fn_8b_43] name[^fn_8b_45] he does not mention. R. Shesheth son of R. Idi replied: He[^fn_8b_46] only mentioned those, the loss of whose virginity[^fn_8b_47] is dependent on an act[^fn_8b_48] but one the loss of whose virginity[^fn_8b_47] is not dependent on an act[^fn_8b_49] he does not mention. R. Hanina son of R. Ika replied: He[^fn_8b_46] only mentioned those[^fn_8b_47] which do not change[^fn_8b_50] into their original condition[^fn_8b_51] but one which does change to its original condition[^fn_8b_52] he does not mention. Rabina replied: He[^fn_8b_53] only mentioned that to which a purchaser is likely to object[^fn_8b_54] but that to which a purchaser is not likely to object[^fn_8b_55] he does not mention. But do not people object?[^fn_8b_56] Was it not in fact taught, 'R. Hiyya stated: As leaven is wholesome for the dough so is menstrual blood wholesome for a woman'[^fn_8b_57] and it was also taught in the name of R. Meir, 'Every woman who has an abundance of menstrual blood has many children'?[^fn_8b_57] — Rather say: He[^fn_8b_53] only mentioned that which a purchaser is anxious to acquire[^fn_8b_58] but that[^fn_8b_59] which a purchaser is not anxious to acquire[^fn_8b_60] he does not mention.

Our Rabbis taught: What is meant by a virgin soil? One which[^fn_8b_61] turns up clods[^fn_8b_62] and whose earth is not loose. If[^fn_8b_61] a potsherd is found in it, it may be known that it had once been cultivated;[^fn_8b_63] if flint, it is undoubtedly[^fn_8b_64] virgin soil.

'A WOMAN IN PREGNANCY'? ONE WHOSE EMBRYO 'CAN BE DISCERNED. At what stage[^fn_8b_65] is the embryo discernible? — Symmachus citing R. Meir replied: Three months after conception. And though there is no actual proof for this statement there is an allusion[^fn_8b_66] to it, for it is said in Scripture, And it came to pass about three months after[^fn_8b_67] etc. 'An allusion to it' \[you say\], is not this a text of Scripture and a most reliable[^fn_8b_68] proof? — \[It can only be regarded as an allusion\] because some women[^fn_8b_69] give birth after nine months and others after seven months.[^fn_8b_70]

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman was[^fn_8b_71] in a condition of presumptive pregnancy and after observing a discharge of blood she miscarried an inflated object[^fn_8b_72] or any other object which had no vitality[^fn_8b_73] she[^fn_8b_74] is still deemed to be[^fn_8b_75] in the condition of her presumptive pregnancy and it suffices for her to reckon her period of menstrual uncleanness from the time of her observation of the discharge.[^fn_8b_76] And though there is no actual proof for this ruling[^fn_8b_77] there is an allusion[^fn_8b_78] to it, for it is said in Scripture, We have been with child, we have been in pain, we have as it were brought forth wind.[^fn_8b_79] But why only 'an allusion to it' seeing that the text provides actual[^fn_8b_80] proof? — That text was in fact written about males.[^fn_8b_81]

I would, however, point out an incongruity: If a woman was in hard labour[^fn_8b_82] for two days[^fn_8b_83] and on the third day[^fn_8b_84] she miscarried an inflated object or any thing that had no vitality, she[^fn_8b_85] is regarded as bearing in the condition of a zabah.[^fn_8b_86] Now if you maintain that such miscarriage is a proper birth [pg 9a]

did not the All Merciful \[it may be objected\] ordain that \[a flow of blood in\] painful labour immediately before birth[^fn_9a_1] is regarded as clean?[^fn_9a_2] — R. Papi replied: Leave alone the question of the twenty-four hours retrospective uncleanness[^fn_9a_3] which only involves a Rabbinical enactment.[^fn_9a_4] R. Papa replied: The actual reason[^fn_9a_5] is that the woman[^fn_9a_6] feels a heaviness in her head and limbs;[^fn_9a_7] well then, here also[^fn_9a_8] she feels a heaviness in her head and in her limbs.[^fn_9a_9]

R. Jeremiah enquired of R. Zera: What is the ruling[^fn_9a_10] where a woman observed a flow and immediately after her pregnancy was discerned?
