Is she retrospectively unclean because her pregnancy was not known at the time she observed the flow or is she not retrospectively unclean since she observed it immediately before she became aware of her pregnancy? — The other replied: The sole reason[^fn_9a_11] is that she[^fn_9a_12] feels a heaviness in her head and limbs[^fn_9a_13] but[^fn_9a_14] at the time she observed the flow she felt no heaviness either in her head or in her limbs.[^fn_9a_15]

A certain old man asked R. Johanan: 'What is the ruling if, when the time of her fixed period had come during the days of her pregnancy and she did not examine herself? I am raising this question on the view of the authority who laid down \[that a woman's duty to hold an examination on the arrival of her\] fixed periods is an ordinance of the Torah.[^fn_9a_16] What is the ruling \[I ask\]? Must she[^fn_9a_17] examine herself since \[the duty of holding an examination on the arrival of\] the fixed periods is an ordinance of the Torah[^fn_9a_16] or is it possible that since[^fn_9a_18] her menstrual blood is suspended,[^fn_9a_19] she requires no examination'?[^fn_9a_20] — The other[^fn_9a_21] replied, You have learnt it: R. Meir ruled, If a woman was in a hiding-place[^fn_9a_22] when the time of her fixed period arrived and she did not examine herself she is nevertheless clean because fear suspends the menstrual flow.[^fn_9a_23] Now the reason is[^fn_9a_24] that there was fear, but if there had been no fear and the time of her fixed period had arrived and she did not examine herself she would have been deemed unclean. It is thus clear[^fn_9a_25] \[that a woman's duty to examine herself at the time of the arrival of her\] fixed periods is an ordinance of the Torah and that, nevertheless, since there was fear, her menstrual blood is deemed to be suspended and she requires no exemption; so also here,[^fn_9a_26] since her menstrual blood is suspended she requires no examination.

'A NURSING WOMAN'? A WOMAN BEFORE SHE HAS WEANED etc. Our Rabbis taught: A nursing mother whose child died within twenty-four months[^fn_9a_27] is in exactly the same position as all other women[^fn_9a_28] and causes retrospective uncleanness for a period of twenty-four hours or from the previous to the last examination. If, therefore,[^fn_9a_29] she continued to suck it for four or five years it suffices for her to reckon her period of uncleanness from the time she has observed the flow; so R. Meir. R. Judah, R. Jose and R. Simeon ruled: Only during the twenty-four months[^fn_9a_30] does it suffice for women to reckon their uncleanness from the time they have observed a flow.[^fn_9a_31] Therefore,[^fn_9a_32] even if she suckled it for four or five years she causes uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from the previous to the last examination.[^fn_9a_33] Now if you will carefully consider \[the views just expressed\] you will find that[^fn_9a_34] according to the view of R. Meir the menstrual blood is decomposed and turns into milk while according to the view of R. Jose, R. Judah and R. Simeon the woman's limbs[^fn_9a_35] are disjointed and her natural vigour[^fn_9a_36] does not return before the lapse of twenty-four months. Why the necessity for the 'therefore'[^fn_9a_37] of R. Meir?[^fn_9a_38] — On account of the 'therefore'[^fn_9a_39] of R. Jose. But why the necessity for the 'therefore' of R. Jose?[^fn_9a_40] — It might have been assumed that R. Jose maintains that[^fn_9a_41] there are two \[causes\];[^fn_9a_42] hence we were informed[^fn_9a_43] \[that he upholds the one cause only\].[^fn_9a_44] So it was also taught: The menstrual blood[^fn_9a_45] is decomposed and turns into milk; so R. Meir. R. Jose stated: Her limbs[^fn_9a_46] are disjointed and her natural strength does not return before twenty-four months.[^fn_9a_47] R. Elai explained: What is R. Meir's reason?[^fn_9a_48] That it is written, Who can bring a clean thing[^fn_9a_49] from out of an unclean?[^fn_9a_50] Is it not the Only One?[^fn_9a_51] And the Rabbis?[^fn_9a_52] — R. Johanan replied: The reference[^fn_9a_53] is to semen which is unclean, while the man who is created from it is clean; and R. Eleazar replied: The reference[^fn_9a_53] is to the water of sprinkling[^fn_9a_54] in the case of which the man who sprinkles it as well as the man upon whom it is sprinkled is clean while he who touches it is unclean. But is the man who sprinkles it clean? Is it not in fact written, And he that sprinkleth the water of sprinkling shall wash his clothes?[^fn_9a_55] — What is meant by 'He that sprinkleth'? He that touches it. But is it not actually written, 'He that sprinkleth'[^fn_9a_55] and also 'He that toucheth'?[^fn_9a_55] Furthermore, is not 'He that sprinkleth' required to wash his clothes[^fn_9a_55] while 'He that toucheth' is not required to do so?[^fn_9a_55] — Rather say: What is meant by 'He that sprinkleth'? He that carries.[^fn_9a_56] Then why was it not written, 'He that carries'? — We were informed[^fn_9a_57] that uncleanness is not contracted unless one carried the minimum quantity prescribed for sprinkling. This is a satisfactory explanation according to him who holds[^fn_9a_58] that sprinkling must be performed with a prescribed minimum of the water.[^fn_9a_59] What, however, can be said according to him who holds that no prescribed minimum is required?[^fn_9a_58] — Even according to him who holds that no prescribed quantity is required the ruling refers only to the quantity applied to the body of the man but as regards that which is in the vessel a prescribed quantity is required; as we have learnt: What must be the quantity of water[^fn_9a_59] that it shall suffice for a sprinkling? As much as suffices for both the dipping therein of the tops of the stalks and for the sprinkling.[^fn_9a_60] It is, in fact, in view of such laws[^fn_9a_61] that Solomon observed, I said: 'I will get wisdom'; but it was far from me.[^fn_9a_62]

WHO IS REGARDED 'AN OLD WOMAN'? ANY WOMAN OVER WHOM THREE ONAHS HAVE PASSED NEAR THE TIME OF HER OLD AGE. What is to be understood by NEAR THE TIME OF HER OLD AGE? — Rab Judah replied: The age when her women friends speak of her as an old woman; and R. Simeon[^fn_9a_63] replied: [pg 9b]

when people call her mother in her presence[^fn_9b_1] and she does not blush. R. Zera and R. Samuel b. Isaac differ:[^fn_9b_2] One says, '\[When she is called mother\] and[^fn_9b_3] she does not mind,' and the other says, 'And[^fn_9b_3] she does not blush' — What is the practical difference between them? — The practical difference between them is the case of one who blushes but does not mind.

What is the length of an 'onah? — Resh Lakish citing R. Judah Nesi'ah[^fn_9b_4] replied: A normal 'onah is thirty days; but Raba, citing R. Hisda, replied: Twenty days. In fact, however, there is no difference of opinion between them. One Master[^fn_9b_5] reckons both the clean and the unclean days[^fn_9b_6] while the other Master[^fn_9b_7] does not reckon the unclean days.[^fn_9b_8]

Our Rabbis taught: If over an old woman have passed three 'onahs[^fn_9b_9] and then she observed a flow, it suffices for her to reckon her period of uncleanness from the time she observed the flow; if another three 'onahs have passed[^fn_9b_9] and then she observed a flow, it again suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it. If, however, another three 'onahs have passed[^fn_9b_9] and then she observed a flow she is regarded[^fn_9b_10] as all other women and causes uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from the previous examination to the last examination. This[^fn_9b_11] is the case not only[^fn_9b_12] where she observed the flow at perfectly regular intervals[^fn_9b_13] but even where she observed it at successively decreasing intervals or[^fn_9b_14] increasing intervals.[^fn_9b_15] \[You say,\] 'Even[^fn_9b_16] where she observed it at successively decreasing intervals'. It thus follows[^fn_9b_17] that there is no need to mention that this law[^fn_9b_11] applies where she observed the flow at perfectly regular ones. But should not the law be reversed, seeing that where she observes a flow at perfectly regular intervals she thereby establishes for herself a fixed period and it should, therefore, suffice for her to reckon her period of uncleanness from the time she observed the flow? And should you reply that this[^fn_9b_18] represents the view of the Rabbis who differ from R. Dosa in maintaining that even a woman who has a fixed period causes retrospective uncleanness for twenty-four hours,[^fn_9b_19] \[it could be objected:\] Should not the order[^fn_9b_20] have been reversed to read as follows: Not only where she observed the flow at successively decreasing intervals or increasing intervals[^fn_9b_21] but even where she observed it at perfectly regular ones?[^fn_9b_22] — Read: Not only where she observed the flow at successively decreasing intervals or increasing intervals[^fn_9b_21] but even where she observed it at perfectly regular ones.[^fn_9b_23] And if you prefer I might reply, It is this that was meant: This[^fn_9b_24] does not apply where a woman observed the flow at perfectly regular intervals but only where she observed it at successively decreasing or increasing ones. Where, however, she observed it at perfectly regular intervals she thereby establishes for herself a fixed period and it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she has observed the flow. And whose view does this represent? That of R. Dosa.[^fn_9b_19]

R. ELIEZER RULED: FOR ANY WOMAN OVER WHOM HAVE PASSED etc. It was taught: R. Eliezer said to the Sages. It once happened to a young woman at Haitalu[^fn_9b_25] that her menstrual flow was interrupted for three 'onahs, and when the matter was submitted to the Sages they ruled that it sufficed for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed the flow. They replied: A time of emergency is no proof. What was the emergency? — Some say, It was a time of dearth,[^fn_9b_26] while others say, The quantity of foodstuffs the woman had prepared[^fn_9b_27] was rather large and the Rabbis took into consideration the desirability of avoiding the loss of the levitically clean things.

Our Rabbis taught: It once happened that Rabbi acted in agreement with the ruling of R. Eliezer, and after he reminded himself observed, 'R. Eliezer deserves to be relied upon in an emergency'. What could be the meaning of 'after he reminded himself'? If it be explained: After he reminded himself that the *halachah* was not in agreement with R. Eliezer but in agreement with the Rabbis \[the difficulty would arise:\] How could he act according to the former's ruling even in an emergency? — The fact is that it was not stated whether the law was in agreement with the one Master or with the other Master. Then what is meant by 'after he reminded himself'? — After he reminded himself that it was not an individual that differed from him but that many differed from him, he observed 'R. Eliezer deserves to be relied upon in an emergency'.

Our Rabbis taught: If a young girl who had not yet attained the age of menstruation[^fn_9b_28] observed a discharge, after the first time it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it; after the second time also[^fn_9b_29] it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it, but after the third time[^fn_9b_30] she is in the same position as all other women[^fn_9b_31] and[^fn_9b_32] causes uncleanness retrospectively[^fn_9b_33] for twenty-four hours or from her previous examination to her last examination. If subsequently three 'onahs have passed over her[^fn_9b_34] and then she again observed a discharge it suffices for her[^fn_9b_35] to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it.[^fn_9b_36] If another three 'onahs have passed over her[^fn_9b_34] and then again she observed a discharge it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it. But if another three 'onahs have passed over her[^fn_9b_37] and she again observed a discharge she is in the same position as all other women[^fn_9b_38] and causes uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from her previous examination to her last one.[^fn_9b_39] When, however, a girl had attained the age of menstruation,[^fn_9b_40] after the first observation it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed the discharge, while after the second time she causes uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from her previous examination to her last examination.[^fn_9b_41] If subsequently three 'onahs have passed over her[^fn_9b_42] and then she again observed a discharge, it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it.[^fn_9b_43]

The Master said,[^fn_9b_44] 'If subsequently three 'onahs have passed over her and then she again observed a discharge, it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it'. [pg 10a]

What is the ruling where[^fn_10a_1] she again observes discharges at the end of subsequent single 'onahs?[^fn_10a_2] — R. Giddal citing Rab replied: After the first time and after the second time it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time of her observation of the discharge, but after the third time she causes uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from her previous examination to her last examination.

'If another three 'onahs have passed over her and then again she observed a discharge it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it'. What is the ruling where she again observes discharges at the end of single 'onahs?[^fn_10a_3] — R. Kahana citing R. Giddal who had it from Rab replied: After the first time it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed the discharge but after the second time she causes uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from her previous examination to her last examination. Whose view does this[^fn_10a_4] represent? That of Rabbi who laid down that if a thing has occurred twice presumption is established.[^fn_10a_5] Read then the final clause:[^fn_10a_6] 'If subsequently three 'onahs have passed over her and then she again observed a discharge, it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time she observed it'. Does not this agree only with the view of R. Eliezer?[^fn_10a_7] And should you reply that it in fact represents the view of Rabbi but that in the case of \[an interval of three\] 'onahs he holds the same view as R. Eliezer, \[it could be retorted\]: Does he indeed hold the same view seeing that it was stated, 'After he reminded himself'?[^fn_10a_8] — The fact is that it represents the view of R. Eliezer but[^fn_10a_9] \[in respect of presumption in the case of\] menstrual periods he is of the same opinion as Rabbi.[^fn_10a_10]

A stain \[discovered by one who had not yet reached the age of menstruation\] between her first and second \[observation of a discharge\] is regarded as clean,[^fn_10a_11] but as regards one discovered between her second and third observation, Hezekiah ruled: It is unclean, while R. Johanan ruled: It is clean. 'Hezekiah ruled: It is unclean', since, when she observed \[a discharge for the third time\] she becomes unclean \[retrospectively\],[^fn_10a_12] her stain also[^fn_10a_13] causes her to be unclean; 'while R. Johanan ruled: It is clean,' for this reason: Since[^fn_10a_14] she was not yet confirmed in the condition of presumptive menstruation[^fn_10a_15] she cannot be regarded as unclean on account of her stain. [pg 10b]

R. Elai demurred:[^fn_10b_1] But what is the difference between this class of woman and a virgin \[just married\] whose blood is clean?[^fn_10b_2] — R. Zera replied: In the case of the latter her secretion[^fn_10b_3] is frequent[^fn_10b_4] but in that of the former her secretion is not frequent.[^fn_10b_5]

'Ulla stated: R. Johanan who had it from R. Simeon b. Jehozadak[^fn_10b_6] ruled, 'If a young girl who had not yet attained the age of menstruation observed a discharge, her spittle or her *midras*-uncleanness in the street[^fn_10b_7] after a first discharge and after a second discharge is clean,[^fn_10b_8] and her stain is also clean'; but I do not know \[whether the last ruling\][^fn_10b_9] was his own or his Master's.[^fn_10b_10] In what practical issue could this matter? — In respect of establishing the ruling[^fn_10b_11] to be the view of one authority[^fn_10b_11] against two authorities.[^fn_10b_12] When Rabin and all the other seafarers came[^fn_10b_13] they stated that the ruling was in agreement with the view of R. Simeon b. Jehozadak.

R. Hilkiah b. Tobi ruled: In the case of a young girl who had not yet reached the age of menstruation[^fn_10b_14] a discharge of menstrual blood, even if it continued[^fn_10b_15] throughout all the seven days,[^fn_10b_16] is regarded as a single observation.[^fn_10b_17] \[Since you say,\] 'Even[^fn_10b_18] if it continued'[^fn_10b_15] it follows that there is no necessity to state that the law is so[^fn_10b_19] where there was a break.[^fn_10b_20] But is not this contrary to reason, seeing that a break would cause the discharge to be like two separate observations? — Rather read: In the case of a young girl who had not yet reached the age of menstruation,[^fn_10b_14] a discharge of menstrual blood that[^fn_10b_21] continued throughout all the seven days[^fn_10b_22] is regarded as a single observation. R. Shimi b. Hiyya ruled: Dripping is not like an observation.[^fn_10b_23] is But does not the woman in fact observe it?[^fn_10b_24] — Read: It is not like a continuous discharge but like one broken up.[^fn_10b_25] Does this[^fn_10b_26] then imply that the continuous discharge[^fn_10b_27] was one like[^fn_10b_28] a river?[^fn_10b_29] — Rather read: It is only like a continuous discharge.[^fn_10b_30]

Our Rabbis taught: It is established that the daughters of Israel before reaching the age of puberty are definitely[^fn_10b_31] in a condition of presumptive cleanness and the \[elder\] women need not examine them. When they have reached the age of puberty they are definitely[^fn_10b_31] in a condition of presumptive uncleanness and \[elder\] women must examine them. R. Judah ruled: They must not examine them with their fingers[^fn_10b_32] because they might corrupt them,[^fn_10b_33] but they dab them with oil within and wipe it off from without and they are thus self examined.[^fn_10b_34]

R. JOSE RULED: FOR A WOMAN IN PREGNANCY etc. A Tanna recited in the presence of R. Eleazar, 'R. Jose ruled: As for a woman in pregnancy and a nursing woman over whom three onahs have passed it suffices for her[^fn_10b_35] \[to reckon her[^fn_10b_35] period of uncleanness from\] the time of her \[observation of the flow\]'. 'You', the other remarked, 'began with two[^fn_10b_36] and finished with one;[^fn_10b_37] do you perchance mean: A pregnant woman who was also[^fn_10b_38] a nurse,[^fn_10b_39] and this[^fn_10b_40] teaches us incidentally the law that \[in respect of an interval of three 'onahs\][^fn_10b_41] the days of a woman's pregnancy supplement those of her nursing and those of her nursing supplement those of her pregnancy? As it was taught: 'The days of her pregnancy supplement those of her nursing and the days of her nursing supplement those of her pregnancy. In what manner? If there was a break[^fn_10b_42] of two 'onahs during her pregnancy and of one during her nursing, or of two during her nursing and one during her pregnancy, or of one and a half during her pregnancy and one and a half during her nursing, they are all combined into a series of three 'onahs'.[^fn_10b_43] One can well understand the ruling that 'the days of her pregnancy supplement those of her nursing' since this is possible where a woman became pregnant while she was still continuing her nursing. But how is it possible that 'the days of her nursing[^fn_10b_44] supplement those of her pregnancy'?[^fn_10b_45] — If you wish I might reply: This is possible in the case of a dry birth.[^fn_10b_46] And if you prefer I might reply: Menstrual blood is one thing and birth blood is another thing.[^fn_10b_47] And if you prefer I might reply: Read the first clause only.[^fn_10b_48]

OF WHAT DID THEY SPEAK WHEN THEY LAID DOWN THAT IT SUFFICES \[FOR THEM TO RECKON\] THEIR \[PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] THE TIME \[OF THEIR DISCOVERY OF THE FLOW\]'? etc. Rab stated: This[^fn_10b_49] refers to all of them,[^fn_10b_50] and Samuel stated: This[^fn_10b_49] was learnt only in respect of a virgin[^fn_10b_51] and an old woman[^fn_10b_52] but for pregnant or nursing women[^fn_10b_53] it suffices for them, throughout all the days of their pregnancy and throughout all the days of their nursing respectively to reckon their uncleanness from the time of their observing a flow. In the same manner R. Simeon b. Lakish stated: This[^fn_10b_54] refers to all of them; while R. Johanan stated: This was learnt only in respect of a virgin and an old woman but for pregnant or nursing women it suffices throughout all the days of their pregnancy and throughout all the days of their nursing respectively to reckon their uncleanness from the time of their observing the flow. This dispute[^fn_10b_55] is analogous to one between Tannas. \[For it was taught\]: If pregnant or nursing women were [pg 11a]

bleeding profusely it suffices for them, throughout all the days of their pregnancy and throughout all the days of their nursing respectively, to reckon their uncleanness from the time of their observing their flow; so R. Meir. R. Jose and R. Judah and R. Simeon, however, ruled: Only after a first observation did \[the Sages\] rule that it suffices for them[^fn_11a_1] to reckon their uncleanness from the time of their observing the flow but after a second observation they cause uncleanness retrospectively for twenty-four hours or from their previous examination to their last examination.

IF, HOWEVER, SHE SUFFERED THE FIRST FLOW etc. R. Huna ruled: If on three occasions she jumped and suffered a flow she[^fn_11a_2] has thereby established for herself a fixed period.[^fn_11a_3] In what respect?[^fn_11a_4] If it be suggested, In respect of certain days,[^fn_11a_5] could it not be objected that on any day on which she did not jump she observed no flow?[^fn_11a_6] — Rather, \[the fixation meant is in respect\] of jumps.[^fn_11a_7] But surely it was taught: 'Any regular discharge established as a result of an accident, even though it had been repeated many times, does not establish a fixed period'. Does not this mean that no fixed period whatsoever[^fn_11a_8] is established? — No, it means that no fixed period is established in respect of days alone[^fn_11a_9] or jumps alone,[^fn_11a_10] but as regards days and jumps jointly[^fn_11a_11] a fixed period is well established.[^fn_11a_12] But 'is it not obvious[^fn_11a_13] \[that no fixed period can be established\] in respect of days alone?[^fn_11a_14] — R. Ashi replied: \[This[^fn_11a_15] was necessary in a case\] for instance, where the woman jumped on two Sundays and suffered a flow while on a Sabbath[^fn_11a_16] she jumped and suffered no flow but on the Sunday following she observed one without jumping. As it might have been presumed that it had now become known retrospectively that[^fn_11a_17] it was the day[^fn_11a_18] and not the jumping[^fn_11a_19] that had caused the flow,[^fn_11a_20] we were informed[^fn_11a_21] that it was the jump of the previous day[^fn_11a_16] 'that was the cause[^fn_11a_22] and that the reason why the woman did not observe it was because the jump was premature.[^fn_11a_23]

Another reading:[^fn_11a_24] R. Huna' ruled: If on three occasions she jumped and suffered a flow she has thereby established for herself a fixed period in respect of days but not in respect of jumps. In what circumstances?[^fn_11a_25] — R. Ashi replied: If a woman jumped on two Sundays and on each occasion suffered a flow while[^fn_11a_26] on one[^fn_11a_27] Sunday she suffered one without jumping where it is obvious that it is the day[^fn_11a_28] that is the cause.[^fn_11a_29]

***MISHNAH***. ALTHOUGH \[THE SAGES\] HAVE LAID DOWN THAT \[FOR A WOMAN WHO HAS A SETTLED PERIOD\] IT SUFFICES TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM THE TIME SHE OBSERVED THE FLOW, SHE MUST NEVERTHELESS EXAMINE HERSELF \[REGULARLY\],[^fn_11a_30] EXCEPT WHERE SHE IS A MENSTRUANT[^fn_11a_31] OR[^fn_11a_32] IS CONTINUING IN THE BLOOD OF PURIFICATION.[^fn_11a_33] SHE[^fn_11a_34] MUST ALSO USE TESTING-RAGS WHEN[^fn_11a_35] SHE HAS MARITAL INTERCOURSE EXCEPT WHEN SHE CONTINUES IN THE BLOOD OF PURIFICATION[^fn_11a_33] OR WHEN SHE IS A VIRGIN[^fn_11a_36] WHOSE BLOOD IS CLEAN.[^fn_11a_37] AND TWICE \[DAILY\] MUST SHE[^fn_11a_34] EXAMINE HERSELF: IN THE MORNING[^fn_11a_38] AND AT THE \[EVENING\] TWILIGHT,[^fn_11a_39] AND ALSO WHEN SHE IS ABOUT[^fn_11a_40] TO PERFORM HER MARITAL DUTY.[^fn_11a_41] PRIESTLY WOMEN ARE SUBJECT TO AN ADDITIONAL RESTRICTION \[IN HAVING TO MAKE EXAMINATION\] WHEN THEY ARE ABOUT TO EAT *TERUMAH*. R. JUDAH RULED: \[THESE MUST EXAMINE THEMSELVES\] ALSO AFTER THEY HAVE CONCLUDED A MEAL[^fn_11a_42] OF *TERUMAH*. {¶=1.3}

***GEMARA***. EXCEPT WHEN SHE IS A MENSTRUANT, because during the days of her menstruation she needs no examination.[^fn_11a_43] This[^fn_11a_44] is quite satisfactory according to R. Simeon b. Lakish who ruled, 'A woman may establish for herself a settled period during the days of her *zibah*[^fn_11a_45] but not during the days of her menstruation',[^fn_11a_46] \[since the discarding of an examination would be\] well justified.[^fn_11a_47] According to R. Johanan, however, who ruled, 'A woman may establish for herself a settled period during the days of her menstruation', why should she not examine herself seeing that it is possible that she had established for herself a settled period?[^fn_11a_48] — R. Johanan can answer you: I only spoke of a case where the woman observed the flow issuing[^fn_11a_49] from a previously closed source,[^fn_11a_50] but I did not speak of one where she observed it issuing[^fn_11a_51] from an already open source.[^fn_11a_52]

OR IS CONTINUING IN THE BLOOD OF PURIFICATION. It was assumed that the reference is to one who is only desirous of continuing in the blood of purification.[^fn_11a_53] Now this[^fn_11a_54] is quite satisfactory according to Rab who holds that 'it[^fn_11a_55] all emanates from the same source which the Torah declared to be unclean \[during a certain period\][^fn_11a_56] and clean \[during another period\]'[^fn_11a_57] \[since the discarding of an examination would be\] well justified;[^fn_11a_58] but according to Levi who holds that 'it[^fn_11a_55] emanates from two different sources'[^fn_11a_59] why should she not examine herself, seeing that it is possible[^fn_11a_60] that the unclean source had not yet ceased to flow?[^fn_11a_61] — Levi can answer you: This[^fn_11a_62] is in agreement with[^fn_11a_63] [pg 11b]

Beth Shammai who hold that 'it[^fn_11b_1] all emanates from the same source'.[^fn_11b_2] But would the Tanna teach an anonymous Mishnah[^fn_11b_3] in agreement with the view of Beth Shammai?[^fn_11b_4] — This is an anonymous ruling that is followed by a divergence of opinion, and wherever an anonymous ruling is followed by a dispute the *halachah* does not agree with the anonymous ruling. And if you prefer I might reply: Was it stated,[^fn_11b_5] 'desirous of CONTINUING'?[^fn_11b_6] It was only stated, 'CONTINUING'.[^fn_11b_7] But if the woman was already 'continuing'[^fn_11b_7] what was the purpose of stating the ruling?[^fn_11b_8] — It might have been assumed that she should examine herself in case she establishes for herself[^fn_11b_9] a settled period, hence we were informed \[that no examination is necessary\] because no settled period can be established \[by the regularity of a discharge from\] a clean source for that of an unclean one. This is satisfactory according to Levi who stated that there are two sources,[^fn_11b_10] but according to Rab who stated that there was only one source[^fn_11b_10] why should she not examine herself seeing that she might have established for herself[^fn_11b_9] a settled period? — Even in that case she cannot establish a settled period in the clean days for the unclean ones.

SHE MUST ALSO USE TESTING-RAGS WHEN SHE HAS MARITAL INTERCOURSE etc. We have learnt elsewhere: If a young girl, whose age of menstruation[^fn_11b_11] had not yet arrived, married, Beth Shammai ruled: She is allowed[^fn_11b_12] four nights,[^fn_11b_13] and Beth Hillel ruled: Until the wound is healed.[^fn_11b_14] R. Giddal citing Samuel stated: They[^fn_11b_15] learnt this[^fn_11b_16] only in the case where bleeding through intercourse had not ceased, though she subsequently observed a discharge that may not have been due to intercourse;[^fn_11b_17] but if bleeding through intercourse had ceased[^fn_11b_18] and then she observed a discharge[^fn_11b_19] she[^fn_11b_20] is unclean.[^fn_11b_21] If one night has passed without intercourse and then she observed a discharge she is unclean. If the colour of her blood changed[^fn_11b_22] she is unclean.

R. Jonah raised an objection:[^fn_11b_23] OR WHEN SHE IS A VIRGIN WHOSE BLOOD IS CLEAN \[she need not use testing-rags\]. But why should she not rather use testing-rags[^fn_11b_24] seeing that it is possible that the colour of her blood had changed? — Raba replied, Read the first clause: EXCEPT WHERE SHE IS A MENSTRUANT OR IS CONTINUING IN THE BLOOD OF PURIFICATION, from which it follows that only in those cases no examination is required but that a virgin whose blood is clean does require one.[^fn_11b_25] But, then, are not the two rulings[^fn_11b_26] mutually contradictory? — The former[^fn_11b_27] refers to one who had marital intercourse, where it might well be assumed that the membrum was the cause of the change;[^fn_11b_28] while the latter[^fn_11b_29] refers to one who had no marital intercourse.[^fn_11b_30] So it was also taught: This[^fn_11b_31] applies only in the case where 'bleeding through intercourse had not ceased, though she subsequently observed a discharge that may not have been due to intercourse, but if bleeding through intercourse had ceased and then she observed a discharge she is unclean. If one night has passed without intercourse and then she observed a discharge she is unclean. If the colour of her blood has changed she is unclean.[^fn_11b_32]

TWICE \[DAILY\] MUST SHE etc. Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: They learnt this[^fn_11b_33] only in respect of clean things, but to her husband she is permitted.[^fn_11b_34] Is not this[^fn_11b_35] obvious, seeing that we learnt, IN THE MORNING?[^fn_11b_36] — Rather, if the statement[^fn_11b_37] was at all made it was in connection with the final clause: AND[^fn_11b_38] ALSO WHEN SHE IS ABOUT TO PERFORM HER MARITAL DUTY; Rab Judah citing Samuel stated, They learnt this only as regards a woman who was handling clean things, who, since it is necessary that she examine herself[^fn_11b_39] for the sake of the clean things,[^fn_11b_40] must also examine herself[^fn_11b_41] for the sake of her husband, but if a woman was not handling clean things she requires no examination. But what new point does he[^fn_11b_42] teach us, seeing that we have learnt: All women are in a condition of presumptive cleanness for their husbands?[^fn_11b_43] — If the ruling were to be derived from the Mishnah[^fn_11b_43] it might have been presumed that the ruling applied only to a woman who had a settled period but that a woman who had no settled period does require examination.[^fn_11b_44] But does not our Mishnah[^fn_11b_45] deal with one who has a settled period?[^fn_11b_46] — Our Mishnah deals with both one who had a settled period, and one who had no settled period,[^fn_11b_47] and it is this that was meant,[^fn_11b_48] that although she had a settled period, since she must be examined for the sake of the clean things she handled she must also be examined for the sake of her husband. But did not Samuel state this[^fn_11b_49] once, for R. Zera citing R. Abba b. Jeremiah who had it from Samuel stated, 'A woman who had no settled period may not perform marital intercourse before she has examined herself'[^fn_11b_50] and it has been explained[^fn_11b_50] to refer to one who was engaged in the handling of clean things?[^fn_11b_51] — The one statement[^fn_11b_52] was inferred from the other.[^fn_11b_53] So it was also taught: This[^fn_11b_54] applies only to clean things[^fn_11b_55] but to her husband she is permitted.[^fn_11b_56] This,[^fn_11b_57] however, applies only where he left her in a state of presumptive cleanness, but if he left her in one of presumptive uncleanness she remains for ever in her uncleanness until she tells him, 'I am clean'. [pg 12a]

R. Zera enquired of Rab Judah: Should[^fn_12a_1] a wife examine herself[^fn_12a_2] for her husband? — The other replied: She should not examine herself. But \[why should she not\] examine herself, seeing that none could be the worse for it?[^fn_12a_3] If \[she were to do\] so her husband would be uneasy in his mind[^fn_12a_4] and he would keep away from her.

R. Abba enquired of R. Huna: Must[^fn_12a_5] a woman examine herself immediately \[after intercourse\] in order to make her husband liable to a sin-offering?[^fn_12a_6] The other replied: Is it at all possible for an examination to take place immediately \[after intercourse\], seeing that it was taught: 'What is meant by "immediately"? This may be illustrated by the parable of an attendant[^fn_12a_7] and the witness[^fn_12a_8] who stand at the side of the lintel[^fn_12a_9] where the witness enters immediately after the attendant goes out, this being the interval which the Rabbis allowed as regards wiping off[^fn_12a_10] but not as regards examination'?[^fn_12a_11] — The question rather is whether she must wipe herself.[^fn_12a_12] Some there are who say that it was this that he[^fn_12a_13] enquired of him:[^fn_12a_14] Must a woman examine herself \[after intercourse\][^fn_12a_15] in order to make her husband liable[^fn_12a_16] to a suspended guilt-offering?[^fn_12a_17] — The other replied: She should not examine herself. But \[why should she not\] examine herself, seeing that none could be the worse for it?[^fn_12a_18] — If \[she were to do\] so[^fn_12a_19] her husband would be uncertain in his mind[^fn_12a_20] and he would keep away from her.

AND ALSO WHEN SHE IS ABOUT etc. R. Ammi citing R. Jannai remarked: And this is the test[^fn_12a_21] of virtuous women.[^fn_12a_22] Said R. Abba b. Memel to R. Ammi: The Tanna learnt MUST,[^fn_12a_23] \[how then could\] you learn 'virtuous women'?[^fn_12a_22] — The other replied: Because I maintain that whosoever observes the enactments of the Sages may be described as[^fn_12a_24] virtuous.[^fn_12a_25] Said Raba: Would then[^fn_12a_26] one who does not observe the enactments of the Sages merely lose the designation of[^fn_12a_27] virtuous man but would not be called wicked? Rather, said Raba, as for virtuous women the testing-rag, with which they have examined themselves before one intercourse, they do not use it before any other intercourse, but those who are not virtuous use it and do not mind.

\[Reverting to\] the main text,[^fn_12a_28] 'R. Zera citing R. Abba b. Jeremiah who had it from Samuel stated: A woman who has no settled period may not perform marital intercourse before she has examined herself'. Said R. Zera to R. Abba b. Jeremiah: Is it[^fn_12a_29] only one who has no settled period that must have an examination while a woman who has a settled period requires no examination?[^fn_12a_30] — The other replied: A woman who has a settled period must have an examination[^fn_12a_31] only when she is awake[^fn_12a_32] but not when she is asleep;[^fn_12a_33] while a woman who has no settled period must have an examination whether she is awake or asleep. Raba observed: Could he[^fn_12a_34] not reply[^fn_12a_35] that a woman who had a settled period must be examined[^fn_12a_36] in respect of clean things[^fn_12a_37] but not in respect of her husband \[alone\][^fn_12a_38] while a woman who had no settled period must have an examination even in respect of her husband \[alone\]?[^fn_12a_39] As, however, he did not give such a reply it may be inferred that Samuel holds the view that in respect of her husband alone[^fn_12a_38] a woman[^fn_12a_40] needs no examination.[^fn_12a_41]

Our Rabbis taught: The wives of ass-drivers,[^fn_12a_42] labourers[^fn_12a_43] and people coming from a house of mourning[^fn_12a_43] or a house of feasting[^fn_12a_44] are in respect of their husbands[^fn_12a_45] deemed to be in a state of presumptive cleanness and the latter may, therefore, come and stay with them whether they are asleep or awake. This, however, applies only where the men[^fn_12a_46] left the woman in a state of presumptive cleanness but if they left them in a state of presumptive uncleanness each woman is forever regarded as unclean until she announces to her husband 'I am clean'. But how does Samuel[^fn_12a_47] explain this case?[^fn_12a_48] If it refers to a woman who has a settled period, does not a difficulty arise from the case where she is awake?[^fn_12a_49] And if it refers to one who has no settled period, does not a difficulty arise both from the case where she is awake and from that where she is asleep?[^fn_12a_50] — As a matter of fact it refers to one who had a settled period[^fn_12a_51] but[^fn_12a_52] as the husband had solicited her[^fn_12a_53] there can be no more reliable[^fn_12a_54] examination than this.[^fn_12a_55]

R. Papa asked Raba: May one[^fn_12a_56] act in accordance with that Baraitha?[^fn_12a_57] [pg 12b]

— The other replied: Brewer,[^fn_12b_1] no; because \[otherwise\][^fn_12b_2] she would become repulsive to him.

R. Kahana stated, 'I asked the women folk of the house of R. Papa and of R. Huna son of R. Joshua, "Do the Rabbis on coming home from the schoolhouse require you to undergo an examination"? And they answered me in the negative'. But why did he[^fn_12b_3] not ask[^fn_12b_4] the Rabbis themselves? — Because it is possible that they imposed additional restrictions upon themselves.[^fn_12b_5]

Our Rabbis taught: A woman who has no settled period is forbidden marital intercourse and is entitled neither to a *kethubah*[^fn_12b_6] nor to a usufruct[^fn_12b_7] nor to maintenance,[^fn_12b_8] nor to her worn-out clothes.[^fn_12b_9] Her husband, furthermore, must divorce her and may never marry her again; so R. Meir. R. Hanina b. Antigonus ruled: She must use two testing-rags when she has marital intercourse; they render her unfit[^fn_12b_10] and they also render her fit.[^fn_12b_11] In the name of Abba Hanan it was stated: Woe to her husband.[^fn_12b_12] 'She is forbidden marital intercourse', because she might[^fn_12b_13] cause him moral injury. 'And is entitled neither to a kethubah', since she is unfit for cohabitation she is not entitled to a *kethubah*. 'Nor to usufruct nor to maintenance nor to her worn-out clothes' because the provisions[^fn_12b_14] embodied in the agreed terms of a *kethubah* are subject to the same laws as the *kethubah* itself.[^fn_12b_15] 'Her husband, furthermore, must divorce her and may never marry her again'. Is not this obvious?[^fn_12b_16] — It was necessary in the case where she was subsequently cured.[^fn_12b_17] As it might have been presumed that \[in such a case\] he may remarry her we were informed \[that this is forbidden\], because it may sometimes happen that having proceeded to marry another man she would be cured and \[her first husband\] would then say, 'Had I known that to be the case I would not have divorced her even if you had given me a hundred maneh', and the get would thus be annulled and her children would be bastards.[^fn_12b_18]

'In the name of Abba Hanan it was stated: Woe to her husband'. Some explain: He said this in opposition to R. Meir,[^fn_12b_19] because \[Abba Hanan maintains that\] she must be allowed to collect her *kethubah*. Others there are who explain: He said it in opposition to R. Hanina b. Antigonus,[^fn_12b_20] because \[Abba Hanan maintains that intercourse is always forbidden\] since thereby she might[^fn_12b_21] cause her husband to sin.

Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Hanina b. Antigonus. But in what case? If it is one where the woman is engaged in the handling of clean things, has not Samuel \[it may be objected\] said it once?[^fn_12b_22] And if it is one where she was not engaged in the handling of clean things, did he not say \[it may again be objected\] that as far as her husband is concerned she requires no examination, for did not R. Zera in fact state in the name of R. Abba b. Jeremiah who had it from Samuel, 'A woman who had no settled period may not perform marital intercourse before she examines herself', and it has been explained to refer to one who was engaged in the handling of clean things?[^fn_12b_23] — He who taught the one did not teach the other.[^fn_12b_24] [pg 13a]

## CHAPTER II

***MISHNAH***. EVERY HAND THAT MAKES FREQUENT EXAMINATION IS IN THE CASE OF WOMEN PRAISEWORTHY,[^fn_13a_1] BUT IN THE CASE OF MEN IT OUGHT TO BE CUT OFF.[^fn_13a_2] {¶=2.1}

***GEMARA***. Wherein \[in this respect\][^fn_13a_3] do women differ from men?[^fn_13a_4] — Women \[in this matter\] are not sensitive,[^fn_13a_5] hence they are praiseworthy,[^fn_13a_1] but in the case of men who are highly sensitive \[their hands\] ought to be cut off.[^fn_13a_2] But, if so,[^fn_13a_2] what was the point in saying 'MAKES FREQUENT' \[seeing that the same reason[^fn_13a_2] applies\] also where \[the examinations are\] infrequent? — When 'MAKES FREQUENT' was mentioned it was intended to refer to women only.[^fn_13a_6]

One taught: This[^fn_13a_7] applies only to the emission of semen but as regards flux[^fn_13a_8] a man also is as praiseworthy as the women;[^fn_13a_9] and even in regard to the emission of semen, if he desires to make the examination with a splinter or with a potsherd[^fn_13a_10] he may do so. May he not, however, do it with a rag, seeing that it was taught: A man may examine himself with a rag or with any other thing he wishes? — As Abaye stated elsewhere: 'With a thick rag'.[^fn_13a_10] So also here[^fn_13a_11] it may be explained: With a thick rag.[^fn_13a_10] And in what connection was Abaye's statement made? In connection with the following: If a priest, while eating *terumah*, felt a shiver run through his body[^fn_13a_12] he takes hold of his membrum[^fn_13a_13] and swallows the *terumah*.[^fn_13a_14] 'Takes hold'! But has it not been taught: R. Eliezer said, 'Whoever holds his membrum when he makes water is as though he had brought a flood on the world'?[^fn_13a_15] To this Abaye replied. 'With a thick rag'.[^fn_13a_16] Raba replied: It[^fn_13a_17] may even be said to apply to a soft rag for once the semen has been detached the subsequent touch does no longer matter.[^fn_13a_18] And Abaye?[^fn_13a_19] — He made provision against the possibility of an additional discharge.[^fn_13a_20] And Raba? — He does not consider the possibility of any additional discharges. But does he not, seeing that it was taught, 'To what may this[^fn_13a_21] be compared? To the putting of a finger upon the eye where, as long as the finger remains on it, the eye continues to tear'?[^fn_13a_22] Now Raba?[^fn_13a_23] — It is quite uncommon for one to get heated twice in immediate succession.[^fn_13a_24]

\[Reverting to\] the main text: 'R. Eliezer said, Whoever holds his membrum when he makes water is as though he had brought a flood on the world'. But, they said to R. Eliezer, would not the spray bespatter his feet and he would appear to be maimed in his privy parts so that he[^fn_13a_25] would be the cause of casting upon his children the reflection of being illegitimate? — It is preferable, he answered them, that a man should be the cause of casting upon his children the reflection of being illegitimate than that he should make himself a wicked man, even for a while, before the Omnipresent. Another \[Baraitha\] taught: R. Eliezer replied to the Sages. It is possible for a man to stand on a raised spot and to make water or to make water in loose earth and thus to avoid making himself wicked, even for a while, before the Omnipresent. Which[^fn_13a_26] did he[^fn_13a_27] tell them[^fn_13a_28] first? If it be suggested that it was the first mentioned statement that he gave them first \[is it likely, it may be objected\], that after he spoke to them of a prohibition[^fn_13a_29] he would merely offer a remedy?[^fn_13a_30] — The fact is that it was the last mentioned statement[^fn_13a_31] that he gave them first, and when they asked him, 'What is he to do when he can find no raised spot or loose earth', he answered them, 'It is preferable that a man should be the cause of casting upon his children the reflection of being illegitimate than that he should make himself a wicked man, even for a while, before the Omnipresent'.

But why all these precautions?[^fn_13a_32] — Because otherwise one might emit semen in vain, and R. Johanan stated: Whosoever emits semen in vain deserves death, for it is said in Scripture. And the thing[^fn_13a_33] which he did[^fn_13a_33] was evil in the sight of the Lord, and He slew him also.[^fn_13a_34] R. Isaac and R. Ammi said. He[^fn_13a_35] is as though he shed blood, for it is said in Scripture. Ye that inflame yourselves among the terebinths, under every leafy tree, that slay the children in the valleys under the clefts of the rocks;[^fn_13a_36] read not 'that slay'[^fn_13a_37] but 'that press out'.[^fn_13a_38] R. Assi said: He[^fn_13a_39] is like one who worships idols; for here[^fn_13a_36] it is written, 'Under every leafy tree' and elsewhere[^fn_13a_40] it is written, upon the high mountains … and under every leafy tree.[^fn_13a_41]

Rab Judah and Samuel once stood upon the roof of the Synagogue of Shaf-weyathib[^fn_13a_42] in Nehardea. Said Rab Judah to Samuel 'I must make water'. 'Shinena',[^fn_13a_43] the other replied, 'take hold of your membrum[^fn_13a_44] and make the water outside \[the roof\]'. But how could he[^fn_13a_45] do so, seeing that it was taught: R. Eliezer said, Whoever holds his membrum when he makes water is as though he brought a flood on the world? — Abaye replied: He treated this case as that of a reconnoitering troop, concerning which we learnt, 'If a reconnoitering troop has entered a town in time of peace the open wine jars are forbidden[^fn_13a_46] and the closed ones are permitted,[^fn_13a_47] but in times of war the former as well as the latter are permitted because the troops have no time to offer libations'.[^fn_13a_48] Thus it clearly follows that owing to their being in a state of fear they do not think[^fn_13a_49] of offering libations, and so also in this case, since he[^fn_13a_45] was in a state of fear he would not think of lustful matters. But what fear could there be here? — If you wish I might reply: The fear of the night and of the roof.[^fn_13a_50] If you prefer I might reply: The fear of his Master.[^fn_13a_51] If you prefer I might say: The fear of the *Shechinah*.[^fn_13a_52] If you prefer I might say: The fear of the Lord that was[^fn_13a_53] upon him,[^fn_13a_54] for Samuel once remarked of him[^fn_13a_55] 'This man is no mortal being'.[^fn_13a_55] If you prefer I might say: He was a married man, and concerning such R. Nahman ruled, 'If a man was married, this is permitted'. If you prefer I might say: It was this that he taught him, vis., that which R. Abba the son of R. Benjamin b. Hiyya learnt: But he may support the testicles from below. And if you prefer I might say: It was this that he taught them, viz., that which R. Abbahu stated in the name of R. Johanan: It has a limit; from the corona downward \[touch\] is permitted [pg 13b]

but from the corona upwards[^fn_13b_1] it is forbidden.

Rab stated: 'A man who wilfully causes erection should be placed[^fn_13b_2] under the ban'. But why did he[^fn_13b_3] not say, 'This is forbidden'? Because the man[^fn_13b_4] merely incites his evil inclination against himself.[^fn_13b_5] R. Ammi, however, stated: He[^fn_13b_4] is called a renegade, because such is the art of the evil inclination: To-day it incites man to do one wrong thing,[^fn_13b_6] and to-morrow[^fn_13b_7] it incites him to worship idols and he proceeds to worship them.

There are others who read: R. Ammi[^fn_13b_8] stated, He who excites himself by lustful thoughts will not be allowed to enter the division of the Holy One, blessed be He. For here it is written, Was evil in the sight of the Lord,[^fn_13b_9] and elsewhere it is written, For Thou art not a God that hath pleasure in wickedness; evil shall not sojourn with Thee.[^fn_13b_10]

R.[^fn_13b_11] Eleazar stated: Who are referred to[^fn_13b_12] in the Scriptural text, Your hands are full of blood?[^fn_13b_13] Those that commit masturbation with their hands.

It was taught at the school of R. Ishmael, Thou shalt not commit adultery[^fn_13b_14] implies, Thou shalt not practise masturbation either with hand or with foot.

Our Rabbis taught: 'proselytes and those that play with children delay the advent of the Messiah'. The statement about proselytes may be understood on the lines of the view of R. Helbo, for R. Helbo said, 'proselytes are as hard for Israel to endure as a sore',[^fn_13b_15] what, however, could be meant by 'those that play with children'?[^fn_13b_16] If it be suggested: Those that practise pederasty \[it could well be objected\]: Are not such people subject to stoning?[^fn_13b_17] If, however, it be suggested: Those that practise onanism through external contact[^fn_13b_18] \[it could be objected\]: Are not such deserving destruction by flood?[^fn_13b_17] — The meaning rather is: Those that marry minors who are not capable of bearing children, for R. Jose[^fn_13b_19] stated: The Son of David[^fn_13b_20] will not come before all the souls in Guf[^fn_13b_21] will have been disposed of, since it is said, For the spirit that enwrappeth itself is from Me, and the souls which I have made.[^fn_13b_22]

BUT IN THE CASE OF MEN IT OUGHT TO BE CUT OFF. The question was raised: Have we here[^fn_13b_23] learnt a law or merely an execration? 'Have we here learnt a law' as in the case where R. Huna cut off one's hand;[^fn_13b_24] 'or merely an execration'? — Come and hear what was taught: R. Tarfon said, 'If his hand touched the membrum let his hand be cut off upon his belly'. 'But', they said to him,[^fn_13b_25] 'would not his belly be split'? 'It is preferable', he replied, 'that his belly shall be split rather than that he should go down into the pit of destruction'.[^fn_13b_26] Now if you concede that we have here[^fn_13b_27] learnt a law[^fn_13b_28] one can well understand why they said, 'Would not his belly be split'; but if you maintain that we have only learnt of an execration,[^fn_13b_29] what could be meant by \[the question\] 'His belly be split'? — What then would you suggest, that we have learnt here a law, would it not suffice, \[it may be objected, that the cutting off shall\] not be done on his belly? — The fact, however, is that it was this that R. Tarfon meant: Whosoever puts his hand below his belly that hand shall be cut off. They said to R. Tarfon, 'If a thorn stuck in his belly, should he not remove it'? 'No', he replied. 'But \[they said\] would not his belly be split'?[^fn_13b_30] 'It is preferable', he replied, 'that his belly shall be split rather than that he should go down to the pit of destruction'.[^fn_13b_26]

***MISHNAH***. IN THE CASE OF A DEAF,[^fn_13b_31] AN IMBECILE, A BLIND OR AN INSANE[^fn_13b_32] WOMAN, IF OTHER WOMEN OF SOUND SENSES ARE AVAILABLE[^fn_13b_33] THEY ATTEND TO HER,[^fn_13b_34] AND SHE MAY THEN EAT *TERUMAH*. {¶=2.2}

***GEMARA***. Why should not a DEAF woman make her own examination, seeing that it was taught: Rabbi stated, A deaf woman was living in our neighbourhood and not only[^fn_13b_35] did she examine herself but her friends also on observing a discharge would show it to her?[^fn_13b_36] — There it was a woman who could speak but not hear while here the reference is to one who can neither speak nor hear; as we have learnt: The deaf person of whom the Sages spoke is always[^fn_13b_37] one who can neither hear nor speak.[^fn_13b_38]

A BLIND. Why should she not make her own examination and show the testing-rag to her friend? — R. Jose son of R. Hanina replied: The 'blind' is no part of the Mishnah.[^fn_13b_39]

OR AN INSANE WOMAN. Is not this exactly the same as IMBECILE?[^fn_13b_40] This refers to one whose mind was deranged owing to a disease.

Our Rabbis taught: A priest who is an imbecile may be ritually immersed and then fed with *terumah*[^fn_13b_41] in the evening.[^fn_13b_42] He must also be watched that he does not fall asleep.[^fn_13b_43] If he falls asleep he is deemed unclean[^fn_13b_44] and if he does not fall asleep he remains clean. R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok ruled: He should be provided with a leather bag.[^fn_13b_45] The Rabbis said to him: 'Would not this cause heat all the more'? 'According to your view', he replied, 'should an imbecile have no remedy'? 'According to our view', they retorted, 'only if he falls asleep[^fn_13b_46] is he deemed unclean but if he does not fall asleep he remains clean, while according to your view there is the possibility that he might discharge a drop of blood of the size of a mustard seed and this would be absorbed in the bag'.[^fn_13b_47]

A Tanna taught: It was stated in the name of R. Eleazar, The imbecile is to be provided with a metal bag. Abaye explained: It must be one of copper, as we have learnt:[^fn_13b_48] R. Judah ruled, Those buds of hyssop[^fn_13b_49] are regarded[^fn_13b_50] as if they had been made of copper.[^fn_13b_51]

R. Papa remarked: From this[^fn_13b_52] it may be inferred that breeches[^fn_13b_53] are forbidden. But is it not written in Scripture, And thou shalt make them linen breeches to cover the flesh of their nakedness?[^fn_13b_54] — That may be explained as it was taught: To what were the breeches of the priests like? They were like the knee breeches of horsemen, reaching upwards to the loins and downwards to the thighs. They also had laces but had no padding either back or front.[^fn_13b_55]

Abaye stated: [pg 14a]

Camel riders[^fn_14a_1] are forbidden to eat *terumah*.[^fn_14a_2] So it was also taught: All camel-drivers are wicked,[^fn_14a_3] all sailors are righteous,[^fn_14a_4] but among the ass-drivers some are wicked and others righteous. Some say: The latter are those who use a saddle[^fn_14a_5] and the former are those who use no saddle;[^fn_14a_6] while others say: The former are those who ride astraddle[^fn_14a_7] and the latter are those who do not ride astraddle.[^fn_14a_8]

R. Joshua b. Levi cursed the man who sleeps on his back.[^fn_14a_9] But this, surely, is not correct,[^fn_14a_10] for did not R. Joseph rule that one lying on his back should not read the *shema'*,[^fn_14a_11] from which it follows, does it not, that it is only the *shema'* that he must' not read but that he may well sleep in this manner? — As regards sleeping on one's back this is quite proper if one slightly inclines sideways, but as regards the reading of the *shema'* even if one inclines sideways this is forbidden.[^fn_14a_12] But did not R. Johanan turn slightly on his side and read the *shema'*? — R. Johanan was different \[from other people\] because he was corpulent.[^fn_14a_13]

***MISHNAH***. IT IS THE CUSTOM OF THE DAUGHTERS OF ISRAEL WHEN HAVING MARITAL INTERCOURSE TO USE TWO TESTING-RAGS, ONE FOR THE MAN AND THE OTHER FOR HERSELF,[^fn_14a_14] AND VIRTUOUS WOMEN PREPARE ALSO A THIRD RAG WHEREBY TO MAKE THEMSELVES FIT FOR MARITAL DUTY.[^fn_14a_15] IF A VESTIGE OF BLOOD IS FOUND ON HIS RAG[^fn_14a_16] THEY ARE BOTH UNCLEAN[^fn_14a_17] AND ARE ALSO UNDER THE OBLIGATION OF BRINGING A SACRIFICE.[^fn_14a_18] IF ANY BLOOD IS FOUND ON HER RAG IMMEDIATELY AFTER THEIR INTERCOURSE THEY ARE BOTH UNCLEAN AND ARE ALSO UNDER THE OBLIGATION OF BRINGING A SACRIFICE. IF, HOWEVER, ANY BLOOD IS FOUND ON HER RAG AFTER A TIME THEY ARE UNCLEAN[^fn_14a_19] BY REASON OF DOUBT[^fn_14a_20] BUT EXEMPT FROM THE SACRIFICE. WHAT IS MEANT BY 'AFTER A TIME'? WITHIN AN INTERVAL IN WHICH SHE CAN DESCEND FROM THE BED AND WASH HER FACE.[^fn_14a_21] BUT \[IF BLOOD WAS FOUND SOME TIME\] AFTER SUCH AN INTERVAL SHE CAUSES UNCLEANNESS RETROSPECTIVELY[^fn_14a_22] FOR A PERIOD OF TWENTY-FOUR HOURS[^fn_14a_23] BUT SHE DOES NOT CAUSE THE MAN WHO HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HER TO BE UNCLEAN.[^fn_14a_24] R. AKIBA RULED: SHE[^fn_14a_25] ALSO CAUSES THE MAN WHO HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HER TO BE UNCLEAN.[^fn_14a_26] THE SAGES, HOWEVER, AGREE WITH R. AKIBA THAT ONE WHO OBSERVED A BLOODSTAIN CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS TO THE MAN WHO HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HER. {¶=2.3}

***GEMARA***. But[^fn_14a_27] why should not the possibility be considered that the blood might be that of a louse?[^fn_14a_28] — R. Zera replied that place is presumed to be tested as far as a louse is concerned. There are others, however, who reply: It is too narrow for a louse. What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_14a_29] — The practical difference between them is the case where a crushed louse was found.[^fn_14a_30] According to the reply[^fn_14a_31] that the place is presumed to be tested, this must have come from somewhere else,[^fn_14a_32] but according to the reply[^fn_14a_31] that the place is too narrow it might be presumed that the attendant[^fn_14a_33] has crushed it.[^fn_14a_34]

It was stated: If a woman examined herself with a rag that she had previously examined,[^fn_14a_35] and then she pressed it against her thigh on which she found blood on the following day, Rab ruled: She[^fn_14a_36] is subject to the uncleanness of a menstruant.[^fn_14a_37] Said R. Shimi b. Hiyya to him: But, surely, you told us, 'She has only to take the possibility[^fn_14a_38] into consideration'. It was also stated: Samuel ruled: She is subject to the uncleanness of a menstruant.[^fn_14a_37] And so they also ruled at the schoolhouse: She is subject to the uncleanness of a menstruant.

It was stated: If a woman examined herself with a rag which she had not previously examined and having put it into a box she found upon it, on the following day, some blood,[^fn_14a_39] R. Joseph stated: Throughout all his lifetime R. Hiyya regarded \[her\] as unclean but in his old age he ruled that \[she\] was clean. The question was raised: What[^fn_14a_40] does he[^fn_14a_41] mean: That throughout all his[^fn_14a_42] lifetime he regarded \[her\] as menstrually unclean[^fn_14a_43] and in his old age he ruled that \[she\] was clean as far as menstruation is concerned but unclean on account of the bloodstain,[^fn_14a_44] or it is possible that throughout his lifetime he regarded \[her\] as unclean on account of the stain[^fn_14a_44] and in his old age he ruled that \[she\] was absolutely[^fn_14a_45] clean? — Come and hear what was taught: If a woman examined herself with a rag which she had not previously examined and having put it into a box she found upon it, on the following day, some blood, Rabbi ruled: She is regarded as menstrually unclean,[^fn_14a_46] and R. Hiyya ruled: She is regarded as unclean on account of the bloodstain.[^fn_14a_47] [pg 14b]

Said R. Hiyya to him: 'Do you not agree that it[^fn_14b_1] must be slightly bigger than the size of a bean?'[^fn_14b_2] 'Indeed', the other replied. 'If so',[^fn_14b_3] the first retorted, 'you also regard it as a stain'.[^fn_14b_4] Rabbi, however, holds the opinion that it is necessary for the stain to be slightly bigger than the size of a bean in order to exclude the possibility of its being the blood of a louse, but as soon as this possibility is ruled out the blood must undoubtedly have come from her body. Now did not this occur[^fn_14b_5] when he was in his old age but when he was young he regarded it[^fn_14b_6] as menstrually unclean?[^fn_14b_7] This is conclusive.

Rabbi was commending R. Hama b. Bisa to R. Ishmael son of R. Jose as a great man, when the latter said to him, 'If you come across him[^fn_14b_8] bring him to me'. When he[^fn_14b_9] came he[^fn_14b_10] said to him, 'Ask me something'. 'What is the ruling', the other asked, 'if a woman examined herself with a rag which she had not previously examined and having put it into a box she found some blood upon it on the following day?' 'Shall I give you,' the first answered, 'the ruling according to the views of my father[^fn_14b_11] or shall I rather give it to you according to the views of Rabbi?'[^fn_14b_12] 'Tell me,' the other said, 'the ruling according to Rabbi'. 'Is this the person', R. Ishmael exclaimed, 'of whom it is said that he is a great man! How could one ignore[^fn_14b_13] the views of the Master[^fn_14b_14] and listen to those of the disciple?[^fn_14b_15] R. Hama b. Bisa, however, was of the opinion that since Rabbi was the head of the college and the Rabbis were frequently in his company his traditions were more reliable.[^fn_14b_16] What is the view of Rabbi \[that has just been referred to\] and what is that of R. Jose? — R. Adda b. Mattena replied: —

A Tanna taught, Rabbi declares her[^fn_14b_17] unclean and R. Jose declares her clean. In connection with this R. Zera stated: When Rabbi declared her unclean he did so in agreement with the ruling of R. Meir, but when R. Jose declared her clean he did so in accordance with his own view. For we learnt:[^fn_14b_18] If a woman when attending to her needs[^fn_14b_19] observed a discharge of blood, R. Meir ruled: If she was standing at the time she is unclean but if she was sitting she is clean. R. Jose ruled: In either case she is regarded as clean.[^fn_14b_20] Said R. Aha son of Raba to R. Ashi: But did not R. Jose the son of R. Hanina state that when R. Meir ruled that the woman was unclean he did so only on account of the bloodstain,[^fn_14b_21] whereas Rabbi regarded her as unclean by reason of menstruation?[^fn_14b_22] — The other replied, What we maintain is this: When that ruling[^fn_14b_23] was stated it was that the uncleanness was due to menstruation.[^fn_14b_24]

IF ANY BLOOD IS FOUND ON HER RAG IMMEDIATELY AFTER HER INTERCOURSE THEY ARE BOTH UNCLEAN etc. Our Rabbis taught:[^fn_14b_25] What is meant by 'immediately'? This may be illustrated by the parable of the attendant and the witness who stood at the side of the lintel where the witness enters immediately after the attendant goes out, this being the interval which the Rabbis allowed as regards wiping off,[^fn_14b_26] but not as regards an examination.[^fn_14b_27]

IF, HOWEVER, ANY BLOOD IS FOUND ON HER RAG AFTER A TIME etc. A Tanna taught: They[^fn_14b_28] do incur the obligation of bringing a suspensive guilt-offering. But what is the reason of our Tanna?[^fn_14b_29] — It is essential[^fn_14b_30] \[that the doubt shall be of the same nature as in the case of the consumption of\] one piece of two pieces.[^fn_14b_31]

WHAT IS MEANT BY 'AFTER A TIME'? etc. Is not, however, this[^fn_14b_32] incongruous with the following: What is meant by 'after a time'? R. Eleazar[^fn_14b_33] son of R. Zadok explained: Within an interval in which[^fn_14b_34] she can stretch out her hand, put it under the cushion or bolster, take out a testing-rag and make examination with it?[^fn_14b_35] — R. Hisda replied: By AFTER is meant the interval following this interval.[^fn_14b_36] But was it not stated in connection with this,[^fn_14b_37] IF, HOWEVER, ANY BLOOD IS FOUND ON HER RAG AFTER A TIME THEY ARE UNCLEAN, BY REASON OF THE DOUBT BUT EXEMPT FROM THE SACRIFICE. WHAT IS MEANT BY 'AFTER A TIME'? WITHIN AN INTERVAL IN WHICH SHE CAN DESCEND FROM THE BED AND WASH HER FACE?[^fn_14b_38] — It is this that was implied:[^fn_14b_39] WHAT IS MEANT BY 'AFTER A TIME'? Within an interval in which she can stretch out her hand, put it under the cushion or bolster, take out a testing-rag and make examination with it; and WITHIN AN INTERVAL IN WHICH SHE CAN DESCEND FROM THE BED AND WASH HER FACE \[the question of uncleanness is subject to\] a divergence of view between R. Akiba and the Sages. But was it not stated,[^fn_14b_40] AFTER SUCH AN INTERVAL?[^fn_14b_41] — It is this that was meant: And this is the interval concerning which R. Akiba and the Sages are at variance.

R. Ashi replied: The former and the latter[^fn_14b_42] represent the same length of time; when she has the testing-rag in her hand the time IS WITHIN AN INTERVAL IN WHICH SHE CAN DESCEND FROM THE BED AND WASH HER FACE, but if she has not the rag in her hand the time is limited to 'within an interval in which she can stretch out her hand, put it under the cushion or bolster, take out a testing-rag and make examination with it'.

An objection was raised: What is meant by 'after a time'? This question was submitted by R. Eleazar son of R. Zadok to the Sages at Usha when he asked them, [pg 15a]

'Are you perchance of the same opinion as R. Akiba that the woman[^fn_15a_1] carries uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her?'[^fn_15a_2] 'We', they answered him, 'have not heard his ruling'.[^fn_15a_3] 'Thus', he said to them, 'did the Sages at Jamnia enunciate the ruling: If the woman did not delay more than the time in which she can descend from the bed and wash her face,[^fn_15a_4] this[^fn_15a_5] is regarded as 'within the time limit' and both are unclean on account of the doubt,[^fn_15a_6] and exempt from bringing a sacrifice but they are subject to the obligation of a suspensive guilt-offering. If she delayed for such a time during which she could descend from the bed and wash her face,[^fn_15a_7] this[^fn_15a_8] is regarded as being 'after the time',[^fn_15a_9] Similarly if she delayed[^fn_15a_10] for twenty-four hours[^fn_15a_11] or for a period between her previous and her present examination,[^fn_15a_12] the man who had intercourse with her is unclean on account of his contact,[^fn_15a_13] but not on account of his intercourse.[^fn_15a_14] R. Akiba ruled: He also contracts uncleanness on the ground of his intercourse.[^fn_15a_15] R. Judah son of R. Johanan b. Zakkai ruled: Her husband may enter the Temple and burn incense.[^fn_15a_16] Now according to R. Hisda[^fn_15a_17] one can well see why the Rabbis declare the man clean, but according to R. Ashi[^fn_15a_18] why do the Rabbis declare him clean? And should you reply that this is a case where she did not have the rag in her hand[^fn_15a_19] \[it could be retorted:\] Should not then[^fn_15a_20] a distinction have been made explicitly between the case where the woman had a rag in her hand and where she had no rag in her hand?[^fn_15a_21] — This is a difficulty.

'R. Judah son of R. Johanan b. Zakkai ruled: Her husband may enter the Temple and burn incense'. But why should not a prohibition be imposed[^fn_15a_22] on the ground that the man came in contact with a menstruant during the twenty-four hours of her retrospective uncleanness? — He[^fn_15a_23] holds the same view as Shammai who ruled: For all women it suffices to reckon their period of uncleanness from the time of their discovering the flow.[^fn_15a_24] But should not a prohibition be imposed[^fn_15a_21] on the ground that the man has experienced an emission of semen? — This is a case where his intercourse was not consummated.[^fn_15a_25]

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, AGREE WITH R. AKIBA THAT ONE WHO OBSERVED A BLOODSTAIN. Rab explained: \[She conveys UNCLEANNESS\] retrospectively and the ruling is that of R. Meir.[^fn_15a_26] Samuel, however, explained: \[She conveys UNCLEANNESS\] from now[^fn_15a_27] onwards and the ruling is that of the Rabbis. 'From now onwards'! Would not this[^fn_15a_28] be obvious? — It might have been presumed that, since retrospective uncleanness for a period of twenty-four hours is only a Rabbinical measure and the uncleanness of bloodstains at all times[^fn_15a_29] is also only a Rabbinical measure, as during the twenty-four hours' period a woman does not convey uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her so also in the case of a stain[^fn_15a_29] does she not convey uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her, hence we were informed \[that she does convey uncleanness to the man\]. Might it not, however, be suggested that the law is so indeed?[^fn_15a_30] — \[No, since\] in the former case there is no slaughtered ox in your presence[^fn_15a_31] but here there is a slaughtered ox in your presence.[^fn_15a_32] Resh Lakish also explained in the same way[^fn_15a_33] \[that uncleanness is conveyed\] retrospectively and that the ruling is that of R. Meir. R. Johanan explained: \[The uncleanness is conveyed\] from now onwards and the ruling is that of the Rabbis.

***MISHNAH***. ALL WOMEN ARE IN THE CONDITION OF PRESUMPTIVE CLEANNESS FOR THEIR HUSBANDS.[^fn_15a_34] FOR THOSE WHO RETURN FROM A JOURNEY THEIR WIVES ARE IN THE CONDITION OF PRESUMPTIVE CLEANNESS. {¶=2.4}

***GEMARA***. What need was there[^fn_15a_35] to state,[^fn_15a_36] THOSE THAT RETURN FROM A JOURNEY? — It might have been presumed that this[^fn_15a_37] applies only to a husband who was in the town, since in such a case the woman thinks of her duties[^fn_15a_38] and duly examines herself, but not to a husband who was not in town since the question of \[marital\] duty does not occur to her, hence we were informed \[that the law applies to the latter case also). Resh Lakish in the name of R. Judah Nesi'ah[^fn_15a_39] observed: But this[^fn_15a_40] applies only where the husband came and found her within her usually clean period.[^fn_15a_41] R. Huna observed: This[^fn_15a_42] was learnt only of a woman who had no settled period, but if she had a settled period intercourse with her is forbidden.[^fn_15a_43] Topsy turvy![^fn_15a_44] Does not, on the contrary, the reverse stand to reason, since in the case of a woman who has no settled period it might well be assumed that she experienced a discharge, but where she has a settled period \[she should be presumed to be clean\] since her period was fixed? — Rather, if the statement was at all made it was made in the following terms: R. Huna said, This[^fn_15a_45] was learnt only in the case of a woman the time of whose settled period had not arrived[^fn_15a_46] but if that time had arrived[^fn_15a_47] she is forbidden,[^fn_15a_43] for he[^fn_15a_47] is of the opinion that \[the laws of\] settled periods[^fn_15a_48] are Pentateuchal. Rabbah b. Bar Hana said: Even if the time of her settled period has arrived she is also permitted,[^fn_15a_49] for he is of the opinion that \[the laws relating to\] settled period are only Rabbinical.[^fn_15a_50] R. Ashi reported thus: R. Huna said, [pg 15b]

This[^fn_15b_1] was learnt only of a woman who had no settled period that was determinable by days alone but one that was determinable by both days and leaps, so that since the period depends on some specific act it might well be presumed, that she did not leap and that, therefore, did not observe any discharge. Where, however, she has a settled period that was determinable by the days alone, she must have no intercourse, for he is of the opinion that the restrictions relating to settled periods are Pentateuchal. Rabbah b. Bar Hana ruled: Even if she has a settled period that was determined by the days alone, she is permitted intercourse, for he holds the opinion that \[the restrictions relating to\] settled periods are only Rabbinical.

R. Samuel citing R. Johanan ruled: If a woman has a settled period, her husband[^fn_15b_2] may[^fn_15b_3] calculate the days of that period and[^fn_15b_4] come in unto her.[^fn_15b_5] Said R. Samuel b. Yeba to R. Abba: Did R. Johanan refer also to a young wife who[^fn_15b_6] is too shy to perform immersion? — The other replied: Did then R. Johanan speak of one who had actually[^fn_15b_7] observed a discharge? It may \[in fact be held\] that R. Johanan spoke[^fn_15b_8] only of a case where it is doubtful whether or not the woman did observe a discharge and where, \[so that\] even if some reason could be found for assuming that she did observe one, it may also be assumed that she had since performed immersions,[^fn_15b_9] but in a case where it is certain that she had observed a discharge, who could say that she had since performed immersion? And, seeing that it is a question of a doubt[^fn_15b_10] being opposed by a certainty[^fn_15b_11] \[she must be deemed unclean\] since a doubt cannot take one out of a certainty. But does it not? Was it not in fact taught: If a haber[^fn_15b_12] died and left a store-room full of fruits, even if they were only then due to be tithed,[^fn_15b_13] they are presumed to have been properly prepared.[^fn_15b_14] Now here it is a case of certain *tebel*[^fn_15b_15] and there is only the doubt as to whether or not it was tithed, and the doubt nevertheless sets aside the certainty? — No, there it is a case of a certainty against a certainty, in agreement with a statement of R. Hanina of Hozae,[^fn_15b_16] for R. Hanina of Hozae said: It is presumed with a haber that he does not allow anything to pass out of his control unless it has been duly prepared. And if you prefer I might say: It is a case of doubt against doubt, since \[the man might have acted\] in accordance with a suggestion of R. Oshaia, for R. Oshaia said: A man[^fn_15b_17] may resort to a device with his produce and store it[^fn_15b_18] together with its chaff[^fn_15b_19] so that[^fn_15b_20] his cattle may eat of it[^fn_15b_21] and it is exempt from the tithe.[^fn_15b_22]

But does not a doubt set aside a certainty? Surely it has been taught: It once happened that the handmaid of a certain tax-collector in Rimmon[^fn_15b_23] threw the body of a premature child into a pit, and a priest[^fn_15b_24] came and gazed into it to ascertain whether it was male or female,[^fn_15b_25] and when the matter came before the Sages[^fn_15b_26] they pronounced him clean because weasels and martens are commonly found there.[^fn_15b_27] Now here, surely, it is a certainty that the woman had thrown a premature child into the pit and a doubt whether they had dragged it away or not, and yet does not the doubt set aside the certainty? — Do not read, 'Threw the body of a premature child into a pit' but [pg 16a]

'a kind of premature child'.[^fn_16a_1] But was it not stated, 'To ascertain whether it was male or female'?[^fn_16a_2] — It is this that was meant: And a priest came and gazed into it to ascertain whether she had aborted an inflated object or a premature child and, if some ground could be found for assuming that she aborted a premature child, to ascertain whether it was male or female. And if you prefer I might reply: Since weasels and martens are commonly found there they had certainly dragged it away.[^fn_16a_3]

An enquiry was addressed to[^fn_16a_4] R. Nahman: \[Is the examination at\] regular menstrual periods Pentateuchal[^fn_16a_5] or only Rabbinical?[^fn_16a_6] The latter replied: Since our colleague Huna citing Rab ruled, If a woman who has a settled period did not make an examination when that period arrived but later on[^fn_16a_7] observed a discharge, she must take into consideration the possibility \[of a discharge\] on the date of the settled period,[^fn_16a_8] and also the possibility of \[twenty-four hours retrospective uncleanness\] on account of her observation.[^fn_16a_9] Thus[^fn_16a_10] it clearly follows that \[the examination at\] regular menstrual periods is Pentateuchal. There are others who say that he[^fn_16a_11] replied thus: The reason then[^fn_16a_12] is that she had 'observed a discharge,'[^fn_16a_13] but if she had not observed one the possibility[^fn_16a_14] need not be taken into consideration. Thus[^fn_16a_15] it follows clearly that \[the examination at\] regular menstrual periods is only Rabbinical.

It was stated: If a woman had a settled period, and when the time of that period arrived she did not make the examination and later she did make one, Rab ruled: If on examination she found that she was unclean she is unclean but if she found that she was clean she remains clean. Samuel, however, ruled, Even if on examination she found herself clean she is deemed unclean, since the guest[^fn_16a_16] comes at the usual time. Must it be assumed that they[^fn_16a_17] differ on \[the question of the necessity for an examination at\] regular menstrual periods, one Master[^fn_16a_18] holding that it is Pentateuchal[^fn_16a_19] and the other Master[^fn_16a_20] maintaining that it is only Rabbinical?[^fn_16a_21] R. Zera replied: Both[^fn_16a_17] may agree that[^fn_16a_22] \[the examination at\] regular menstrual periods is Pentateuchal, but[^fn_16a_23] one ruling[^fn_16a_24] refers to a woman who examined herself within the period of the duration of her menstruation[^fn_16a_25] while the other[^fn_16a_26] refers to a woman who did not examine herself within the period of the duration of her menstruation.[^fn_16a_27] R. Nahman b. Isaac maintained: They[^fn_16a_17] differ on the very question of \[the necessity for an examination at\] the regular menstrual periods, one Master[^fn_16a_28] holding that it is Pentateuchal[^fn_16a_29] while the other Master[^fn_16a_30] maintains that it is only Rabbinical.

R. Shesheth observed: \[The discussion here\] is analogous to that of the following Tannas: \[For it was taught:\] R. Eliezer[^fn_16a_31] ruled, She[^fn_16a_32] is to be regarded as menstrually unclean,[^fn_16a_33] while R. Joshua[^fn_16a_34] ruled: Let her be examined.[^fn_16a_35] And these Tannas[^fn_16a_36] differ on the same principle as the following Tannas. For it was taught: R. Meir ruled, She[^fn_16a_37] is to be regarded as menstrually unclean,[^fn_16a_38] while the Sages[^fn_16a_34] ruled, Let her be examined.[^fn_16a_35] Abaye observed, We also learnt to the same effect. For we learnt: R. Meir ruled, If a woman was in a hiding place[^fn_16a_39] when the time of her regular period arrived and she did not examine herself, she is nevertheless clean, because fear suspends the menstrual flow.[^fn_16a_40] The reason then[^fn_16a_41] is that there was fear, but if there had been no fear she would have been deemed unclean. Thus it clearly follows \[that the necessity for an examination at\] regular periods is Pentateuchal. May it be assumed that the following Tannas also differ on the same principle? For it was taught: If a woman observed some blood \[that might be\] due to a wound,[^fn_16a_42] even if this occurred during her usual period of menstruation, she is deemed to be clean;[^fn_16a_43] so R. Simeon b. Gamaliel. Rabbi ruled: If she has a regular period[^fn_16a_44] she[^fn_16a_45] must take her period into consideration.[^fn_16a_46] Now do they not differ on this principle, one Master[^fn_16a_47] holding that \[the examinations at\] the regular periods are Pentateuchal, while the other Master[^fn_16a_48] holds that they are only Rabbinical? — Rabina replied: No; both may agree that \[the examinations at\] the regular periods are only Rabbinical, but it is on the question whether the interior of the uterus is unclean[^fn_16a_49] that they differ. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel holds that the woman is clean[^fn_16a_50] but the blood[^fn_16a_51] is unclean because it comes through the uterus,[^fn_16a_52] and Rabbi[^fn_16a_53] in effect said to him: If[^fn_16a_54] you take into consideration the possibility of her usual menstrual flow, the woman also should be unclean,[^fn_16a_55] and if[^fn_16a_56] you do not take into consideration the possibility of her usual menstrual flow, \[the blood also should be clean since\] the interior of the uterus[^fn_16a_57] is clean.
