***MISHNAH***. BETH SHAMMAI RULED: A WOMAN NEEDS TWO[^fn_16a_58] TESTING-RAGS FOR EVERY INTERCOURSE,[^fn_16a_59] OR SHE MUST PERFORM IT IN THE LIGHT OF A LAMP.[^fn_16a_60] BETH HILLEL RULED: TWO TESTING-RAGS[^fn_16a_61] SUFFICE HER FOR THE WHOLE NIGHT.[^fn_16a_62] [pg 16b] {¶=2.5}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: Although \[the Sages\] have said, 'He who has intercourse in the light of a lamp is contemptible',[^fn_16b_1] Beth Shammai ruled: A woman needs two[^fn_16b_2] testing-rags for every intercourse[^fn_16b_3] or she must perform it in the light of a lamp, but Beth Hillel ruled: Two testing-rags suffice for her for the whole night.

It was taught: Beth Shammai said to Beth Hillel, 'According to your view[^fn_16b_4] is there no need to provide against the possibility that she might emit[^fn_16b_5] a drop of blood of the size of a mustard seed in the course of the first act and this would be covered up with semen during the second act?'[^fn_16b_6] 'But', replied Beth Hillel, even according to your view[^fn_16b_7] is there no need to provide against the possibility that the spittle,[^fn_16b_8] while still in the mouth,[^fn_16b_9] was crushed out of existence?'[^fn_16b_10] '\[We maintain our view,\] the former retorted, 'because what is crushed once is not the same as that which is crushed twice'.

It was taught: R. Joshua stated, 'I approve[^fn_16b_5] of the view of Beth Shammai'.[^fn_16b_7] 'Master', said his disciples to him, 'what an extension \[of the restrictions\] you have imposed upon us!' 'It is a good thing', he replied, 'that I should impose extensive restrictions upon you in this world in order that your days may be prolonged in the world to come.

R. Zera remarked: From the words of all these authorities[^fn_16b_11] we may infer[^fn_16b_12] that a conscientious man should not indulge in intercourse twice in succession.[^fn_16b_13] Raba said: One may indulge in intercourse twice in succession, for that ruling[^fn_16b_14] was taught only in respect of clean objects.[^fn_16b_15] So it was also taught: This[^fn_16b_16] applies only to clean objects[^fn_16b_15] but to her husband she is permitted.[^fn_16b_17] This,[^fn_16b_18] however, applies only where he had left her in a state of presumptive cleanness, but if he left her in a state of presumptive uncleanness she is presumed to be in that state forever until she tells him, 'I am clean'.

R. Abba citing R. Hiyya b. Ashi who had it from Rab ruled: If a woman[^fn_16b_19] examined herself with a testing-rag which was subsequently lost she is forbidden intercourse until she had reexamined herself. R. Ela demurred: If it had not been lost[^fn_16b_20] would she not[^fn_16b_21] have been allowed intercourse even though she is unaware \[whether there was or there was not a discharge\], why then should she not now also[^fn_16b_22] be allowed intercourse? — Raba replied: In the former case her proof is in existence,[^fn_16b_23] but in the latter case[^fn_16b_22] her proof is not in existence.[^fn_16b_24]

R. Johanan stated: It is forbidden to perform one's marital duty in the day-time.[^fn_16b_25] What is the Scriptural proof? That it is said, Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night wherein it was said: 'A man-child is brought forth'.[^fn_16b_26] The night is thus set aside[^fn_16b_27] for conception but the day is not set aside for conception. Resh Lakish stated: \[The proof is\] from here: But he that despiseth His ways[^fn_16b_28] shall die.[^fn_16b_29] As to Resh Lakish, how does he expound R. Johanan's text?[^fn_16b_26] — He requires it for the same exposition as that made by R. Hanina b. Papa. For R. Hanina b. Papa made the following exposition: The name of the angel who is in charge of conception is 'Night', and he takes up a drop and places it in the presence of the Holy One, blessed be He, saying, 'Sovereign of the universe, what shall be the fate of this drop? Shall it produce a strong man or a weak man, a wise man or a fool, a rich man or a poor man?' Whereas 'wicked man' or 'righteous one' he does not mention, in agreement with the view of R. Hanina. For R. Hanina stated: Everything is in the hands of heaven except the fear of God, as it is said, And now, Israel, what doth the Lord thy God require of thee, but to fear etc.[^fn_16b_30] And R. Johanan?[^fn_16b_31] — If that were the only meaning,[^fn_16b_32] Scripture should have written,[^fn_16b_33] 'A man-child is brought forth'[^fn_16b_34] why then was it stated, 'was brought forth a man-child'?[^fn_16b_35] To indicate that the night[^fn_16b_36] is set aside for conception[^fn_16b_36] but the day is not set aside for conception. As to R. Johanan how does he expound the text of Resh Lakish?[^fn_16b_29] — He requires it for \[an application to the same types\] as those described in the Book of Ben Sira:[^fn_16b_37] 'There are three \[types\] that I hate, yea, four that I do not love: A Scholar[^fn_16b_38] who frequents wine-shops[^fn_16b_39] \[or, as others say, a scholar that is a gossip\],[^fn_16b_40] a person who sets up a college in the high parts of a town,[^fn_16b_41] one who holds the membrum when making water and one who enters his friend's house suddenly'.[^fn_16b_42] R. Johanan observed:[^fn_16b_43] Even his own house.

R. Simeon b. Yohai observed: There are four \[types\][^fn_16b_44] which the Holy One, blessed be He, hates, and as for me, I do not love them: The man who enters his house suddenly and much more so \[if he so enters\] his friend's house, the man who holds the membrum when he makes water, [pg 17a]

the man who when naked makes water in front of his bed, and the man who has intercourse in the presence of any living creature. 'Even', said Rab Judah to Samuel, 'in the presence of mice?' 'Shinena',[^fn_17a_1] the other replied, 'no; but \[the reference is to\] a house like that of So and so where they have intercourse in the presence of their men-servants and maidservants.[^fn_17a_2] But what was the exposition they made? — Abide ye here with[^fn_17a_3] the ass,[^fn_17a_4] implies: peoples that are like an ass. Rabbah son of R. Huna used to chase away the wasps from his curtained bed.[^fn_17a_5] Abaye drove away the flies.[^fn_17a_6] Rabba[^fn_17a_7] chased away the mosquitoes.[^fn_17a_6]

R. Simeon b. Yohai stated, There are five things which \[cause the man\] who does them to forfeit his life and his blood is upon his own head: Eating[^fn_17a_8] peeled garlic, a peeled onion or a peeled egg, or drinking diluted liquids that[^fn_17a_9] were kept over night; spending a night in a graveyard; removing one's nails and throwing them away in a public thoroughfare; and blood-letting followed immediately by intercourse.

'Eating peeled garlic etc.' Even though they are deposited in a basket and tied up and sealed, an evil spirit rests upon them. This, however, has been said only where their roots or peel did not remain[^fn_17a_10] with them, but if their roots or peel remained with them there can be no objection.[^fn_17a_11]

'And drinking diluted liquids that were kept over night'. Rab Judah citing Samuel explained: This applies only where they were kept over night in a metal vessel. R. Papa stated: Vessels made of alum crystals are the same in this respect as vessels made of metal. So also said R. Johanan: This applies only where they were kept in a metal vessel; and vessels made of alum crystals are the same in this respect as vessels made of metal.

         'Spending a night in a graveyard', in order that a spirit of uncleanness may rest upon him.[^fn_17a_12] \[This should not be done\] since in consequence he might sometimes be exposed to danger.

'Removing one's nails and throwing them away in a public thoroughfare'. \[This is dangerous\] because a pregnant woman passing over them would miscarry. This, however, has been said only of a case where one removes them with a pair of scissors. Furthermore, this has been said only of a case where one removes the nails of both hands and feet. Furthermore, this has been said only in the case where one did not cut anything immediately after cutting them but if something was cut immediately after they were cut there can be no danger.[^fn_17a_13] This, however, is not \[to be relied upon\]. One should be on his guard in all the cases mentioned.[^fn_17a_14]

Our Rabbis taught: Three things have been said about the disposal of nails: He who burns them is a pious man, he who buries them is a righteous man, and he who throws them away is a wicked man.[^fn_17a_15]

'And blood-letting followed immediately by intercourse'. \[This should be avoided\] because a Master said: If a man has intercourse immediately after being bled, he will have feeble[^fn_17a_16] children; and if intercourse took place after both husband and wife have been bled, they will have children afflicted with ra'athan.[^fn_17a_17] Rab[^fn_17a_18] stated: This has been said only in the case where nothing was tasted after the bleeding but if something was tasted after it there can be no harm.[^fn_17a_19]

R. Hisda ruled: A man is forbidden to perform his marital duty in the day-time, for it is said, But thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.[^fn_17a_20] But what is the proof? — Abaye replied: He might observe something repulsive in her and she would thereby become loathsome to him.

R. Huna said, Israel are holy and do not perform their marital duties in the day-time. Raba said, But in[^fn_17a_21] a dark house this is permitted; and a scholar[^fn_17a_22] may darken a room with his cloak and perform his marital duty. \[But\] we have learnt, OR SHE MUST PERFORM IT IN THE LIGHT OF A LAMP? — Read: SHE MUST examine IT IN THE LIGHT OF A LAMP.

Come and hear: Although \[the Sages\] have said, He who has intercourse in the light of a lamp is loathsome \[etc.\]?[^fn_17a_23] — Read: He who examines his bed[^fn_17a_24] in the light of a lamp is loathsome.[^fn_17a_25]

Come and hear: And the people of the house of Monobaz[^fn_17a_26] did three things, and on account of these they were honourably mentioned: They performed their marital duties in the day-time, they examined their beds with cotton,[^fn_17a_27] and they observed the rules of uncleanness and cleanness in the case of snow. At all events, was it not here stated, 'They performed their marital duties in the day-time'? Read: They examined their beds in the day-time. This may also be supported by logical argument. For if one were to imagine \[that the reading is\] 'performed their marital duties', would they have been 'honourably mentioned'? — Yes, indeed;[^fn_17a_28] because owing to the prevalence[^fn_17a_29] of sleep[^fn_17a_30] she is likely to become repulsive to him.

'They examined their beds with cotton.' This provides support for a ruling of Samuel. For Samuel ruled: The bed[^fn_17a_31] may be examined only with cotton tufts or with clean and soft wool. Rab observed: This explains what they said in Palestine[^fn_17a_32] on Sabbath eves,[^fn_17a_33] when I was there, 'Who requires cotton tufts for his bread',[^fn_17a_31] and I did not understand at the time what they meant.

Raba stated: Old flax garments are admirably suited for examination purposes. But can this be correct,[^fn_17a_34] seeing that the school of Manasseh taught: The bed[^fn_17a_31] may not be examined either with a red rag or with a black one or with flax,[^fn_17a_35] but only with cotton tufts or with clean and soft wool?[^fn_17a_36] This is no difficulty, since the latter refers to flax while the former refers to garments of flax. And if you prefer I might reply: Both refer to garments of flax but the latter deals with new ones while the former deals with old ones.[^fn_17a_37]

'They observed the rules of uncleanness and cleanness in the case of snow.' We learnt elsewhere: Snow is neither a food nor a drink. Though one intended to use it as food it is not subject to the laws of the uncleanness of foodstuffs,[^fn_17a_38] \[but if one intended to use it\] as a drink it is subject to the laws of the uncleanness of drinks. If a part of it contracted uncleanness all of it does not become unclean,[^fn_17a_39] but if a part of it became clean[^fn_17a_40] all of it becomes clean. Now is not this self contradictory? You first said, 'If a part of it contracted uncleanness all of it does not become unclean', and then you said, 'If a part of it became clean all of it becomes clean', which implies, does it not, that all of it was previously unclean?[^fn_17a_41] — Abaye replied: This is a case, for instance, where it[^fn_17a_42] was carried across the air-space of an oven,[^fn_17a_43] \[in which case all the snow is unclean\] because the Torah testified concerning an earthen vessel[^fn_17a_44] that [pg 17b]

even if it was full of mustard seed[^fn_17b_1] \[all within it is unclean\].[^fn_17b_2]

***MISHNAH***. THE SAGES SPOKE OF A WOMAN IN METAPHOR: \[THERE IS IN HER\] CHAMBER[^fn_17b_3] AN ANTE-CHAMBER[^fn_17b_4] AND AN UPPER CHAMBER.[^fn_17b_5] THE BLOOD OF THE CHAMBER[^fn_17b_6] IS UNCLEAN, THAT OF THE UPPER CHAMBER[^fn_17b_7] IS CLEAN. IF BLOOD IS FOUND IN THE ANTE-CHAMBER, AND THERE ARISES A DOUBT ABOUT ITS CHARACTER,[^fn_17b_8] IT IS DEEMED UNCLEAN, BECAUSE IT IS PRESUMED TO HAVE COME FROM THE SOURCE.[^fn_17b_3] {¶=2.6}

***GEMARA***. Rami b. Samuel and R. Isaac son of Rab Judah learnt the tractate of *Niddah* at R. Huna's. Rabba son of R. Huna once found them while they were sitting at their studies and saying: The chamber is within, the ante-chamber is without and the upper chamber is built above them,[^fn_17b_9] and a duct communicates between the upper chamber and the ante-chamber.[^fn_17b_10] If blood is found anywhere from the duct inwards, and there is any doubt about its character,[^fn_17b_8] it is deemed unclean[^fn_17b_11] but if it is found anywhere from the duct outwards, and there is a doubt about its character,[^fn_17b_8] it is deemed clean.[^fn_17b_12] He[^fn_17b_13] thereupon proceeded to his father and said to him, 'You told them, Master,[^fn_17b_14] that "if there is any doubt about its character[^fn_17b_15] it is deemed unclean", but have we not learnt: BECAUSE IT IS PRESUMED TO HAVE COME FROM THE SOURCE?'[^fn_17b_16] 'I', the other replied, 'meant this: \[Blood found anywhere\] from the duct inwards is[^fn_17b_17] undoubtedly unclean,[^fn_17b_18] \[but if it was found anywhere\] from the duct outwards, it is deemed to be doubtfully unclean'.[^fn_17b_19] Said Abaye: Why is[^fn_17b_20] it \[that if blood is found anywhere\] from the duct outwards it is deemed to be doubtfully unclean?[^fn_17b_21] Obviously because it is possible that she bowed down and the blood flowed thither from the chamber. \[But, then, why in the case where blood is found anywhere\] from the duct inwards, is it not also assumed that she might have staggered backwards[^fn_17b_22] and the blood originated from the upper chamber?[^fn_17b_23] Rather, said Abaye, if you follow possibilities[^fn_17b_24] the uncleanness is doubtful in either case[^fn_17b_25] and if you follow presumption \[blood found anywhere\] from the duct inwards is undoubtedly unclean,[^fn_17b_26] \[but if it was found anywhere\] from the duct outwards it is undoubtedly clean.[^fn_17b_27]

R. Hiyya taught: Blood found in the ante-chamber[^fn_17b_28] renders \[the woman\] liable \[for a sin-offering\] if she enters the Sanctuary,[^fn_17b_29] and *terumah*[^fn_17b_30] must be burnt on its account.[^fn_17b_29] R. Kattina, however, ruled: No sin-offering[^fn_17b_31] is incurred if she enters the Sanctuary,[^fn_17b_32] and *terumah*[^fn_17b_30] is not burnt on its account.[^fn_17b_32] According to the first alternative[^fn_17b_33] which Abaye mentioned, viz., 'If you follow possibilities',[^fn_17b_34] support is available for the ruling of R. Kattina[^fn_17b_35] but[^fn_17b_36] a divergence of view is presented against R. Hiyya. According to the second alternative[^fn_17b_33] you mentioned, viz., 'If you follow presumption'[^fn_17b_37] support is provided for the ruling of R. Hiyya[^fn_17b_38] [pg 18a]

but[^fn_18a_1] a divergence of view is presented against R. Kattina.[^fn_18a_2] According to the ruling of R. Huna[^fn_18a_3] neither of them differs from the other,[^fn_18a_4] since one[^fn_18a_5] might deal with blood found anywhere from the duct inwards while the other[^fn_18a_6] might deal with such as was found anywhere from the duct outwards. According to Rami b. Samuel and R. Isaac the son of Rab Judah, however, who ruled, 'From the duct outwards, and there is a doubt about its character, it is deemed clean' and 'from the duct inwards, and there is a doubt about its character, it is deemed unclean', how are these rulings[^fn_18a_7] to be explained? Obviously \[as referring[^fn_18a_8] to blood found\] anywhere from the duct inwards.[^fn_18a_9] Must it then be assumed[^fn_18a_10] that their ruling differs from that of R. Hiyya?[^fn_18a_11] — This is no difficulty, since one[^fn_18a_12] refers to blood found on the floor of the ante-chamber[^fn_18a_13] while the others[^fn_18a_14] refer to blood found on the roof of the ante-chamber.[^fn_18a_15]

R. Johanan stated: In three instances[^fn_18a_16] did the Sages follow the majority rule[^fn_18a_17] and treated them as certainties, viz., the 'source', the 'placenta' and the 'piece'. The 'source'? The case already spoken of.[^fn_18a_18] The 'placenta'? Concerning which we have learnt: If a placenta[^fn_18a_19] is within a house, the house is unclean;[^fn_18a_20] and this is so not because a placenta is regarded as a child but because generally there is no placenta without a child in it.[^fn_18a_21] R. Simeon said, The child might have been mashed[^fn_18a_22] before it came forth.[^fn_18a_23] A 'piece'? For it was taught:[^fn_18a_24] If a woman aborted a shaped[^fn_18a_25] hand or a shaped foot she[^fn_18a_26] is subject to the uncleanness of birth,[^fn_18a_27] and there is no need to consider the possibility[^fn_18a_28] that it might have come from a shapeless body.[^fn_18a_29] But are there[^fn_18a_30] no others?[^fn_18a_31] Is there not in fact the case of nine shops[^fn_18a_32] concerning which it was taught: If there were nine shops[^fn_18a_32] all of which were selling ritually killed meat and one shop that was selling *nebelah*[^fn_18a_33] meat and a man bought some meat in one of them and he does not know in which of them he bought it, the meat is forbidden on account of the doubt;[^fn_18a_34] but if[^fn_18a_35] meat is found,[^fn_18a_36] the majority rule is to be followed?[^fn_18a_37] — We[^fn_18a_38] speak of uncleanness;[^fn_18a_39] we do not discuss the question of a prohibition.[^fn_18a_40] But is there not the case of the nine \[dead\] frogs among which there was one \[dead\] creeping thing[^fn_18a_41] and a man touched one of them and he does not know which one it was that he touched, where he is unclean on account of the doubt if this occurred in a private domain,[^fn_18a_42] but if it occurred in a public domain such a doubtful case is regarded as clean; and if one[^fn_18a_43] was found[^fn_18a_44] the majority rule is to be followed?[^fn_18a_45] — We[^fn_18a_46] deal with the uncleanness of a woman; we do not discuss general questions of uncleanness. But is there not the following case of which R. Joshua b. Levi spoke: If a woman crossed a river [pg 18b]

and miscarried[^fn_18b_1] in it, she must bring a sacrifice which may be eaten, since we follow the majority of women, and the majority of women bear normal children?[^fn_18b_2] — We spoke of Tannaitic rulings;[^fn_18b_3] we did not discuss reported traditions.[^fn_18b_4] But, surely, when Rabin came[^fn_18b_5] he stated, 'R. Jose son of R. Hanina raised an objection \[against R. Joshua b. Levi from a Baraitha dealing with\] a forgetful woman,[^fn_18b_6] but I do not know what objection it was',[^fn_18b_7] Does not this mean that it[^fn_18b_8] presented no objection but rather provided support?[^fn_18b_9] — No; it is possible \[that he meant that it\] neither presented an objection nor provided any support.

What does it[^fn_18b_10] exclude?[^fn_18b_11] If it be suggested that it[^fn_18b_10] was intended to exclude the case[^fn_18b_12] where the majority rule is opposed by the rule of presumption[^fn_18b_13] so that in such a case *terumah*[^fn_18b_14] may not be burnt on its account,[^fn_18b_15] surely \[it could be retorted\] did not R. Johanan once say this,[^fn_18b_16] for we learnt, 'If a child is found at the side of dough, with a piece of dough in his hand, R. Meir declares the dough clean, but the Sages declare it unclean because it is the nature of a child to slap[^fn_18b_17] \[dough\]';[^fn_18b_18] and when it was asked, 'What is R. Meir's reason' \[the answer given was that\] he holds the view that though most children slap dough a minority of them do not, and since this dough stands in the presumption of cleanness;[^fn_18b_19] you combine the status of the minority[^fn_18b_20] with the rule of presumption[^fn_18b_21] and the majority rule[^fn_18b_22] is impaired,[^fn_18b_23] while the Rabbis \[regard\] the minority as non-existent, and, where the majority rule is opposed by that of presumption, the majority rule takes precedence; and in connection with this Resh Lakish citing R. Oshaia stated: This is a presumption[^fn_18b_24] on the strength of which *terumah* is burnt,[^fn_18b_25] while R. Johanan stated, This[^fn_18b_26] is not a presumption on the strength of which *terumah* is burnt?[^fn_18b_27] — It[^fn_18b_28] was rather intended to exclude the rule of majority of which R. Judah spoke.[^fn_18b_29] For we learnt: If a woman aborted a shapeless object,[^fn_18b_30] if there was blood with it she is unclean[^fn_18b_31] otherwise she is clean; R. Judah ruled: In either case she is unclean.[^fn_18b_32] And in connection with this Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: R. Judah declared the woman unclean only where the shapeless object had the colour of one of the four kinds of blood,[^fn_18b_33] but if it had that of any other kinds of blood[^fn_18b_34] the woman is clean, while R. Johanan stated: \[If it had the colour\] of one of the four kinds of blood[^fn_18b_35] all[^fn_18b_36] agree that she is unclean, and if it had that of any other kinds of blood all agree that she is clean; they[^fn_18b_37] differ only in the case where she aborted something [pg 19a]

and she does not know what she has aborted.[^fn_19a_1] \[In such a case,\] R. Judah holds, one must be guided by the nature of most of such shapeless objects, and most such objects have the colour of one of the four kinds of blood, while the Rabbis hold that we do not say that one must be guided by the nature of most such objects.[^fn_19a_2]

***MISHNAH***. FIVE KINDS OF BLOOD IN A WOMAN ARE UNCLEAN: RED, BLACK, A COLOUR LIKE BRIGHT CROCUS, OR LIKE EARTHY WATER OR LIKE DILUTED WINE.[^fn_19a_3] BETH SHAMMAI RULED: ALSO A COLOUR LIKE THAT OF FENUGREEK WATER OR THE JUICE OF ROASTED MEAT; BUT BETH HILLEL DECLARE THESE CLEAN. ONE THAT IS YELLOW, AKABIA B. MAHALALEL DECLARES UNCLEAN AND THE SAGES DECLARE CLEAN. R. MEIR SAID: EVEN IF IT DOES NOT CONVEY UNCLEANNESS AS A BLOODSTAIN IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS AS A LIQUID.[^fn_19a_4] R. JOSE RULED: IT DOES NEITHER THE ONE NOR THE OTHER.[^fn_19a_5] {¶=2.7}

WHAT COLOUR IS REGARDED AS 'RED'? ONE LIKE THE BLOOD OF A WOUND.[^fn_19a_4] 'BLACK'? LIKE THE SEDIMENT OF INK; IF IT IS DARKER IT IS UNCLEAN AND IF LIGHTER IT IS CLEAN. 'BRIGHT CROCUS COLOUR'? LIKE THE BRIGHTEST SHADE IN IT.[^fn_19a_4] 'A COLOUR LIKE EARTHY WATER'? EARTH FROM THE VALLEY OF BETH KEREM[^fn_19a_6] OVER WHICH WATER IS MADE TO FLOAT. 'ONE LIKE DILUTED WINE'? TWO PARTS OF WATER AND ONE OF WINE OF THE WINE OF SHARON.

***GEMARA***. Whence is it deduced that there is clean discharge of blood in a woman? Is it not possible that all blood that issues from her is unclean? — R. Hama b. Joseph citing R. Oshaia[^fn_19a_7] replied: Scripture says, If there arise a matter too hard for thee in judgment, between blood and blood,[^fn_19a_8] which implies between clean blood and unclean blood. But then, would the expression 'between a leprous stroke and a leprous stroke'[^fn_19a_8] also mean between an unclean stroke and a clean one? And should you reply: This is so indeed, \[it could be retorted:\] Is there at all a leprous stroke that is clean? And should you reply, 'It is all turned white; he is clean',[^fn_19a_9] \[it could be retorted:\] That is called a white scurf![^fn_19a_10] Consequently it must mean: Between human leprosy and the leprosy of houses and the leprosy of garments, all of which are unclean; why then should it not be said heres also that the distinction implied is that between the blood of a menstruant and that of one suffering from gonorrhoea both of which are unclean?[^fn_19a_11] — What a comparison! There[^fn_19a_12] \[the controversy[^fn_19a_13] is well justified[^fn_19a_14] since\] a difference of opinion might arise in the case of human leprosy on the lines of that between R. Joshua and the Rabbis. For we have learnt: If the bright spot[^fn_19a_15] preceded the white hair, he[^fn_19a_16] is unclean; if the reverse was the case, he is clean. If \[the order of appearance is\] a matter of doubt he is unclean; but R. Joshua said: It is as though darkened,[^fn_19a_17] and in connection with this Rabbah explained: It is as though \[the spot\] darkened[^fn_19a_18] and he is therefore clean.[^fn_19a_19] As regards leprosy in houses the point at issue[^fn_19a_20] may be the one between R. Eleazar son of R. Simeon and the Rabbis. For we have learnt: R. Eleazar son of R. Simeon ruled: A house never becomes unclean unless the leprosy appears in the size of two beans on two stones,[^fn_19a_21] in two walls,[^fn_19a_21] at a corner,[^fn_19a_22] and it must be two beans in length and one bean in breadth.[^fn_19a_23] What is R. Eleazar son of R. Simeon's reason? — It is written[^fn_19a_24] wall[^fn_19a_25] and it is also written walls,[^fn_19a_26] now what wall is it that is like two walls? Admit that that is a corner.[^fn_19a_27] As regards leprosy in garments the divergence of opinion[^fn_19a_28] may be the one between R. Jonathan b. Abtolemos and the Rabbis. For it was taught: R. Jonathan[^fn_19a_29] b. Abtolemos stated, Whence is it deduced that leprosy that is spread over entire garments is clean? Since karahath[^fn_19a_30] and gabahath[^fn_19a_31] are mentioned in respect of garments, and karahath[^fn_19a_32] and gabahath[^fn_19a_33] are also mentioned in the case of human beings, as in the latter case if the leprosy spread over the whole body, he is clean so also in the former case if it spread over the whole garment it is clean.[^fn_19a_34] Here,[^fn_19a_35] however, if clean blood does not exist, what could be the point at issue between them?[^fn_19a_36] But whence is it inferred that these kinds of blood are clean and the others are unclean?[^fn_19a_37] — R. Abbahu replied: Since Scripture says, And the Moabites saw the water as red as blood,[^fn_19a_38] which indicates that blood is red.[^fn_19a_39] Might it not be suggested that only red blood[^fn_19a_40] is unclean but no other?[^fn_19a_41] — R. Abbahu replied: Scripture says; Her blood,[^fn_19a_42] Her blood[^fn_19a_43] implying four kinds.[^fn_19a_44] But have we not learnt, FIVE KINDS? — R. Hanina replied: Black blood is really red \[blood\] that had deteriorated.[^fn_19a_45] So it was also taught: Black blood is like the sediment of ink; if it is dark it is unclean, and if lighter, even though it has the colour of stibium, it is clean. And black blood is not black originally. It[^fn_19a_46] assumes the black colour only after it is discharged, like the blood of a wound which becomes black after it had been discharged from it.

BETH SHAMMAI RULED: ALSO A COLOUR LIKE THAT OF FENUGREEK. But do not Beth Shammai uphold the deduction from, Her blood,[^fn_19a_42] her blood[^fn_19a_43] which imply four kinds?[^fn_19a_44] — If you wish I may reply that they do not uphold it — And if you prefer I may reply that they do uphold it, but[^fn_19a_47] did not R. Hanina explain, 'Black blood is really red \[blood\] that had deteriorated'?[^fn_19a_48] Well, here also[^fn_19a_49] it may be explained that \[the blood\][^fn_19a_50] had merely deteriorated.

BUT BETH HILLEL DECLARE THESE CLEAN. Is not this ruling identical with that of the first Tanna?[^fn_19a_51] — The practical difference between them is [pg 19b]

the question of suspense.[^fn_19b_1]

ONE THAT IS YELLOW, AKABIA B. MAHALALEL DECLARES UNCLEAN. But does not Akabia uphold the deduction from 'Her blood, her blood', which imply four kinds?[^fn_19b_2] — If you wish I may reply: He does not uphold it. And if you prefer I may reply: He does uphold it; but did not R. Hanina explain, 'Black blood is really red \[blood\] that had deteriorated'? Well, here also it may be explained that \[the blood\] had merely deteriorated.[^fn_19b_2]

AND THE SAGES DECLARE IT CLEAN. Is not this ruling identical with that of the first Tanna?[^fn_19b_3] — The practical difference between them is the question of suspense.[^fn_19b_4]

R. MEIR SAID: EVEN IF IT DOES NOT CONVEY UNCLEANNESS AS A BLOODSTAIN etc. R. Johanan stated: R. Meir took up[^fn_19b_5] the line of Akabia b. Mahalalel and declared it[^fn_19b_6] unclean;[^fn_19b_7] and it is this that he in effect said to the Rabbis, 'Granted that where a woman finds a yellow bloodstain on her garment you do not regard her as unclean;[^fn_19b_8] where she observed a discharge of yellow blood from her body[^fn_19b_9] she must be deemed unclean'. If so, instead of saying, EVEN IF IT DOES NOT CONVEY UNCLEANNESS AS A BLOODSTAIN IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS AS A LIQUID, should he not have said 'on account of her observation'?[^fn_19b_10] — Rather, it is this that he in effect said to them, 'Granted that where the woman observed yellow blood at the outset you do not[^fn_19b_11] regard her as unclean;[^fn_19b_12] where she observed first red blood[^fn_19b_13] and then a yellow discharge the latter also must be deemed unclean,[^fn_19b_14] since it is something like the liquids[^fn_19b_15] of a *zab* or a zabah'.[^fn_19b_16] And the Rabbis?[^fn_19b_17] — \[An unclean liquid must be\] similar to spittle; as spittle is formed in globules when it is discharged so must any other unclean liquid be one that is formed in globules when it is discharged; that liquid[^fn_19b_18] is therefore excluded since it is not formed in globules when discharged. If so, do not the Rabbis indeed give R. Meir a most satisfactory answer?[^fn_19b_19] — It is rather this that he said to them in effect: 'It[^fn_19b_18] should have the status of a liquid in respect of rendering seed susceptible to uncleanness'.[^fn_19b_20] And the Rabbis?[^fn_19b_21] — \[For such a purpose\] it is necessary that it shall be like the blood of the slain,[^fn_19b_22] which is not the case here. If so, did not the Rabbis indeed answer R. Meir well?[^fn_19b_19] — It is rather this that he in effect said to them: 'Deduce this[^fn_19b_23] by gezera shawah;[^fn_19b_24] here[^fn_19b_25] it is written, Thy shoots[^fn_19b_26] are a park of pomegranates[^fn_19b_27] and elsewhere it is written, And sendeth[^fn_19b_28] water upon the fields.[^fn_19b_29] And the Rabbis?[^fn_19b_30] A man may infer a ruling a minori ad majus on his own but he may not infer on his own one that is derived from a gezera shawah.[^fn_19b_31]

R. JOSE RULED: IT DOES NEITHER THE ONE NOR THE OTHER etc. Is not this ruling identical with that of the first Tanna?[^fn_19b_32] — It is this that we were informed: Who is the first Tanna? R. Jose; for he who repeats a thing in the name of him who said it brings deliverance into the world.[^fn_19b_33]

WHAT COLOUR IS REGARDED AS RED? ONE LIKE THE BLOOD OF A WOUND. What is meant by LIKE THE BLOOD OF A WOUND? — Rab Judah citing Samuel replied: Like the blood of a slaughtered ox.[^fn_19b_34] Why then was it not stated, 'Like the blood of slaughtering'? — If it had been stated, 'Like the blood of slaughtering' it might have been presumed to mean like the blood during the entire process of slaughtering,[^fn_19b_35] hence we were told, LIKE THE BLOOD OF A WOUND, meaning like that caused by the first stroke of the knife. 'Ulla replied:[^fn_19b_36] Like the blood of \[a wound inflicted on\] a live bird. The question was raised: Does 'live'[^fn_19b_37] exclude a slaughtered bird or does it possibly exclude an emaciated one? — This is undecided.[^fn_19b_38] Ze'iri citing R. Hanina replied:[^fn_19b_36] Like the blood of a head louse. An objection was raised: If she[^fn_19b_39] killed a louse she may attribute the stain to it.[^fn_19b_40] Does not this refer to a louse of any part of the body? — No, to one of her head. Ammi of Wardina[^fn_19b_41] citing R. Abbahu replied:[^fn_19b_36] Like the blood of the little finger of the hand that was wounded and healed and wounded again. Furthermore, it does not mean that of any person but only that of a young unmarried man. And up to what age? — Up to that of twenty.

An objection was raised: She[^fn_19b_39] may attribute it to her son[^fn_19b_42] or to her husband.[^fn_19b_42] \[Now the attribution\] to her son is quite reasonable since it is possible \[that he was unmarried\],[^fn_19b_43] but how is this possible in the case of her husband?[^fn_19b_44] — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: Where, for instance, the woman entered the bridal chamber but had no intercourse.[^fn_19b_45] R. Nahman replied:[^fn_19b_46] Like the blood of the arteries.[^fn_19b_47]

An objection was raised: It once happened that R. Meir attributed it[^fn_19b_48] [pg 20a]

to collyrium[^fn_20a_1] and Rabbi attributed it to the sap of a sycamore.[^fn_20a_2] Now did not these cases[^fn_20a_3] deal with the question of red blood?[^fn_20a_4] — No; with that of other kinds of blood.

Amemar and Mar Zutra and R. Ashi once sat before a cupper,[^fn_20a_5] and when the first cupping-horn was taken off Amemar he saw it and said to the others, 'The red[^fn_20a_6] of which we have learnt[^fn_20a_7] is a shade like this'. When the second one was taken off from him, he said to them, 'This has a different shade'. 'One like myself', observed R. Ashi, 'Who does not know the difference between the one and the other must not act as an examiner of blood'.

'BLACK? LIKE THE SEDIMENT \[OF INK\]. Rabbah son of R. Huna stated: The HERETH[^fn_20a_8] of which the Rabbis spoke[^fn_20a_7] is ink. So it was also taught: Black[^fn_20a_9] is a colour like hereth and the 'black' of which the Rabbis spoke[^fn_20a_9] is the colour of ink. Then why was it not directly stated, 'Ink'? — If 'ink' had been stated, it might have been presumed to refer to the watery part of the ink,[^fn_20a_10] hence we were informed that the colour is like that of the sediment of the ink. The question was raised: Is the reference to liquid, or to dry ink? — Come and hear of \[the practice of\] R. Ammi who used to split a grain of dry ink and with its aid performed the necessary examination.

Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: \[If a woman's discharge has a colour\] like that of black wax, black ink or a black grape she is unclean; and it is this that was meant by what we learnt: IF IT IS DARKER IT IS UNCLEAN.

R. Eleazar ruled: \[A discharge that has a colour\] like that of a black olive, pitch or a raven is clean; and it is this that was alluded to in what we have learnt: IF LIGHTER IT IS CLEAN.

'Ulla explained:[^fn_20a_11] One like a Siwa[^fn_20a_12] cloak. 'Ulla once visited Pumbeditha when he noticed an Arab merchant who was wearing a black cloak. 'The black of which we have learnt',[^fn_20a_13] he told them, 'is a colour like this'. They pulled it off him in bits[^fn_20a_14] and paid him for it four hundred *zuz*.

R. Johanan explained:[^fn_20a_11] \[One of the colour of\] those court[^fn_20a_15] clothes that are imported from courtiers beyond the sea. This then implies that such clothes are black, but did not R. Jannai address the following request to his sons: 'My children, do not bury me either in black shrouds or white shrouds; "either in black", peradventure I may be worthy \[of a place in paradise\] and I would be like a mourner among bridegrooms;[^fn_20a_16] "or in white", peradventure I might not be worthy and would be like a bridegroom among mourners;[^fn_20a_17] but \[bury me\] only in court[^fn_20a_15] clothes that are imported from countries beyond the sea', which clearly proves, does it not, that these are not black?[^fn_20a_18] — This is no difficulty, the latter[^fn_20a_19] referring to wrappers,[^fn_20a_20] while the former[^fn_20a_21] refers to clothes worn[^fn_20a_22] at table.[^fn_20a_23]

Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: And all these[^fn_20a_24] must be tested only on a white strip of cloth. R. Isaac b. Abudemi ruled: But black blood may be tested on a red strip of cloth. R. Jeremiah of Difti observed: There is really no difference of opinion between them,[^fn_20a_25] since the latter speaks only of black blood while the former refers to the other kinds of blood. R. Ashi demurred: If so, why did not Samuel say, 'With the exception of black'? Rather, said R. Ashi, they[^fn_20a_26] differ on the very question of black itself.

'Ulla ruled: In the case of all these[^fn_20a_27] if the discharge is darker[^fn_20a_28] It is unclean and if it is lighter[^fn_20a_28] it is clean, as is the case with black.[^fn_20a_29] Then why did it mention only black? — As it might have been presumed that, since R. Hanina stated, 'Black \[blood\] is really red blood that had deteriorated', it should, therefore, be unclean even if it is lighter, hence we were informed \[that IF LIGHTER IT IS CLEAN\].

R. Ammi b. Abba ruled: In the case of all these[^fn_20a_27] if the discharge is darker[^fn_20a_28] it is unclean and if it is lighter it is also unclean, the only exception being black.[^fn_20a_30] What then[^fn_20a_31] was the use of the standard shade laid down by the Rabbis? — To exclude[^fn_20a_32] one that was extremely faint.[^fn_20a_33] There are others who read: Rami b. Abba ruled: In the case of all these[^fn_20a_34] if the discharge is darker[^fn_20a_35] it is clean and if it is lighter it is also clean, the only exception being black;[^fn_20a_30] and it is in this case that the Rabbinical standard is of use.

Bar Kappara ruled: In the case of all these[^fn_20a_34] if the discharge is darker it is unclean and if lighter it is clean, the exception being \[the colour of\] diluted wine in which a darker shade is clean and a lighter one is also clean. Bar Kappara was shown a lighter shade[^fn_20a_36] and he declared it clean, and when he was shown a darker shade[^fn_20a_36] he also declared it clean. 'How great is the man', exclaimed R. Hanina, 'who in practice acts[^fn_20a_37] in agreement with his view.

A COLOUR LIKE BRIGHT CROCUS. A Tanna taught: Fresh crocus and not dry one. One \[Baraitha\] taught: Like the lower leaf[^fn_20a_38] but not like the upper one, and another \[Baraitha\] taught: Like the upper leaf but not like the lower one, while a third \[Baraitha\] taught: Like the upper leaf and much more so like the lower one, and a fourth \[Baraitha\] taught: Like the lower leaf and much more so like the upper one![^fn_20a_39] — Abaye replied: The crocus has three rows of leaves[^fn_20a_40] and there are three leaves in each row; keep[^fn_20a_41] to the middle row[^fn_20a_42] and the middle leaf of that row.[^fn_20a_43] When they came before R. Abbahu he told them: What we learnt \[about the colour of the crocus refers to such as are still\] attached to their clods.[^fn_20a_44]

OR LIKE EARTHY WATER. Our Rabbis taught: Like earthy water — one brings fertile soil from the valley of Beth Kerem over which he causes water to float; so R. Meir. R. Judah[^fn_20a_45] said: From the valley of Jotapata.[^fn_20a_46] R. Jose said: From the valley of Sikni.[^fn_20a_47] R. Simeon said: Also from the valley of Gennesaret[^fn_20a_48] and similar soil. Another \[Baraitha\] taught: And like earthy water — one brings fertile soil from the valley of Beth Kerem and over it he causes water to float until it forms a layer as thin as the husk of garlic; and no quantity has been prescribed for the water since none has been prescribed for the earth.[^fn_20a_49] The water, furthermore, is not to be examined when it is clean but when turbid. If they become clear they must be stirred up again;[^fn_20a_50] and when they are stirred one must not do it with the hand but with a vessel. The question was raised: \[Does the expression,\] 'One must not do it with the hand but with a vessel' mean that a man must not put it in his hand and stir it in it but that where it is in a vessel it is quite proper for him to stir it with his hand, or is it possible that the meaning is that one must not stir it with his hand[^fn_20a_51] but with an instrument?[^fn_20a_52] — Come and hear: When he examines it[^fn_20a_53] he must do it in a cup only.[^fn_20a_54] But does not the question yet remain: If the examination must be in a cup, wherewith must the stirring be done? — This is undecided.[^fn_20a_55]

When they came before Rabba b. Abbuha he told them: What we learnt \[about the earth refers to such as is\] in its own place.[^fn_20a_56]

R. Hanina used to break up a piece of potter's clay and thereby performed the examination. R. Ishmael son of R. Jose cursed with croup any other person who adopts such a method [pg 20b]

for R. Hanina was wise enough;[^fn_20b_1] all others are not so wise. R. Johanan remarked: The wisdom of R. Hanina caused me not to examine any blood, for when I declared any unclean he declared it clean and when I declared it clean he declared it unclean. R. Eleazar remarked: R. Hanina's modesty is the cause of my examining blood. \[For I felt\] if R. Hanina who was modest allowed himself to be involved in doubt and examined blood, should not I examine it? R. Zera remarked: The Babylonian coinage was the cause of my refusing to examine blood; for I thought: If I do not understand the coinage system would I understand the nature of blood? This then implies that capability to examine blood depends on an understanding of the coinage; but did not Rabbah in fact understand the coinage system and yet did not understand the qualities of blood? — He was really drawing an inference a minori ad majus: If Rabbah who understood the coinage system refused to examine blood, should I[^fn_20b_2] examine it?

'Ulla once visited Pumbeditha[^fn_20b_3] and when some blood was brought to him for examination he refused to see it. If, he said, R. Eleazar who was the supreme authority in the Land of Israel[^fn_20b_4] refused to see blood whenever he visited the place of R. Judah, should I see it?[^fn_20b_5] And why was he described as the supreme authority in the Land of Israel? — Because a woman once brought some blood before R. Eleazar when R. Ammi sat in his presence. Having smelt it he[^fn_20b_6] told her, 'This is blood of lust'.[^fn_20b_7] After she went out R. Ammi joined her and she told him, 'My husband was away on a journey but I felt an intense longing for him'. Thereupon he[^fn_20b_8] applied to him[^fn_20b_6] the text, The counsel of the Lord is with them that fear Him.[^fn_20b_9]

Ifra Hormiz,[^fn_20b_10] the mother of King Shapur, once sent some blood to Raba when R. Obadiah was sitting in his presence. Having smelt it he said to him, 'This is blood of lust'.[^fn_20b_7] 'Come and see', she remarked to her[^fn_20b_11] son, 'how wise the Jews are'. 'It is quite possible', he replied, 'that he[^fn_20b_12] hit upon it like a blind man on a window'. Thereupon she sent to him[^fn_20b_12] sixty different kinds of blood and he identified them all but the last one which was lice blood with which he was not acquainted. Luckily,[^fn_20b_13] however, he sent her[^fn_20b_14] a comb that exterminates lice. 'O, you Jews', she exclaimed, you seem to live in the inner chamber of one's heart'.[^fn_20b_15]

Rab Judah stated: 'At first I used to examine blood, but since the mother of my son Isaac told me, "We do not bring the first drop to the Rabbis because it is dirty", I refuse to see it.[^fn_20b_16] \[An examination, however, for the purpose of distinguishing\] between the blood of uncleanness and cleanness[^fn_20b_17] I certainly do perform'.[^fn_20b_18]

Yaltha[^fn_20b_19] once brought some blood to Rabbah b. Bar Hana who informed her that it was unclean. She then took it to R. Isaac the son of Rab Judah who told her that it was clean. But how could he act in this manner, seeing that is was taught: If a Sage declared \[aught\] unclean another Sage[^fn_20b_20] may not declare it clean; if he forbade anything his colleague may not permit it?[^fn_20b_21] — At first he[^fn_20b_22] informed her indeed that it was unclean,[^fn_20b_23] but when she told him that on every other occasion he[^fn_20b_24] declared such blood as clean, but that on the last occasion he had a pain in his eye, he gave her his ruling that it was clean. But are women believed in such circumstances? — Yes, and so it was also taught: A woman[^fn_20b_25] is believed when she says, 'I saw a kind of blood like this one[^fn_20b_26] but I have lost it.'[^fn_20b_27]

The question was raised: What is the law \[where a woman says\], A kind of blood like this[^fn_20b_28] has been declared clean by such and such a Sage?[^fn_20b_29] — Come and hear: A woman[^fn_20b_25] is believed when she says, 'I saw a kind of blood like this one[^fn_20b_26] but I have lost it.'[^fn_20b_30] But is not that case[^fn_20b_31] different, since the blood is not available?[^fn_20b_32] — Come and hear the case of Yaltha: She once brought some blood to Rabbah b. Bar Hana who informed her that it was unclean. She then took it[^fn_20b_33] to R. Isaac the son of Rab Judah who told her that it was clean. But how could he act in this manner, seeing that it was taught: If a Sage declared \[a person or an article\] unclean no other Sage[^fn_20b_34] may declare it clean etc. And we explained that at first he[^fn_20b_22] informed her indeed that it was unclean, but when she told him that on every other occasion he[^fn_20b_24] declared such blood as clean but that on that day he had a pain in his eye, he changed his view and gave her his ruling that it was clean.[^fn_20b_35] Now this proves quite clearly, does it not, that a woman is believed? — R. Isaac b. Judah may have relied on his own traditions and experience.[^fn_20b_36]

Rabbi once examined some blood at night and declared it unclean but when he examined it in the day time he declared it clean. Then he waited a while and again declared it unclean. 'Woe to me', he said, 'I may have made a mistake'.[^fn_20b_37] 'I may have made a mistake'! Has he not in fact made a mistake, seeing that it was taught: A Sage must not say,[^fn_20b_38] 'If it had been moist it would undoubtedly have been unclean'; he must rather say, 'The judge must be guided only by what his eyes see'? — At first[^fn_20b_39] he presumed it to be definitely unclean, but when he observed in the morning that its colour had changed[^fn_20b_40] he said[^fn_20b_41] that it was undoubtedly clean but that at night it could not be seen properly. When, however, he observed that the colour had changed again[^fn_20b_42] he said, 'It must be unclean blood but the colour is steadily fading away.

Rabbi examined blood in the light of a lamp. R. Ishmael son of R. Joseph[^fn_20b_43] examined it even on a cloudy day between the pillars.[^fn_20b_44] R. Ammi b. Samuel ruled: All kinds of blood must be examined only between the sunlight and the shade. R. Nahman citing Rabbah b. Abbuha ruled: The examination may be performed in the sunlight under the shadow of one's hand.[^fn_20b_45]

'ONE LIKE DILUTED WINE'? TWO PARTS etc. A Tanna taught: [pg 21a]

Sharon wine[^fn_21a_1] \[diluted\] is regarded[^fn_21a_2] as the Carmel wine in its natural undiluted state when it is new.[^fn_21a_3] R. Isaac b. Abudemi ruled: All these[^fn_21a_4] must be examined only in a plain Tiberian cup.[^fn_21a_5] What is the reason? — Abaye replied: Generally[^fn_21a_6] a cup that contains a *log* is made of a *maneh*[^fn_21a_7] and one that contains two *log* is made of two hundred *zuz*, but the plain Tiberian cup, even if it contains two *log*, is made of one *maneh*, and since it is so thin \[the colour of the wine can\] be recognized better \[than in any other kind of cup\].

## CHAPTER III

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN ABORTED A SHAPELESS OBJECT,[^fn_21a_8] IF THERE WAS BLOOD WITH IT, SHE IS UNCLEAN,[^fn_21a_9] OTHERWISE SHE IS CLEAN[^fn_21a_10] R. JUDAH RULED: IN EITHER CASE SHE IS UNCLEAN.[^fn_21a_11] {¶=3.1}

IF A WOMAN ABORTED AN OBJECT THAT WAS LIKE A RIND, LIKE A HAIR, LIKE EARTH, LIKE RED FLIES, LET HER PUT IT IN WATER AND IF IT DISSOLVES[^fn_21a_12] SHE IS UNCLEAN,[^fn_21a_9] BUT IF IT DOES NOT SHE IS CLEAN.[^fn_21a_13]

IF AN ABORTION WAS IN THE SHAPE OF FISHES, LOCUSTS, OR ANY FORBIDDEN ANIMALS OR CREEPING THINGS, IF THERE WAS BLOOD WITH THEM SHE IS UNCLEAN,[^fn_21a_9] OTHERWISE SHE IS CLEAN.[^fn_21a_13]

IF AN ABORTION HAD THE SHAPE OF A BEAST, A WILD ANIMAL OR A BIRD, WHETHER CLEAN OR UNCLEAN,[^fn_21a_14] IF IT WAS A MALE SHE MUST CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AND SUBSEQUENT CLEANNESS FOR THE PERIODS PRESCRIBED\] FOR A MALE,[^fn_21a_15] AND IF IT WAS A FEMALE SHE MUST CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AND SUBSEQUENT CLEANNESS FOR THE PERIODS PRESCRIBED\] FOR A FEMALE,[^fn_21a_16] BUT IF THE SEX IS UNKNOWN SHE MUST CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AND SUBSEQUENT CLEANNESS FOR THE PERIODS PRESCRIBED\] FOR BOTH MALE AND FEMALE;[^fn_21a_17] SO R. MEIR. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: ANYTHING THAT HAS NOT THE SHAPE OF A HUMAN BEING CANNOT BE REGARDED AS A HUMAN CHILD.

***GEMARA***. Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: R. Judah declared the woman[^fn_21a_18] unclean only where the object had the colour of one of the four kinds of blood,[^fn_21a_19] but if it had that of any of the other kinds of blood[^fn_21a_20] she is clean.[^fn_21a_21] R. Johanan, however, stated: \[If the object had the colour\] of one of the four kinds of blood[^fn_21a_22] all[^fn_21a_23] agree that the woman is unclean and if it had the colour of any of the other kinds of blood all[^fn_21a_24] agree that she is clean; they[^fn_21a_25] differ only in the case where she aborted something and she does not know what she aborted.[^fn_21a_26] \[In such a case.\] R. Judah holds, one must be guided by the nature of most of shapeless objects, and most shapeless objects have the colour of one of the four kinds of blood, while the Rabbis hold that we do not say, 'most shapeless objects have the colour of one of the four kinds of blood'. But is this correct?[^fn_21a_27] Surely when R. Hoshaia arrived from Nehardea he came \[to the schoolhouse\] and brought with him a Baraitha: If a woman aborted a shapeless object that was red, black, green or white,[^fn_21a_28] if there was blood with it, she is unclean, otherwise she is clean. R. Judah ruled: In either case she is unclean. Now does not this present a difficulty against Samuel in one respect and against R. Johanan in two respects? 'Against Samuel in one respect, since Samuel stated, 'R. Judah declared the woman unclean only where the shapeless object had the colour of one of the four kinds of blood' whereas here 'green and white'[^fn_21a_29] were mentioned and R. Judah nevertheless disagrees.[^fn_21a_30] And were you to reply that R. Judah differs only in respect of red and black but not in that of green or white \[the question would arise:\] For whose benefit then was green and white mentioned? If it be suggested: For that of the Rabbis,[^fn_21a_31] \[it could be retorted:\] Since the Rabbis declared the woman clean even in the case of red and black blood,[^fn_21a_32] was it any longer necessary to state that the same law applies also to green and white?[^fn_21a_29] Must it not then be conceded that these[^fn_21a_33] were mentioned for the benefit of R. Judah[^fn_21a_34] who, it thus follows, does differ.[^fn_21a_35] Furthermore, according to R. Johanan[^fn_21a_36] who also stated, '\[If it had the colour\] of one of the four kinds of blood all agree that she is unclean', \[the additional difficulty arises:\] Were not red and black also mentioned and the Rabbis nevertheless differ.[^fn_21a_37] And should you reply that the Rabbis differ only in regard to green and white but not in that of red and black \[the difficulty would arise:\] For whose benefit, then, were red and black mentioned? If it be suggested: For that of R. Judah \[it could be retorted:\] Since green and white are regarded as unclean, was it at all necessary to mention red and black? Must it not then be conceded that these were mentioned for the benefit of the Rabbis who, it follows, do differ?[^fn_21a_37] — Rather, explained R. Nahman b. Isaac: The point at issue between them[^fn_21a_38] is the question whether it is possible for the uterus[^fn_21a_39] to open[^fn_21a_40] without bleeding.[^fn_21a_41] They[^fn_21a_38] thus differ on the same principle as that on which the following Tannas differ. For it was taught: If a woman was in hard labour for two days[^fn_21a_42] and on the third she aborted and[^fn_21a_43] does not know what she had aborted[^fn_21a_44] [pg 21b]

her case is one of doubtful childbirth and doubtful *zibah*, and[^fn_21b_1] she must, therefore, bring a sacrifice[^fn_21b_2] which may not be eaten.[^fn_21b_3] R. Joshua ruled: She must bring a sacrifice and it may be eaten, since it is impossible for the uterus to open without some bleeding.[^fn_21b_4]

Another version reads as follows. Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: R. Judah declared the woman unclean only where the object had the colour of one of the four kinds of blood, but if it had that of any of the other kinds of blood she is clean. But is this correct? Surely when R. Hoshaia arrived from Nehardea he came \[to the schoolhouse\] and brought with him a Baraitha: If a woman aborted a shapeless object that was red, black, green or white, if there was blood with it, she is unclean, otherwise she is clean; but R. Judah ruled: In either case she is unclean. Now here red, black, green and white were mentioned and R. Judah nevertheless disagrees.[^fn_21b_5] And should you reply that R. Judah differs only in respect of red and black but not in that of green and white \[the question would arise\]: For[^fn_21b_6] whose benefit then was green and white mentioned? If it be suggested: For that of the Rabbis \[it could be retorted\]: Since the Rabbis declared the woman clean even in the case of red and black blood, was it any longer necessary to state that the same law applies also to green and white? Must it not then be conceded that these were mentioned for the benefit of R. Judah who,[^fn_21b_7] it thus follows, does differ?[^fn_21b_8] — Rather, said R. Johanan,[^fn_21b_9] the point at issue between them is the question whether it is possible for the uterus to open without bleeding.[^fn_21b_5] They thus differ on the same principle as that on which the following Tannas differ. For it was taught: If a woman was in hard labour for two days and on the third she aborted and she does not know what she had aborted, her case is one of doubtful childbirth and doubtful *zibah*, and she must, therefore, bring a sacrifice which may not be eaten. R. Joshua ruled: She must bring a sacrifice, and it may be eaten, since it is impossible for the uterus to open without some bleeding.[^fn_21b_5]

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman aborted a shapeless object. Symmachus ruled in the name of R. Meir, and R. Simeon b. Menasia likewise gave the same ruling: It must be split, and if there was blood in it the woman is unclean and if there is none in it she is clean. This is in agreement with the Rabbis but also more restrictive than the ruling of the Rabbis. It is 'in agreement with the Rabbis' who ruled that it was possible for the uterus to open without bleeding; but it is 'also more restrictive than the ruling of the Rabbis', since they hold that only where the blood was with it[^fn_21b_10] is the woman unclean[^fn_21b_11] but not where it was only within it,[^fn_21b_12] while Symmachus holds that \[the woman is unclean\] even if the blood was only within it.[^fn_21b_12] Another \[Baraitha\] taught: If a woman aborted a shapeless object. R. Aha ruled: It must be split, and if its interior shows red,[^fn_21b_13] the woman is unclean, otherwise she is clean. This is in agreement with Symmachus,[^fn_21b_14] but also more restrictive than the ruling of Symmachus.[^fn_21b_15] Again another \[Baraitha\] taught: If a woman aborted a shapeless object, R. Benjamin ruled: It must be split, and if there was a bone in it, its mother is unclean by reason of childbirth.[^fn_21b_16] R. Hisda explained: This applies only to a white object.[^fn_21b_17] So also when a pair \[of scholars\][^fn_21b_18] from Adiabene arrived they came \[into the schoolhouse\] and brought with them the following Baraitha: If a woman aborted a white shapeless object it must be split and if there was a bone in it the mother is unclean by reason of childbirth.[^fn_21b_16]

R. Johanan citing R. Simeon b. Yohai ruled: If a woman aborted a shapeless object it must be split, and if it contained a quantity of accumulated blood she is unclean, otherwise[^fn_21b_19] she is clean. This is in agreement with Symmachus[^fn_21b_20] but is also the most lenient of all the previous rulings.[^fn_21b_21]

R. Jeremiah enquired of R. Zera: What is the ruling where a woman observed a discharge of blood in a tube?[^fn_21b_22] Since the All Merciful has said, In her flesh[^fn_21b_23] He implied: But not in a tube,[^fn_21b_24] or is it possible that the text, 'In her flesh', was required for the deduction that it[^fn_21b_25] causes uncleanness within[^fn_21b_26] as well as without?[^fn_21b_27] — The other replied: The All Merciful said, In her flesh[^fn_21b_23] implying: But not in a tube; for if the expression 'In her flesh' had been required for the deduction that it[^fn_21b_25] causes uncleanness within as well as without, Scripture should have said, Her flesh,[^fn_21b_28] why then did it say, 'In her flesh'? Both rulings may, therefore, be deduced. But did not R. Johanan rule in the name of R. Simeon b. Yohai: If a woman aborted a shapeless object it must be split, and if there was in it a quantity of accumulated blood she is unclean, otherwise she is clean?[^fn_21b_29] — What a comparison![^fn_21b_30] In that case it is usual for a woman to observe blood in a shapeless abortion,[^fn_21b_31] but in this case it is not usual for a woman to observe blood in a tube.[^fn_21b_32]

May it be suggested that the question of blood in a tube is a point at issue between Tannas? For it was taught: If a woman aborted a shapeless object, even though it is full of blood, it is only where there was a discharge of blood with it[^fn_21b_33] that the woman is unclean; otherwise she is clean. R. Eliezer ruled: 'In her flesh'[^fn_21b_23] implies: But not \[where the blood was\] within a sac or within any shapeless abortion. (Is not R. Eliezer's ruling identical with that of the first Tanna?[^fn_21b_34] — Read: For R. Eliezer ruled, 'In her flesh' implies: But not \[where the blood was\] within a sac or within any shapeless abortion). But the Sages ruled: This is not menstrual blood but the blood of a shapeless object.[^fn_21b_35] Now does not the first Tanna also declare her clean?[^fn_21b_36] But the fact is that the difference between them is the case where the abortion was chapped. The first Tanna is of the opinion that 'In her flesh' implies: But not \[where the blood was\] in a sac or in a shapeless object,[^fn_21b_37] and the same applies also to a tube.[^fn_21b_37] This, however, holds good only where it[^fn_21b_38] was smooth,[^fn_21b_39] but if it was chapped[^fn_21b_40] the woman is unclean. What is his reason? It may be described as 'In her flesh'.[^fn_21b_41] Thereupon the Rabbis came to declare: Although it[^fn_21b_38] was chapped \[the woman is clean since\] the discharge is not menstrual but that of the shapeless object.[^fn_21b_42] Menstrual blood, however, is undoubtedly a cause of uncleanness[^fn_21b_43] even if it was in a tube![^fn_21b_44] — Abaye replied: As regards a tube all[^fn_21b_45] agree that the woman is clean,[^fn_21b_46] [pg 22a]

and they only differ in the case of a shapeless object.[^fn_22a_1] One Master[^fn_22a_2] holds that it is usual for a woman to observe blood in a shapeless object[^fn_22a_3] and the Masters[^fn_22a_4] hold that it is not usual for a woman to observe blood in such an object.[^fn_22a_5] Raba replied that all[^fn_22a_6] agreed that it is not usual for a woman to observe blood in a shapeless object, but it is on the question whether the woman is clean[^fn_22a_7] and the interior of the uterus is unclean[^fn_22a_8] that they differ, R. Eliezer being of the opinion that though the woman is clean[^fn_22a_9] the blood is unclean since it comes through the uterus,[^fn_22a_10] while the Rabbis hold the opinion that the woman is clean and the interior of the uterus is also clean.[^fn_22a_11]

Rabba required of R. Huna: What is the ruling where one observed semen on a splinter?[^fn_22a_12] Did the Divine Law say, From him[^fn_22a_13] to indicate that the man is unclean only when it[^fn_22a_14] issued naturally from his body but not when it was brought out by means of a splinter, or is it possible that the expression 'from him' implies \[that the man is unclean\] only when his uncleanness[^fn_22a_12] has come out of his body, in which case \[he is unclean\] even though that was effected by means of a splinter? — The other replied: You can infer the ruling \[from the fact\] that the man himself[^fn_22a_15] becomes unclean only when the quantity of semen emitted suffices to close up the orifice of the membrum.[^fn_22a_16] This then[^fn_22a_17] implies that the man[^fn_22a_18] is regarded as having touched the semen.[^fn_22a_19] But, then, this[^fn_22a_20] should not cause \[the counting of the clean days\] after a *zibah* to be void.[^fn_22a_21] Why then was it taught: This is the law of him that hath an issue,[^fn_22a_22] and of him from whom the flow of seed[^fn_22a_23] goeth out,[^fn_22a_24] as *zibah*[^fn_22a_25] causes \[the counting of the clean days\] to be void[^fn_22a_26] so does semen? — The other replied: As regards counting again, this is the reason why the previous counting is void: because it is impossible for semen to be emitted[^fn_22a_27] without an admixture of some particles of *zibah*.[^fn_22a_28] Now then,[^fn_22a_29] this should cause the counting of all the seven days[^fn_22a_30] to be void,[^fn_22a_31] why then was it taught: 'This is the law of him that hath an issue etc.', as *zibah* causes the clean days to be counted again so does semen? But in case you should assume that as *zibah* causes the counting of all the seven days[^fn_22a_30] to be void so does semen also, it was expressly stated, So that he is unclean thereby;[^fn_22a_24] you can apply to it[^fn_22a_32] only that which had been said about it,[^fn_22a_33] hence it causes the counting of one day only to be void?[^fn_22a_34] — The other[^fn_22a_35] replied: It is a decree of Scripture that an absolute *zibah* in which no semen is mixed causes the counting of all seven days to be void, but particles of *zibah* in which semen is mixed cause only the counting of one day[^fn_22a_36] to be void.

R. Jose son of R. Hanina enquired of R. Eleazar: What is the ruling in the case of dry blood?[^fn_22a_37] Did the Divine Law say, Have an issue[^fn_22a_38] of her blood[^fn_22a_39] to indicate that it must be actually flowing,[^fn_22a_40] hence it refers only to fluid blood but not to dry, or is it possible that the expression, 'have all issue of her blood'[^fn_22a_41] was used merely because blood usually flows, but the same law in fact applies to dry blood also? — The other replied: You have learnt it: The blood of a menstruant and the flesh of a corpse convey uncleanness when fresh or when dry.[^fn_22a_42] Said he \[R. Jose\] to him, 'Where the blood was first fresh and then it dried up, I have no question to ask; my question arises only where it was originally dry'.[^fn_22a_43] 'This also', the other replied, 'you have learnt: IF A WOMAN ABORTED AN OBJECT THAT WAS LIKE A RIND, LIKE A HAIR, LIKE EARTH, LIKE RED FLIES, LET HER PUT IT IN WATER [pg 22b]

AND IF IT DISSOLVES SHE IS UNCLEAN.[^fn_22b_1] But if so,[^fn_22b_2] \[should not uncleanness be caused\] even if the object was not dissolved? — Rabbah replied: If it is not dissolved it is an independent creature.[^fn_22b_3] But is there such a phenomenon?[^fn_22b_4] Yes; and so it was taught: R. Eleazar son of R. Zadok stated, A report of the following two incidents was brought up by my father from Tib'in[^fn_22b_5] to Jamnia. It once happened that a woman was aborting objects like pieces of red rind and the people came and asked my father, and my father asked the Sages, and the Sages asked the physicians who explained to them that that woman had an internal sore \[the crust\] of which she cast out in the shape of the pieces of red rind. \[It was ruled that\] she should put them in water and if they dissolved she should be declared unclean. And yet another incident occurred when a woman was aborting objects like red hairs, and she came and asked my father, and my father asked the Sages, and the Sages asked the physicians who explained to them that the woman had a wart[^fn_22b_6] in her internal organs and that that was the cause of her aborting objects like red hairs.[^fn_22b_7]

LET[^fn_22b_8] HER PUT IT IN WATER AND IF IT DISSOLVES SHE IS UNCLEAN. Resh Lakish ruled: And \[this must be done\] with lukewarm water.[^fn_22b_9] So it was also taught: Let her put it in water, viz., in lukewarm water. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: She \[must attempt to\] crush it with spittle on her nail. What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_22b_10] — Rabina replied: The practical difference between them is \[an abortion that can be\] crushed by the exercise of pressure.[^fn_22b_11]

Elsewhere we have learnt: How long must they[^fn_22b_12] be soaked in the lukewarm water?[^fn_22b_13] Twenty-four hours.[^fn_22b_14] Now in this case,[^fn_22b_15] what length of time is required? Do we require a period of twenty-four hours or not?[^fn_22b_16] Is it only in regard to a creeping thing and carrion, which are tough, that a twenty-four hours' soaking is required but not in that of blood, which is soft, or is it possible that there is no difference? — This is undecided.[^fn_22b_17]

IF AN ABORTION WAS IN THE SHAPE OF FISHES. But why does not R. Judah[^fn_22b_18] disagree[^fn_22b_19] in this case also?[^fn_22b_20] — Resh Lakish replied: This[^fn_22b_21] was indeed learnt as a controversial ruling,[^fn_22b_22] and it[^fn_22b_21] represents only the opinion of the Rabbis. R. Johanan, however, replied: It[^fn_22b_23] may even be said to agree with R. Judah,[^fn_22b_24] for R. Judah gave his ruling[^fn_22b_25] only there, in the case of a SHAPELESS OBJECT, since it is the nature of blood to congeal and to assume the form of a shapeless object,[^fn_22b_26] but \[not here,[^fn_22b_27] since\] it[^fn_22b_28] can never assume the form of a creature.[^fn_22b_29] According, however, to that version in which R. Johanan stated that 'the point at issue between them is the question whether it is possible for the uterus to open without bleedings',[^fn_22b_30] should not R. Judah[^fn_22b_31] have disagreed in this case also? — He who learnt that version[^fn_22b_32] reads here: Both R. Johanan and Resh Lakish replied: This[^fn_22b_33] was learnt as a controversial ruling,[^fn_22b_34] and it[^fn_22b_33] represents only the view of the Rabbis.

IF AN ABORTION HAD THE SHAPE OF A BEAST etc. Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: What is the reason of R. Meir? Since in their case[^fn_22b_35] an expression of forming[^fn_22b_36] is used as in that of man.[^fn_22b_37] Now then, if an abortion was in the likeness of a sea-monster[^fn_22b_38] would its mother be unclean by reason of child-birth, since an expression of forming was used in its case as in that of man, it having been said, And God created[^fn_22b_39] the great sea-monsters?[^fn_22b_40] — I can answer: An expression of forming[^fn_22b_41] may be deduced from another expression of forming[^fn_22b_42] but one of creating[^fn_22b_43] may not be deduced from one of forming.[^fn_22b_44] But where lies the practical difference between the two expressions? Surely the School of R. Ishmael taught: And the priest shall return,[^fn_22b_45] and the priest shall come,[^fn_22b_46] 'returning' and 'coming' are the same thing![^fn_22b_47] Furthermore, why should not one expression of 'creating'[^fn_22b_43] be deduced from another expression of 'creating', it being written, And God created man in His own image?[^fn_22b_48] — I can answer: 'And … created'[^fn_22b_48] is required for its own context while 'and … formed is available for deduction, hence it is that the expression of 'forming'[^fn_22b_49] may be deducted from the similar one of 'forming'.[^fn_22b_44] On the contrary \[might it not be submitted that\] 'And … formed'[^fn_22b_44] was required for its own context while 'and … created'[^fn_22b_48] is available for deduction, hence the expression of 'creating'[^fn_22b_43] may be deduced from 'creating'?[^fn_22b_48] — The fact is that the expression 'And … formed' is available for deduction on the two sides: It is available in the case of man[^fn_22b_50] and it is also available in that of beast;[^fn_22b_51] but the expression of 'And … created' is available for deduction only in the case of man[^fn_22b_52] but it is not available for the purpose in that of sea-monsters.[^fn_22b_53] But why is it[^fn_22b_54] regarded available for deduction in the case of beast? If it be suggested because it is written, And God made the beast of the earth[^fn_22b_55] and it is also written, And out of the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field,[^fn_22b_56] is not a similar expression \[it may be retorted\] also available for deduction in the case of a sea-monster, since it is written, And God made … and every thing that creepeth upon the ground,[^fn_22b_57] and it is also written, And God created the great seamonsters?[^fn_22b_58] — 'Every thing that creepeth' that was written in the previously mentioned verse refers to those on the dry land. What, however, is the practical difference between an expression that is available for deduction on one side and one that is available for deduction on two sides?[^fn_22b_59] — The practical difference is the statement Rab Judah made in the name of Samuel who had it from R. Ishmael:[^fn_22b_60] From any *gezerah shawah*[^fn_22b_61] neither of whose terms is available for deduction[^fn_22b_62] no deduction may be made;[^fn_22b_63] if one of the terms is available for the purpose, then according to R. Ishmael, a deduction may be made and no refutation may be offered, while according to the Rabbis deduction may be made[^fn_22b_64] but a refutation[^fn_22b_65] may be offered; and if both terms are available for deduction, all[^fn_22b_66] agree that deduction may be made and no refutation may be offered. As to R. Ishmael, however, what is the practical difference between a *gezerah shawah* one of whose terms only is available for deduction and one both of whose terms are available for the purpose? — The practical difference is that where there is one of which one term only is available for deduction and another both of which both terms are available for deduction we must leave the former [pg 23a]

and make the deduction from the latter. And it is for this reason[^fn_23a_1] that in the case of beast the All Merciful made both terms available for deduction: In order that no deduction shall be made from one of which one term only is available for deduction.[^fn_23a_2]

R. Aha son of Raba taught this[^fn_23a_3] in the name of R. Eleazar in the direction of leniency. From any *gezerah shawah* none of whose terms is available for deduction, one may make the deduction and one may also offer a refutation; if one of its terms only is available for the purpose, deduction, according to R. Ishmael, may be made and no refutation may be offered, while according to the Rabbis deduction may be made and a refutation may be offered; and if two of its terms are available for deduction, all agree that deduction may be made and no refutation may be offered. But according to the Rabbis[^fn_23a_4] what is the practical difference between one whose one term is available for deduction and one none of whose terms is available for deduction? — The practical difference between them is the case where you find a *gezerah shawah* one of whose terms is available for deduction and another none of whose terms is available for the purpose, and neither the one nor the other can be refuted, in such a case we must leave the one neither of whose terms is available and make deduction from the one of which one term is available. But what refutation is there in this case?[^fn_23a_5] — One might object:[^fn_23a_6] A man is different[^fn_23a_7] since he contracts uncleanness[^fn_23a_8] even when he is alive.[^fn_23a_9]

R. Hiyya b. Abba citing R. Johanan also stated,[^fn_23a_10] This is the reason of R. Meir: Since the expression of 'forming' has been used in its case as in that of man. Said R. Ammi to him: Now then, If an abortion was in the shape of a mountain would the woman who aborted it[^fn_23a_11] be unclean by reason of the birth because it is said, For, lo, He that formeth[^fn_23a_12] the mountains and createth the wind?[^fn_23a_13] — The other replied: Does she ever abort a mountain? She can only abort something in the shape of a stone, and that can only be described as a lump.[^fn_23a_14] But then, if the abortion was some inflated object would the woman who aborted it[^fn_23a_11] be unclean by reason of the birth because the expression of 'creating' has been used about it as about man, since it is written, And createth[^fn_23a_15] the wind?[^fn_23a_13] And should you reply: it[^fn_23a_16] is not available for deduction,[^fn_23a_17] \[it could be retorted:\] Since it could have been written, 'Formeth the mountains and the wind', and yet it was written 'And createth the wind' it may be inferred, may it not, that it[^fn_23a_16] was intended to be made available for deduction? — The other replied: An analogy for legal purposes may be drawn between words that occur in the Pentateuch[^fn_23a_18] but no analogy may be drawn between words that occur respectively in the Pentateuch and in the post-Pentateuchal books.[^fn_23a_19]

Rabbah[^fn_23a_20] b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan stated, This is the reason of R. Meir: Because \[the pupils[^fn_23a_21] of\] their[^fn_23a_22] eyes are similar to those of human beings. Now then, if an abortion was in the likeness of a serpent would the woman who aborted it[^fn_23a_11] be unclean on account of the birth since its eye-ball is round like that of a human eye? And should you suggest that the law is so indeed \[it could be retorted\]: Why then was not the serpent mentioned?[^fn_23a_23] — If the serpent had been mentioned[^fn_23a_23] it might have been presumed that only in the case of the serpent do the Rabbis disagree with R. Meir, since the expression of 'forming' was not written about it but that in the case of a beast or a wild animal they do not differ from him since the expression of 'forming' had been written about it.[^fn_23a_24] But was it not stated in regard to blemishes,[^fn_23a_25] 'One whose eyeball is like that of a man'?[^fn_23a_26] — This is no difficulty, the one[^fn_23a_27] refers to the black of the eye[^fn_23a_28] while the other refers to the slit.[^fn_23a_29]

R. Jannai stated, This is the reason of R. Meir: Because their[^fn_23a_30] eyes are fixed in the front of their heads[^fn_23a_31] like those of men. But what about[^fn_23a_32] a bird whose eyes are not fixed in the front of its head and R. Meir nevertheless ruled that it is a cause of uncleanness? — Abaye replied: This[^fn_23a_33] applies only to the kadia[^fn_23a_34] and the kipufa.[^fn_23a_35] It[^fn_23a_33] does not then apply to other birds! An objection was raised: R. Hanina b. Gamaliel[^fn_23a_36] stated, I approve of the view of R. Meir in regard to beasts and wild animals and that of the Sages in regard to birds. Now what did he mean by 'birds'? If it be suggested: kadia[^fn_23a_34] and kipufa[^fn_23a_35] \[the difficulty would arise\]: Wherein do beasts and wild animals differ \[from other creatures\]? \[Obviously in that\] that their eyes are fixed in front of their heads like those of men. Now are not those of the kadia[^fn_23a_34] and the kipufa[^fn_23a_35] fixed in the same position?[^fn_23a_37] Consequently[^fn_23a_38] he must have meant other birds. Thus it may be implied, may it not, that R. Meir differs from the Rabbis in regard to the other birds?[^fn_23a_39] — Some part is missing[^fn_23a_40] and this is the correct reading: R. Hanina b. Gamaliel[^fn_23a_36] stated, I approve of the view of R. Meir in regard to beasts and wild animals, this applying also to the kadia and the kipufa; and that of the Sages in regard to other birds; for even R. Meir disagreed with them only in regard to the kadia and the kipufa, but in the case of other birds he agrees with them. And so it was also taught: R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok stated: An abortion that had the shape of a beast or a wild animal is, according to the view of R. Meir, regarded as a valid birth, but according to the view of the Sages it is no valid birth; and in the case of birds an examination should take place. Now according to whose view should an examination take place? Obviously[^fn_23a_41] according to that of R. Meir who ruled that the law[^fn_23a_42] applied[^fn_23a_43] to the kadia and the kipufa and not to the other birds! R. Aha son of R. Ika retorted: No; the examination should take place according to the Rabbis who ruled that kadia and kipufa are regarded as valid births[^fn_23a_43] but not other birds. But wherein does the kadia or the kipufa in this respect differ from beasts and wild animals?[^fn_23a_44] — In that they have jaws like those of men.[^fn_23a_45]

R. Jeremiah enquired of R. Zera: According to R. Meir who ruled: 'A beast that was in a woman's body is a valid birth', what is the law where its father[^fn_23a_46] received for it a token of betrothal?[^fn_23a_47] — In what respect could this[^fn_23a_48] ever matter? — In respect of causing its sister to be forbidden.[^fn_23a_49] This then presumes[^fn_23a_50] that it is viable! But did not Rab Judah citing Rab state: R. Meir gave his ruling[^fn_23a_51] only because in the case of its own species[^fn_23a_52] it is viable?[^fn_23a_53] Said R. Aha b. Jacob: 'To such an extent did R. Jeremiah try[^fn_23a_54] to make R. Zera laugh; but the latter did not laugh'.[^fn_23a_55]

\[Reverting to\] the \[previous\] text, 'Rab Judah citing Rab stated: R. Meir gave his ruling only because in the case of its own species it is viable.' Said R. Jeremiah of Difti: [pg 23b]

We also learnt the same thing:[^fn_23b_1] An abortion in the shape of a beast, wild animal or bird \[is regarded as a valid birth\];[^fn_23b_2] so R. Meir. And the Sages ruled: \[It is no valid birth\][^fn_23b_3] unless it has the features of a human being.
