But if the abortion was a sandal,[^fn_23b_4] a placenta or a foetus with some articulated shape, or if a child issued cut up in pieces, the son born after it is regarded as the firstborn in respect of inheritance but he is no firstborn as far as the priest is concerned.[^fn_23b_5] Now if one could imagine that such an abortion is viable, would the son born after it be regarded as the firstborn in regard to inheritance?[^fn_23b_6] Said Raba: It may well be maintained that it is viable but the case there[^fn_23b_7] is different \[from what might have been expected\][^fn_23b_8] since Scripture said, The first of his mourning[^fn_23b_9] which refers to the one for whom[^fn_23b_10] his[^fn_23b_11] heart aches, and thus excludes an abortion for which[^fn_23b_12] his heart does not ache.[^fn_23b_13]

R. Adda b. Ahaba enquired of Abaye: According to R. Meir who ruled that a beast that was in the bowels of a woman is a valid birth, what is the ruling where a human child was in the bowels of a beast?[^fn_23b_14] — In what respect does this matter? — In that of permitting it to be eaten.[^fn_23b_15] But why can you not solve this question from the following ruling of R. Johanan; for R. Johanan ruled: If one slaughtered a beast and found in it an object of the shape of a dove it[^fn_23b_16] is forbidden to be eaten?[^fn_23b_17] — What a comparison! In that case[^fn_23b_16] there are neither cloven feet nor hoofs, but in this case, granted that there are no cloven feet, there is at least some thing like a hoof.[^fn_23b_18]

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, RULED: ANYTHING THAT HAS NOT etc. R. Jeremiah b. Abba citing Rab stated: All[^fn_23b_19] agree that if its body was that of a he-goat and its face that of a human being it is regarded as a human child;[^fn_23b_20] if its body was that of a human being and its face that of a he-goat it is no valid birth.[^fn_23b_20] They[^fn_23b_19] differ only where it had the face of a human being but was so created that one of its eyes was like that of a beast, since R. Meir holds that it[^fn_23b_21] need only have some of the features of a human face[^fn_23b_22] while the Sages hold that it[^fn_23b_21] must have all the features of a human face. They[^fn_23b_23] said to R. Jeremiah b. Abba, Was not the reverse taught: R. Meir said, 'It must have all the features of a human face'[^fn_23b_24] while the Sages said, 'It need only have some of the features of a human face'?[^fn_23b_24] — He answered them: If this was taught so you may well rely on it.[^fn_23b_25]

R. Jeremiah b. Abba citing R. Johanan ruled:[^fn_23b_26] The forehead, the eyebrows, the eyes, the cheeks and the chin must all be present at the same time.[^fn_23b_27] Raba, however, citing Hasa ruled:[^fn_23b_26] The forehead, the eyebrow, the eye, the cheek and the chin must all be present at the same time.[^fn_23b_27] These, however,[^fn_23b_28] do not differ in principle from one another, since the former ruled according to him who said that[^fn_23b_27] 'it must have all the features of a human face'. while the latter ruled according to him who stated, 'it need only have some of the features of a human face'.

An objection was raised: By the 'shape of the face' of which the Sages spoke[^fn_23b_29] was meant the presence of even only one of the features of the face,[^fn_23b_30] except the ear.[^fn_23b_31] This shows, does it not, that a single feature suffices?[^fn_23b_32] — Abaye replied: That[^fn_23b_33] was taught only to indicate what constitutes a hindrance,[^fn_23b_34] and it[^fn_23b_33] is in agreement with him who stated \[that the reading\][^fn_23b_35] was 'it must have all the features of a human face'. And if you prefer I might say: It[^fn_23b_33] is in fact in agreement with him who stated that the reading[^fn_23b_35] was it need only have one of the features of a human face' but[^fn_23b_36] the meaning[^fn_23b_37] of 'one'[^fn_23b_38] is one of each.[^fn_23b_39]

Raba ruled: If a foetus was created with one eye and one thigh, the woman who gives birth to it[^fn_23b_40] is unclean[^fn_23b_41] if these were on the side,[^fn_23b_42] but if they were in the middle[^fn_23b_43] she is clean.[^fn_23b_44] Raba further ruled: If a child's gullet is perforated[^fn_23b_45] his mother is unclean,[^fn_23b_46] but if his gullet is closed up[^fn_23b_47] she is clean.[^fn_23b_48]

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman aborted a stumped body she is not unclean by reason of such a birth. And what is meant by a stumped body? — Rabbi replied: One short of a part which if taken from a live person would cause him to die. And what is the extent of the part that if taken from a live person would cause him to die? — R. Zakkai replied: [pg 24a]

To the top of the knee joint.[^fn_24a_1] R. Jannai replied: To his lower orifices.[^fn_24a_2] R. Johanan citing R. Jose b. Joshua replied: To the position of his navel. The point at issue between R. Zakkai and R. Jannai is whether a trefah[^fn_24a_3] animal[^fn_24a_4] can survive.[^fn_24a_5] The latter holds that a trefah animal can survive[^fn_24a_6] while the former holds that it cannot survive.[^fn_24a_7] The point at issue between R. Jannai and R. Johanan[^fn_24a_8] is a ruling of R. Eleazar; for R. Eleazar ruled: If the haunch and its hollow were removed the animal is *nebelah*.[^fn_24a_9] R. Papa stated: The dispute[^fn_24a_10] refers only to cases where the lower part of the body is affected[^fn_24a_11] but if the upper part is affected,[^fn_24a_12] even if the missing part is ever so small the woman is clean.[^fn_24a_13] So also said R. Giddal in the name of R. Johanan: If a woman aborted a foetus whose skull is a shapeless lump she[^fn_24a_14] is clean.[^fn_24a_13] R. Giddal citing R. Johanan further stated: If a woman aborted a foetus shaped like the ramification of a palmtree[^fn_24a_15] she is clean.[^fn_24a_13]

It was stated: If a woman aborted a foetus whose face was mashed,[^fn_24a_16] R. Johanan ruled: She[^fn_24a_14] is unclean; and Resh Lakish ruled: She is clean. R. Johanan raised an objection against Resh Lakish: If a woman aborted a shaped[^fn_24a_17] hand or a shaped foot she[^fn_24a_14] is subject to the uncleanness of birth[^fn_24a_18] and there is no need to consider the possibility[^fn_24a_19] that it might have come from a shapeless body.[^fn_24a_20] Now if it were so,[^fn_24a_21] should it not have been stated, 'The possibility that it might have come from a shapeless body or from a foetus whose face was mashed'?[^fn_24a_22]

R. Papi stated:[^fn_24a_23] Where its[^fn_24a_24] face was mashed no one[^fn_24a_25] disputes the ruling that the woman is unclean. They only differ where its face was entirely covered over,[^fn_24a_26] and the statement[^fn_24a_27] was made in the reverse order: R. Johanan ruled: His mother is clean; and Resh Lakish ruled: His mother is unclean. Should not then[^fn_24a_28] Resh Lakish raise an objection against R. Johanan from that \[Baraitha\]?[^fn_24a_29] — Because the latter could have answered him: 'A stumped body' and 'a foetus whose face was entirely covered over are identical terms.[^fn_24a_30]

The sons of R. Hiyya once toured the countryside. When they appeared before their father he asked them, 'Has any case been submitted for your consideration?' 'The case of a foetus whose face was entirely covered over', they told him 'has been submitted to us, and we decided that the woman was unclean'. 'Go back', he said to them, 'and declare as clean that which you have declared unclean. For what did you think?[^fn_24a_31] That you are restricting the law;[^fn_24a_32] but this is a restriction that results in a relaxation, for thereby[^fn_24a_33] you also allow her[^fn_24a_34] the days of cleanness'.[^fn_24a_35]

It was stated: If one aborted a creature that had two backs and two spinal columns, Rab ruled: In the case of a woman it is no valid birth[^fn_24a_36] and in that of a beast it is forbidden to be eaten;[^fn_24a_37] but Samuel ruled: In the case of a woman it is a valid birth[^fn_24a_38] and in that of a beast it is permitted to be eaten.[^fn_24a_39] On what principle do they[^fn_24a_40] differ? — On that of R. Hanin b. Abba; for R. Hanin b. Abba stated, 'The cloven'[^fn_24a_41] is a creature that has two backs and two spinal columns'.[^fn_24a_42] Rab maintains that such a creature exists nowhere in the world, and that when the All Merciful taught Moses about it[^fn_24a_43] he must have taught him about one that was still in her dam's bowels, while Samuel maintains that such a creature does exist in the world so that when the All Merciful taught Moses about it[^fn_24a_43] he taught him about the species in general,[^fn_24a_44] but one that is still in its dam's bowels is well permitted to be eaten.[^fn_24a_45] R. Shimi b. Hiyya pointed out an objection to Rab: R. Hanina b. Antigonus stated, Any \[firstling of beasts\] that had two backs and two spinal columns is unfit for the Temple service;[^fn_24a_46] from which[^fn_24a_47] it is obvious, is it not, that it is viable?[^fn_24a_48] — 'Is it you, Shimi?' the other[^fn_24a_49] replied, 'this[^fn_24a_50] refers to a case where its spinal column was only crooked'.[^fn_24a_51]

An objection was raised: Among embryos[^fn_24a_52] there are some that are forbidden[^fn_24a_53] viz, a four monthly embryo among small cattle, and an eight monthly one among large cattle, and one that is younger[^fn_24a_54] is equally forbidden. From this is excluded one that had two backs and two spinal columns. Now what is meant by 'is excluded'? Obviously that it[^fn_24a_55] is excluded from the category of embryos[^fn_24a_56] in that it is forbidden to be eaten even while still in its dam's body?[^fn_24a_57] — Rab[^fn_24a_58] explains in accordance with his own view, and Samuel[^fn_24a_59] explains it in accordance with his view. 'Rab explains in accordance with his own view', thus: A four monthly embryo among small cattle and an eighth monthly one among large cattle, and one that is younger is equally forbidden. This applies only where it saw the light[^fn_24a_60] but while it is still in its dam's bowels it is permitted; but from this is excluded one that has two backs and two spinal columns which, even while still in its dam's bowels, is also forbidden. [pg 24b]

Samuel also 'explains it in accordance with his view', thus: A four monthly embryo among small cattle, and an eight monthly one among large cattle, and one that is younger is equally forbidden. This, however, applies only to one whose period of pregnancy[^fn_24b_1] had not ended, but if the period has ended it is permitted; and from this is excluded one who had two backs and two spinal columns which, even though its period of pregnancy had ended, it is forbidden if it saw the light[^fn_24b_2] but permitted when still in its dam's body.[^fn_24b_3]

A Tanna recited before Rab: As it might have been assumed that if an abortion was a creature with a shapeless body or with a shapeless head its mother is unclean by reason of its birth, it was explicitly stated in Scripture, If a woman be delivered, and bear a man-child etc.[^fn_24b_4] And in the eighth day the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised etc.,[^fn_24b_5] thus implying[^fn_24b_6] that only a child that is fit for the covenant of the eight days[^fn_24b_7] \[causes uncleanness to his mother\] but these[^fn_24b_8] are excluded, since they are not fit for the covenant of the eight days. 'And', said Rab to him, 'conclude your statement thus:[^fn_24b_9] And one who had two backs and two spinal columns'.

R. Jeremiah b. Abba intended to give a practical decision[^fn_24b_10] in agreement with the view of Samuel,[^fn_24b_11] but R. Huna said to him: 'What have you in your mind? To impose a restriction?[^fn_24b_12] But this is a restriction that results in a relaxation, since you must in consequence[^fn_24b_13] allow her also a period of clean blood.[^fn_24b_14] Act rather in accordance with the view of Rab, since we have an established rule that in ritual matters the law is in agreement with Rab irrespective of whether this leads to a relaxation or a restriction.

Raba said: It has been stated that a woman may bear[^fn_24b_15] at nine months[^fn_24b_16] and also at seven months.[^fn_24b_16] Can \[then\] large cattle who bear[^fn_24b_17] at nine months also bear[^fn_24b_17] at seven months or not? — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied, Come and hear: 'One that is younger is equally forbidden'.[^fn_24b_18] Does not this also refer to the large cattle?[^fn_24b_19] — No, it may only refer to the small cattle.[^fn_24b_20] What an argument this is! If you grant that the reference[^fn_24b_21] was to the large cattle also, one can well see the necessity for it. For it might have been presumed that since \[a seven monthly\] is viable in the case of a woman it is also viable in that of cattle, we were informed that it is not viable; but if you maintain that reference was made to small cattle only, this would be obvious, for can a three monthly abortion live?[^fn_24b_22] — It[^fn_24b_23] was necessary: As it might have been presumed that anyone \[born within\] less than two months \[before the conclusion of the normal conception\] can survive,[^fn_24b_24] hence we were informed that it[^fn_24b_25] was not viable.

Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: If an abortion had the likeness of Lilith[^fn_24b_26] its mother is unclean by reason of the birth, for it is a child, but it has wings. So it was also taught: R. Jose stated, It once happened at Simoni[^fn_24b_27] that a woman aborted the likeness of Lilith, and when the case came up for a decision before the Sages they ruled that it was a child but that it also had wings. If an abortion had the likeness of a serpent, Hanina the son of R. Joshua's brother ruled: Its mother is unclean by reason of the birth. R. Joseph proceeded to report the ruling to R. Gamaliel when the latter sent word \[to\][^fn_24b_28] R. Joshua, 'Take charge of[^fn_24b_29] your nephew and come with him to me'. As they were going, Hanina's[^fn_24b_30] daughterin-law came out to meet R. Joshua.[^fn_24b_31] 'Master', she said to him, 'what is your ruling where an abortion had the likeness of a serpent?' 'Its mother', he replied, 'is clean'. 'But', she retorted, 'was it not in your name that my mother-in-law told me that its mother was unclean?' 'And', he asked her, 'on what ground?' 'Since \[she told him\] its eye-ball is round like that of a human being'. As a result of her statements R. Joshua recollected his ruling and sent the following message to R. Gamaliel: 'Hanina gave his ruling on my authority'.[^fn_24b_32] Abaye observed: From this incident it may be learnt that when a scholar gives a ruling he should also indicate his reason so that when he is ever reminded of it he would recollect it.

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN ABORTED A SAC FULL OF WATER, FULL OF BLOOD, OR FULL OF MATTER OF VARIOUS COLOURS, SHE NEED NOT TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THE POSSIBILITY OF ITS BEING A VALID BIRTH; BUT IF ITS LIMBS WERE FASHIONED SHE MUST CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AND SUBSEQUENT CLEANNESS FOR THE PERIODS PRESCRIBED\] FOR BOTH MALE AND FEMALE.[^fn_24b_33] IF SHE ABORTED A SANDAL OR A PLACENTA SHE MUST ALSO CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR BOTH MALE AND FEMALE.[^fn_24b_33] {¶=3.2}

***GEMARA***. One can well understand why BLOOD or WATER[^fn_24b_34] \[constitutes no valid birth, since in this respect\] it is of no consequence;[^fn_24b_35] but as regards MATTER OF VARIOUS COLOURS,[^fn_24b_36] why should not the possibility be taken into consideration that it had originally been a child that was now squashed? — Abaye replied: How much of undiluted wine must the mother of this thing have drunk that her embryo should be squashed within her bowels![^fn_24b_37] Raba replied: We have learnt, FULL OF, and if it were the case that the embryo had been squashed something would have been missing.[^fn_24b_38] R. Adda b. Ahaba replied: We have learnt, MATTER OF VARIOUS COLOURS, and if it were the case that an embryo had been squashed it would all have been reduced to the same colour.

It was taught: Abba Saul stated, I was once a grave-digger[^fn_24b_39] when I made a practice of carefully observing the bones of the dead. The bones of one who drinks undiluted wine are burned; those of one who drinks wine excessively diluted are dry;[^fn_24b_40] and those of one who drinks wine properly mixed are full of marrow.[^fn_24b_41] The bones of a person whose drinking exceeds his eating are burned; those of one whose eating exceeds his drinking are dry,[^fn_24b_40] and those of one who eats and drinks in a proper manner are full of marrow.[^fn_24b_41]

It was taught: Abba Saul (or, as some say, R. Johanan stated): I was once a grave-digger.[^fn_24b_39] On one occasion, when pursuing a deer, I entered the thigh-bone of a corpse, and pursued it for three parasangs but did neither reach the deer nor the end of the thigh-bone.[^fn_24b_42] When I returned I was told that it was the thigh-bone of Og, King of Bashan.[^fn_24b_43]

It was taught: Abba Saul stated, I was once a grave-digger[^fn_24b_39] and on one occasion there was opened a cave under me and I stood in the eye-ball of a corpse up to my nose. When I returned I was told that it was the eye of Absalom. And should you suggest that Abba Saul was a dwarf \[it may be mentioned that\] Abba Saul was the tallest man in his generation, and R. Tarfon reached to his shoulder and that R. Tarfon was the tallest man in his generation and R. Meir reached to his shoulder. R. Meir was the tallest man in his generation and Rabbi reached to his shoulder. Rabbi was the tallest man in his generation and R. Hiyya reached to his shoulder, and R. Hiyya was the tallest in his generation and Rab reached to his shoulder. Rab was the tallest man in his generation and Rab Judah reached to his shoulder, and Rab Judah was the tallest man in his generation and his waiter Adda reached to his shoulder. [pg 25a]

Pushtabna[^fn_25a_1] of Pumbeditha reached to[^fn_25a_2] half the height of the waiter Adda, while everybody else reached only to the loins of Pushtabna of Pumbeditha.

A question was raised in the presence of Rabbi: What is the ruling where a woman aborted a sac full of flesh? 'I did not hear of such a law', he answered them. 'Thus', announced R. Ishmael son of R. Jose before him, 'said my father: If it was full of blood the woman is unclean as a menstruant, but if it was full of flesh she is unclean as a woman after childbirth'. The other said to him: Had you told us something new in the name of your father we would have listened to you; but now, since his first ruling[^fn_25a_3] was given in accordance with the view of an individual, viz., in agreement with Symmachus who cited R. Meir,[^fn_25a_4] his second ruling also[^fn_25a_5] might be one given in accordance with the view of R. Joshua;[^fn_25a_6] but the *halachah* is not in agreement with R. Joshua. For it was taught: If an abortion was a sac with no fashioned limbs, R. Joshua ruled: It[^fn_25a_7] is regarded as a valid birth[^fn_25a_8] but the Sages ruled, it is no valid birth.[^fn_25a_9]

R. Simeon b. Lakish citing R. Oshaia stated: The dispute[^fn_25a_10] refers only to a sac that was turbid[^fn_25a_11] but if it was clear[^fn_25a_12] all agree that it is no valid birth. R. Joshua b. Levi, however, stated: The dispute[^fn_25a_10] refers to the case of a clear sac. The question was raised:[^fn_25a_13] Do they differ only in the case of a clear sac but in that of a turbid one all agree that it is a valid birth or is it possible that they differ about the one as well as about the other? — This stands undecided.[^fn_25a_14] An objection was raised: This exposition was made by R. Joshua b. Hananiah: And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skins, and clothed them[^fn_25a_15] teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, makes no skin for man before[^fn_25a_16] he is formed. Thus it is clearly proved that a valid birth[^fn_25a_17] depends on the skin irrespective of whether the sac was turbid or clear. Now if you grant[^fn_25a_18] that the dispute[^fn_25a_19] refers to the case of a clear sac there is full justification for his[^fn_25a_20] need for a Scriptural text;[^fn_25a_21] but if you maintain[^fn_25a_22] that the dispute refers only to a turbid sac,[^fn_25a_23] what need was there for a Scriptural text seeing that the reason[^fn_25a_24] is a matter of logic? Consequently it may be inferred that the dispute refers also to a clear sac.[^fn_25a_25] This is conclusive.

R. Nahman citing Rabbah b. Abbuha also[^fn_25a_26] stated: They[^fn_25a_27] differ only in regard to a turbid sac but as regards a clear one all agree that it is no valid birth. Raba raised an objection against R. Nahman: But they ruled: The token of a valid birth[^fn_25a_28] in small cattle is a discharge from the womb,[^fn_25a_29] in large cattle the placenta,[^fn_25a_30] and in a woman the sac or placenta',[^fn_25a_31] but, it follows, the abortion of a sac in cattle provides no exemption.[^fn_25a_32] Now, if you grant that they[^fn_25a_27] differ in the case of a clear sac, one can well see the reason why only a woman whose case Scripture specifically included,[^fn_25a_33] was granted exemption in respect of a sac[^fn_25a_31] while cattle whose case Scripture did not include no exemption was granted in respect of a sac, but if you maintain that the dispute concerns only a turbid sac consider! \[The question of the validity of the birth being dependent\] on a logical reason[^fn_25a_34] what difference in this respect could there be between a woman and cattle?[^fn_25a_35] — You think that R. Joshua was quite certain \[of the nature of the sac\],[^fn_25a_36] but the fact is that R. Joshua was rather doubtful on the matter and, therefore, he followed a restrictive course in both cases.[^fn_25a_37] \[Only the question of the firstborn son\] of[^fn_25a_38] a woman, which is a mere monetary matter,[^fn_25a_39] \[did he rule that the abortion of a sac constitutes a valid birth,[^fn_25a_40] because\] in a case of doubt in monetary matters a lenient course[^fn_25a_41] is followed.[^fn_25a_42] On the question of the firstling of cattle, however, which involves a ritual prohibition of shearing[^fn_25a_43] and of work[^fn_25a_44] \[he ruled the abortion of a sac to be an invalid birth,[^fn_25a_45] because\] in case of doubt in a ritual prohibition a restrictive course must be followed; and so also \[on the question of the uncleanness\] of a woman \[the abortion of a sac is deemed to be a valid birth,[^fn_25a_46] because\] in a case of doubtful uncleanness[^fn_25a_47] a restrictive course must be followed. But was he[^fn_25a_48] in doubt?[^fn_25a_49] Did he not, in fact, quote a Scriptural text?[^fn_25a_50] — The ruling is only Rabbinical[^fn_25a_51] and the Scriptural text is a mere prop.[^fn_25a_52]

Said R. Hanina b. Shelemya to Rab: We have[^fn_25a_53] the statements of[^fn_25a_54] Rabbi,[^fn_25a_55] of[^fn_25a_54] R. Ishmael son of R. Jose,[^fn_25a_56] of R. Oshaia[^fn_25a_57] and of R. Joshua b. Levi;[^fn_25a_58] with whose view does the Master agree? — I maintain, the other replied, that in neither case[^fn_25a_59] need she take into consideration the possibility of a valid birth. Samuel, however, ruled: In either case[^fn_25a_60] must she consider the possibility of a valid birth.[^fn_25a_61] Samuel in this ruling follows his previously expressed view. For R. Dimi when he came[^fn_25a_62] stated: Never at Nehardea[^fn_25a_63] did they declare \[one who aborted\] a sac[^fn_25a_64] to be clean[^fn_25a_65] except in the case of a certain sac that was submitted to Samuel on which a hair that lay on one side could be seen through the other side when he said: If it were in fact an embryo it would not have been so transparent.

BUT IF ITS LIMBS WERE FASHIONED etc. Our Rabbis taught: What is meant by a sac the limbs of which are fashioned? Abba Saul explained: A foetus which in its primary stage resembles a locust,[^fn_25a_66] and its two eyes are like two drippings[^fn_25a_67] of a fly. R. Hiyya taught: They are far removed from one another. Its two nostrils are like two drippings of a fly. R. Hiyya taught: They are near one to another. Its mouth is as narrow as a stretched hair,[^fn_25a_68] its membrum[^fn_25a_69] is of the size of a lentil[^fn_25a_70] and in the case of a female \[the organ\] has the appearance of the longitudinal \[slit\][^fn_25a_71] of a barley grain; but it has no shaped hands or feet.[^fn_25a_72] Of such a foetus there is this description in the post-Pentateuchal Scriptures:[^fn_25a_73] Hast thou not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like cheese? Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh and knit me together with bones and sinews. Thou hast granted me life and favor, and Thy providence hath preserved my spirit.[^fn_25a_74] It[^fn_25a_75] must not be examined in water because water is hard[^fn_25a_76] [pg 25b]

and disturbs its shape. It must rather be examined in oil because oil is mild and makes it clear. Furthermore, it must be examined in sunlight only. How is it to be examined? 'How is it to be examined' \[you ask\]! Of course as has just been described. — Rather, wherewith is it to be examined in order to ascertain whether it was male or female? — Abba Saul b. Nashor, as others say, Abba Saul b. Ramash replied: One brings a splinter with a smooth top and moves it \[in an upward direction\] in that place.[^fn_25b_1] If it is caught it will be known that the foetus is a male,[^fn_25b_2] and if not it will be known to be a female. R. Nahman citing Rabbah b. Abbuha stated: This[^fn_25b_3] was learnt only of a movement in an upward direction,[^fn_25b_2] but if sideways \[it is no reliable test, since\] it may be assumed \[that the obstruction\] was caused by the sides of the womb. R. Adda b. Ahaba stated: A Tanna taught, If the foetus was a female the organ has the appearance of the \[longitudinal\] slit of a barley grain.[^fn_25b_4] R. Nahman demurred: Is it not possible that it[^fn_25b_5] is merely the depression between[^fn_25b_6] the testes? — Abaye replied: Since the testes themselves are indistinguishable, would the depression between them be distinguishable?[^fn_25b_7]

R. Amram stated: A Tanna taught, 'Its[^fn_25b_8] two thighs are like two silk threads', and in connection with this R. Amram explained: Like those of the woof;[^fn_25b_9] 'and its two arms are like two threads of silk', in connection with which R. Amram explained: Like those of the warp.[^fn_25b_9]

Samuel said to Rab Judah: Shinena,[^fn_25b_10] give no practical decision \[on the validity of a birth\] unless the embryo has hair \[on its head\]. But could Samuel have said such a thing, seeing that he ruled, 'In either case must she consider the possibility of a valid birth'? — R. Ammi b. Samuel replied: This was explained to me by the Master Samuel: She must indeed take into consideration the possibility of a valid birth;[^fn_25b_11] but she is not allowed the privilege of the clean days[^fn_25b_12] unless the embryo had hair \[on its head\]. This then implies that Samuel was doubtful on the point.[^fn_25b_13] But is it not a fact that when a certain sac was submitted to the Master Samuel he said, 'This is forty-one days old', but on calculating the time since the woman had gone to perform her ritual immersion[^fn_25b_14] until that day and finding that there were no more than forty days he declared, 'This man[^fn_25b_15] must have had marital intercourse during her menstrual period' and having been arrested[^fn_25b_16] he confessed?[^fn_25b_17] — Samuel was different from other people because his knowledge was exceptional.[^fn_25b_18]

IF SHE ABORTED A SANDAL etc. Our Rabbis taught: A sandal is like a sea-fish \[of the same name\].[^fn_25b_19] At first it is a normal foetus but later it is crushed. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel said: A sandal resembles the tongue of a big ox. In the name of our Masters it was testified: A sandal[^fn_25b_20] must have the facial features.[^fn_25b_21] Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: The *halachah* is that a sandal[^fn_25b_20] must have the facial features. R. Adda citing R. Joseph who had it from R. Isaac ruled: A sandal[^fn_25b_20] must have the facial features even if only at the back, this being a case similar to that of a man who slapped his fellow and caused his face to turn backwards.

In the days of R. Jannai it was desired to declare \[the mother of\] a sandal that had no facial features as clean.[^fn_25b_22] Said R. Jannai to them: You would declare \[the mother of newly born\] children[^fn_25b_23] as clean![^fn_25b_24] — But was it not taught, 'In the name of our Masters it was testified: A sandal[^fn_25b_25] must have the facial features'?[^fn_25b_26] — R. Bibi b. Abaye citing R. Johanan replied: It was on the evidence of R. Nehunya[^fn_25b_27] that this ruling[^fn_25b_28] was learnt.[^fn_25b_29] R. Ze'ira observed: R. Bibi was lucky \[to be the first\] with his reported traditions, for both I and he were sitting in the presence of R. Johanan when he discoursed upon this tradition, but he[^fn_25b_30] forestalled me and, reporting it first, gained the advantage.

Why was a sandal[^fn_25b_31] at all mentioned, seeing that there can be no birth of a sandal without that of an embryo with it?[^fn_25b_32] — If a female child were to be born with it this would be so indeed,[^fn_25b_33] but here we are dealing with one with which a male was born.[^fn_25b_34] As it might have been presumed that, since R. Isaac b. Ammi stated, 'If the woman is first to emit the semen she bears a male child and if the male is first to do it she bears a female child', the one[^fn_25b_35] is a male as well as the other is a male,[^fn_25b_36] hence we were informed \[that no such assumption is made, for\] it might equally be assumed that both emitted their semen simultaneously so that one might be a male while the other[^fn_25b_35] is a female.[^fn_25b_37] Another explanation:[^fn_25b_38] \[Sandal[^fn_25b_39] was mentioned\] in order that if a woman bore a female child before sunset and a sandal after sunset[^fn_25b_40] she must count the beginning of her period of menstruation in accordance with the first birth and in accordance with the second birth.[^fn_25b_41]

As regards the sandal that we learnt [pg 26a]

in the laws of the firstborn,[^fn_26a_1] what practical law[^fn_26a_2] is thereby taught?[^fn_26a_3] — That the son who follows it[^fn_26a_4] is regarded as a firstborn son in respect of inheritance[^fn_26a_5] but not \[in regard to his redemption\] from the priest.[^fn_26a_6] What practical law is taught by that of the sandal of which we learnt in the case of those who incur the penalty of *kareth*?[^fn_26a_7] — That if the embryo[^fn_26a_8] is born from her side,[^fn_26a_9] and the sandal from her womb she[^fn_26a_10] must bring a sacrifice on account of the sandal. But according to R. Simeon who ruled that 'a foetus born from the side constitutes a valid birth',[^fn_26a_11] what can be said?[^fn_26a_12] — R. Jeremiah replied: That if a woman bears the child while she is an idolatress and the sandal after she has been converted \[to Judaism\] she[^fn_26a_13] must bring a sacrifice on account of the sandal.

The following was said by the Rabbis before R. Papa: But are all these answers[^fn_26a_14] tenable? Was it not in fact taught, 'When they[^fn_26a_15] issue they do so only while clinging to one another'?[^fn_26a_16] — R. Papa replied: From this[^fn_26a_17] it may be inferred that the embryo clings to the sandal at the middle of the latter[^fn_26a_18] which lies across the head of the former.[^fn_26a_19] Consequently, as regards the law of the firstborn, \[the reference is to a case\], for instance, where the embryo[^fn_26a_20] issued with its head first[^fn_26a_21] so that the sandal[^fn_26a_22] issued first.[^fn_26a_23] As regards the law concerning those punishable by *kareth* it is a case where they[^fn_26a_24] issued with their feet first so that the embryo was born first.[^fn_26a_25] R. Huna b. Tahlifa citing Raba explained: It may even be said that they[^fn_26a_26] cling together side by side, but reverse the previous statement:[^fn_26a_27] As regards the law of the firstborn \[the reference is to a case\] where they[^fn_26a_26] issued with their feet first; so that the embryo, being animated hangs on and does not easily come out; while the sandal, not being animated, glides and comes speedily out. As regards the law concerning those subject to the penalty of *kareth* \[the reference is to a case\] where they issued with their heads first, so that the embryo, being animated is deemed to have consummated its birth as soon as its head came out; while the sandal \[being inanimated cannot be deemed to have been born\] until its greater part came out.

***MISHNAH***. IF A PLACENTA IS WITHIN A HOUSE, THE HOUSE IS UNCLEAN;[^fn_26a_28] NOT BECAUSE A PLACENTA IS A CHILD BUT BECAUSE GENERALLY THERE CAN BE NO PLACENTA WITHOUT A CHILD. R. SIMEON SAID, THE CHILD MIGHT HAVE BEEN MASHED[^fn_26a_29] BEFORE IT CAME FORTH.[^fn_26a_30] {¶=3.3}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: The placenta in its first stage resembles a thread of the woof and in its final stage it resembles a lupine. It is hollow like a trumpet; and no placenta is smaller than a handbreadth. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel stated: The placenta resembles the craw of a hen[^fn_26a_31] out of which the small bowels issue.[^fn_26a_32]

R. Oshaia, the youngest of the fellowship,[^fn_26a_33] taught:[^fn_26a_34] Five things have a prescribed minimum of a handbreadth, and they are the following. A placenta, a *shofar*, a spine, a *sukkah* wall and a bundle of hyssop. As to the placenta there is the ruling just mentioned.[^fn_26a_35] '*Shofar*'?[^fn_26a_36] For it was taught: What must be the size of a *shofar*?[^fn_26a_37] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel explained: It must be of such a size as can be held in one's hand and be seen at either end, viz.,[^fn_26a_38] a handbreadth.[^fn_26a_39] What is meant by 'spine'? The ruling which R. Parnak laid down in the name of R. Johanan: The spine of the lulab must be long enough to project a handbreadth above the myrtle.[^fn_26a_40] 'The *Sukkah*[^fn_26a_41] wall'? As it was taught: Two walls[^fn_26a_42] must be proper ones but the third is valid even if it is only one handbreadth wide. 'Hyssop'? As R. Hiyya taught: The bundle of hyssop[^fn_26a_43] must be a handbreadth long.

R. Hanina b. Papa stated: Shila of the village of Tamartha discoursed on three Baraithas and two reported traditions dealing with the prescribed size of a handbreadth. 'Two'[^fn_26a_44] \[you say\]; is it not only one?[^fn_26a_45] — Abaye replied, read:[^fn_26a_46] R. Hiyya stated,[^fn_26a_47] 'The bundle of hyssop must be a handbreadth long'. But are there no others?[^fn_26a_48] Is there not in fact \[the law that an enclosed space of\] one handbreadth square and one handbreadth in height, forming a cube[^fn_26a_49] conveys uncleanness[^fn_26a_50] and constitutes a screen[^fn_26a_51] against uncleanness?[^fn_26a_52] — We spoke of the size of 'a handbreadth'; we did not speak of 'a handbreadth square'. But is there not the law concerning a stone that projected one handbreadth from an oven[^fn_26a_53] or three fingerbreadths from a double stove[^fn_26a_54] in which case it serves as a connecting link?[^fn_26a_55] We spoke only of cases where the size of less than a handbreadth is invalid, but here the law would apply all the more to such a case where the size is of less than a handbreadth and it is a handle of the oven. But is there not [pg 26b]

the law of ovens of the size of one handbreadth?[^fn_26b_1] For we learnt:[^fn_26b_2] — An oven \[if it is to be susceptible to uncleanness must\] ab initio[^fn_26b_3] be no less than four handbreadths high, and what remains of it[^fn_26b_4] must[^fn_26b_5] be no less than four handbreadths high; so R. Meir. But the Sages ruled: This applies only to a big oven but if it is a small one \[it is susceptible to uncleanness\] ab initio, after its manufacture is completed, whatever its size, and what is left of it \[remains unclean\] if it was the greater part of it.[^fn_26b_6] And \[to the question\] what is meant by 'whatever its size', R. Jannai replied: One handbreadth, since ovens of the height of one handbreadth are made![^fn_26b_7] — He[^fn_26b_8] did not speak of laws about which a divergence of view exists.[^fn_26b_9] Now that you have arrived at this argument that law[^fn_26b_10] \[it may be explained\][^fn_26b_11] is also one in dispute, for in the final clause it was stated: R. Judah said, They spoke of the length of a handbreadth only between the oven and the wall.[^fn_26b_12] But is there not also a border of a handbreadth?[^fn_26b_13] — He does not deal with sizes that are prescribed in Scripture. But is there not the ark-cover that was one handbreadth thick?[^fn_26b_14] — He[^fn_26b_8] does not discuss holy things. But is there not \[the following law\]: It suffices for a cross-beam[^fn_26b_15] to be one handbreadth wide?[^fn_26b_16] — He[^fn_26b_17] does not discuss Rabbinical laws.[^fn_26b_18] \[He was concerned only\] with such as are prescribed in Scripture and in connection with which no sizes[^fn_26b_19] have been specified.

R. Isaac b. Samuel b. Martha once sat at his studies before R. Kahana and in the course of the session he observed: Rab Judah citing Rab laid down that throughout the first three days[^fn_26b_20] the placenta[^fn_26b_21] is attributed to the child,[^fn_26b_22] but henceforth the possibility of the birth of a second child[^fn_26b_23] must be considered.[^fn_26b_24] Said the other to him: But could Rab have said such a thing? Did not Rab in fact state, 'One child is not detained at all after the other \[had been born\]'?[^fn_26b_25] The first remained silent. Said the other to him: Is it not possible that one statement[^fn_26b_26] referred to an abortion, while the other[^fn_26b_27] referred to a child that was viable? — You, the first[^fn_26b_28] answered, have indeed stated Rab's actual rulings, for Rab has explicitly made the following statement: If a woman aborted an embryo and after that she aborted a placenta, if this occurred within three days[^fn_26b_29] the placenta is attributed to the embryo, but if it occurred at any subsequent time the possibility of the abortion of a second embryo must be taken into consideration. If, however, she gave birth to a normal child and subsequently aborted a placenta, even if that occurred between that moment and ten days later,[^fn_26b_30] the possibility of the abortion of a second child[^fn_26b_31] need not be considered at all.

Samuel and the disciples of Rab and Rab Judah[^fn_26b_32] were once sitting at their studies when R. Joseph the son of R. Menashya of Dewil passed along in great haste. 'There comes towards us', he exclaimed, 'a man whom we can throw down with a piece of straw[^fn_26b_33] and he would allow himself to be thrown down and pushed out'.[^fn_26b_34] In the meanwhile he approached them. What, said Samuel to him, did Rab rule in regard to a placenta? — Thus, the other replied, said Rab: The placenta may be attributed only to a child that is viable.[^fn_26b_35] Samuel then put the question to all the disciples of Rab and they told him the same thing. Thereupon he turned round and looked at Rab Judah with displeasure.[^fn_26b_36]

R. Jose b. Saul enquired of Rabbi: What is the law where there was an abortion in the shape of a raven and \[this was followed by\] a placenta?[^fn_26b_37] — The other replied: We can attribute a placenta only to an embryo in whose species[^fn_26b_38] the placenta is \[one of their organs\].[^fn_26b_39] What is the law where the placenta is tied to it?[^fn_26b_40] — You, the other replied, have asked a question about that which does not exist. He raised an objection against him: If a woman aborted something in the shape of a beast, a wild animal or a bird, and a placenta with them, whenever the placenta is attached to it there is no need to take into consideration the possibility of the existence of a second embryo, but if no placenta is attached to it the possibility of the existence of a second embryo[^fn_26b_41] must be considered, and one[^fn_26b_42] must \[impose on the woman\] on account of them[^fn_26b_43] [pg 27a]

the restrictions of the two births;[^fn_27a_1] for it is assumed[^fn_27a_2] that the foetus of the placenta may have been crushed[^fn_27a_3] and that the placenta of the foetus[^fn_27a_4] was also crushed.[^fn_27a_5] This is indeed a refutation.

Rabbah b. Shila citing R. Mattena who had it from Samuel stated: It once happened that a placenta was attributed to an embryo as late as[^fn_27a_6] ten days \[after the latter's birth\].[^fn_27a_7] \[The law, however, that it\] is to be attributed \[to the existing embryo\] applies only[^fn_27a_8] where the expulsion of the placenta followed the birth of the embryo.[^fn_27a_9] Rabbah b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan stated: It once happened that a placenta was attributed to an embryo as late as[^fn_27a_10] twenty-three days \[after the birth of the latter\]. 'You once told us', said R. Joseph to him, 'as late as twenty-four days'. R. Aha son of 'Awira citing R. Johanan[^fn_27a_11] stated: It once happened that the birth of an embryo was delayed for thirty-three days after that of its predecessor. 'You', said R. Joseph to him, 'have in fact told us thirty-four days.' \[Such an incident may be explained\] satisfactorily according to him who holds that a woman who bears at nine months does not necessarily complete the full number,[^fn_27a_12] since in such circumstances it is possible that the features of one embryo were completed at the end[^fn_27a_13] of seven months[^fn_27a_14] and those of the other at the beginning[^fn_27a_13] of the ninth month,[^fn_27a_15] but according to him who maintains that a woman who bears at nine months does complete the full number,[^fn_27a_12] what can be said \[in explanation of the incident\]?[^fn_27a_16] — Reverse the statements:[^fn_27a_17] Thirty-three days in the case of the placenta[^fn_27a_18] and twenty-three days in that of the embryo.[^fn_27a_19]

R. Abin b. R. Adda citing R. Menahem of Kefar She'arim or, as some say, Beth She'arim, stated: It once happened that a child was born three months later than its predecessor and lo, both sit before us in the schoolhouse. And who are they? — Judah and Hezekiah the sons of R. Hiyya. But did not a Master say that a woman in conception cannot conceive again?[^fn_27a_20] — Abaye replied: It was the same drop but it was divided in two sections; the features of one of these were completed at the beginning of the seventh month and those of the other were completed at the end of the ninth month.

IF A PLACENTA IS WITHIN A HOUSE, THE HOUSE IS UNCLEAN. Our Rabbis taught: If a placenta is in a house, the house is unclean; not because a placenta is a child but because generally there can be no placenta with which there is no child; so R. Meir. R. Jose, R. Judah and R. Simeon regard \[the house\] as clean. 'Do you not agree', they said to R. Meir, 'that if it had been carried out in a bowl into an outer room it would be clean?' 'Indeed', he replied. 'But why?'[^fn_27a_21] 'Because it[^fn_27a_22] is no longer in existence'. 'As', they retorted, 'it is not in existence in the outer room so is it not in existence in the inner room'.[^fn_27a_23] 'What was mashed once', he replied, 'is not like that which was mashed twice.'[^fn_27a_24]

R. Papa once sat behind R. Bubi in the presence of R. Hamnuna and in the course of the session he observed: What is R. Simeon's reason?[^fn_27a_25] He is of the opinion that any uncleanness with which anything of a different kind of uncleanness has been mixed is neutralized. Said R. Papa to them: 'Is this also the reason of R. Judah and R. Jose?'[^fn_27a_26] They laughed at him. 'Is not this obvious', they said, 'why should there be any difference?'[^fn_27a_27] — 'Even such a question',[^fn_27a_28] said R. Papa, 'a man should submit to his Master[^fn_27a_29] and not be content with silence;[^fn_27a_30] for it is said, If thou hast done foolishly[^fn_27a_31] thou art[^fn_27a_32] lifting up thyself;[^fn_27a_33] but[^fn_27a_34] if thou hast planned devices,[^fn_27a_35] lay thy hand upon thy mouth.[^fn_27a_36]

R. Simeon[^fn_27a_37] follows the view he expressed elsewhere. For it was taught: If some earth fell into a ladleful of corpse-mould \[the latter remains\] unclean, but R. Simeon holds it to be clean. What is R. Simeon's reason? — Raba[^fn_27a_38] replied: 'I met the Rabbis of the schoolhouse while they were sitting at their studies and explaining that[^fn_27a_39] it is impossible that \[somewhere in the mixture\] two particles of earth to one of the corpse-mould should not represent the larger portion, so that[^fn_27a_40] something is missing',[^fn_27a_41] and I said to them, 'On the contrary! It is impossible that \[somewhere in the mixture\] two particles of the corpse-mould should not represent a part greater than [pg 27b]

one particle of earth,[^fn_27b_1] so that[^fn_27b_2] the quantity is increased'.[^fn_27b_3] The fact, however, is, said Raba,[^fn_27b_4] that this is the reason of R. Simeon: Its final stage[^fn_27b_5] is treated as its first stage.[^fn_27b_6] As in its first stage any other matter[^fn_27b_7] becomes its antidote[^fn_27b_8] so also in its final stage[^fn_27b_5] any other matter[^fn_27b_9] becomes its antidote,[^fn_27b_8] What is that law?[^fn_27b_10] — It was taught: In what circumstances is a corpse subject to the uncleanness of[^fn_27b_11] corpse-mould and in what circumstances is a corpse not subject to the uncleanness of corpse-mould? If a corpse was buried naked in a marble sarcophagus or on a stone floor[^fn_27b_12] it is one that is subject to the uncleanness of corpse-mould. And in what circumstances is a corpse not subject to the uncleanness of corpse-mould? If it was buried in its shroud,[^fn_27b_13] or in a wooden coffin,[^fn_27b_14] or on a brick floor[^fn_27b_14] it is one that is not subject to the uncleanness of corpse-mould.[^fn_27b_15] And \[the Sages\] spoke of the uncleanness of corpse-mould only in the case of one who died, thus excluding a killed person who[^fn_27b_16] is not \[subject to this law\].[^fn_27b_17]

\[To turn to\] the main text, 'If some earth fell into a ladleful of corpse-mould \[the latter remains\] unclean, but R. Simeon holds it to be clean. If a ladleful of corpse-mould was scattered in a house the house is unclean,[^fn_27b_18] but R. Simeon holds it to be clean'.[^fn_27b_19] And both these rulings were required. For if we had been informed of the first one only[^fn_27b_20] it might have been presumed that only in that case do the Rabbis maintain their view,[^fn_27b_21] since it[^fn_27b_22] is collected together but that where it was scattered they agree with R. Simeon, since a succession of incomplete overshadowings[^fn_27b_23] is of no consequence.[^fn_27b_24] And if we had been informed of the latter only[^fn_27b_25] it might have been presumed that only in that case does R. Simeon maintain his view,[^fn_27b_26] since a succession of incomplete overshadowings[^fn_27b_23] is of no consequence,[^fn_27b_27] but that in the former case[^fn_27b_28] he agrees with the Rabbis.[^fn_27b_21] Hence both were required.

Elsewhere we learnt:[^fn_27b_29] A ladleful and more of the earth of a graveyard[^fn_27b_30] is unclean,[^fn_27b_31] but R. Simeon regards it as clean.[^fn_27b_32] What is the reason of the Rabbis? — Because it is impossible to have 'a ladleful[^fn_27b_33] and more' of the earth of a graveyard in which there is not contained a ladleful of corpse-mould.[^fn_27b_34]

Now that you have explained that R. Simeon's reason is because 'its final stage is treated as its first stage',[^fn_27b_35] what could be his reason in the case of a PLACENTA?[^fn_27b_36] — R. Johanan replied: Because the law of neutralization in the larger quantity[^fn_27b_37] has been applied to it.[^fn_27b_38] R. Johanan in fact follows here[^fn_27b_39] a view he expressed elsewhere. For R. Johanan stated: R. Simeon and R. Eliezer b. Jacob laid down the same ruling.[^fn_27b_40] R. Simeon laid down the ruling we have just spoken of.[^fn_27b_41] R. Eliezer \[also laid down the same ruling\] for we learnt:[^fn_27b_42] R. Eliezer b. Jacob ruled, If a beast[^fn_27b_43] of the class of large cattle discharged a clot of blood, this[^fn_27b_44] shall be buried[^fn_27b_45] and \[the beast\] is exempt from the law of the firstling;[^fn_27b_46] and in connection with this R. Hiyya taught: It[^fn_27b_44] does not convey uncleanness either through touch or through carriage.[^fn_27b_47] But since it conveys no uncleanness either through touch or through carriage[^fn_27b_48] why[^fn_27b_49] should it be buried? — In order to publish the fact that \[the beast\] is exempt from the law of the firstling. It thus clearly follows that it[^fn_27b_44] is deemed to be a proper embryo,[^fn_27b_50] then why did R. Hiyya teach, 'It does not convey uncleanness either through touch or through carriage'? — R. Johanan replied: Because the law of neutralization in the larger quantity[^fn_27b_51] has been applied to it.[^fn_27b_52]

R. Ammi citing R. Johanan stated: R. Simeon, however,[^fn_27b_53] agrees that its mother is unclean by reason of childbirth. Said a certain old man to R. Ammi: 'I will explain to you R. Johanan's reason:[^fn_27b_54] For Scripture says, If a woman conceived seed[^fn_27b_55] and bore a man-child etc.,[^fn_27b_56] which implies: Even if she bore in the same manner only as she 'conceived seed'[^fn_27b_57] she is unclean by reason of childbirth.

Resh Lakish ruled: A sac that was beaten up in its fluid assumes the same status as a corpse whose shape was destroyed.[^fn_27b_58] Said R. Johanan to Resh Lakish: Whence do we infer that a corpse whose shape had been destroyed is clean? If it be suggested, From the following statement which R. Shabthai cited in the name of R. Isaac of Magdala or, as others say, R. Isaac of Magdala cited in the name of R. Shabthai, 'If a corpse has been burnt but its shape remained[^fn_27b_59] it is unclean. It once happened that on account of such a corpse[^fn_27b_60] the big[^fn_27b_61] doors[^fn_27b_62] were declared unclean[^fn_27b_63] [pg 28a]

but the small doors[^fn_28a_1] were declared clean'; from which you infer that the reason \[why the big doors were declared unclean is\] because its shape is still intact but had it not been in such a condition they[^fn_28a_2] would have been clean; on the contrary \[it could be retorted\] draw from this the following inference:[^fn_28a_3] Only when its shape is intact were the small doors declared clean but otherwise the small doors also are unclean, since everyone of them is fit for carrying through it one limb at a time.[^fn_28a_4] Said Rabina to R. Ashi: \[Do you know\] in agreement with whose view R. Johanan made his statement?[^fn_28a_5] In agreement with that of R. Eliezer, For we learnt: The ashes of burnt corpses, R. Eliezer ruled, \[convey uncleanness\] if they are a quarter of a *kab* in quantity.[^fn_28a_6] How is one to imagine a corpse that was burnt but whose shape remained intact? — Abaye replied: In such a case, for instance, as where it was burnt on a leather spread.[^fn_28a_7] Raba replied: In such a case, for instance, as where it was burnt on a hard cemented substance.[^fn_28a_8] Rabina replied: Where, for instance, it was only charred.[^fn_28a_9]

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman aborted a shaped[^fn_28a_10] hand or a shaped[^fn_28a_11] foot she[^fn_28a_12] is subject to the uncleanness of childbirth and there is no need to consider the possibility that it might have come from a shapeless body.[^fn_28a_13] Both R. Hisda and Rabbah b. R. Huna ruled: She[^fn_28a_14] is not allowed the days of cleanness.[^fn_28a_15] What is the reason? — It might be assumed that[^fn_28a_16] her bearing took place long ago.[^fn_28a_17] R. Joseph raised an objection: If a woman aborted an embryo and[^fn_28a_18] it is unknown what \[was the sex of the embryo\] she aborted she must continue \[her periods of uncleanness and cleanness as\] for both a male child and a female child.[^fn_28a_19] Now if it is to be upheld[^fn_28a_20] that in any such case[^fn_28a_21] it might be assumed that her bearing took place long ago,[^fn_28a_22] why[^fn_28a_23] was it not also stated, 'and as for menstruation'?[^fn_28a_24] — Abaye replied: If 'as for menstruation' had been mentioned it might have been presumed that[^fn_28a_25] she brings a sacrifice[^fn_28a_26] which[^fn_28a_27] may not be eaten; hence we were informed[^fn_28a_28] that it may be eaten.[^fn_28a_29]

R. Huna ruled: If an embryo put forth its hand and then drew it back its mother is unclean on account of childbirth; for it is said, And it came to pass, when she bore,[^fn_28a_30] that one put out a hand.[^fn_28a_31] Rab Judah raised an objection: If an embryo put forth its hand its mother need not consider the possibility of any restriction![^fn_28a_32] — R. Nahman replied: This was explained to me by R. Huna that the woman must indeed consider the possibility \[that it is a valid birth\],[^fn_28a_33] but we do not allow her the privilege of the clean days[^fn_28a_34] unless the greater part of the embryo has issued forth. But was it not stated 'Its mother need not consider the possibility of any restriction'? — Abaye replied: Pentateuchally she need not consider the possibility of any restriction, but it is Rabbinically that she must take into consideration the possibility \[that it might have constituted a valid birth\]. But did he[^fn_28a_35] not quote a Scriptural text?[^fn_28a_36] — The restriction is Rabbinical, and the Scriptural text is a mere prop.[^fn_28a_37]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN ABORTED A *TUMTUM* OR AN ANDROGINOS,[^fn_28a_38] SHE MUST CONTINUE \[IN HER UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR BOTH A MALE[^fn_28a_39] AND A FEMALE,[^fn_28a_40] IF SHE GAVE BIRTH TO A *TUMTUM* AND A MALE, OR TO AN ANDROGINOS AND A MALE, SHE MUST ALSO CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR BOTH A MALE[^fn_28a_39] AND A FEMALE.[^fn_28a_40] IF SHE HAVE A *TUMTUM* AND A FEMALE OR AN ANDROGINOS AND A FEMALE, SHE NEED CONTINUE \[IN UNCLEANNESS AS\] FOR A FEMALE ONLY.[^fn_28a_41] IF THE EMBRYO ISSUED IN PIECES[^fn_28a_42] OR IN A REVERSED POSITION[^fn_28a_43] IT IS DEEMED BORN AS SOON AS ITS GREATER PART ISSUED FORTH. IF IT CAME FORTH IN THE NORMAL WAY \[IT IS NOT DEEMED BORN\] UNTIL THE GREATER PART OF ITS HEAD ISSUED FORTH. AND WHAT IS MEANT \[BY THE ISSUE OF\] THE 'GREATER PART OF ITS HEAD'? THE ISSUE[^fn_28a_44] OF ITS FOREHEAD. {¶=3.4}

***GEMARA***. Now that it has been laid down that for a *TUMTUM* alone or for an ANDROGINOS alone SHE MUST CONTINUE \[IN HER UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR BOTH A MALE AND A FEMALE, why should it again be necessary \[to state that the same law applies where she gave birth to\] A *TUMTUM* AND A MALE OR TO AN ANDROGINOS AND A MALE? — This was necessary: As it might have been suggested that since R. Isaac had stated, 'If the woman emits her semen first she bears a male and if the man emits his first she bears a female',[^fn_28a_45] it should be assumed that since the one is a male the other[^fn_28a_46] also is a male, hence we were informed \[that no such assumption is made, since\] it might equally be assumed that both[^fn_28a_47] emitted their semen simultaneously, the one resulting in a male and the other in a female.[^fn_28a_48]

R. Nahman citing Rab ruled: If a *tumtum* or an androginos observed a white,[^fn_28a_49] or a red[^fn_28a_50] discharge he[^fn_28a_51] does not incur the obligation of an offering for entering the Sanctuary[^fn_28a_52] nor is *terumah*[^fn_28a_53] to be burnt on his account.[^fn_28a_54] If he[^fn_28a_51] observed a simultaneous discharge of white and red,[^fn_28a_55] he incurs indeed no obligation of an offering for entering the Sanctuary[^fn_28a_56] but *terumah*[^fn_28a_53] must be burnt on his account;[^fn_28a_57] for[^fn_28a_58] it is said, Both male and female [pg 28b]

shall ye put out,[^fn_28b_1] only a confirmed male or a confirmed female \[shall ye put out\], but not a *tumtum* or an androginos. May it be suggested that the following provides support for his[^fn_28b_2] view? \[For it was taught:\] 'If a *tumtum* or an androginos observed a white,[^fn_28b_3] or a red discharge, he incurs no obligation of an offering for entering the Sanctuary nor is *terumah* to be burnt on his account. If he observed a simultaneous discharge of white and red he incurs indeed no obligation of an offering for entering the Sanctuary but *terumah* must be burnt on his account'. Now is not the reason[^fn_28b_4] because it is said, Both male and female shall ye put out,[^fn_28b_5] which implies only a confirmed male and a confirmed female \[shall ye put out\] but not a *tumtum* or an androginos?[^fn_28b_6] — 'Ulla replied: No; this may represent the view of[^fn_28b_7] R. Eliezer.[^fn_28b_8] For we learnt: R. Eliezer stated, \[It is written, If any one touch … the carcass of\] unclean swarming things and … it being hidden from him,[^fn_28b_9] one incurs the obligation of an offering only when the unclean swarming thing is hidden from him[^fn_28b_10] but no offering is incurred when the Sanctuary is hidden from him.[^fn_28b_11] R. Akiba stated, \[Scripture says:\] It being hidden from him that he is unclean,[^fn_28b_9] one incurs the obligation of an offering only when it is 'hidden from him that he is unclean'[^fn_28b_10] but no offering is incurred when the Sanctuary is hidden from him.[^fn_28b_12] And when it was asked, 'What is the practical difference between them?'[^fn_28b_13] Hezekiah replied: The practical difference between them is \[the case of a man who is uncertain whether he touched\] a dead creeping thing or the carcass of a beast, R. Eliezer[^fn_28b_14] holding that it is necessary[^fn_28b_15] that a person shall know[^fn_28b_16] whether he had contracted uncleanness through a creeping thing or through the carcass of a beast, while R. Akiba[^fn_28b_17] maintains that this is not necessary.[^fn_28b_18] Now did not R. Eliezer state there[^fn_28b_18] that 'it is necessary that a person should know whether he contracted uncleanness through a creeping thing or the carcass of a beast'?[^fn_28b_19] Well here also[^fn_28b_20] it is necessary[^fn_28b_21] that the person[^fn_28b_22] should know whether he became unclean on account of the white discharge or an account of the red one; but according to R. Akiba who stated that a person incurs the obligation of an offering on account of uncleanness[^fn_28b_23] an offering would be incurred here[^fn_28b_20] also on account of the uncleanness.[^fn_28b_23] But, according to Rab, why is it that they[^fn_28b_22] incur no offering for entering the Sanctuary? Because \[you say\] it is written, Both male and female shall ye put out,[^fn_28b_24] which implies that only a confirmed male and a confirmed female \[must be put out\] but not a *tumtum* or an androginos. But, if so, *terumah*[^fn_28b_25] also should not be burnt, since it is written, And of them that have an issue, whether it be a man, or a woman,[^fn_28b_26] which implies[^fn_28b_27] does it not, that only a confirmed male and a confirmed female \[is subject to the restrictions\][^fn_28b_28] but not a *tumtum* or an androginos?[^fn_28b_29] — That text[^fn_28b_26] is required for an exposition like the one made by R. Isaac; for R. Isaac stated: 'whether it be a man'[^fn_28b_26] includes[^fn_28b_30] a male leper as regards his sources,[^fn_28b_31] 'or a woman'[^fn_28b_26] includes a female leper as regards her sources.[^fn_28b_32] But is not that text[^fn_28b_33] also required \[for a deduction that the injunction[^fn_28b_34] applies only\] to that which may attain cleanness in a ritual bath,[^fn_28b_35] thus excluding an earthenware vessel;[^fn_28b_36] so R. Jose?[^fn_28b_37] — If so[^fn_28b_38] the All Merciful should have written, 'man'.[^fn_28b_39] And should you retort that if the All Merciful had only written 'man' it might have been presumed that a metal vessel need not be sent out[^fn_28b_40] \[it may be pointed out that this[^fn_28b_41] could have been\] deduced from Whatsoever[^fn_28b_42] is unclean by the dead,[^fn_28b_43] what need then was there for the specification of 'male and female'? Obviously to deduce the same ruling as Rab did. Might it not then be suggested that the entire text served the same purpose as that to which Rab applied it?[^fn_28b_44] — If that were the case[^fn_28b_45] it should have been written, 'male and female' why then the expression 'both male and female'?[^fn_28b_46] 'Both'[^fn_28b_47] consequently includes all objects that attain cleanness in a ritual bath. But if so,[^fn_28b_48] even if he[^fn_28b_49] became unclean through any other cause of uncleanness,[^fn_28b_50] he should not be sent out, should he?[^fn_28b_51] — Scripture said, 'from[^fn_28b_52] male' \[implying that the text deals only with\] an uncleanness that is discharged from the male.[^fn_28b_53] Does, however, any Scriptural expression of 'both male and female' serve to exclude the *tumtum* and the androginos? Surely in the case of valuations it is written, 'The male',[^fn_28b_54] and it was taught: 'The male'[^fn_28b_54] but no *tumtum* or androginos. As it might have been presumed that he is not subject to the valuation of a man but is subject to that of a woman it was explicitly stated. 'The male[^fn_28b_55]  … And if it be a female'[^fn_28b_56] implying:[^fn_28b_57] Only a confirmed male and a confirmed female[^fn_28b_58] but no *tumtum* or androginos.[^fn_28b_59] Is not then the reason \[for the exclusion\][^fn_28b_60] that it was written, 'The male[^fn_28b_55]  … And if it be a female',[^fn_28b_56] but from the expression of 'male and female' alone neither[^fn_28b_61] could have been excluded?[^fn_28b_62] — That text[^fn_28b_63] is required [pg 29a]

to indicate a distinction between the valuation of a man and the valuation of a woman.[^fn_29a_1]

IF THE EMBRYO ISSUED IN PIECES OR IN A REVERSED CONDITION etc. R. Eleazar ruled: Even if the head was with them;[^fn_29a_2] but R. Johanan ruled: This[^fn_29a_3] was learnt only in a case where the head was not with them but where the head was with them the embryo is deemed born.[^fn_29a_4] May it be suggested that they[^fn_29a_5] differ on a principle of Samuel for Samuel has laid down: The head[^fn_29a_6] does not exempt[^fn_29a_7] in the case of miscarriages?[^fn_29a_8] — Where it[^fn_29a_9] is whole there is no difference of opinion whatever;[^fn_29a_10] they only differ in a case where it[^fn_29a_9] issued in pieces, one Master[^fn_29a_11] holding the opinion that the head is of importance[^fn_29a_12] only where the miscarriage is whole but where it is in pieces it is of no importance, while the other Master[^fn_29a_13] holds that even where it[^fn_29a_9] is in pieces the head is of importance.[^fn_29a_9] There[^fn_29a_15] are some who teach this passage as an independent discussion:[^fn_29a_16] R. Eleazar ruled, The head[^fn_29a_17] has not the status of the greater part of the limbs[^fn_29a_18] but R. Johanan ruled: The head has the same status as the greater part of the limbs. They thus differ on the validity of Samuel's principle.[^fn_29a_19]

We learnt: IF THE EMBRYO ISSUED IN PIECES OR IN A REVERSED POSITION IT IS DEEMED BORN AS SOON AS ITS GREATER PART ISSUED FORTH. Now since 'OR[^fn_29a_20] IN A REVERSED POSITION' was specifically stated it follows that 'IN PIECES' refers to one that issued in a normal position,[^fn_29a_21] and yet it was stated, IT IS DEEMED BORN AS SOON AS ITS GREATER PART ISSUED. Does not this then present an objection against R. Johanan? — R. Johanan can answer you: Read, ISSUED IN PIECES and IN A REVERSED POSITION. But was it not stated 'OR'?[^fn_29a_22] It is this that was meant: IF THE EMBRYO ISSUED IN PIECES OR whole, but in either case, IN A REVERSED POSITION, IT IS DEEMED BORN AS SOON AS ITS GREATER PART ISSUED FORTH. R. Papa stated, \[This[^fn_29a_23] is\] a matter of dispute between the following Tannas: 'If an embryo issued in pieces or in a reversed position it is deemed born as soon as its greater part issued forth. R. Jose ruled: Only when it issued in the normal way'. What does he[^fn_29a_24] mean? — R. Papa replied: It is this that was meant:[^fn_29a_25] If the embryo issued in pieces and in a reversed position[^fn_29a_26] it is deemed born as soon as its greater part issued forth, but \[it follows\] if it issued in the normal way[^fn_29a_21] the head alone[^fn_29a_27] causes exemption.[^fn_29a_28] R. Jose ruled: Only where its greater part issued in the normal manner.[^fn_29a_29] R. Zebid demurred:[^fn_29a_30] Thus it follows[^fn_29a_31] that where the embryo issued in a reversed position[^fn_29a_32] even the issue of its greater part causes no exemption,[^fn_29a_31] but surely, have we not an established rule that the greater part[^fn_29a_33] counts as the whole? Rather, said R. Zebid, it is this that was meant:[^fn_29a_34] If the embryo issued in pieces and in a reversed position it is deemed born as soon as its greater part issued forth, but \[it follows\] if it issued in the normal way the head alone causes exemption.[^fn_29a_28] R. Jose[^fn_29a_35] ruled: Only[^fn_29a_36] where it issued in the normal manner in a condition of viability.[^fn_29a_37] So it was also taught: If the embryo issued in pieces and[^fn_29a_38] in a reversed position it is deemed born as soon as its greater part issued forth, but, it follows, if it issued in the normal way the head alone causes exemption. R. Jose ruled: Only when it issued in the normal manner in a condition of viability. And what is 'the normal manner in a condition of viability'? The issue[^fn_29a_39] of the greater part of its head. And what is meant by 'the greater part of its head'? R. Jose[^fn_29a_40] said: The issue of its temples. Abba Hanan citing R. Joshua said: The issue of its forehead; and some say: The appearance[^fn_29a_41] of the corners of its head.[^fn_29a_42]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN ABORTED AND[^fn_29a_43] IT IS UNKNOWN WHAT WAS \[THE SEX OF THE EMBRYO\] SHE MUST CONTINUE \[HER PERIODS OF UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR BOTH A MALE CHILD[^fn_29a_44] AND A FEMALE CHILD.[^fn_29a_45] IF IT IS UNKNOWN WHETHER IT WAS A CHILD OR NOT, SHE MUST CONTINUE \[HER PERIODS OF CLEANNESS AND UNCLEANNESS AS\] FOR A MALE AND A FEMALE[^fn_29a_46] AND AS A MENSTRUANT.[^fn_29a_47] {¶=3.5}

***GEMARA***. R. Joshua b. Levi ruled: If a woman crossed a river and miscarried in it, she[^fn_29a_48] must bring a sacrifice which may 'be eaten, since we are guided by the nature of[^fn_29a_49] the majority of women and the majority of women bear normal children.

We learnt: IF IT IS UNKNOWN WHETHER IT WAS A CHILD OR NOT, SHE MUST CONTINUE \[HER PERIODS OF CLEANNESS AND UNCLEANNESS AS\] FOR A MALE AND A FEMALE AND AS A MENSTRUANT. But[^fn_29a_50] why should she continue as a menstruant. Why should it not be said, 'Be guided by the nature of the majority of women and the majority of women bear normal children'.[^fn_29a_51] — Our Mishnah deals with a case where there was no presumption of the existence of an embryo,[^fn_29a_52] while R. Joshua b. Levi spoke of one where there was such presumption.

Come and hear: 'If a beast went out[^fn_29a_53] full[^fn_29a_54] and returned[^fn_29a_55] empty, the young that is born subsequently is deemed to be a firstling of a doubtful nature'.[^fn_29a_56] But[^fn_29a_50] why \[should its nature be a matter of doubt\]? \[Why not\] be guided by the majority of beasts and, since the majority of beasts bear normal young, this one also[^fn_29a_57] must be an ordinary beast?[^fn_29a_58] — Rabina replied, Because it may be said: Most beasts bear young that are exempt from the law of the firstling[^fn_29a_59] and a minority of them bear young that are not exempt from the law of the firstling but all that bear secrete,[^fn_29a_60] and in the case of this beast, since it did not secrete, the majority rule has been impaired. If, however, all that bear secrete, must not the young, since this beast did not secrete, be a valid firstling?[^fn_29a_61] — Rather say: Most of those that bear secrete, and in the case of this beast, since it did not secrete, the majority rule is impaired.

When Rabin came[^fn_29a_62] he stated: 'R. Jose b. Hanina raised an objection[^fn_29a_63] \[from a Baraitha dealing with\] a forgetful woman,[^fn_29a_64] but I do not know what objection it was'. What was it? — It was taught: [pg 29b]

If a woman who departed in a condition of pregnancy[^fn_29b_1] and returned[^fn_29b_2] without child[^fn_29b_3] spent, within our cognizance,[^fn_29b_4] three clean weeks[^fn_29b_5] and another ten weeks which were alternately unclean[^fn_29b_6] and clean,[^fn_29b_7] she may perform her marital duty on the night preceding the thirty-fifth day[^fn_29b_8] and she is ordered to undergo ninety-five ritual immersions;[^fn_29b_9] so Beth Shammai. But Beth Hillel ruled: Thirty-five immersions.[^fn_29b_10] R. Jose son of R. Judah ruled: It suffices if one immersion is performed after the final \[period of uncleanness\]. Now[^fn_29b_11] one can well understand why the woman may not perform her marital duty during the first week,[^fn_29b_12] since she might be presumed to have given birth[^fn_29b_13] to a male child.[^fn_29b_14] During the second week she might be presumed to have given birth[^fn_29b_13] to a female child.[^fn_29b_15] During the third week she might be presumed to have given birth[^fn_29b_13] to a female child while she was in the condition of a zabah.[^fn_29b_16] But[^fn_29b_17] why should she[^fn_29b_18] not be permitted to perform her marital duty in the fourth week though she had observed a discharge of blood seeing that it is clean blood?[^fn_29b_19] Must it not then be admitted that the reason[^fn_29b_20] is because we are not guided here by the majority rule?[^fn_29b_21] — What then[^fn_29b_22] \[is the justification for the statement\] 'I do not know what objection it was'? — It might be presumed that her delivery took place a long time ago.[^fn_29b_23] But why should she not be allowed to perform her marital duty during the fifth week[^fn_29b_24] which[^fn_29b_25] is a clean one? — In the case of the fourth week[^fn_29b_26] every day might be regarded as being possibly the conclusion of \[the clean days prescribed for\] a childbirth and the beginning of the period of menstruation, so that the twenty-eighth day itself[^fn_29b_27] might be presumed to be the first day of the menstrual period and she must consequently continue \[her uncleanness for\] seven days in respect of her menstruation.[^fn_29b_28] But why should she not be permitted to perform her marital duty on the twenty-first day?[^fn_29b_29] — This[^fn_29b_30] is in agreement with the view of R. Simeon who ruled: It is forbidden to do so[^fn_29b_31] since, thereby, she[^fn_29b_32] might be involved in a doubtful uncleanness.[^fn_29b_33] But[^fn_29b_34] why should she not be permitted intercourse in the evening?[^fn_29b_35] — This is a case where she observed the discharge in the evening.[^fn_29b_36] 'And she is ordered to undergo ninety-five ritual immersions: During the first week[^fn_29b_37] she is ordered immersion every night, since it might be presumed that she gave birth[^fn_29b_38] to a male child.[^fn_29b_39] During the second week she is ordered immersion every night,[^fn_29b_40] since it might be presumed that she gave birth[^fn_29b_41] to a female child;[^fn_29b_39] and every day, since it might also be presumed that she gave birth to a male child while she was in a condition of *zibah*.[^fn_29b_42] During the third week she is ordered immersion every day, since it might be presumed that she gave birth to a female child while she was in a state of *zibah*;[^fn_29b_43] and every night, because Beth Shammai follow the view they expressed elsewhere that one who performed immersion on a long day[^fn_29b_44] must again perform immersion \[at its conclusion\].[^fn_29b_45] [pg 30a]

Consider! How many[^fn_30a_1] are the days of cleanness?[^fn_30a_2] Sixty-six.[^fn_30a_3] Deduct[^fn_30a_4] the third week[^fn_30a_5] in which the woman was required to perform \[nightly\] immersions[^fn_30a_6] there remain sixty minus one. Now, sixty minus one and thirty-five[^fn_30a_7] are ninety-four, how then is the number of ninety-five obtained?[^fn_30a_8] — R. Jeremiah of Difti replied: This is a case, for instance, where the woman[^fn_30a_9] made her appearance before us at twilight,[^fn_30a_10] so that[^fn_30a_11] we impose upon her an additional immersion.[^fn_30a_12] According to Beth Hillel, however, who maintain that one who performed immersion on a long day[^fn_30a_13] requires no immersion \[at the conclusion\][^fn_30a_14] how is the number thirty-five obtained?[^fn_30a_8] — Twenty-eight, as has been explained,[^fn_30a_15] while during the fifth week we require the woman to undergo immersion every night, since[^fn_30a_16] it might be assumed \[that each day[^fn_30a_17] is the\] last of the days of her menstruation.[^fn_30a_18] What need was there for the mention of ten weeks[^fn_30a_19] seeing that eight and a half[^fn_30a_20] would suffice?[^fn_30a_21] — Since he had to mention half a week he mentioned all of it, and since he had to mention an unclean week[^fn_30a_22] he also mentioned a clean one.[^fn_30a_23] But are there \[not also the additional\] immersions[^fn_30a_24] due to the possibility of the woman's being a zabah?[^fn_30a_25] They[^fn_30a_26] only count the immersions before intercourse[^fn_30a_27] but not those that follow. But according to Beth Shammai who[^fn_30a_28] count also the immersions that follow intercourse, why was no mention made of the immersions that are due to the possibility of the woman's being a zabah? — They[^fn_30a_29] only deal with immersions that are occasioned by childbirth but do not discuss those that are due to *zibah*. Is there then \[no mention of the possibility that the woman might have\] given birth to a child while she was in a condition of *zibah*?[^fn_30a_30] — They do take note of the 'possibility of a birth in a condition of *zibah*, but no note is taken of *zibah* alone. Why should not the woman perform immersion in the day-time of each of the days of the first week after she appeared before us, seeing that it is possible that her counting[^fn_30a_31] ended on that day?[^fn_30a_32] — This is in agreement with[^fn_30a_33] R. Akiba who ruled: It is required that the counting[^fn_30a_31] shall take place within our cognizance.[^fn_30a_34] But why should she not perform immersion at the end of the first week?[^fn_30a_35] — They do not discuss one day of a week. But why should she not perform immersion on the first day she comes to us, seeing that it is possible that she is awaiting a day for a day?[^fn_30a_36] — They deal with a major zabah[^fn_30a_37] but not with a minor one.[^fn_30a_38] Three rulings may thus be inferred: It may be inferred that it was R. Akiba who ruled that the counting[^fn_30a_39] must take place within our cognizance; and it may be inferred that it was R. Simeon who stated, 'The Sages have truly laid down that it is forbidden to do so since thereby she might be involved in a doubtful uncleanness';[^fn_30a_40] and it may also be inferred that it is a religious duty to perform immersion at the proper time.[^fn_30a_41] R. Jose son of R. Judah, however, ruled: It suffices if one immersion is performed after the final \[period of uncleanness\], and we do not uphold the view that it is a religious act to perform immersion at the proper time.[^fn_30a_41]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN MISCARRIED ON THE FORTIETH DAY,[^fn_30a_42] SHE NEED NOT TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THE POSSIBILITY OF A VALID CHILDBIRTH; BUT IF ON THE FORTY-FIRST DAY,[^fn_30a_42] SHE MUST CONTINUE \[HER PERIODS OF UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR BOTH A MALE AND A FEMALE[^fn_30a_43] AND AS FOR A MENSTRUANT.[^fn_30a_44] R. ISHMAEL RULED: \[IF SHE MISCARRIED ON\] THE FORTY-FIRST DAY[^fn_30a_42] SHE CONTINUES \[HER PERIODS OF UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR A MALE[^fn_30a_45] AND AS FOR A MENSTRUANT, BUT IF ON THE EIGHTY-FIRST DAY SHE MUST CONTINUE \[THESE PERIODS AS\] FOR A MALE AND A FEMALE AND A MENSTRUANT; BECAUSE A MALE IS FULLY FASHIONED[^fn_30a_46] ON THE FORTY-FIRST DAY AND A FEMALE ON THE EIGHTY-FIRST DAY. THE SAGES, HOWEVER, MAINTAIN THAT BOTH THE FASHIONING[^fn_30a_47] OF THE MALE AND THE FASHIONING[^fn_30a_47] OF THE FEMALE TAKE THE SAME COURSE, EACH LASTING FORTY-ONE DAYS. {¶=3.6}

***GEMARA***. Why was MALE mentioned?[^fn_30a_48] If in respect of the days of uncleanness, FEMALE was mentioned;[^fn_30a_49] and if in respect of the days of cleanness,[^fn_30a_50] [pg 30b]

was not menstruant mentioned?[^fn_30b_1] — In order that if the woman observed a discharge on the thirty-fourth day[^fn_30b_2] and then observed one on the forty-first day[^fn_30b_3] she[^fn_30b_4] shall remain unclean[^fn_30b_5] until the forty-eighth day.[^fn_30b_6] And so also in respect \[of the possible birth of\] a female[^fn_30b_7] \[the last word had to be mentioned\] so that if she observed any blood on the seventy-fourth day and these again on the eighty-first day she shall remain unclean until the eighty-eighth day.[^fn_30b_8]

R. ISHMAEL RULED: \[IF SHE MISCARRIED ON\] THE FORTY-FIRST DAY SHE CONTINUES \[HER PERIODS OF UNCLEANNESS AND CLEANNESS AS\] FOR A MALE AND AS FOR A MENSTRUANT etc. It was taught: R. Ishmael stated, Scripture prescribed uncleanness[^fn_30b_9] and cleanness[^fn_30b_10] in respect of a male[^fn_30b_11] and it also prescribed uncleanness[^fn_30b_12] and cleanness[^fn_30b_13] in respect of a female,[^fn_30b_14] as in the case of the former[^fn_30b_15] his fashioning period[^fn_30b_16] corresponds to his unclean and clean periods[^fn_30b_17] so also in the case of the latter[^fn_30b_18] her fashioning period[^fn_30b_19] corresponds to her unclean and clean periods.[^fn_30b_17] They[^fn_30b_20] replied: The duration of the fashioning period cannot be derived from that of uncleanness. Furthermore, they said to R. Ishmael, A story is told of Cleopatra the queen of Alexandria[^fn_30b_21] that when her handmaids were sentenced to death by royal decree they[^fn_30b_22] were subjected to a test[^fn_30b_23] and it was found that both \[a male and a female embryo\] were fully fashioned on the forty-first day. He replied: I bring you proof from the Torah and you bring proof from some fools! But what was his 'proof from the Torah'? If it was the argument, 'Scripture prescribed uncleanness and cleanness in respect of a male and it also prescribed uncleanness and cleanness in respect of a female etc.', have they not already replied, 'The duration of the fashioning period cannot be derived from that of uncleanness'? — The Scriptural text says, She bear,[^fn_30b_24] Scripture thus[^fn_30b_25] doubles the ante-natal period[^fn_30b_26] in the case of a female.[^fn_30b_27] But why \[should the test spoken of by the Rabbis be described as\] 'proof from some fools'? — It might be suggested that the conception of the female preceded that of the male by forty days.[^fn_30b_28] And the Rabbis?[^fn_30b_29] — They[^fn_30b_30] were made to drink[^fn_30b_31] a scattering drug[^fn_30b_32] And R. Ishmael?[^fn_30b_33] — Some constitution is insusceptible[^fn_30b_34] to a drug.[^fn_30b_35] Then said R. Ishmael to them:[^fn_30b_36] A story is told of Cleopatra the Grecian[^fn_30b_37] queen that when her handmaids were sentenced to death under a government order they were subjected to a test and it was found that a male embryo was fully fashioned on the forty-first day[^fn_30b_38] and a female embryo on the eighty-first day. They replied: No one adduces proof from fools.
