What is the reason?[^fn_30b_39] — It is possible that the handmaid with the female delayed[^fn_30b_40] \[intercourse\] for forty days and that it was only then that conception occurred.[^fn_30b_41] And R. Ishmael?[^fn_30b_42] — They were placed in the charge of a warden.[^fn_30b_43] And the Rabbis?[^fn_30b_44] — There is no guardian against unchastity;[^fn_30b_45] and the warden himself might have intercourse with them. But[^fn_30b_46] is it not possible that if a surgical operation had been performed on the forty-first day the female embryo also might have been found in a fully fashioned condition like the male?[^fn_30b_47] — Abaye replied: They[^fn_30b_48] were equal as far as these distinguishing marks were concerned.[^fn_30b_49]

THE SAGES, HOWEVER, MAINTAIN THAT BOTH THE FASHIONING OF THE MALE AND THE FASHIONING OF THE FEMALE etc. Is not the ruling of the Sages identical with that of the first Tanna?[^fn_30b_50] And should you reply that the object[^fn_30b_51] was to indicate that the anonymous Mishnah represented the view of the Rabbis because when an individual is opposed by many the *halachah* is in agreement with the many, is not this[^fn_30b_52] obvious?[^fn_30b_53] — It might have been presumed that R. Ishmael's reason is acceptable since it is also supported by a Scriptural text,[^fn_30b_54] hence we were informed[^fn_30b_55] \[that the *halachah* is in agreement with the Sages\].[^fn_30b_56]

R. Simlai delivered the following discourse: What does an embryo resemble when it is in the bowels of its mother? Folded writing tablets.[^fn_30b_57] Its hands rest on its two temples respectively, its two elbows on its two legs and its two heels against its buttocks. Its head lies between its knees, its mouth is closed and its navel is open, and it eats what its mother eats and drinks what its mother drinks, but produces no excrements because otherwise it might kill its mother. As soon, however, as it sees the light[^fn_30b_58] the closed organ[^fn_30b_59] opens and the open one[^fn_30b_60] closes, for if that had not happened the embryo could not live even one single hour. A light burns above its head and it looks and sees from one end of the world to the other, as it is said, then his lamp shined above my head, and by His light I walked through darkness.[^fn_30b_61] And do not be astonished at this, for a person sleeping here[^fn_30b_62] might see a dream in Spain. And there is no time in which a man enjoys greater happiness than in those days,[^fn_30b_63] for it is said, O that I were as the months of old, as in the days when God watched over me;[^fn_30b_64] now which are the days' that make up 'months'[^fn_30b_65] and do not make up years? The months of pregnancy of course.[^fn_30b_66] It is also taught all the Torah from beginning to end,[^fn_30b_67] for it is said, And he taught me, and said unto me: 'Let thy heart hold fast my words, keep my commandments and live',[^fn_30b_68] and it is also said, When the converse of God was upon my tent.[^fn_30b_69] Why the addition of[^fn_30b_70] 'and it is also said'? — In case you might say that it was only the prophet who said that,[^fn_30b_71] come and hear 'when the converse of God was upon my tent.[^fn_30b_69] As soon as it, sees the light an angel approaches, slaps it on its mouth and causes it to forget all the Torah completely,[^fn_30b_67] as it is said, Sin coucheth at the door.[^fn_30b_72] It does not emerge from there before it is made to take an oath,[^fn_30b_73] as it is said, That unto Me every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear;[^fn_30b_74] 'That unto Me every knee shall bow' refers to the day of dying of which it is said All they that go down to the dust shall kneel before Him;[^fn_30b_75] 'Every tongue shall swear' refers to the day of birth of which it is said, He that hath clean hands, and a pure heart, who hath not taken My name[^fn_30b_76] in vain, and hath not sworn deceitfully.[^fn_30b_77] What is the nature of the oath that it is made to take? Be righteous, and be never wicked; and even if all the world tells you, You are righteous', consider yourself wicked.[^fn_30b_78] Always bear in mind[^fn_30b_79] that the Holy One, blessed be He, is pure, that his ministers are pure and that the soul which He gave you is pure; if you preserve it in purity, well and good, but if not, I will take it away from you. The school of R. Ishmael taught: This may be compared to the case of a priest who handled over some *terumah* to an 'am ha-arez and told him, 'If you preserve it under conditions of cleanness, well and good, but if not, I will burn it in your presence'. R. Eleazar [pg 31a]

observed: What is the Scriptural proof?[^fn_31a_1] From my mother's womb Thou art gozi.[^fn_31a_2] What is the proof that 'gozi' implies 'swearing'? — Because it is written, Swear \[gozi\] concerning thy naziriteship and cast away.[^fn_31a_3]

R. Eleazar further stated: What does an embryo resemble when it is in its mother's bowels? A nut floating in a bowl of water. Should someone put his finger upon it, it would sink on the one side or on the other.

Our Rabbis taught: During the first three months[^fn_31a_4] the embryo occupies the lowest chamber, during the middle ones it occupies the middle chamber and during the last months it occupies the uppermost chamber; and when its time to emerge arrives it turns over and then emerges, and this is the cause of the woman's pains.[^fn_31a_5] This also agrees with what was taught:[^fn_31a_6] The pains of a female birth are more intense than those of a male birth. R. Eleazar further observed, 'What is the Scriptural proof for this?[^fn_31a_7] When I was made in secret, and curiously wrought in the lowest parts of the earth;[^fn_31a_8] it does not say 'dwelt' but 'curiously wrought'.[^fn_31a_9] Why are the pains of a female birth greater than those of a male birth? — The female emerges in the position she assumes during intercourse and the male emerges in the position he assumes during intercourse. The former, therefore, turns her face upwards[^fn_31a_10] while the latter[^fn_31a_11] need not turn his face.

Our Rabbis taught: During the first three months[^fn_31a_4] marital intercourse is injurious to the woman and it is also injurious to the child. During the middle ones it is injurious to the woman but beneficial for the child. During the last months it is beneficial for both the woman and the child, since on account of it the child becomes well-formed and of strong vitality.

One taught: He who indulges in marital intercourse on the ninetieth day[^fn_31a_4] is as though he had shed blood. But whence could one know this?[^fn_31a_12] — Rather, said Abaye, one carries on marital intercourse in the usual manner and the Lord preserveth the simple.[^fn_31a_13]

Our Rabbis taught: There are three partners in man, the Holy One, blessed be He, his father and his mother. His father supplies the semen of the white substance out of which are formed the child's bones, sinews, nails, the brain in his head and the white in his eye; his mother supplies the semen of the red substance out of which is formed his skin, flesh, hair, blood[^fn_31a_14] and the black of his eye; and the Holy One, blessed be He, gives him the spirit and the breath,[^fn_31a_15] beauty of features, eyesight, the power of hearing[^fn_31a_16] and the ability to speak[^fn_31a_17] and to walk,[^fn_31a_18] understanding and discernment. When his time to depart from the world approaches the Holy One, blessed be He, takes away his share and leaves the shares of his father and his mother with them. R. Papa observed: It is this that people have in mind when they say, 'Shake off the salt[^fn_31a_19] and cast the flesh to the dog'.[^fn_31a_20]

R. Hinena b. Papa gave the following exposition: What is the purport of the Scriptural text, Who doeth great things past finding out,' yea, marvellous things without number?[^fn_31a_21] Come and see the contrast between the potency of the Holy One, blessed be He, and that of mortal man.[^fn_31a_22] A man might put his things[^fn_31a_23] in a skin bottle[^fn_31a_24] \[whose holes[^fn_31a_25] are\] tied up and whose orifice is turned upwards and yet it is doubtful whether \[the things\] would be preserved or not, whereas the Holy One, blessed be He, fashions the embryo in a woman's internal organ that is open and whose orifice is turned downwards and yet it is preserved. Another exposition: If a man puts his things on the scale of a balance, the heavier they are the lower the scale descends, whereas the Holy One, blessed be He, \[fashioned the woman in such a manner that\] the heavier the embryo the higher it rises.[^fn_31a_26]

R. Jose the Galilean gave the following exposition: What is the purport of the Scriptural text, I will give thanks unto Thee, for I am fearfully and wonderfully made; wonderful are Thy works; and that my soul knoweth right well?[^fn_31a_27] Come and see the contrast between the potency of the Holy One, blessed be He, and that of mortal man.[^fn_31a_28] If a man[^fn_31a_29] puts different seeds in a bed each grows in the manner of its own particular species, whereas the Holy One, blessed be He, fashions the embryo in the woman's bowels in such a manner that all[^fn_31a_30] grow into one and the same kind. Another exposition: If a dyer puts different ingredients into a boiler they all unite into one colour, whereas the Holy One, blessed be He, fashions the embryo in a woman's bowels in a manner that each element develops in its own natural way.[^fn_31a_31]

R. Joseph gave the following exposition: What is the purport of the Scriptural text, I will give thanks unto Thee, O Lord; for though Thou wast angry with me, Thine anger is turned away, and Thou comfortest me.[^fn_31a_32] The text alludes to[^fn_31a_33] two men who set out on a trading expedition when a thorn got into \[the foot of\] one of them who[^fn_31a_34] began to blaspheme and to revile. After a time, however, when he heard that his friend's ship had sunk into the sea he[^fn_31a_35] began to laud and praise. Hence it is written, 'Thine anger is turned away, and Thou comfortest me'. This is indeed in line with what R. Eleazar stated: What is implied by the Scriptural text, Who doeth wondrous things alone;[^fn_31a_36] and blessed be His glorious name for ever?[^fn_31a_37] Even the person for whom a miracle is performed[^fn_31a_38] is unaware of the miracle.[^fn_31a_39]

R. Hanina b. Papa made the following exposition: What is the implication of the Scriptural text, Thou measurest my going about and my lying down, and art acquainted with all my ways?[^fn_31a_40] It[^fn_31a_41] teaches that man is not fashioned from all the drop but only from its purest part. The school of R. Ishmael taught: This is analogous to the action of one who, winnowing[^fn_31a_42] in threshing floors, takes up the edible part and leaves the refuse. This is in agreement with an exposition of R. Abbahu. For R. Abbahu pointed out an incongruity: It is written, For Thou hast winnowed me from[^fn_31a_43] strength[^fn_31a_44] and it is also written,[^fn_31a_45] The God that girdeth me with strength![^fn_31a_46] David in effect said to the Holy One, blessed be He, 'Sovereign of the world, Thou hast winnowed me[^fn_31a_47] and Thou hast girded me with strength'.

R. Abbahu also gave this exposition: What is the implication of the Scriptural text, Who hath counted the dust of Jacob, or numbered the stock of Israel?[^fn_31a_48] It teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, sits and counts the stock of Israel. 'When \[He wonders\] will appear the drop from which a righteous man could be fashioned'? Moreover, it is for this reason that the eye of the wicked Balaam was blinded. He said, 'Would He who is pure and holy and whose ministers are pure and holy look upon such a thing?' His eye was forthwith blinded, for it is written, And the saying of the man whose eye is closed.[^fn_31a_49] This is in line with what R. Johanan stated: What is the implication of the Scriptural text, And he lay with her in that night?[^fn_31a_50] It teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, assisted in that matter. For it is said, Issachar is a large-boned ass;[^fn_31a_51] it is the ass[^fn_31a_52] that has caused[^fn_31a_53] the birth of Issachar.

R. Isaac citing R. Ammi[^fn_31a_54] stated: If the woman emits her semen first she bears a male child; if the man emits his semen first she bears a female child; for it is said, If a woman emits semen[^fn_31a_55] and bear a man-child.[^fn_31a_56]

Our Rabbis taught: At first it used to be said that 'if the woman emits her semen first she will bear a male, and if the man emits his semen first she will bear a female', but the Sages did not explain the reason, until R. Zadok came and explained it: These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore unto Jacob in Paddan-aram, with his daughter Dinah,[^fn_31a_57] Scripture thus ascribes the males to the females[^fn_31a_58] and the females to the males.[^fn_31a_59]

And the sons of Ulam were mighty men of valour, archers; and had many sons, and sons' sons.[^fn_31a_60] Now is it within the power of man to increase[^fn_31a_61] the number of 'sons and sons' sons'? But the fact is that because [pg 31b]

they contained themselves during intercourse[^fn_31b_1] in order that their wives should emit their semen first so that their children shall be males, Scripture attributes to them the same merit as if they had themselves caused the increase of the number of their sons and sons' sons. This explains what R. Kattina said, 'I could make all my children to be males'. Raba stated: One who desires all his children to be males should cohabit twice in succession.

R. Isaac citing R. Ammi[^fn_31b_2] further stated: A woman conceives only immediately before her menstrual period, for it is said, Behold I was brought forth in iniquity;[^fn_31b_3] but R. Johanan stated: A woman conceives only immediately after her ritual immersion, for it is said, And in cleansing[^fn_31b_4] did my mother conceive me.[^fn_31b_5] What is the proof that 'het'[^fn_31b_6] bears the meaning of cleansing? — Since it is written 'we-hitte[^fn_31b_7] the house'[^fn_31b_8] and this is translated,[^fn_31b_9] 'And so shall he cleanse the house'. And if you prefer I might reply: The proof is derived from the following: Purge[^fn_31b_10] me with hyssop and I shall be clean.[^fn_31b_11]

R. Isaac citing R. Ammi further stated: As soon as a male comes into the world peace comes into the world, for it is said, Send ye a gift[^fn_31b_12] for the ruler of the land[^fn_31b_13] \[and the Hebrew for\] male[^fn_31b_14] \[is composed of the consonants of the 'words for\] 'this is a gift'.[^fn_31b_15]

R. Isaac citing[^fn_31b_16] R. Ammi further stated: When a male comes into the world his provision comes with him, \[the Hebrew for\] male \[zakar, being composed of the consonants of the words for\] 'this is provision \[zeh kar\]', for it is written, And he prepared a great provision \[kera\] for them.[^fn_31b_17] A female has nothing with her, \[the Hebrew for\] female \[nekebah\] implying 'she comes with nothing' \[nekiyyah ba'ah\]. Unless she demands her food nothing is given to her, for it is written, Demand \[nakebah\][^fn_31b_18] from[^fn_31b_19] me thy wages and I will give it.[^fn_31b_20]

R. Simeon b. Yohai was asked by his disciples: Why did the Torah ordain that a woman after childbirth should bring a sacrifice? He replied: When she kneels in bearing she swears impetuously that she will have no intercourse with her husband. The Torah, therefore, ordained that she should bring a sacrifice. (R. Joseph demurred: Does she not[^fn_31b_21] act presumptuously[^fn_31b_22] in which case the absolution of the oath[^fn_31b_23] depends on her regretting it?[^fn_31b_24] Furthermore, she should[^fn_31b_25] have brought a sacrifice prescribed for an oath!)[^fn_31b_26] And why did the Torah ordain that in the case of a male \[the woman is clean\] after seven days and in that of a female after fourteen days? \[On the birth of a\] male with whom all rejoice she regrets her oath after seven days, \[but on the birth of a female\] about whom everybody is upset she regrets her oath after fourteen days. And why did the Torah ordain circumcision on the eighth day?[^fn_31b_27] In order that the guests[^fn_31b_28] shall not enjoy themselves[^fn_31b_29] while his father and mother are not in the mood for it.[^fn_31b_30]

It was taught: R. Meir used to say, Why did the Torah ordain that the uncleanness of menstruation should continue for seven days? Because being in constant contact with his wife[^fn_31b_31] \[a husband might\] develop a loathing towards her. The Torah, therefore, ordained: Let her[^fn_31b_32] be unclean for seven days[^fn_31b_33] in order that[^fn_31b_34] she shall be beloved by her husband as at the time of her first entry into the bridal chamber.

R. Dostai son of R. Jannai was asked by his disciples: Why[^fn_31b_35] does a man go in search of a woman and no woman goes in search of a man? This is analogous to the case of a man who lost something. Who goes in search of what? He who lost the thing goes in search of what he lost.[^fn_31b_36] And why does the man lie face downwards and the woman face upwards towards the man? He \[faces the elements\] from which he was created[^fn_31b_37] and she \[faces the man\] from whom she was created.[^fn_31b_38] And why is a man easily pacified and a woman is not easily pacified? He \[derives his nature\] from the place from which he was created[^fn_31b_39] and she \[derives hers\] from the place from which she was created.[^fn_31b_40] Why is a woman's voice sweet and a man's voice is not sweet? He \[derives his\] from the place from which he was created[^fn_31b_41] and she \[derives hers\] from the place from which she was created.[^fn_31b_42] Thus it is said, For sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.[^fn_31b_43]

## CHAPTER IV

***MISHNAH***. THE DAUGHTERS OF THE SAMARITANS[^fn_31b_44] ARE REGARDED AS MENSTRUANTS FROM THEIR CRADLE;[^fn_31b_45] AND THE SAMARITANS IMPART UNCLEANNESS TO A COUCH UNDERNEATH AS TO A COVER ABOVE,[^fn_31b_45] SINCE THEY COHABIT WITH MENSTRUANTS BECAUSE \[THEIR WIVES\] CONTINUE \[UNCLEAN FOR SEVEN DAYS\] ON ACCOUNT OF A DISCHARGE OF ANY BLOOD.[^fn_31b_46] ON ACCOUNT OF THEIR \[UNCLEANNESS,\][^fn_31b_47] HOWEVER, NO OBLIGATION[^fn_31b_48] IS INCURRED FOR ENTRANCE INTO THE TEMPLE NOR IS *TERUMAH*[^fn_31b_49] BURNT ON THEIR ACCOUNT, SINCE THEIR UNCLEANNESS[^fn_31b_50] IS ONLY OF A DOUBTFUL NATURE.[^fn_31b_51] {¶=4.1}

***GEMARA***. How is this[^fn_31b_52] to be imagined? If they[^fn_31b_53] observed a discharge, then[^fn_31b_54] even our daughters also \[should in such circumstances be regarded as unclean\]; and if they[^fn_31b_55] have not observed any discharge, their daughters also should not be regarded as unclean, should they? — Raba son of R. Aha son of R. Huna citing R. Shesheth replied: Here we are dealing with cases of which nothing definite is known, but since a minority exists that experience discharges, the possibility of such a discharge is taken into consideration. And who is the Tanna that[^fn_31b_56] takes a minority into consideration? [pg 32a]

— It is R. Meir. For it was taught: A minor, whether male or female, may neither perform, nor submit to *halizah*, nor contract levirate marriage; so R. Meir. They[^fn_32a_1] said to R. Meir: You spoke well when you ruled that they 'may neither perform, nor submit to halizah', since in the Pentateuchal section[^fn_32a_2] man[^fn_32a_3] was written, and we draw a comparison between woman and man.[^fn_32a_4] What, however, is the reason why they may not contract levirate marriage? He replied: Because a minor male might be found to be a saris;[^fn_32a_5] a minor female might be found to be incapable of procreation;[^fn_32a_6] and thus the law of incest[^fn_32a_7] would be violated where no religious act[^fn_32a_8] is thereby performed. And the Rabbis?[^fn_32a_9] — Follow the majority of minor males and the majority of minors are no sarisim; follow the majority of minor females, and the majority of minor females are not incapable of procreation.[^fn_32a_10] Might it not be suggested that R. Meir was heard \[to take a minority into consideration only where that\] minority is frequent; was he, however, heard \[to maintain his view in regard to\] an infrequent minority? — This also is a frequent minority, for it was taught: R. Jose stated, It happened at 'En Bol[^fn_32a_11] that the infant was made to undergo ritual immersion[^fn_32a_12] before her mother;[^fn_32a_13] and Rabbi stated, It once happened at Beth She'arim that the infant was made to undergo ritual immersion[^fn_32a_12] before her mother;[^fn_32a_13] and R. Joseph stated, It once happened at Pumbeditha that the infant was made to undergo ritual immersion[^fn_32a_12] before her mother;[^fn_32a_13] One can well understand the incidents spoken of by R. Joseph and Rabbi[^fn_32a_14] since \[immersion was necessary as a protection for\] the *terumah*[^fn_32a_15] of Palestine; but why was that necessary[^fn_32a_16] in the case spoken of by R. Joseph,[^fn_32a_17] seeing that Samuel had laid down: The *terumah* of a country outside the Land of Israel is not forbidden unless \[it came in contact\] with a person whose uncleanness emanated from his body,[^fn_32a_18] and this applies only to eating but not to contact?[^fn_32a_19] — Mar Zutra replied: This[^fn_32a_20] was required only in regard to anointing her with the oil of *terumah*;[^fn_32a_21] for it was taught: And they shall not profane the holy things of the children of Israel, which they set apart unto the Lord[^fn_32a_22] includes[^fn_32a_23] one who anoints oneself or drinks.[^fn_32a_24] But what need was there for a Scriptural text \[for inclusion in the prohibition of\] one who drinks, seeing that drinking is included in eating?[^fn_32a_25] — Rather \[say that the text[^fn_32a_22] was intended\] to include one who anoints oneself \[in the same prohibition\] as one who drinks.[^fn_32a_26] And if you prefer I might reply, The prohibition[^fn_32a_27] is derived from here: And it is come into his inward parts like water, and like oil into his bones.[^fn_32a_28] But if so[^fn_32a_29] should not our daughters also \[be unclean from their cradle\]? — For us who make a deduction of the use of 'and if a woman'[^fn_32a_30] instead of 'a woman' and \[our daughters,\] when observing any discharge are kept away,[^fn_32a_31] the Rabbis enacted no preventive measure; but as regards the Samaritans[^fn_32a_32] who do not make any deduction from the use of 'and if a woman'[^fn_32a_30] instead of 'a woman', and \[their daughters\] when observing any discharge are not kept away,[^fn_32a_31] the Rabbis enacted the preventive measure. What is the exposition of 'a woman', 'and if a woman'? — It was taught: \[If it had been written,\][^fn_32a_33] 'A woman', I would only know that a woman \[is subject to the restrictions of menstrual uncleanness\], whence could it be deduced that an infant one day old is also subject to the restrictions of menstruation? Hence it was explicitly stated, 'And if a woman'.[^fn_32a_33] Thus it is evident that in including a child Scripture included even one who is one day old. May not, however, an incongruity be pointed out: \[If Scripture had only written,\][^fn_32a_34] 'the woman' I would only know \[that the restriction applies to\] a woman, whence could it be derived that a child who is three years and one day old \[is equally under the restrictions\] in respect of cohabition? Hence it was explicitly stated, 'The woman also'?[^fn_32a_34] — Raba replied: These[^fn_32a_35] are traditional laws but the Rabbis tacked them on to Scriptural texts. Which one \[can be deduced from\] the Scriptural text and which is only a traditional law?[^fn_32a_36] If it be suggested that the law relating to an infant one day old is traditional and that the one relating to such as is three years and one day old is deduced from a Scriptural text, is not the text \[it may be retorted\] written in general terms?[^fn_32a_37] — Rather say: The law relating to one who is three years and one day old is traditional and the one derived from the text is that concerning an infant who is one day old. But since the former law is traditional, what was the purpose of the Scriptural text?[^fn_32a_38] [pg 32b]

— To exclude a man from the uncleanness of a red discharge.[^fn_32b_1] But consider the following Baraitha:[^fn_32b_2] From the term of 'woman'[^fn_32b_3] I would only infer that a woman \[is subject to the restriction of *zibah*\], whence, however, could it be deduced that a female child that is ten days old[^fn_32b_4] is also subject to the restrictions of *zibah*? Hence it was explicitly stated, And if a woman.[^fn_32b_3] Now, what need was there for this text,[^fn_32b_5] seeing that the law could have been inferred from that of menstruation?[^fn_32b_6] — It was necessary. For if the All Merciful had written the law in regard to a menstruant only it might have been presumed that it applied only to the menstruant, since even if she observed a discharge on one day only she must continue unclean for seven days, but not to a zabah for whom, if she observed a discharge[^fn_32b_7] on one day, it suffices to wait only one day corresponding to it;[^fn_32b_8] hence the necessity for the second text. Then why should not the All Merciful write the law in regard to a zabah and there would be no need to give it again in regard to a menstruant, since one knows that there can be no zabah unless she was previously a menstruant? — That is so indeed. Then what was the need for the Scriptural text?[^fn_32b_9] — To exclude a man from the uncleanness of a red discharge.[^fn_32b_10] But was he not already once excluded?[^fn_32b_11] — One text serves to exclude him from the uncleanness of a discharge of red semen and the other from that of blood.

The same law[^fn_32b_12] applies also to males. For it was taught:[^fn_32b_13] 'A man, a man',[^fn_32b_14] what need was there for the repetition of 'man'? To include a male child one day old who also is to be subject to the uncleanness of *zibah*; so R. Judah. R. Ishmael son of R. Johanan b. Beroka said: This[^fn_32b_15] is not necessary, for, surely, Scripture says, Whether it be a man or a woman,[^fn_32b_16] 'whether it be a man' implies any one who is man, whether adult or infant; 'or a woman' implies any one who is a female irrespective of whether she is adult or minor. If so, why was it expressly stated, 'a man, a man'?[^fn_32b_17] The Torah used an ordinary form of speech.[^fn_32b_18] Thus it is evident that in including a child Scripture included even an infant one day old. Does not, however, an incongruity arise: \[If Scripture had only written\][^fn_32b_19] 'a man' I would only know \[that the law applied to\] a man, whence could it be derived that it also applies to a child who is nine years and one day old? Hence it was explicitly stated, And a man?[^fn_32b_19] — Raba replied: These[^fn_32b_20] are traditional laws but the Rabbis found props for them in Scriptural texts. Which one is only a traditional law and which can be deduced from the Scriptural text? If it be suggested that the law relating to an infant one day old is traditional and that relating to a child who is nine years and one day old is deduced from a Scriptural text, is not the text \[it could be objected\] written in general terms?[^fn_32b_21] — Rather say: The law relating to a child who is nine years and one day old is traditional and the one relating to an infant one day old is derived from the Scriptural text. But, since the former is a traditional law, what was the purpose of the Scriptural text? — To exclude a woman from the uncleanness of a white discharge.

What need was there for Scripture to write \[an additional word[^fn_32b_22] and letter\][^fn_32b_23] as regards males and females respectively?[^fn_32b_24] — These were necessary. For if the All Merciful had written the law in respect of males only it might have been presumed that it applied to them alone since they become unclean by \[three\] observations[^fn_32b_25] \[on the same day\] as by \[three observations on three successive\] days,[^fn_32b_26] but not to females who do not become unclean by \[three\] observations \[on the same day\] as by \[three observations on three successive\] days. And if the All Merciful had written the law in respect of females alone, it might have been presumed to apply to them only, since they become unclean even if a discharge was due to a mishap but not to males who do not become unclean when a discharge is due to a mishap.[^fn_32b_27] \[The additional letters and words were, therefore,\] necessary.

THE SAMARITANS IMPART UNCLEANNESS TO A COUCH UNDERNEATH AS TO A COVER ABOVE, What is meant by A COUCH UNDERNEATH AS A COVER ABOVE? If it be suggested to mean that if there were ten spreads[^fn_32b_28] and he sat upon them they all become unclean, is not this \[it could be retorted\] obvious seeing that he exercised pressure upon them?[^fn_32b_29] — The meaning rather is that a couch underneath one who had intercourse with a menstruant is subject to the same law of uncleanness as the cover above a *zab*.[^fn_32b_30] As the cover above a *zab* imparts uncleanness to foods and drinks only so does the couch underneath one who had intercourse with a menstruant impart uncleanness to foods and drinks only. Whence is the law concerning the cover above a *zab* deduced? — From the Scriptural text, And whosoever toucheth any thing that was under him shall be unclean.[^fn_32b_31] For what could be the meaning of 'under him'? [pg 33a]

If it be suggested: Under the *zab* \[it could be objected: This\][^fn_33a_1] is derived from, And whosoever toucheth his bed.[^fn_33a_2] Consequently it must mean: Whosoever toucheth any thing under which the *zab* was';[^fn_33a_3] and this is[^fn_33a_4] the cover above the *zab*,[^fn_33a_5] Scripture[^fn_33a_6] segregated it from a grave uncleanness[^fn_33a_7] and transferred it to a lighter uncleanness in order to tell you that it imparts uncleanness to foods and drinks only.[^fn_33a_8] Might it not be suggested that Scripture segregated it from the grave uncleanness only in order that it shall not impart uncleanness to a man[^fn_33a_9] and thereby also impart uncleanness to his clothes, but that it does impart uncleanness to a man[^fn_33a_9] or to clothes?[^fn_33a_10] — Scripture said: Shall be unclean,[^fn_33a_11] which implies[^fn_33a_12] an uncleanness of a lighter character, And whence is the law concerning the couch beneath one who had intercourse with a menstruant deduced? — From what was taught: And her impurity be upon him.[^fn_33a_13] As it might have been presumed that he is released from his uncleanness as soon as he is released,[^fn_33a_14] it was explicitly stated, He shall be unclean seven days.[^fn_33a_13] Then why was it explicitly stated, 'And her impurity be upon him'? As it might have been presumed that he imparts no uncleanness to man or earthenware, it was explicitly stated, 'And her impurity be upon him',[^fn_33a_13] as she imparts uncleanness to man[^fn_33a_15] and to earthenware[^fn_33a_16] so does he impart uncleanness to man[^fn_33a_15] and earthenware.[^fn_33a_16] In case it might be suggested:[^fn_33a_17] As she causes a couch or a seat to become unclean so as to impart uncleanness to a man and thereby also impart uncleanness to his clothes, so does he also cause his couch and seat to impart uncleanness to man and thereby impart uncleanness to his clothes, it was explicitly stated: And every bed whereon he lieth shall be unclean.[^fn_33a_18] For[^fn_33a_19] it should not have been stated. 'and every bed on which he lieth shall be unclean', then why was it written, 'And every bed on which etc.'? Scripture has, thereby, segregated it from a grave uncleanness[^fn_33a_20] and transferred it to a lighter uncleanness, to tell you that it imparts uncleanness to foods and drinks only. R. Ahai demurred: Might it not be suggested that Scripture had segregated it from a grave uncleanness and transferred it to a lighter uncleanness only in order that it shall not impart uncleanness to a man and thereby also convey it to his clothes, but that it does impart uncleanness to a man[^fn_33a_21] or to clothes?[^fn_33a_22] — R. Assi replied: Shall be unclean[^fn_33a_23] implies[^fn_33a_24] an uncleanness of a lighter nature. Might it not be argued: 'And her impurity be upon him'[^fn_33a_18] is a generalization, 'and every bed'[^fn_33a_18] is a specification[^fn_33a_25] and, since the scope of a generalization when followed by a specialization already comprehended in it is limited by the thing specified, only[^fn_33a_26] a bed and a seat, but no other thing should convey uncleanness? — Abaye replied: 'He shall be unclean for seven days'[^fn_33a_18] makes a break in the context, so that this is a case of a generalization and a specification that are distant from one another and whenever a generalization and a specification are distant from one another the rule of generalization and specification does not apply. Raba replied: The rule[^fn_33a_27] in fact does apply, but the expression of 'and every'[^fn_33a_18] is an extension.[^fn_33a_28] R. Jacob demurred: Might it not be argued that he[^fn_33a_29] is[^fn_33a_30] subject to the same uncleanness as she in this respect: As in her case no distinction is made between her touch and her bed as regards the conveyance of uncleanness to a person and to his clothes, thus adopting the stricter course,[^fn_33a_31] so also in his case no distinction should be made between his touch and his bed as regards the conveyance of uncleanness to a person and to his clothes, the lenient course being adopted?[^fn_33a_32] — Raba replied:[^fn_33a_33] 'Upon him' implies: To put a load upon him.[^fn_33a_34]

SINCE THEY COHABIT WITH MENSTRUANTS etc. Do they all[^fn_33a_35] cohabit with menstruants? — R. Isaac of Magdala replied: This was learnt about married persons only.

BECAUSE \[THEIR WIVES\] CONTINUE \[UNCLEAN FOR SEVEN DAYS\] ON ACCOUNT OF A DISCHARGE OF ANY BLOOD etc. It was taught: R. Meir stated, If they continue \[unclean for seven days\] on account of a discharge of any blood,[^fn_33a_36] is not this[^fn_33a_37] rather an important safeguard for them? But the fact is that when they observe a discharge of red blood they treat it as supplementary to a previous discharge of yellow blood.[^fn_33a_38] Another explanation: She includes the day on which her discharge ceases[^fn_33a_39] in the number of the seven days.[^fn_33a_40] Rami b. Hama demurred: Why indeed should she not count it,[^fn_33a_41] and why should not we also count it,[^fn_33a_41] seeing that we have an established rule that part of a day is regarded as the whole of it? — Raba retorted: If so,[^fn_33a_42] how could it be possible for an emission of semen to cause the counting[^fn_33a_43] after a *zibah* to be void seeing that a part of the day is to be counted as the whole of it?[^fn_33a_44] If one had observed the discharge in the middle of the day the law might indeed be so,[^fn_33a_45] but here we might be dealing with one who observed the discharge near sunset?[^fn_33a_46] — Could it then definitely be assumed that[^fn_33a_47] the Scriptural text was written only \[in regard to a discharge\] near sunset? — Yes; you must indeed allow the text to be so explained, for it[^fn_33a_48] forces this interpretation upon itself.

Rami b. Hama enquired: If a woman[^fn_33a_49] ejected some semen;[^fn_33a_50] does she cause her counting[^fn_33a_51] after a *zibah* to be void? Is she regarded as one who observed an emission of semen and causes, therefore, the counting[^fn_33a_51] to be void [pg 33b]

or is she rather regarded as one who merely touched it and, therefore, she does not cause the counting to be void? — Raba replied, His error is as deep as his subtlety: Granted that she causes her counting to be void, how many days could be affected? Should it be suggested that the counting of all the seven days should be void \[it could be objected\]: Is it not enough that she is treated like the man who had the intercourse with her?[^fn_33b_1] Should it be suggested that she should cause the counting of one day to be void \[it could be retorted:\] Did not the All Merciful say, And after that she shall be clean,[^fn_33b_2] 'after' means after all of them, implying that no uncleanness[^fn_33b_3] may intervene between them? — But according to your view, how could a *zab* himself cause the counting of one day to be void seeing that the All Merciful said, He shall number to himself seven days for his cleansing.[^fn_33b_4] which implies that no uncleanness must intervene between them?[^fn_33b_5] What then have you to say in reply? That the meaning is that only the uncleanness of *zibah* must not intervene between them;[^fn_33b_6] well, here also it may be explained that the meaning is that only the uncleanness of *zibah* must not intervene between them.[^fn_33b_7]

ON ACCOUNT OF THEIR \[UNCLEANNESS\]. HOWEVER, NO OBLIGATION IS INCURRED FOR ENTRANCE INTO THE TEMPLE etc. R. Papa once visited Tuak[^fn_33b_8] when he remarked, 'If there lives a scholar in this place I would go and pay him my respects'.[^fn_33b_9] 'A scholar lives here', said an old woman to him, 'and his name is R. Samuel and he learns Tannaitic traditions. May it be God's will that you be like him'. 'Since', he thought. 'she blesses me by him I can gather[^fn_33b_10] that he is a God[^fn_33b_11]-fearing man'. He thereupon visited him when the latter treated him to[^fn_33b_12] a bull; and he also treated him to an incongruity[^fn_33b_13] between Tannaitic teachings: We have learnt, ON ACCOUNT OF THEIR \[UNCLEANNESS\]. HOWEVER, NO OBLIGATION IS INCURRED FOR ENTRANCE INTO THE TEMPLE NOR IS *TERUMAH* BURNT ON THEIR ACCOUNT, SINCE THEIR[^fn_33b_14] UNCLEANNESS IS ONLY OF A DOUBTFUL NATURE, from which it is evident that *terumah* is not burnt in a case of doubt. But have we not learnt to the contrary: In six doubtful cases of uncleanness is *terumah* burnt \[and one of them is\] the doubtful uncleanness of the clothes of an 'am ha-arez?[^fn_33b_15] — 'May it be God's will', exclaimed R. Papa, 'that this bull shall be eaten in peace:[^fn_33b_16] Here[^fn_33b_17] we are dealing with the case of a Samaritan who was a haber'.[^fn_33b_18] 'But would you presume[^fn_33b_19] \[the other retorted\] that a Samaritan who is a haber had intercourse with a menstruant?' When he left him[^fn_33b_20] and came to R. Shimi b. Ashi the latter said to him: Why did you not answer him \[that our Mishnah[^fn_33b_21] deals\] with the case of a Samaritan who, having performed ritual immersion, came up and trod upon the clothes[^fn_33b_22] of a haber and the clothes[^fn_33b_22] of this haber then came in contact with *terumah*,[^fn_33b_23] so that if \[the *terumah* were to be treated as unclean\] on account of the uncleanness of the 'am ha-arez \[it could be objected\]: He has, surely, performed ritual immersion.[^fn_33b_24] And if the uncleanness were to be attributed to his likely intercourse with a menstruant \[it could be objected\]: It is doubtful whether he had his intercourse recently or some time ago.[^fn_33b_25] And even if you were to find some ground for assuming that his intercourse took place recently there is still the doubt whether she had completed her period of cleanness for yellow blood or not.[^fn_33b_26] This then is a case of double doubt,[^fn_33b_27] and no *terumah* may be burnt on account of a doubly doubtful uncleanness. But why should not the uncleanness of the *terumah* be established[^fn_33b_28] on account of its contact with the clothes of an 'am ha-arez, a Master having stated: The clothes of an 'am ha-arez are like midras uncleanness[^fn_33b_29] to Pharisees?[^fn_33b_30] — The other replied: This is a case of a naked Samaritan.

***MISHNAH***. THE DAUGHTERS OF THE SADDUCEES, SO LONG AS THEY ARE IN THE HABIT OF WALKING IN THE PATHS OF THEIR FATHERS, ARE TO BE REGARDED AS SAMARITAN WOMEN. IF THEY LEFT THOSE PATHS[^fn_33b_31] TO WALK IN THE PATHS OF ISRAEL, THEY ARE TO BE REGARDED AS ISRAELITISH WOMEN. R. JOSE RULED: THEY ARE ALWAYS REGARDED AS ISRAELITISH WOMEN UNLESS THEY LEAVE THE PATHS OF ISRAEL TO WALK IN THE PATHS OF THEIR FATHERS. {¶=4.2}

***GEMARA***. The question was raised: What is the law[^fn_33b_32] where their attitude is unknown?[^fn_33b_33] — Come and hear: THE DAUGHTERS OF THE SADDUCEES, SO LONG AS THEY ARE IN THE HABIT OF WALKING IN THE PATHS OF THEIR FATHERS, ARE TO BE REGARDED AS SAMARITAN WOMEN; from which it follows that if their attitude is unknown they are like Israelitish women. Read then the final clause: IF THEY LEFT THESE PATHS TO WALK IN THE PATHS OF ISRAEL, THEY ARE TO BE REGARDED AS ISRAELITISH WOMEN; from which it follows that if their attitude is unknown they are like Samaritan women! But the fact is that no inference may be drawn from this \[Mishnah\].

Come and hear what we have learnt: R. JOSE RULED, THEY ARE ALWAYS REGARDED AS ISRAELITISH WOMEN UNLESS THEY LEAVE THE PATHS OF ISRAEL TO WALK IN THE PATHS OF THEIR FATHERS. Thus it follows that the first Tanna[^fn_33b_34] holds that when their attitude is unknown they are to be regarded as Samaritan women. This is conclusive.

Our Rabbis taught: It once happened that a Sadducee was conversing with a High Priest in the market place when some spittle was squirted from his mouth and fell on the clothes of the High Priest. The face of the High Priest[^fn_33b_35] turned yellow and he hurried to his[^fn_33b_36] wife[^fn_33b_37] who assured him that although they were wives of Sadducees they paid homage to the Pharisees and showed their blood to the Sages.[^fn_33b_38] R. Jose observed: We[^fn_33b_39] know them better than anybody else \[and can testify\] that they show their menstrual blood to the Sages. There was only one exception, a woman who lived in our neighbourhood who did not show her blood to the Sages but she died. But why was he[^fn_33b_40] not concerned about the uncleanness[^fn_33b_41] that is occasioned by the spittle of an 'am ha-arez?[^fn_33b_42] — Abaye replied: This was a case of a Sadducee who was a haber.[^fn_33b_43] Said Raba: Is a Sadducee who is a haber presumed[^fn_33b_44] to have intercourse with a menstruant? Rather, said Raba: [pg 34a]

The incident occurred during a festival and the uncleanness of an 'am ha-arez[^fn_34a_1] during a festival the Rabbis treated as clean; for it is written, So all the men of Israel were gathered again against the city, knit together[^fn_34a_2] as one man,[^fn_34a_3] the text thus treated them all[^fn_34a_4] as haberim.[^fn_34a_5]

***MISHNAH***. THE BLOOD[^fn_34a_6] OF AN IDOLATRESS AND THE CLEAN BLOOD[^fn_34a_7] OF A LEPROUS WOMAN, BETH SHAMMAI DECLARE CLEAN[^fn_34a_8] AND BETH HILLEL HOLD THAT IT IS LIKE HER SPITTLE OR HER URINE,[^fn_34a_9] THE BLOOD OF A WOMAN AFTER CHILDBIRTH WHO DID NOT[^fn_34a_10] UNDERGO RITUAL IMMERSION, BETH SHAMMAI RULED, IS LIKE HER SPITTLE OR HER URINE,[^fn_34a_9] BUT BETH HILLEL RULED: IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY, THEY[^fn_34a_11] AGREE, HOWEVER, THAT IF SHE GAVE BIRTH WHILE IN *ZIBAH*, IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY. {¶=4.3}

***GEMARA***. But do not Beth Shammai uphold the tradition: Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them, when any man hath an issue,[^fn_34a_12] only the children of Israel convey uncleanness by *zibah* and idolaters do not convey uncleanness by *zibah*, but a preventive measure has been enacted against them that they should be regarded as zabim in all respects?[^fn_34a_13] — Beth Shammai can answer you:[^fn_34a_14] How should it act? If it were to convey uncleanness both when wet and when dry, you would treat it as a Pentateuchal uncleanness.[^fn_34a_15] If it were to convey uncleanness only when wet and not when dry, you might also make the same distinction in a Pentateuchal uncleanness.[^fn_34a_16] If so, should not the same provision[^fn_34a_17] be made in the case of her spittle and her urine also?[^fn_34a_18] — Since a distinguishing rule has been laid down in regard to her blood[^fn_34a_19] it is sufficiently known that her spittle and her urine are only Rabbinically unclean. And why should no distinguishing rule be laid down in respect of her spittle or her urine while her blood should be ruled to be unclean? — Concerning her spittle and her urine, since they are frequently discharged, the Rabbis have enacted a preventive measure, but concerning her blood which is not frequently discharged the Rabbis have enacted no preventive measure.

Raba ruled: His[^fn_34a_20] discharge' in *zibah* is unclean[^fn_34a_21] even according to Beth Shammai[^fn_34a_22] and his discharge of semen is clean even according to Beth Hillel.[^fn_34a_23] 'His discharge in *zibah* is unclean even according to Beth Shammai' since a distinguishing rule[^fn_34a_24] can be made in connection with the discharge of his semen. 'His discharge of semen is clean even according to Beth Hillel', since the Rabbis have enacted a distinguishing rule[^fn_34a_24] in order that *terumah* or other holy things shall not be burnt on its account.[^fn_34a_25] But why should not the distinguishing rule be enacted in regard to his discharge in *zibah* while his discharge of semen should be declared unclean? — Concerning his discharge in *zibah* which is not dependent on an act of his the Rabbis have enacted a preventive measure, but concerning a discharge of his semen which does depend on an act of his[^fn_34a_26] the Rabbis enacted no preventive measure.

May it be suggested that the following provides support to his[^fn_34a_27] ruling: If an idolatress discharged the semen of an Israelite, it is unclean; but if the daughter of an Israelite discharged the semen of an idolater, it is clean.[^fn_34a_28] Now does not this mean that it is completely clean?[^fn_34a_29] — No; clean Pentateuchally but unclean Rabbinically. Come and hear: It thus follows[^fn_34a_30] that the semen of an Israelite is unclean everywhere, [pg 34b]

even in the bowels of an idolatress,[^fn_34b_1] while that of an idolater is clean everywhere, even in the bowels of an Israelitish woman, with the exception of any urine of hers that is mixed up with it.[^fn_34b_2] And should you argue that here also it is only Pentateuchally clean but unclean Rabbinically, \[it could be retorted:\] Does then her urine convey uncleanness Pentateuchally?[^fn_34b_3] Consequently it may be inferred that it[^fn_34b_4] is clean even Rabbinically. This is conclusive.

The Master said, 'The semen of an Israelite is unclean everywhere, even in the bowels of an idolatress'. May you not thereby solve a question of R. Papa; for R. Papa enquired. 'What is the law regarding the semen of an Israelite in the bowels of an idolatress?' \[Concerning a discharge\] within three days[^fn_34b_5] R. Papa raised no questions. His enquiry related only to one after three days.[^fn_34b_6] What, he asked, is the law? Is it only in the case of Israelites, who are anxious to observe the commandments, that their bodies engender heat and the semen decomposes[^fn_34b_7] but in the case of idolaters, who are not anxious to observe the commandments, their bodies engender no heat and their \[semen\] therefore does not decompose, or is it possible that on account of their consumption of forbidden animals and reptiles their bodies also engender heat and their semen also decomposes? — This remains undecided.

THE CLEAN BLOOD OF A LEPROUS WOMAN, BETH SHAMMAI etc. What is Beth Hillel's reason? — R. Isaac replied: 'Whether it be a man'[^fn_34b_8] includes[^fn_34b_9] a male leper as regards his sources;[^fn_34b_10] 'or a woman'[^fn_34b_8] includes[^fn_34b_9] a female leper as regards her sources. Now what could be meant by 'her sources'? If it be suggested: Her other sources[^fn_34b_11] \[the objection could be made that the uncleanness of these\] could be inferred from that of the male.[^fn_34b_12] The reference consequently must be to \[the uncleanness of\] her blood,[^fn_34b_13] to declare her 'CLEAN BLOOD' unclean. And Beth Shammai?[^fn_34b_14] — \[The uncleanness of\] a female could not be deduced from that of a male, for it can be objected: The position of the male is different[^fn_34b_15] since he is also required[^fn_34b_16] to uncover his head and to rend his clothes[^fn_34b_17] and he is also forbidden cohabitation; \[how then could his uncleanness\] be compared to that of a female[^fn_34b_18] who is not \[subject to his restrictions\]?[^fn_34b_19] And Beth Hillel?[^fn_34b_20] — The All Merciful could have written down the restrictions in regard to the female and there would have been no need to repeat them in regard to the male; for it could have been argued: If in the case of a female,[^fn_34b_18] who is not required to uncover her head or to rend her clothes and who is not forbidden cohabitation either, the All Merciful included her sources[^fn_34b_21] how much more then should this be the rule[^fn_34b_18] in the case of the male.[^fn_34b_22] Now since the text serves no purpose in regard to the male,[^fn_34b_23] apply it to the female; and since it can serve no purpose as far as her other sources[^fn_34b_24] are concerned,[^fn_34b_25] apply it to her blood, to declare her 'CLEAN BLOOD' unclean. And Beth Shammai?[^fn_34b_26] — The uncleanness of a male cannot be deduced from that of a female, for it can be objected: The position of a female is different,[^fn_34b_27] since she becomes unclean[^fn_34b_28] even as a result of a mishap; \[how then could her uncleanness\] be compared to that of a male who is not \[subject to such a restriction\]? And Beth Hillel?[^fn_34b_26] — The subject dealt with is the position of[^fn_34b_29] the leper, how can they raise an objection against it from that of the *zab*?[^fn_34b_30] And Beth Shammai?[^fn_34b_26] — They raise objections from any form of uncleanness. And if you prefer I might reply that Beth Shammai can answer you: The expression[^fn_34b_30] 'whether it be a man'[^fn_34b_31] is required for the following exposition: 'Whether it be a man' whosoever is a man irrespective of whether he is of age or only a minor.[^fn_34b_32] And Beth Hillel?[^fn_34b_33] — They derive this ruling from 'This is the law of him that hath an issue'[^fn_34b_34] which implies, whether he be of age or a minor.

R. Joseph stated: When R. Simeon b. Lakish discoursed on the *zab* he raised the following question.[^fn_34b_35] Does the first observation[^fn_34b_36] of a *zab* who was a minor convey uncleanness by contact? The All Merciful having said, This is the law of him that hath an issue and of him from whom the flow of seed goeth out,[^fn_34b_37] therefore only if his 'flow of seed' causes uncleanness does his first observation also cause uncleanness, but the minor,[^fn_34b_38] since his 'flow of seed' conveys no uncleanness, his first observation also conveys no uncleanness; or is it possible that it is unclean, since if he observed two discharges the two are combined?[^fn_34b_39] — Raba replied. Come and hear: This is the law of him that have an issue,[^fn_34b_37] implies, whether he is of age or a minor; as in the case of an adult a first observation conveys uncleanness so also in that of a minor a first observation conveys uncleanness.

R. Joseph enquired: Does the blood of a first observation of a leper convey uncleanness by contact? Is the place of the *zibah* a source and, therefore, conveys uncleanness,[^fn_34b_40] or is it possible that it is no source and, therefore, conveys no uncleanness?[^fn_34b_41] — Raba replied, Come and hear: His issue is unclean,[^fn_34b_42] this teaches concerning an issue of a *zab* that it is unclean.[^fn_34b_43] Now of what kind of person has this been said? If it be suggested: Of one who is only a *zab*[^fn_34b_44] [pg 35a]

\[the difficulty would arise:\] If it[^fn_35a_1] causes the uncleanness of others,[^fn_35a_2] is it not obvious that it causes that of the man himself?[^fn_35a_3] It is consequently obvious that this has been said of a *zab* who is a leper.[^fn_35a_4] And since a Scriptural text was required to include him in the category of uncleanness after a second observation,[^fn_35a_5] it may be inferred that the place of the *zibah* is no source.[^fn_35a_6] Said Rab Judah of Diskarta[^fn_35a_7] to Raba: What is the proof?[^fn_35a_8] Is it not still possible to maintain that the text deals with one who is only a *zab*;[^fn_35a_9] and as to your objection 'If it causes the uncleanness of others, is it not obvious that it causes that of the man himself?' \[It can be retorted:\] The case of the scapegoat[^fn_35a_10] proves \[the invalidity of your argument\], for it causes uncleanness to others[^fn_35a_11] while it is itself clean.[^fn_35a_12] Abaye observed: Why did he[^fn_35a_13] at all raise such a question, seeing that he himself stated, 'This is the law of him that hath an issue,[^fn_35a_14] implies, whether he is of age or a minor', and since this law[^fn_35a_15] has been deduced by him from that text,[^fn_35a_14] the expression of 'whether it be a man'[^fn_35a_16] remains free for the purpose of including a leper in regard to his source and 'or a woman' serves to include a female leper in regard to her sources; and the All Merciful has compared[^fn_35a_17] the leper to the confirmed *zab*:[^fn_35a_18] As the confirmed *zab* conveys uncleanness through carriage so does the first discharge of a leper convey uncleanness by carriage.

R. Huna ruled: The first observed discharge of a *zab* conveys uncleanness[^fn_35a_19] even in the case of a mishap; for it is said, This is the law of him that hath an issue, and of him from whom the flow of seed goeth out;[^fn_35a_14] as 'the flow of seed' conveys uncleanness even in the case of a mishap so does the first observed discharge of a *zab* convey uncleanness even in the case of a mishap. Come and hear: If he observed a first discharge, he must be examined.[^fn_35a_20] Is not this done to determine his[^fn_35a_21] uncleanness?[^fn_35a_22] — No; in regard to a sacrifice.[^fn_35a_23] Come and hear: At the second observation of a discharge he must be examined.[^fn_35a_20] Now for what purpose? If it be suggested: For that of a sacrifice but not for that of uncleanness[^fn_35a_24] \[it could be retorted:\] Apply here the Scriptural text 'out of his flesh'.[^fn_35a_25] which implies, but not as a result of a mishap.[^fn_35a_26] Consequently it must be for the purpose of uncleanness. And since the final clause refers to an examination in regard to uncleanness must not the first clause also refer to one for uncleanness?[^fn_35a_27] — What an argument! Each might refer to an examination for different purposes.[^fn_35a_28]

Come and hear: R. Eliezer ruled: Even at the third observation he must be examined on account of the sacrifice.' From which it follows, does it not, that the first Tanna requires it[^fn_35a_29] on account of the uncleanness?[^fn_35a_22] — No; all may require it[^fn_35a_29] on account of the sacrifice, but here they[^fn_35a_30] differ on the exposition of the eth[^fn_35a_31] particles. The Rabbis base no exposition on the eth particles and R. Eliezer does. 'The Rabbis base no exposition on the eth particles': 'He that hath an issue'[^fn_35a_32] represents one discharge, 'his issue'[^fn_35a_33] represents a second one; so far 'for the man';[^fn_35a_34] while at the third discharge the All Merciful compared him to the woman.[^fn_35a_35] 'And R. Eliezer does': 'He that hath an issue'[^fn_35a_36] represents one discharge, 'eth'[^fn_35a_37] represents a second one, 'his issue'[^fn_35a_38] represents a third one, while at the fourth discharge the All Merciful compared him to the woman.[^fn_35a_39]

Come and hear: R. Isaac said, A *zab*, surely, was included in the same law of uncleanness as one who emitted semen,[^fn_35a_40] why then was he excluded?[^fn_35a_41] In order to relax the law for him in one respect and to restrict it for him in another respect. 'To relax the law for him' in that he does not become unclean in case of a mishap; and to restrict it for him' [pg 35b]

in that he causes a couch and a seat to be unclean.[^fn_35b_1] Now when \[does this ruling apply\]? If it be suggested: When a second discharge was observed \[the objection would arise\]: How could he then be included in 'the same law of uncleanness as one who emitted semen'? It is consequently obvious \[that is was meant to apply\] when a first discharge was observed;[^fn_35b_2] and yet it was stated, was it not, 'To relax the law for him in that he does not become unclean in case of a mishap'?[^fn_35b_3] — But how do you understand this: 'To restrict it for him in that he causes a couch and a seat to be unclean'; is he capable[^fn_35b_4] after a first observation to cause a couch and a seat to be unclean? But the fact is that it is this that was meant: 'R. Isaac said, A *zab* after his first observation was surely included in the same law of uncleanness as one who emitted semen, why then was he in the case of a second observation excluded? In order to relax the law for him in one respect and to restrict it for him in another respect. "To relax the law for him" in that he does not become unclean in case of a mishap; "and to restrict it for him" in that he causes a couch and a bed to be unclean'.[^fn_35b_5]

R. Huna stated: The discharge of a *zab* resembles the dough water of barley. The discharge of the *zab* issues from dead flesh while semen issues from live flesh. The former is watery and resembles the white of a crushed egg while the latter is viscous and resembles the white of a sound egg.

THE BLOOD OF A WOMAN AFTER CHILDBIRTH WHO DID NOT UNDERGO RITUAL IMMERSION etc. It was taught: Beth Hillel said to Beth Shammai, Do you not agree that if a menstruant who did not undergo ritual Immersion observed some blood she is unclean?[^fn_35b_6] Said Beth Shammai to them: \[This is\] no \[comparison\]. If you apply this law[^fn_35b_7] to a menstruant who, even after she had undergone immersion, is unclean if she observed a discharge, would you also apply it to a woman after childbirth who, if she had undergone immersion and then observed a discharge, is clean? The former retorted: The case of one who gave birth during *zibah* proves our case; for if such a woman had undergone ritual immersion[^fn_35b_8] and observed a discharge after the counted days she is clean[^fn_35b_9] while if she did not undergo immersion and observed a discharge she is unclean. The latter replied: The same law[^fn_35b_10] applies,[^fn_35b_11] and this is our reply. This then implies that they[^fn_35b_12] are in disagreement.[^fn_35b_13] But have we not learnt: THEY[^fn_35b_12] AGREE, HOWEVER, THAT IF SHE GAVE BIRTH WHILE IN *ZIBAH*, IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY? — This is no difficulty, since the latter[^fn_35b_14] refers to one who already counted the prescribed days while the former[^fn_35b_15] refers to one who did not count them.[^fn_35b_16] And so it was also taught: If a woman who gave birth during *zibah* had counted the prescribed number of clean days but did not undergo ritual immersion and then observed a discharge. Beth Shammai gave their ruling[^fn_35b_17] in accordance with their own view[^fn_35b_18] and Beth Hillel ruled in accordance with their own view.[^fn_35b_19]

It was stated: Rab said, \[the blood discharge[^fn_35b_20] emanates[^fn_35b_21] from\] one and the same source; but it is the Torah that declared it unclean during one period[^fn_35b_22] and clean during another.[^fn_35b_23] Levi, however, said, It emanates from two different sources. When the unclean one is closed[^fn_35b_24] the clean one opens, and when the clean one closes,[^fn_35b_25] the unclean one opens. What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_35b_26] — The practical difference between them is the case of a continuous discharge from within the seven days into the period following these seven days, or from within the fourteen days into the period after the fourteenth, or from within the forty days to the period after the forty days or from within the eighty days into the period following eighty days. According to Rab the law is to be relaxed in the first case[^fn_35b_27] and restricted in the latter;[^fn_35b_28] but according to Levi the law is to be restricted in the first case[^fn_35b_29] and relaxed in the latter.[^fn_35b_30]

An objection was raised: THE BLOOD OF A WOMAN AFTER CHILDBIRTH WHO DID NOT UNDERGO RITUAL IMMERSION, BETH SHAMMAI RULED, IS LIKE HER SPITTLE AND HER URINE, BUT BETH HILLEL RULED: IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY, It was now presumed that this is a case where[^fn_35b_31] there was a break.[^fn_35b_32] This then is satisfactory according to Rab who said that the discharge emanates from one and the same source,[^fn_35b_33] for this reason it conveys uncleanness both when wet and dry.[^fn_35b_34] But according to Levi who said that it emanated from two different sources why[^fn_35b_35] should it convey uncleanness both when wet and when dry? — Levi can answer you: We are here dealing with the case of a woman whose discharge was continuous.[^fn_35b_36] But if the discharge was continuous, what is Beth Shammai's reason? — Beth Shammai are of the opinion that there exists only once source. According to Levi[^fn_35b_37] one can quite well see the point that divides Beth Shammai from Beth Hillel;[^fn_35b_38] but, according to Rab,[^fn_35b_39] what[^fn_35b_40] is the point that divides them?[^fn_35b_41] — The point that divides them in the question whether[^fn_35b_42] both the termination of the prescribed number of days and also ritual immersion are required; Beth Shammai holding that the All Merciful made the cleanness dependent on the days alone while Beth Hillel hold that[^fn_35b_43] it is dependent on both the days and immersion.[^fn_35b_44]

Come and hear: THEY AGREE, HOWEVER, THAT IF SHE GAVE BIRTH WHILE IN *ZIBAH*, IT CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY. It was now assumed that here also[^fn_35b_45] it is a case where there was a break.[^fn_35b_46] Now, according to Rab who stated that there exists only one source one can quite well see the reason why the discharge conveys UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY;[^fn_35b_47] but according to Levi who stated that the sources are two why does the discharge[^fn_35b_48] CONVEY UNCLEANNESS BOTH WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY?[^fn_35b_49] — He can answer you: Here also it is a case of a continuous discharge. But if the discharge was continuous, what was the need of stating the law?[^fn_35b_50] — It was necessary to state it for the sake of Beth Shammai: Although Beth Shammai maintain that there is only one source and that the All Merciful had ordained the uncleanness to be dependent entirely on the lapse of the prescribed number of days,[^fn_35b_51] this applies only to a woman in normal[^fn_35b_52] childbirth, the prescribed number of whose unclean days had passed,[^fn_35b_53] but not to a woman who gave birth in *zibah* who is required also to count seven clean days.[^fn_35b_54]

Come and hear: Her sickness shall be unclean[^fn_35b_55] includes[^fn_35b_56] the man who had intercourse with her;[^fn_35b_57] 'her sickness shall be unclean'[^fn_35b_55] includes[^fn_35b_58] the nights;[^fn_35b_59] 'her sickness shall she be unclean'[^fn_35b_60] includes[^fn_35b_58] a woman who gave birth while in *zibah* who remains in her uncleanness[^fn_35b_61] until seven clean days have passed.[^fn_35b_62] This[^fn_35b_63] is quite intelligible according to Rab who said that there exists only one source, since it is for this reason that she[^fn_35b_64] requires seven clean days,[^fn_35b_65] [pg 36a]

but according to Levi, who said that the sources were two, why should it be necessary to count seven days, seeing that the slightest \[break\][^fn_36a_1] should suffice?[^fn_36a_2] — It is this that was meant: It is necessary for her that[^fn_36a_3] there shall be a slight \[break\][^fn_36a_4] in order that \[the following days\] shall be counted as her seven clean ones.

Come and hear: The days of her pregnancy supplement those of her nursing,[^fn_36a_5] and the days of her nursing supplement those of her pregnancy. In what manner? If there was a break of two 'onahs during her pregnancy and of one during her nursing, or of two during her nursing and of one during her pregnancy, or of one and a half during her pregnancy and of one and a half during her nursing, they are all combined into a series of three 'onahs.[^fn_36a_6] Now according to Rab who said that there was only one source this ruling is quite justified, for it is for this reason[^fn_36a_7] that there must be a break of three 'onahs,[^fn_36a_8] but according to Levi who said that there were two sources why[^fn_36a_9] should a break of three 'onahs be required, seeing that the slightest \[break\] should suffice?[^fn_36a_10] — It is this that was meant: It is necessary for her that there shall be a slight \[break\] in order that \[the following days\] shall be counted for her[^fn_36a_11] as three 'onahs.

Come and hear: Both,[^fn_36a_12] however, are of the same opinion that where a woman observed a discharge after her clean blood period[^fn_36a_13] it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time of her observation. Now according to Levi who said that there exist two sources one may well concede this ruling since it is for this reason[^fn_36a_14] that[^fn_36a_15] it suffices for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time of her observation,[^fn_36a_16] but according to Rab who said that there existed only one source, why should it suffice for her to reckon her uncleanness from the time of her observation seeing that[^fn_36a_17] she should have become unclean for twenty-four hours retrospectively? — This is a case where there was not time enough.[^fn_36a_18] But why should she not be unclean from her previous examination to her last examination?[^fn_36a_19] — As there was no interval of twenty-four hours[^fn_36a_20] the Rabbis enacted no preventive measure even in regard to uncleanness from the previous examination to the last examination.

Come and hear: If a woman who was in childbirth during *zibah* had counted the prescribed number of clean days but did not undergo ritual immersion, and then observed a discharge, Beth Shammai gave their ruling in accordance with their own view and Beth Hillel ruled in accordance with their own view.[^fn_36a_21] Now according to Rab who said that there was only one source this ruling is quite justified, since it is for this reason[^fn_36a_22] that[^fn_36a_23] the discharge causes uncleanness both when wet and when dry; but according to Levi who said that there were two sources, why[^fn_36a_24] does the discharge cause uncleanness both when wet and when dry? — Levi can answer you: I maintain the same view as the Tanna who stated that 'both, however, are of the same opinion'.[^fn_36a_25] And if you prefer I might reply that here we are dealing with one whose discharge is continuous. But was it not stated that she had counted?[^fn_36a_26] — Here we are dealing with one who gave birth to a female child while in *zibah* and whose discharge ceased during the first week[^fn_36a_27] but continued again[^fn_36a_28] in the second week,[^fn_36a_27] he being of the opinion that the unclean days of childbirth in which no discharge is observed are counted among the clean days of one's *zibah*.[^fn_36a_29] 

Rabina said to R. Ashi: R. Shamen of Sikara[^fn_36a_30] told us, 'Mar Zutra once visited our place when he delivered a discourse In which he laid down: The law is to be restricted in agreement with Rab[^fn_36a_31] and it is also to be restricted in agreement with Levi'.[^fn_36a_32] R. Ashi stated: The law is in agreement with Rab both in his relaxations[^fn_36a_33] and his restrictions.[^fn_36a_34] Meremar in his discourse laid down: The law is in agreement with Rab both in his relaxations[^fn_36a_33] and restrictions.[^fn_36a_31] And the law is in agreement with Rab both in his relaxations[^fn_36a_33] and restrictions.[^fn_36a_31] [pg 36b]

***MISHNAH***. A WOMAN IN PROTRACTED LABOUR IS REGARDED AS A MENSTRUANT. IF HAVING BEEN IN LABOUR[^fn_36b_1] FOR THREE DAYS OF THE ELEVEN DAYS,[^fn_36b_2] SHE WAS RELIEVED FROM HER PAINS FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS AND THEN GAVE BIRTH, SHE IS REGARDED AS HAVING GIVEN BIRTH IN A *ZIBAH*;[^fn_36b_3] SO R. ELIEZER. R. JOSHUA RULED: THE RELIEF FROM PAIN[^fn_36b_4] MUST HAVE CONTINUED FOR A NIGHT AND A DAY,[^fn_36b_5] AS THE NIGHT AND THE DAY OF THE SABBATH.[^fn_36b_6] THE RELIEF \[SPOKEN OF IS ONE\] FROM PAIN, NOT FROM BLEEDING.[^fn_36b_7] HOW LONG MAY PROTRACTED LABOUR CONTINUE?[^fn_36b_8] R. MEIR RULED: 'EVEN FORTY OR FIFTY DAYS.[^fn_36b_9] R. JUDAH RULED: HER \[NINTH\] MONTH SUFFICES FOR HER.[^fn_36b_10] R. JOSE AND R. SIMEON RULED: PROTRACTED LABOUR CANNOT CONTINUE[^fn_36b_8] FOR MORE THAN TWO WEEKS. {¶=4.4}

***GEMARA***. Is then[^fn_36b_11] every woman IN PROTRACTED LABOUR REGARDED AS A MENSTRUANT?[^fn_36b_12] — Rab replied: She[^fn_36b_13] is deemed to be a menstruant for one day.[^fn_36b_14] Samuel, however, ruled: The possibility must be taken into consideration[^fn_36b_15] that she might be relieved from her pain,[^fn_36b_16] while R. Isaac ruled: A discharge on the part of a woman in labour[^fn_36b_17] is of no consequence.[^fn_36b_18] But was it not stated, A WOMAN IN PROTRACTED LABOUR IS REGARDED AS A MENSTRUANT? — Raba replied: During the days of her menstruation[^fn_36b_19] SHE[^fn_36b_20] IS DEEMED TO BE A MENSTRUANT,[^fn_36b_21] but during the days of *zibah*[^fn_36b_22] she is clean. And so it was also taught: If a woman is in protracted labour during the days of her menstruation[^fn_36b_19] she is deemed to be a menstruant,[^fn_36b_20] but if this occurred during the days of her *zibah*[^fn_36b_22] she is clean. In what circumstances? If she was in labour for one day and had relief from pains for two days, or if she was in labour for two days and had relief from pain for one day,[^fn_36b_23] or if she was relieved from pains and then was again in labour and then was again relieved from pain,[^fn_36b_23] such a woman is regarded as having given birth in *zibah*; but if she was relieved from pain for one day and then was in labour for two days, or if she was relieved for two days and then was in labour for one day, or if she was in labour and then was relieved and then was again in labour, such a woman is not regarded as having given birth in *zibah*; the general rule being that where the pains of labour immediately precede[^fn_36b_24] birth the woman is not regarded as having given birth in *zibah*, but if release from pain immediately precedes[^fn_36b_24] birth the woman[^fn_36b_25] must be regarded as having given birth in *zibah*.[^fn_36b_26] Hananiah the son of R. Joshua's brother ruled: Provided her pains of labour were experienced[^fn_36b_27] on her third day.[^fn_36b_28] even though she had relief during the rest of that day, she[^fn_36b_29] is not regarded as having given birth in *zibah*. What does the expression 'The general rule' include? — It includes the ruling of Hananiah.

Whence is this[^fn_36b_30] deduced? — Our[^fn_36b_31] Rabbis taught: Her blood[^fn_36b_32] refers to blood that is normally discharged,[^fn_36b_33] but not to such as is due to childbirth.[^fn_36b_34] You say. '\[Not to such as is\] due to childbirth'; is it not possible that only that blood is excluded[^fn_36b_35] which is due to an accident?[^fn_36b_34] As it was said, And if a woman have an issue of her blood,[^fn_36b_36] a discharge that is due to an accident is included;[^fn_36b_37] to what then could one apply the limitation of 'her blood'?[^fn_36b_36] Obviously to this: "Her blood" refers to blood that is normally discharged but not to such as is due to childbirth'. But[^fn_36b_38] what reason do you see for holding the blood of childbirth clean and that which is due to an accident unclean? I hold that which is due to childbirth clean since it is followed by cleanness,[^fn_36b_39] but hold that which is due to an accident unclean since it is not followed by cleanness. On the contrary! That which is due to an accident should be held clean since a discharge from a *zab* that is due to an accident is clean? — Now at all events we are dealing with the case of a woman, and we do not find that in the case of a woman blood due to an accident is ever clean. And if you prefer I might reply: What opinion do you hold? Is it to regard a discharge that is due to an accident clean and one that is due to childbirth unclean? Surely you cannot point to any occurrence that is more in the nature of an accident[^fn_36b_40] than this.[^fn_36b_41] If so,[^fn_36b_42] why should it not be said in the case of a menstruant also: Her issue[^fn_36b_43] refers to an issue that is normally discharged but not to such as is due to childbirth?[^fn_36b_44] You say, '\[not to such as is due to\] childbirth'; is it not possible that only that blood is excluded[^fn_36b_34] which is due to an accident?[^fn_36b_34] As it was said, And if a woman have an issue,[^fn_36b_43] a discharge that is due to an accident is included;[^fn_36b_45] to what then could one apply the limitation of 'her issue'?[^fn_36b_46] Obviously to this: 'Her issue' refers to an issue that is normally discharged but not to such as is due to childbirth![^fn_36b_47] — Resh Lakish answered: Scripture said, She shall continue[^fn_36b_48] which implies:[^fn_36b_49] You have another continuation which is of the same nature as this one;[^fn_36b_50] and which is it?[^fn_36b_51] It is that of protracted labour during the days of her *zibah*. Might it not be suggested that this refers to protracted labour during the days of her menstruation? — Rather, said Samuel's father, Scripture said, Then she shall be unclean two weeks, as in her menstruation,[^fn_36b_49] \[implying\] but not 'as in her zibah', from which it may be inferred that her *zibah* is clean; and which is it?[^fn_36b_51] It is that of protracted labour during the days of her *zibah*. Now, however, that it is written, Then she shall be unclean two weeks as in her menstruation,[^fn_36b_52] what need was there for the expression of 'her blood'?[^fn_36b_53] — If not for the expression 'her blood' it might have been presumed that the deduction 'as in her menstration'[^fn_36b_52] and not 'as in her zibah' implies that the discharge is clean even where the woman was relieved from pain,[^fn_36b_54] hence we were informed[^fn_36b_55] \[that the discharge is clean only where it is due to childbirth\].[^fn_36b_56]

Shila b. Abina gave a practical decision in agreement with the view of Rab.[^fn_36b_57] When Rab's soul was about to depart to its eternal rest he[^fn_36b_58] said to R. Assi, 'Go and restrain him,[^fn_36b_59] and if he does not listen to you try to convince him'.[^fn_36b_60] The other thought that he was told, 'put him under the ban'.[^fn_36b_61] After Rab's soul came to its eternal rest he[^fn_36b_62] said to him,[^fn_36b_63] 'Retract, for Rab has retracted'. 'If', the other retorted, 'he had retracted he would have told me so'.[^fn_36b_64] As he[^fn_36b_63] did not listen to him' the latter put him under the ban. 'Is not the Master', the other[^fn_36b_63] asked him, 'afraid of the fire?'[^fn_36b_65] 'I', the former replied, 'am Issi b. Judah[^fn_36b_66] who is Issi b. Gur-aryeh[^fn_36b_67] who is Issi b. Gamaliel who is Issi b. Mahalalel, a brazen mortar[^fn_36b_68] over which rust has no power'. 'And I', the other retorted, 'am Shila b. Abina, an iron pestle that breaks the brazen mortar Thereupon R. Assi fell ill and they had to put him in hot \[blankets\] to relieve him from chills and in cold \[compresses\] to relieve him from heat,[^fn_36b_69] and his soul departed to its eternal rest. [pg 37a]

Shila proceeded to his wife and said to her, 'prepare for me my shroud in order that he have no opportunity of going to Rab and saying things about me'. She prepared his shroud for him; and when the soul of Shila came to its eternal rest people saw a myrtle[^fn_37a_1] flying from the one bier to the other. 'We may conclude', they said, 'that the Rabbis have been reconciled.'

Raba enquired: Does labour[^fn_37a_2] render all previous counting in *zibah*[^fn_37a_3] void? Does any discharge that causes uncleanness render all previous counting void and, therefore, this also \[does it, since\] it causes uncleanness like the days of menstruation; or is it possible that only that which[^fn_37a_4] causes the uncleanness of *zibah* that renders all the previous counting void, and this, therefore, \[does not do it, since\] it is no cause of such uncleanness? — Abaye replied: A *zibah* that is due to an accident provides the answer,[^fn_37a_5] for this is no cause of the uncleanness of *zibah*[^fn_37a_6] and yet renders all previous counting void.[^fn_37a_7] The other retorted: Indeed, this[^fn_37a_8] also is a cause of the uncleanness of *zibah*, for we have learnt: If he observed a first discharge he must be examined, if he observed a second discharge he must be examined, but if he observed a third he need not be examined.[^fn_37a_9] But according to R. Eliezer who ruled, 'Even after a third discharge he must be examined'[^fn_37a_10] would you also maintain that, since it is no cause of the uncleanness of *zibah*, it does not render the previous counting void? — The other replied: According to R. Eliezer the law is so indeed.

Come and hear: R. Eliezer ruled, Even after a third discharge he must be examined, but after a fourth one he need not be examined.[^fn_37a_11] Does not this refer to the rendering of previous counting void?[^fn_37a_12] — No, to the imposition on that drop of an uncleanness that may be conveyed through carriage.

Come and hear: After a third discharge. R. Eliezer ruled, he must be examined; after a fourth one he need not be examined; and it is in regard to a sacrifice that I said this[^fn_37a_13] but not in regard to the rendering void of all previous counting.[^fn_37a_14] But the fact is that[^fn_37a_15] according to R. Eliezer you may well solve from here that even that which causes no uncleanness of *zibah* renders all previous counting void. What, however, \[it is asked\], is the solution of the problem according to the Rabbis? — Come and hear what the father of R. Abin learnt: 'What had his *zibah* caused him? Seven days.[^fn_37a_16] Hence it renders void the counting of seven days. What had his emission of semen caused him? The \[uncleanness of\] one day. Hence it renders void the counting of one day'. Now what is meant by 'seven days'? If it be suggested that it causes him to be unclean for seven days, \[the objection would arise that\] in that case it should have been said: As on account of his *zibah* he is unclean for seven days. Consequently[^fn_37a_17] it follows, that only that which causes the uncleanness of *zibah* renders void the counting of the seven days, but that which does not cause the uncleanness of *zibah* does not render void all previous counting. This is conclusive. Abaye stated: We have an accepted tradition that labour does not render void all previous counting in *zibah*; and should you find a Tanna who said that it did render the counting void, that must be R. Eliezer.[^fn_37a_18]

It was taught: R.
