Marinus ruled, A birth does not render void the previous counting after a *zibah*.[^fn_37a_19] The question was raised: Is it included in the counting?[^fn_37a_20] — Abaye replied: It neither renders void the days that were previously counted[^fn_37a_21] nor is it counted in the prescribed days.[^fn_37a_21] Raba replied: It does not render void the days counted and it is counted among the prescribed days.[^fn_37a_22] Whence, said Raba, do I derive this? From what was taught: And after that she shall be clean,[^fn_37a_23] 'after' means after all of them, implying that no uncleanness may intervene between them.[^fn_37a_24] Now if you agree that \[these days\][^fn_37a_25] are included one can well see the justification for saying that no uncleanness may intervene between them, but if you contend that these days[^fn_37a_25] are not included the birth, surely, would cause a break between them. And Abaye?[^fn_37a_26] — He can answer you: The meaning is that the uncleanness of *zibah* shall not intervene between them.[^fn_37a_27] Whence, said Raba, do I derive this? From what was taught: Of her issue,[^fn_37a_23] 'of her issue' implies but not of her leprosy,[^fn_37a_28] 'of her issue' but not of her childbirth.[^fn_37a_29] And Abaye?[^fn_37a_30] — He can answer you: Deduce once 'Of her issue[^fn_37a_31] but not of her leprosy' and do not deduce again, 'but not of her childbirth'. And Raba?[^fn_37a_32] — What an argument is this![^fn_37a_33] If you agree that 'of her issue'[^fn_37a_31] implies 'but not of her childbirth' one can well justify the text; for since it was required for the deduction about childbirth, leprosy also was mentioned on account of childbirth; but if you contend that 'of her issue' implies only 'but not of her leprosy', \[the objection would arise\] that this could be deduced from And when he that hath an issue is cleansed of his issue,[^fn_37a_34] which implies 'of his issue' and not of his leprosy. And Abaye?[^fn_37a_30] — One[^fn_37a_35] refers to a *zab* and the other to a zabah, both being necessary. For if the All Merciful had only written [pg 37b]

of a *zab* it might have been presumed to apply to him only, since he does not become unclean through a discharge that is due to an accident, but not to a zabah who becomes unclean even through a discharge that is due to an accident. Hence the necessity for the text about the zabah. And if the All Merciful had written only of a zabah, it might have been presumed to apply only to her, since she does not become unclean through observations \[on less than three days\] as on \[three\] days,[^fn_37b_1] but not to a *zab* who becomes unclean through \[three\] observations[^fn_37b_2] as \[through observations on three\] days.[^fn_37b_3] Hence both texts were required.

Said Abaye: Whence do I derive this?[^fn_37b_4] From what was taught: Her sickness shall she be unclean,[^fn_37b_5] includes the man who had intercourse with her; 'her sickness shall she be unclean' includes the nights;[^fn_37b_6] 'her sickness shall she be unclean' includes a woman who gave birth in *zibah* who is required to continue in her uncleanness until seven clean days have passed. Now does not this mean: Clean from the uncleanness of birth?[^fn_37b_7] — No, clean from that of blood.[^fn_37b_8]

Abaye further stated, Whence do I derive this?[^fn_37b_9] From what was taught: As are the days of her menstruation so are the days of her bearing. As the days of her menstruation are not suitable \[for counting as the days\] after her *zibah*[^fn_37b_10] and they cannot be included in the counting of the prescribed seven days, so also the days following her bearing which[^fn_37b_11] are not suitable \[for counting as the days\] after her *zibah* may not[^fn_37b_12] be included in the counting of the seven prescribed days. And Raba? — This is in agreement with[^fn_37b_13] R. Eliezer who ruled: It[^fn_37b_14] also renders void all previous counting.[^fn_37b_15] But may an inference be drawn from the impossible[^fn_37b_16] for the possible?[^fn_37b_17] R. Ahadboy b. Ammi replied: This is the view of R. Eliezer who holds that the possible may be inferred from the impossible.[^fn_37b_18] R. Shesheth, however, replied: Scripture has perforce compared them[^fn_37b_19] to one another.[^fn_37b_20]

There are some who say: R. Ahadboy b. Ammi citing R. Shesheth replied. This represents the view of R. Eliezer who holds that the possible may be deduced from the impossible; but R. Papa replied: Scripture has perforce compared them to one another.

IF HAVING BEEN IN LABOUR FOR THREE DAYS etc. The question was raised: What is the ruling where she was relieved from both?[^fn_37b_21] — R. Hisda replied: She is unclean.[^fn_37b_22] R. Hanina replied: She is clean.[^fn_37b_23] R. Hanina explained: This may be compared to a king who, when going on a tour, is preceded[^fn_37b_24] by his troops and it is known that they are the king's troops.[^fn_37b_25] But R. Hisda, said: \[Immediately before his arrival\] he would require even more troops.[^fn_37b_26]

We learnt: R. JOSHUA RULED, THE RELIEF FROM PAIN MUST HAVE CONTINUED FOR A NIGHT AND A DAY. AS THE NIGHT AND THE DAY OF THE SABBATH. THE RELIEF \[SPOKEN OF IS ONE\] FROM PAIN, NOT FROM BLEEDING. The reason then[^fn_37b_27] is because \[she had relief\] FROM PAIN and NOT FROM BLEEDING, but if she had relief from both[^fn_37b_21] she is clean. Does not this present an objection against R. Hisda? — R. Hisda can answer you: There was no need to state that, if she had relief from both, she is unclean, since \[metaphorically\] the troops completely disappeared; but even where she had relief from pain and not from bleeding where it might have been presumed that as she had not ceased to bleed she has not ceased to labour either and that it was merely stupor that seized her. Hence we were informed \[that even in this case she is unclean\].

We learnt: IF HAVING BEEN IN LABOUR FOR THREE DAYS OF THE ELEVEN DAYS, SHE WAS RELIEVED FROM HER PAINS FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS AND THEN GAVE BIRTH. SHE IS REGARDED AS HAVING GIVEN BIRTH IN *ZIBAH*. Now, how are we to imagine the circumstances? If it be suggested: As it was stated,[^fn_37b_28] \[the objection would arise:\] What need was there to mention THREE seeing that it suffices[^fn_37b_29] if the labour lasted two days and the relief[^fn_37b_30] one day? Consequently it must be this that was meant: IF HAVING BEEN IN LABOUR FOR THREE DAYS she was relieved from both,[^fn_37b_31] or if having been in labour for two days, SHE WAS RELIEVED FROM HER PAINS FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS, SHE IS REGARDED AS HAVING GIVEN BIRTH IN *ZIBAH*, and this presents, does it not, an objection against R. Hanina? — R. Hanina can answer you: No; the circumstances may in fact be as stated,[^fn_37b_32] but it is this that we were informed, that although the labour continued[^fn_37b_33] \[for a part only\] of the third day and she was relieved from her pains for twenty-four hours[^fn_37b_34] she is nevertheless unclean, contrary to the view[^fn_37b_35] of R. Hanina.[^fn_37b_36]

HOW LONG MAY PROTRACTED LABOUR CONTINUE? R. MEIR RULED etc. Now since protracted labour may continue for FIFTY DAYS is there any necessity to mention FORTY? — R. Hisda replied: This is no difficulty, the one[^fn_37b_37] referring to an ailing woman and the other[^fn_37b_38] to a woman in good health.

R. Levi ruled: \[The birth of\] a child is a cause of the cleanness of those days only in which a woman may normally become a zabah,[^fn_37b_39] but Rab ruled: Even in the days that are suitable for the counting prescribed for a zabah.[^fn_37b_40] Said R. Adda b. Ahabah: And according to Rab's view[^fn_37b_41] [pg 38a]

even the days that are suitable for counting after the previous counting had been rendered void[^fn_38a_1] are also clean.[^fn_38a_2]

We have learnt: HOW LONG MAY PROTRACTED LABOUR CONTINUE? R. MEIR RULED: EVEN FORTY OR FIFTY DAYS. Now this might quite possibly happen according to Rab on R. Adda b. Ahabah's interpretation,[^fn_38a_3] but according to Levi[^fn_38a_4] does not this present a difficulty?[^fn_38a_5] — Levi can answer you: Was it stated that she was clean throughout all these days?[^fn_38a_6] \[No; if the birth occurs\] in the days of menstruation[^fn_38a_7] she is regarded as a menstruant and only when it occurs in the days of her *zibah*[^fn_38a_7] is she clean.[^fn_38a_8]

Another reading. R. Levi ruled: \[The birth of\] a child is a cause of cleanness[^fn_38a_9] in those days only in which a woman may normally become a major zabah.[^fn_38a_10] What is the reason? It is written in Scripture,[^fn_38a_11] Her blood many days.[^fn_38a_12] Abba Saul in the name of Rab[^fn_38a_13] ruled: Even in the days in which she may normally become a minor zabah. What is the reason? Days[^fn_38a_14] and All the days[^fn_38a_14] are written in the context.[^fn_38a_15]

We have learnt: HOW LONG MAY PROTRACTED LABOUR CONTINUE? R. MEIR RULED: EVEN FORTY OR FIFTY DAYS. Does not this present a difficulty against both of them?[^fn_38a_16] — Was it stated that she was clean throughout all of them?[^fn_38a_17] \[No;\] if she was in labour during the days of her menstruation she is regarded a menstruant and only where this occurred during the days of her *zibah*[^fn_38a_18] is she clean.

It was taught: R. Meir used to say. A woman may sometimes bleed[^fn_38a_19] for a hundred and fifty days[^fn_38a_20] without becoming a major zabah.[^fn_38a_21] How? The two days[^fn_38a_22] preceding the period of her menstruation,[^fn_38a_23] the seven days of menstruation, two days after menstruation,[^fn_38a_24] fifty days[^fn_38a_25] which childbirth causes to be clean, eighty days[^fn_38a_26] prescribed for a female birth,[^fn_38a_27] seven days of menstruation[^fn_38a_28] and the two days[^fn_38a_29] after the menstruation.[^fn_38a_30] If so,[^fn_38a_31] they[^fn_38a_32] said to him, might not a woman bleed all the days of her life and no major *zibah* would occur in them?[^fn_38a_33] — He replied: 'What is it that you have in mind? Is it the possibility of frequent abortions? The law of protracted labour[^fn_38a_34] does not apply to abortions'.[^fn_38a_35]

Our Rabbis taught: A woman may sometimes[^fn_38a_36] observe a discharge on a hundred days and yet no major *zibah* would result from it. How? The two days[^fn_38a_37] prior to the time of menstruation,[^fn_38a_38] the seven days of menstruation, two days after menstruation,[^fn_38a_39] eighty days following the birth of a female child,[^fn_38a_40] seven days of menstruation and the two days[^fn_38a_39] after menstruation. What new law does this[^fn_38a_41] teach us? — That the law differs[^fn_38a_42] from him who ruled that it was impossible for the uterus to open without some bleeding, \[since thereby\][^fn_38a_43] we were informed that it is possible for the uterus to open without previous bleeding.[^fn_38a_44]

R. JUDAH RULED: … SUFFICES FOR HER etc. It was taught: R. Judah citing R. Tarfon ruled, Her \[ninth\] month suffices for her[^fn_38a_45] and in this there is one aspect of a relaxation of the law[^fn_38a_46] and one of restriction.[^fn_38a_47] How? If she was in labour for two days at the end of the eighth month and for one day at the beginning of the ninth month, even though she gave birth to the child at the beginning of the ninth month, she is regarded as having born it in *zibah*;[^fn_38a_48] but if she was in labour for one day at the end of the eighth month and for two days at the beginning of the ninth, even though she bore the child at the end of the ninth month,[^fn_38a_49] she is not regarded as having given birth in *zibah*.[^fn_38a_50] Said R. Adda b. Ahabah: From this[^fn_38a_51] it may be inferred that R. Judah holds that it is the *shofar*[^fn_38a_52] that is the cause.[^fn_38a_53] But could this[^fn_38a_54] be right,[^fn_38a_55] seeing that Samuel stated: A woman can conceive and bear only on the two hundred and seventy-first day[^fn_38a_56] or on the two hundred and seventy-second day[^fn_38a_57] or on the two hundred and seventy-third day?[^fn_38a_57] He[^fn_38a_58] follows the view of the pious men of old; for it was taught: The pious men of old performed their marital duty on a Wednesday only, in order that their wives[^fn_38a_59] should not be led to[^fn_38a_60] [pg 38b]

a desecration of the Sabbath.[^fn_38b_1] 'On a Wednesday', but not later?[^fn_38b_2] — Read: From Wednesday onwards.[^fn_38b_3] Mar Zutra stated: What was the reason of the pious men of old? — Because it is written, And the Lord gave her conception \[herayon\],[^fn_38b_4] and the numerical value of herayon[^fn_38b_5] is two hundred and seventy-one.[^fn_38b_6]

Mar Zutra further stated: Even according to him who holds that a woman who bears at nine months does not give birth before the full number of months has been completed,[^fn_38b_7] a woman who bears at seven months may give birth before the full number of months has been completed, for it is stated in Scripture. And it came to pass, after the cycles of days[^fn_38b_8] that Hannah conceived, and bore a son;[^fn_38b_9] the minimum of 'cycles'[^fn_38b_10] is two,[^fn_38b_11] and the minimum of 'days[^fn_38b_10] is two.[^fn_38b_12]

R. JOSE AND R. SIMEON RULED: PROTRACTED LABOUR CANNOT CONTINUE FOR MORE THAN TWO WEEKS. Samuel stated: What is the reason of the Rabbis? Because it is written in Scripture. Then she shall be unclean two weeks, as in her menstruation,[^fn_38b_13] which implies: Only 'as in her menstruation' but not as in her *zibah*; from which it follows that her *zibah* is clean for[^fn_38b_14] 'two weeks'.

Our Rabbis taught: A woman may sometimes be in labour[^fn_38b_15] for twenty-five days and no major *zibah* would intervene.[^fn_38b_16] How? Two days preceding her menstruation period;[^fn_38b_17] seven days of menstruation, two days following menstruation and the fourteen days which[^fn_38b_18] the childbirth causes to be clean. It is impossible, however, for her to be in labour for twenty-six days, where there is no child,[^fn_38b_19] without giving birth to it is in *zibah*.[^fn_38b_20] But if there was no child would not[^fn_38b_21] three days suffice?[^fn_38b_22] — R. Shesheth replied. Read: Where there is a child. Said Raba to him: But was it not stated 'where there is no child'? Rather, said Raba, it is this that was meant: It is impossible for her to be in labour for twenty-six days, where there is a child, without giving birth to it in *zibah*; and where there is no child but an abortion she is a zabah even after three days. What is the reason? — The law of protracted labour[^fn_38b_23] does not apply to abortions.

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN WAS IN PROTRACTED LABOUR DURING THE EIGHTY DAYS[^fn_38b_24] PRESCRIBED FOR THE BIRTH OF A FEMALE, ALL KINDS OF BLOOD THAT SHE MAY OBSERVE[^fn_38b_25] ARE CLEAN,[^fn_38b_26] UNTIL THE CHILD IS BORN, BUT R. ELIEZER HOLDS THEM TO BE UNCLEAN.[^fn_38b_27] THEY SAID TO R. ELIEZER: IF IN A CASE WHERE THE LAW WAS RESTRICTED IN REGARD TO BLOOD DISCHARGED IN THE ABSENCE OF PAIN,[^fn_38b_28] IT WAS NEVERTHELESS RELAXED.[^fn_38b_29] IN REGARD TO BLOOD DISCHARGED DURING PROTRACTED LABOUR, IS THERE NOT EVEN MORE REASON TO RELAX THE LAW[^fn_38b_30] IN REGARD TO THE BLOOD OF LABOUR IN A CASE WHERE[^fn_38b_31] IT WAS RELAXED[^fn_38b_32] EVEN IN REGARD TO A DISCHARGE IN THE ABSENCE OF PAIN?[^fn_38b_26] HE REPLIED: IT IS ENOUGH THAT THE CASE INFERRED[^fn_38b_33] SHALL BE TREATED IN THE SAME MANNER AS THE ONE[^fn_38b_34] FROM WHICH IT IS INFERRED. FOR IN WHAT RESPECT WAS THE LAW RELAXED FOR A WOMAN IN THE LATTER CASE?[^fn_38b_35] IN THAT OF THE UNCLEANNESS OF *ZIBAH*[^fn_38b_36] ONLY; WHILE SHE IS STILL SUBJECT TO THE UNCLEANNESS OF THE MENSTRUANT. {¶=4.5}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: She shall continue \[in the blood of her purification\],[^fn_38b_37] includes a woman who was in protracted labour during the eighty days[^fn_38b_24] prescribed for the birth of a female, viz., that all kinds of blood that she may observe are clean, until the embryo is born,[^fn_38b_38] but R. Eliezer holds them to be unclean. They said to R. Eliezer: If in the case where the law was restricted in regard to blood discharged in the absence of pain before the child was born,[^fn_38b_39] it was nevertheless relaxed in regard to blood discharged in the absence of pain after the child was born,[^fn_38b_40] is there not even more reason to relax the law in regard to the blood of labour after the child was born[^fn_38b_40] in a case where it was relaxed in regard to the blood of labour before the child was born? He replied: It is enough that the case inferred[^fn_38b_41] shall be treated in the same manner as the ones from which it is inferred. For in what respect was the law relaxed for a woman in the latter case?[^fn_38b_42] In that of the uncleanness of *zibah* only, while she is still subject to the uncleanness of the menstruant. They said to him, We would submit to you an objection in a different form: If in the case where the law was restricted in regard to blood discharged in the absence of pain before the child was born,[^fn_38b_39] it was nevertheless relaxed in regard to blood discharged at such a time[^fn_38b_43] in protracted labour, is there not even more reason that, where 'the law was relaxed in regard to blood discharged in the absence of pain after the child was born,[^fn_38b_44] the law should be relaxed in regard to blood discharged at such a time[^fn_38b_43] during protracted labour? He replied: Even if you were to offer objections all day long it must be enough that the case inferred[^fn_38b_44] shall be treated in the same manner as the one[^fn_38b_42] from which it is inferred. For in what respect was the law relaxed for a woman in the latter case?[^fn_38b_42] In that of the uncleanness of *zibah* only, while she is still subject to the uncleanness of the menstruant. Raba observed, R. Eliezer could successfully have offered the Rabbis the following reply: Did you not explain Her blood[^fn_38b_45] thus: 'Her blood' refers to blood that is normally discharged, but not to such as is due to childbirth?[^fn_38b_46] Well, here also, it may be explained: And she shall be cleansed from the fountain of her blood,[^fn_38b_47] 'her blood' refers to blood that is normally discharged but not to such as is due to childbirth.[^fn_38b_48] But might it not be suggested[^fn_38b_49] \[that if a discharge occurred\] during the days of menstruation she is a menstruant, \[while if it occurred\] during the days of *zibah* she is clean? — Scripture said, She shall continue,[^fn_38b_50] which implies: One form of continuation throughout all these days.[^fn_38b_51]

***MISHNAH***. THROUGHOUT ALL THE ELEVEN DAYS[^fn_38b_52] A WOMAN IS IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS.[^fn_38b_53] [pg 39a] {¶=4.6}

IF SHE NEGLECTED TO[^fn_39a_1] EXAMINE HERSELF, IRRESPECTIVE OF WHETHER THE NEGLECT[^fn_39a_2] WAS UNWITTING, UNDER CONSTRAINT OR WILFUL, SHE IS CLEAN. IF THE TIME OF HER REGULAR PERIOD HAS ARRIVED AND SHE FAILED TO EXAMINE HERSELF SHE IS DEFINITELY UNCLEAN.[^fn_39a_3] R. MEIR RULED: IF A WOMAN WAS IN A HIDING-PLACE[^fn_39a_4] WHEN THE TIME OF HER REGULAR PERIOD ARRIVED AND SHE FAILED TO EXAMINE HERSELF SHE IS DEFINITELY CLEAN, BECAUSE FEAR SUSPENDS THE FLOW OF BLOOD. BUT THE DAYS PRESCRIBED FOR A *ZAB* OR A ZABAH[^fn_39a_5] OR FOR ONE WHO AWAITS DAY AGAINST DAY[^fn_39a_6] ARE[^fn_39a_7] PRESUMED TO BE UNCLEAN.[^fn_39a_8]

***GEMARA***. In respect of what laws had this[^fn_39a_9] to be stated? — Rab Judah replied: In order to lay down that no examination[^fn_39a_10] is required.[^fn_39a_11] But since it was stated in the final clause, IF SHE NEGLECTED TO EXAMINE HERSELF,[^fn_39a_12] it follows, does it not, that at the outset an examination is required? — The final clause applies to the days of the menstruation period; and it is this that was meant: THROUGHOUT ALL THE ELEVEN DAYS A WOMAN IS IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS[^fn_39a_13] and no examination is necessary, but during the days of her menstruation period[^fn_39a_14] an examination[^fn_39a_15] is required;[^fn_39a_16] but IF SHE NEGLECTED TO EXAMINE HERSELF, IRRESPECTIVE OF WHETHER THE NEGLECT WAS UNWITTING, UNDER CONSTRAINT OR WILFUL, SHE IS CLEAN.[^fn_39a_17]

R. Hisda replied: This[^fn_39a_18] was only required to indicate that R. Meir's ruling that[^fn_39a_19] a woman who has no regular period is forbidden marital intercourse,[^fn_39a_20] applies only to the days of her menstruation period, but during the days of her *zibah* she enjoys[^fn_39a_21] A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS. If so,[^fn_39a_22] why did R. Meir rule: He must divorce her and never remarry her?[^fn_39a_20] — Since it is possible to be tempted[^fn_39a_23] to improper conduct during the days of the menstruation period. But since it was stated in the final clause. IF THE TIME OF HER REGULAR PERIOD HAS ARRIVED AND SHE FAILED TO EXAMINE HERSELF, may it not be concluded that we are here dealing with one who had a REGULAR PERIOD? — The Mishnah is defective and the proper reading is this: THROUGHOUT ALL THE ELEVEN DAYS A WOMAN IS IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS and is, therefore, permitted to her husband, but during the days of her menstruation period she is forbidden to him. This, however, applies only to a woman who has no regular period, but if she has a regular period she is permitted to him and only an examination is necessary. IF SHE NEGLECTED TO EXAMINE HERSELF, IRRESPECTIVE OF WHETHER THE NEGLECT WAS UNWITTING, UNDER CONSTRAINT OR WILFUL, SHE IS CLEAN. IF THE TIME OF HER REGULAR PERIOD HAS ARRIVED AND SHE FAILED TO EXAMINE HERSELF SHE IS DEFINITELY UNCLEAN. But, since the final clause is the view of R. Meir,[^fn_39a_24] the first one is not that of R. Meir, is it? — All the Mishnah represents the view of R. Meir and this is the proper reading: If she was not in a hiding place and the time of her regular period has arrived and she did not examine herself she is unclean, for R. MEIR RULED: IF A WOMAN WAS IN A HIDING PLACE WHEN THE TIME OF HER REGULAR PERIOD ARRIVED AND SHE FAILED TO EXAMINE HERSELF SHE IS CLEAN, BECAUSE FEAR SUSPENDS THE FLOW OF THE BLOOD.

Raba replied: This[^fn_39a_25] is to tell that she[^fn_39a_26] does not[^fn_39a_27] cause twenty-four hours retrospective uncleanness. An objection was raised: A menstruant,[^fn_39a_28] a zabah,[^fn_39a_28] and a woman who awaits day against day[^fn_39a_29] or who is in childbirth[^fn_39a_30] cause twenty-four hours retrospective uncleanness! — This is indeed a refutation.

R. Huna b. Hiyya[^fn_39a_31] citing Samuel replied: This[^fn_39a_25] is to tell that she cannot establish for herself a regular period during the days of her *zibah*.[^fn_39a_32]

R. Joseph[^fn_39a_33] remarked: I have not heard this traditional explanation.[^fn_39a_34] Said Abaye[^fn_39a_35] to him, You yourself have told it to us,[^fn_39a_36] and it was in connection with the following that you told it to us: If she was accustomed to observe a flow of menstrual blood on the fifteenth day,[^fn_39a_37] and this was changed[^fn_39a_38] to the twentieth day,[^fn_39a_37] marital intercourse is forbidden[^fn_39a_39] on both dates.[^fn_39a_40] If this was changed twice to the twentieth day,[^fn_39a_41] marital intercourse is again forbidden on both dates. And in connection with this you have told us: Rab Judah citing Samuel explained. This[^fn_39a_42] was learnt only \[when she was accustomed to observe a flow\] on the fifteenth day after her ritual immersion[^fn_39a_43] which is the twenty-second day[^fn_39a_44] after her observation of her discharge, since on such a day[^fn_39a_45] she is already within the days of her menstruation period,[^fn_39a_46] but the fifteenth day after her observation, on which she is still within the days of her *zibah* period,[^fn_39a_47] cannot be established as a regular period.

R. Papa stated: I recited this tradition before R. Judah of Diskarta \[and asked:\] Granted that she cannot establish thereby[^fn_39a_48] a regular period,[^fn_39a_49] must we take into consideration the possibility of such a regular period?[^fn_39a_50] The latter remained silent and said nothing at all. Said R. Papa: Let us look into the matter ourselves. \[It has been laid down that\] if she was accustomed to observe a flow of menstrual blood on the fifteenth day and this was changed to the twentieth day, marital intercourse is forbidden on both days.[^fn_39a_51] [pg 39b]

And in connection with this Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: This[^fn_39b_1] was learnt only \[when she was accustomed to observe a flow\] on the fifteenth day after her ritual immersion,[^fn_39b_2] which is the twenty-second day[^fn_39b_3] after her observation of her discharge, and it was changed to the twenty-seventh day[^fn_39b_4] so that when the twenty-second day[^fn_39b_5] comes round again she is well within the days of her *zibah* period,[^fn_39b_6] and yet it was stated that intercourse was forbidden on both days. It is thus clear that the possibility of a regular period[^fn_39b_7] must be taken into consideration.[^fn_39b_8] R. Papa is thus[^fn_39b_9] of the opinion that the twenty-two days[^fn_39b_10] are reckoned from the twenty-second day[^fn_39b_11] while the beginning of the menstruation and *zibah* period[^fn_39b_12] is reckoned from the twenty-seventh day.[^fn_39b_13] Said R. Huna son of R. Joshua to R. Papa: Whence do you draw your ruling? Is it not possible that the twenty-second day also is reckoned from the twenty-seventh day,[^fn_39b_14] so that when the twenty-second day comes round again the woman is within the days of her menstruation period?[^fn_39b_15] And this[^fn_39b_16] is also logical. For if you do not admit this,[^fn_39b_16] consider the case of a[^fn_39b_17] hen that laid eggs on alternate days[^fn_39b_18] and once ceased laying for two days and again laid on the following day. When it reverts to its former habit,[^fn_39b_19] does it do so in accordance with the present[^fn_39b_20] or in accordance with the past?[^fn_39b_21] You have no alternative but to admit that it would do it in accordance with the present.[^fn_39b_22] Said R. Papa to him: With reference, however, to what Resh Lakish ruled, 'A woman may establish for herself a settled period during the days of her *zibah* but not during the days of her menstruation' and to what R. Johanan ruled, 'A woman may establish for herself a settled period during the days of her menstruation', is not one to understand this as being a case,[^fn_39b_23] for instance, where she observed a discharge on the first day of the month, on the fifth of the month and again on the first of the second month and on the fifth of that month, and finally[^fn_39b_24] she observed a discharge on the fifth of the month while on the first of that month she observed none? And yet it was stated that 'a woman may establish for herself a settled period during the days of her menstruation'. It thus clearly follows[^fn_39b_25] that we reckon the days from the first day of the month?[^fn_39b_26] — No, the other replied, it is this that R. Johanan meant: A woman, for instance, who observed a discharge on the first day of the month, on the first day of the next month and on the twenty-fifth of that month, and on the first day of the following month, in which case we presume that[^fn_39b_27] she experienced an influx of additional blood.[^fn_39b_28] So also Rabin and all seafarers, when they came,[^fn_39b_29] reported the tradition[^fn_39b_30] in agreement with the explanation of R. Huna son of R. Joshua. [pg 40a]

## CHAPTER V

***MISHNAH***. FOR A FOETUS BORN FROM ITS MOTHER'S SIDE[^fn_40a_1] THERE IS NO NEED[^fn_40a_2] TO SPEND[^fn_40a_3] THE PRESCRIBED DAYS OF UNCLEANNESS[^fn_40a_4] OR THE DAYS OF CLEANNESS;[^fn_40a_5] NOR DOES ONE INCUR ON ITS ACCOUNT THE OBLIGATION TO BRING A SACRIFICE.[^fn_40a_6] R. SIMEON RULED: IT IS REGARDED AS A VALID BIRTH. ALL WOMEN ARE SUBJECT TO UNCLEANNESS[^fn_40a_7] \[IF BLOOD APPEARED\] IN THE OUTER CHAMBER,[^fn_40a_8] FOR IT IS SAID IN SCRIPTURE, HER ISSUE IN HER FLESH BE BLOOD;[^fn_40a_9] BUT A *ZAB* AND ONE WHO EMITTED SEMEN CONVEY NO UNCLEANNESS UNLESS THE DISCHARGE[^fn_40a_10] CAME OUT OF THE BODY. IF A MAN WAS EATING *TERUMAH* WHEN HE FELT THAT HIS LIMBS SHIVERED,[^fn_40a_11] HE TAKES HOLD OF HIS MEMBRUM[^fn_40a_12] AND SWALLOWS THE *TERUMAH*. AND THE DISCHARGES CONVEY UNCLEANNESS, HOWEVER SMALL THE QUANTITY, EVEN IF IT IS ONLY OF THE SIZE OF A MUSTARD SEED OR LESS. {¶=5.1}

***GEMARA***. R. Mani b. Pattish stated: What is the Rabbis' reason?[^fn_40a_13] Scripture said, If a woman have conceived seed and born[^fn_40a_14] a man child,[^fn_40a_15] implying:[^fn_40a_16] Only if she bears where she conceives.[^fn_40a_17] And R. Simeon?[^fn_40a_18] — That text[^fn_40a_19] implies that even if she bore in the same manner only as she conceived[^fn_40a_20] she[^fn_40a_21] is unclean by reason of childbirth.[^fn_40a_22] What, however, is R. Simeon's reason?[^fn_40a_23] — Resh Lakish replied: Scripture said, She bear,[^fn_40a_24] to include[^fn_40a_25] A FOETUS BORN FROM ITS MOTHER'S SIDE. And the Rabbis?[^fn_40a_26] — That text[^fn_40a_24] is required to include[^fn_40a_27] a *tumtum*[^fn_40a_28] and an hermaphrodite. Since it might have been presumed that as it is written man child[^fn_40a_29] and maid child[^fn_40a_30] \[the laws in the context apply only to\] one who is undoubtedly male or undoubtedly female but not to a *tumtum* or an hermaphrodite, hence we were informed that the law applies to the latter also. And R. Simeon?[^fn_40a_31] — He deduces it[^fn_40a_32] from a teaching of Bar Liwai; for Bar Liwai taught. For a son,[^fn_40a_33] implies: For any son, whatsoever his nature; For a daughter,[^fn_40a_33] for any daughter, whatsoever her nature. And the Rabbis?[^fn_40a_34] — They require this text for the deduction that a separate sacrifice is due for each son and for each daughter.[^fn_40a_35] And R. Simeon?[^fn_40a_31] — He deduced it[^fn_40a_32] from the following which a Tanna recited before R. Shesheth: This is the law for her that beareth[^fn_40a_36] teaches[^fn_40a_37] that a woman brings one sacrifice for many children. It might be presumed that she brings only one sacrifice for a birth and for a *zibah* … But would then one sacrifice suffice for a woman after childbirth who ate blood or for one after childbirth who ate forbidden fat? — Rather say: It might be presumed that a woman brings only one sacrifice for a birth that took place before the completion of her clean days and for one that took place after their completion.[^fn_40a_38] Therefore it was expressly written, 'This'.[^fn_40a_39] And the Rabbis?[^fn_40a_40] — Although 'this'[^fn_40a_41] was written it was also necessary to have the text, 'For a son or for a daughter'.[^fn_40a_42] For it might have been presumed that this law[^fn_40a_43] applies only to two distinct conceptions[^fn_40a_44] but[^fn_40a_45] that in the case of a simultaneous conception as, for instance, that of Judah and Hezekiah the sons of R. Hiyya,[^fn_40a_46] one sacrifice suffices,[^fn_40a_47] hence we were informed \[that even in such a case separate sacrifices are required for each birth\].

R. Johanan stated: R. Simeon, however, agrees that in the case of consecrated beasts \[the body of the young extracted by means of a caesarean cut\] is not sacred.[^fn_40a_48] What is the reason? He deduces the expression of 'birth' here[^fn_40a_49] from that of 'birth' in the case of the firstling:[^fn_40a_50] As in the latter case[^fn_40a_51] the reference is to one that openeth the womb[^fn_40a_52] so here also it is only to one that 'openeth the womb'. But why should not the expression of 'birth' here[^fn_40a_49] be deduced from that of 'birth' in the case of a human being:[^fn_40a_53] As in the latter case[^fn_40a_54] a foetus extracted from its mother's side is included[^fn_40a_55] so here also the young extracted from its mother's side should be included? — It stands to reason that the deduction should be made from the firstling, since 'the dam'[^fn_40a_56] might also be deduced from 'the dam'.[^fn_40a_57] On the contrary! Should not the deduction be made from the expression used of the human being, since thereby an ordinary birth[^fn_40a_58] would be deduced from an ordinary birth?[^fn_40a_59] But the fact is that the deduction was properly to be made from the firstling since in both cases[^fn_40a_60] the expression 'dam'[^fn_40a_61] is used, both are sacred beasts and both are subject to the laws of piggul, nothar[^fn_40a_62] and uncleanness.[^fn_40a_63] On the contrary! Should not the deduction be made from the expression used of the human being since both cases[^fn_40a_64] are those of ordinary birth,[^fn_40a_65] neither is restricted to the male sex,[^fn_40a_66] neither[^fn_40a_67] is naturally sacred,[^fn_40a_68] and neither[^fn_40a_69] is a priestly gift?[^fn_40a_70] The former[^fn_40a_71] are more in number.[^fn_40a_72]

R. Hiyya son of R. Huna citing Raba observed, A Baraitha was taught which provides support for the statement of R. Johanan:[^fn_40a_73] R. Judah stated, This is the law of the burnt-offering, it is that which goeth up,[^fn_40a_74] behold these[^fn_40a_75] are three limitations [pg 40b]

excluding[^fn_40b_1] a sacrifice that was slain in the night, whose blood was poured out,[^fn_40b_2] or whose blood was taken outside the hangings,[^fn_40b_3] which, even though it was placed upon the altar, must be taken down.[^fn_40b_4] R. Simeon stated: From the term 'burnt-offering'[^fn_40b_5] I would only know that the law applied to[^fn_40b_6] a valid burnt-offering; whence, however, the inference for including[^fn_40b_7] one that was slain in the night, whose blood was poured out,[^fn_40b_8] whose blood was taken outside the hangings[^fn_40b_3] or was kept overnight, that was taken out,[^fn_40b_9] that was unclean, nothar,[^fn_40b_10] one slain with the intention of eating it later than its permitted time limit or beyond its permitted place limits, whose blood was received or sprinkled by disqualified men,[^fn_40b_11] those sacrifices whose blood is to be sprinkled above[^fn_40b_12] and was sprinkled below,[^fn_40b_12] those whose blood is to be sprinkled below[^fn_40b_12] and was sprinkled above,[^fn_40b_12] those whose blood is to be applied within[^fn_40b_13] and was applied without,[^fn_40b_14] and a paschal lamb and a sin-offering that had not been slain as such?[^fn_40b_15] Whence, I ask, is the inference? Since it was explicitly said in Scripture, This is the law of the burnt-offering,[^fn_40b_16] the scope of the law is widened: One law for all that are placed upon the altar, so that once they have been put up they must not be taken down. As one might presume that I also include[^fn_40b_7] a beast that covered[^fn_40b_17] or was covered,[^fn_40b_18] that was set aside[^fn_40b_19] for an idolatrous purpose, that was worshipped, the hire of a harlot, the price of a dog, kil'ayim, trefah[^fn_40b_20] and one that had been extracted by means of a caesarean operation, it was explicitly stated, 'This'.[^fn_40b_21] But what reason do you see for including[^fn_40b_22] the former and for excluding the latter? [pg 41a]

Since Scripture both widened and limited the scope of the law, you might rightly say:[^fn_41a_1] I include the former whose disqualification arose within the Sanctuary and exclude the latter whose disqualification did not arise within the Sanctuary.[^fn_41a_2] At all events, it was here taught that the young extracted by means of a caesarean operation is not included in the scope of the law;[^fn_41a_3] and this refers, does it not, to the young that were so extracted in the case of a consecrated beast?[^fn_41a_4] — R. Huna son of R. Nathan replied: No, the reference is to one so extracted in the case of a firstling. But is not the law of the firstling[^fn_41a_5] deduced from the expression of openeth the womb.[^fn_41a_6] What then do you suggest? That the reference is to one of the consecrated beasts? Is not[^fn_41a_7] this \[it could be retorted\] inferred from a deduction of 'the dam' from 'the dam'?[^fn_41a_8] — What a comparison![^fn_41a_9] If you grant that the reference is to a consecrated beast one can well understand the necessity for two Scriptural texts:[^fn_41a_10] One[^fn_41a_11] to exclude[^fn_41a_12] the young of an unconsecrated beast born by way of a caesarean cut and then consecrated, and the other,[^fn_41a_13] to exclude[^fn_41a_14] the young of a consecrated beast[^fn_41a_15] born by way of the caesarean cut,[^fn_41a_16] he being of the opinion that the young of consecrated beasts become sacred only after they come into a visible existence,[^fn_41a_17] but if you maintain that the reference is to a firstling \[the objection would arise:\] Is not this[^fn_41a_18] deduced from the expression openeth the womb?[^fn_41a_19] This[^fn_41a_20] may also be supported by reason. For 'a beast that covered or was covered, that was set aside for an idolatrous purpose, that was worshipped and kil'ayim' were mentioned.[^fn_41a_21] Now is the law concerning these deduced from this text?[^fn_41a_22] Is it not in fact deduced from a different text:[^fn_41a_22] Of the cattle[^fn_41a_23] excludes[^fn_41a_24] a beast that covered or was covered, Of the herd[^fn_41a_23] excludes[^fn_41a_24] a beast that was worshipped, Of the flock[^fn_41a_23] excludes[^fn_41a_24] one that was set aside for an idolatrous purpose, Or of the flock[^fn_41a_23] excludes[^fn_41a_25] one that gores?[^fn_41a_26] And, furthermore, is the law concerning kil'ayim[^fn_41a_27] deduced from here? Is it not in fact deduced from a different text: When a bullock, or a sheep, or a goat, is brought forth;[^fn_41a_28] 'a bullock' excludes kil'ayim, 'or a goat' excludes one that[^fn_41a_29] only resembles it?[^fn_41a_30] But the fact is that two series of texts were required there: One in connection with an unconsecrated beast[^fn_41a_31] and the other in connection with a consecrated beast; well then, in this case also two texts were similarly required.

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman was in protracted labour[^fn_41a_32] for three days,[^fn_41a_33] but the embryo was born by way of a caesarean cut, she is to be regarded as having given birth in *zibah*.[^fn_41a_34] R. Simeon, however,[^fn_41a_35] ruled: A woman in such circumstances is not regarded as[^fn_41a_36] having given birth in *zibah*. The blood, furthermore, that issues from that place[^fn_41a_37] is unclean, but R. Simeon declared it clean. The first clause may be well understood, since R. Simeon follows his known view[^fn_41a_38] and the Rabbis follow theirs; on what principle, however, do they differ in the final clause?[^fn_41a_39] — Rabina replied: This is a case where, for instance, the embryo was born through the side [pg 41b]

while the blood issued[^fn_41b_1] through the womb; and R. Simeon follows his view while the Rabbis follow theirs.[^fn_41b_2] R. Joseph demurred: Firstly, is not then the final clause identical with the first?[^fn_41b_3] And, furthermore, 'from that place' means, does it not, the place of birth?[^fn_41b_4] Rather, said R. Joseph, this is a case, where, for instance, both the embryo and the blood issued through the side,[^fn_41b_5] and the point at issue between them[^fn_41b_6] is whether the interior of the uterus is unclean. The Masters hold that the interior of the uterus is unclean,[^fn_41b_7] while the Master holds that the interior of the uterus is clean.[^fn_41b_8]

Resh Lakish stated: According to him who holds the blood to be unclean the woman also[^fn_41b_9] is unclean[^fn_41b_10] and according to him who holds the blood to be clean the woman also is clean. R. Johanan, however, stated: Even according to him who holds the blood to be unclean the woman is clean. In this R. Johanan follows a view he previously expressed. For R. Johanan citing R. Simeon b. Yohai stated: Whence is it deduced that a woman is not unclean[^fn_41b_11] unless the discharge issues through its normal channel? From Scripture which says, And if a man shall lie with a woman having her sickness,[^fn_41b_12] and shall uncover her nakedness — he hath made naked her fountain,[^fn_41b_13] which teaches that a woman is not unclean[^fn_41b_11] unless the discharge of her sickness issues through its normal channel.

Resh Lakish citing R. Judah Nesi'ah[^fn_41b_14] ruled: If the uterus[^fn_41b_15] became detached and dropped upon the ground the woman is unclean, for it is said, Because thy filthiness[^fn_41b_16] was poured out,[^fn_41b_17] and thy nakedness[^fn_41b_18] uncovered.[^fn_41b_19] In what respect?[^fn_41b_20] If it be suggested: In that of an uncleanness for seven days[^fn_41b_11] \[the objection would arise:\] Did not the All Merciful speak of blood and not of a solid piece? — As a matter of fact the reference is to the uncleanness until evening.[^fn_41b_21]

R. Johanan ruled: If the uterus produced a discharge that was[^fn_41b_22] like two pearl drops[^fn_41b_23] the woman is unclean. In what respect? Should it be suggested: In respect of an uncleanness for seven days[^fn_41b_11] \[it might be objected:\] Are there not just five unclean kinds of the blood for a woman, and no more? — The fact is that the reference is to the uncleanness until evening.[^fn_41b_24] This, however, applies only to two drops but if there was only one drop it may be assumed that it originated elsewhere.[^fn_41b_25]

ALL WOMEN ARE SUBJECT TO UNCLEANNESS \[IF BLOOD APPEARED\] IN THE OUTER CHAMBER. Which is the OUTER CHAMBER? — Resh Lakish replied: All that part which, when a child sits, is exposed. Said R. Johanan to him: Is not that place deemed exposed as regards contact with a dead creeping thing?[^fn_41b_26] Rather, said R. Johanan, as far as the glands.[^fn_41b_27] The question was raised: Is the region between the glands regarded as internal or as external? — Come and hear what R. Zakkai taught: The region up to the glands and that between the glands is regarded as internal. In a Baraitha it was taught: As far as the threshing-place. What is meant by threshing-place? — Rab Judah replied: The place where the attendant threshes.[^fn_41b_28]

Our Rabbis taught: In her flesh[^fn_41b_29] teaches that she[^fn_41b_30] contracts uncleanness internally as externally. But from this text I would only know of the menstruant, whence the deduction that the same law applies to a zabah? It was explicitly stated, Her issue[^fn_41b_31] in her flesh.[^fn_41b_29] Whence the proof that the same law applies also to one who emitted semen? It was explicitly stated, Be.[^fn_41b_32] R. Simeon, however, ruled: It is enough that she be subject to the same stringency of uncleanness as the man who had intercourse with her. As he is not subject to uncleanness unless the unclean discharge issued forth, so is she not subject to uncleanness unless her unclean discharge issued forth. But could R. Simeon maintain that 'it is enough that she be subject to the same stringency of uncleanness as the man who had intercourse with her'? Was it not in fact taught: 'They shall both bathe themselves in water, and be unclean until the even.[^fn_41b_33] What, said R. Simeon, does this[^fn_41b_34] come to teach us? If that it applies also to one who came in contact with semen[^fn_41b_35] \[it could be retorted:\] Was it not in fact[^fn_41b_36] stated below, Or from whomsoever \[the flow of seed goeth out\]?[^fn_41b_37] But \[this is the purpose of the text:\] Since the uncleanness arises in a concealed region[^fn_41b_38] and since an uncleanness in a concealed region is elsewhere ineffective, a special Scriptural ordinance was required[^fn_41b_39] \[to give it effect in this particular case\]'[^fn_41b_40] — This is no difficulty: The latter deals with one who received the semen at intercourse,[^fn_41b_41] while the former refers to one who ejected it subsequently.[^fn_41b_42] 'Ejected'! Should not her uncleanness be due[^fn_41b_43] to her preceding intercourse?[^fn_41b_44] — This is a case where she had undergone ritual immersion in respect of her intercourse.[^fn_41b_45] This then[^fn_41b_46] says that for one who had intercourse it suffices to be unclean only until the evening. But did not Raba rule: A woman who had intercourse is forbidden to eat *terumah* for three days since it is impossible that she should not eject some semen during that time?[^fn_41b_47] — Here[^fn_41b_48] we are dealing with one who was immersed[^fn_41b_49] with her bed.[^fn_41b_50] It may thus[^fn_41b_51] be inferred that Raba[^fn_41b_52] spoke of a woman[^fn_41b_53] who went herself on foot and performed immersion, but then is it not possible that she had ejected the semen while she was walking?[^fn_41b_54] [pg 42a]

And should you reply: It is possible that[^fn_42a_1] some remained[^fn_42a_2] \[the objection would arise\]: If so, should not the expression used have been:[^fn_42a_3] We take into consideration the possibility that some might have remained? — The fact, however, is that according to Raba also this is a case where the woman was immersed with her bed, but there is no difficulty since one ruling[^fn_42a_4] deals with a woman who[^fn_42a_5] turned over[^fn_42a_6] while the other[^fn_42a_7] deals with one who[^fn_42a_5] did not turn over;[^fn_42a_8] and Raba[^fn_42a_9] interpreted the Scriptural text in this manner:[^fn_42a_10] When Scripture wrote, They shall both bathe themselves in water and be unclean until the even,[^fn_42a_11] it referred to a woman who did not turn over but one who did turn over is forbidden to eat *terumah* for three days since it is impossible that she should not eject some semen during this time.

R. Samuel b. Bisna enquired of Abaye: 'Is a woman ejecting semen[^fn_42a_12] regarded as observing a discharge or as coming in contact with one?[^fn_42a_13] The practical issue[^fn_42a_14] is the question of rendering[^fn_42a_15] any previous counting[^fn_42a_16] void,[^fn_42a_17] and of conveying uncleanness by means of the smallest quantity[^fn_42a_17] and of conveying uncleanness internally as well as externally'.[^fn_42a_17] But what is the question?[^fn_42a_18] If he[^fn_42a_19] heard of the Baraithas \[he should have known that\] according to the Rabbis she is regarded as observing a discharge while according to R. Simeon she is regarded as coming in contact with one; and if he[^fn_42a_19] did not hear of the Baraitha,[^fn_42a_20] is it not logical that[^fn_42a_21] she should be regarded as coming in contact with one?[^fn_42a_22] — Indeed he may well have heard of the Baraitha and, as far as the Rabbis are concerned, he had no question at all;[^fn_42a_23] what he did ask concerned only the view of R. Simeon. Furthermore, he had no question[^fn_42a_24] as to whether uncleanness is conveyed internally as externally;[^fn_42a_25] what he did ask was whether any previous counting is rendered void and whether uncleanness is conveyed by means of the smallest quantity. When \[he asked in effect\] R. Simeon ruled that 'it is enough that she be subject to the same stringency of uncleanness as the man who had intercourse with her' he meant it only in respect of conveying uncleanness internally as externally[^fn_42a_26] but as regards rendering any previous counting void and conveying uncleanness by means of the smallest quantity she is regarded as one observing a discharge, or is it possible that[^fn_42a_27] there is no difference?[^fn_42a_28] There are others who read: Indeed he[^fn_42a_19] may never have heard of the Baraitha,[^fn_42a_29] but[^fn_42a_30] it is this that he asked in effect: Since the All Merciful has considered it proper to impose a restriction[^fn_42a_31] at Sinai on those who emitted semen,[^fn_42a_32] she must be regarded as one who observed a discharge, or is it possible that no inference may be drawn from Sinai, since it was placed under an anomalous law, seeing that zabs and lepers who are elsewhere subject to major restrictions were not subjected by the All Merciful to that restriction?[^fn_42a_31] — The other[^fn_42a_33] replied: She is regarded as one who has observed a discharge. He[^fn_42a_34] then came to Raba[^fn_42a_35] and put the question to him. The latter replied: She is regarded as one who observed a discharge. He thereupon came to R. Joseph who also told him: She is regarded as one who observed a discharge. He[^fn_42a_34] then returned to Abaye and said to him: 'You all spit the same thing',[^fn_42a_36] 'We', the other replied, 'only gave you the right answer. For when R. Simeon ruled that "it is enough that she be subject to the same stringency of uncleanness as the man who had intercourse with her" it was only in respect of conveying uncleanness internally as externally,[^fn_42a_37] but in respect of rendering any previous counting void and in respect of conveying uncleanness by means of the smallest quantity she is regarded as one who observed a discharge.[^fn_42a_38]

Our Rabbis taught: A menstruant,[^fn_42a_39] a zabah,[^fn_42a_40] one who awaits a day for a day[^fn_42a_40] and a woman after childbirth[^fn_42a_41] contract uncleanness internally[^fn_42a_42] as well as externally. Now, the enumeration of three of these cases[^fn_42a_43] may well be justified, but how is one to explain the mention of the woman after childbirth? If the birth[^fn_42a_44] occurred during her menstruation period she is a menstruant,[^fn_42a_45] and if it occurred during her *zibah* period she is a zabah?[^fn_42a_45] — The mention[^fn_42a_46] was necessary only in the case of one who went down[^fn_42a_47] to perform ritual immersion in order to pass out thereby from the period of uncleanness to that of cleanness;[^fn_42a_48] and this[^fn_42a_49] is in agreement with a ruling given by R. Zera citing R. Hiyya b. Ashi who had it from Rab: If a woman after childbirth went down[^fn_42a_47] to perform ritual immersion in order to pass out thereby from her period of uncleanness to that of cleanness,[^fn_42a_48] and some blood was detached from her body,[^fn_42a_50] while she was going down,[^fn_42a_51] she is unclean,[^fn_42a_52] but if it occurred while she was going up, she is clean.[^fn_42a_53] Said R. Jeremiah to R. Zera: Why should she be unclean if this occurred 'while she was going down'? Is not the blood merely an absorbed uncleanness?[^fn_42a_54] — Go, the other replied, and ask it of R. Abin to whom I have explained the point at the schoolhouse and who nodded to me with his head.[^fn_42a_55] He went and asked him \[the question\], and the latter replied: This was treated like the carcass of a clean bird which[^fn_42a_56] conveys uncleanness to garments[^fn_42a_57] while it is still passing through the oesophagus.[^fn_42a_58] But are the two cases at all similar [pg 42b]

seeing that in the latter case no uncleanness is conveyed by external contact[^fn_42b_1] while here uncleanness would be conveyed when it emerges from the body?[^fn_42b_2] — Here also it is a case where the discharge emerged from the body.[^fn_42b_3] But if it emerged from the body, what need was there to mention such a case?[^fn_42b_4] — It might have been presumed that as the immersion is effective in respect of blood that is internal it is also effective in respect of the other,[^fn_42b_5] hence we were informed \[that in the latter case the immersion is of no avail\]. The difficulty about our cited tradition[^fn_42b_6] is well solved; but as regards the woman after childbirth[^fn_42b_7] \[the difficulty arises again\]: If the birth occurred during her menstruation period she is a menstruant, and if it occurred during her *zibah* period she is a zabah?[^fn_42b_8] — Here we are dealing with the case of a dry birth.[^fn_42b_9] But in the case of a dry birth,[^fn_42b_10] what point is there in the statement that uncleanness is contracted internally as well as externally?[^fn_42b_11] — The statement is justified in a case for instance, where the embryo put its head out of the ante-chamber;[^fn_42b_12] and this[^fn_42b_13] is in agreement with R. Oshaia, for R. Oshaia stated, 'This[^fn_42b_14] is a preventive measure[^fn_42b_15] against the possibility that the embryo might put its head out of the ante-chamber';[^fn_42b_16] and this[^fn_42b_17] is also in line with the following ruling: A certain person once came before Raba and asked him, 'Is it permissible to perform a circumcision on the Sabbath?' 'This', the other replied, 'is quite in order'. After that person went out Raba considered: Is it likely that this man did not know that it was permissible to perform a circumcision on the Sabbath? He thereupon followed him and said to him, 'Pray tell me all the circumstance of the case'.[^fn_42b_18] 'I', the other told him, 'heard the child cry late on the Sabbath eve but it was not born until the Sabbath'. 'This is a case', the first explained to him, 'of a child[^fn_42b_19] who put his head out of the ante-chamber[^fn_42b_20] and consequently his circumcision[^fn_42b_21] is one that does not take place at the proper time,[^fn_42b_22] and on account of a circumcision that does not take place at the proper time the Sabbath may not be desecrated.'[^fn_42b_23]

The question was raised: Is that region in a woman[^fn_42b_24] regarded as an absorbed place or as a concealed one? — In what respect could this matter? — In the case, for instance, where her friend inserted in her in that region a piece of *nebelah* of the size of an olive. If you say that it is regarded as an absorbed place, this *nebelah* being now an absorbed uncleanness[^fn_42b_25] would convey no uncleanness to the woman,[^fn_42b_26] but if you say that it is a concealed place, granted that no uncleanness could be conveyed by means of contact[^fn_42b_27] uncleanness would be conveyed by means of carriage?[^fn_42b_28] — Abaye replied: It is regarded as an absorbed place. Raba replied: It is regarded as a concealed one. Said Raba: Whence do I derive this? From what was taught: Since the uncleanness arises in a concealed region, and since an uncleanness in a concealed region is elsewhere ineffective, a special Scriptural ordinance was required \[to give it effect in this particular case\].[^fn_42b_29] And Abaye?[^fn_42b_30] — The meaning[^fn_42b_31] is this: There is one reason and there is yet another.[^fn_42b_32] In the first place the woman should be clean since the uncleanness is an absorbed one; and, furthermore, even if you were to find some ground for saying that it is a concealed uncleanness and an uncleanness in a concealed region is ineffective, this[^fn_42b_33] is a specific Scriptural ordinance.

The question was raised: Is the region through which the *nebelah* of a clean bird conveys uncleanness to a human being[^fn_42b_34] regarded as an absorbed place or as a concealed one? In what respect can this matter? — In a case, for instance, where his friend pushed a piece of *nebelah* of the size of an olive into his mouth.[^fn_42b_35] If you regard it as an absorbent place, this *nebelah* being now an absorbed uncleanness would convey no uncleanness, but if[^fn_42b_36] you say that it is a concealed one, granted that no uncleanness is conveyed by means of contact,[^fn_42b_37] uncleanness would be conveyed by means of carriage?[^fn_42b_38] — Abaye replied: It is an absorbed place, but Raba replied: It is a concealed one. Whence, said Abaye, do I derive this? From what was taught: As it might have been presumed that the *nebelah* of a beast conveys uncleanness to a person's garments by way of his oesophagus,[^fn_42b_39] it was explicitly stated in Scripture, That which dieth of itself,[^fn_42b_40] or is torn of beasts, he shall not eat to defile himself therewith,[^fn_42b_41] which implies: Only that[^fn_42b_42] which has no other form of uncleanness but that which is conveyed through the eating thereof[^fn_42b_42] \[conveys uncleanness by way of the oesophagus\],[^fn_42b_39] but this[^fn_42b_43] is excluded since it conveys uncleanness even before one had eaten of it. But why should not this[^fn_42b_44] be inferred a minori ad majus from the *nebelah* of a clean bird: If the *nebelah* of a clean bird which is not subject to uncleanness externally is subject to uncleanness internally[^fn_42b_39] how much more then should this,[^fn_42b_43] which is subject to uncleanness externally, be subject to uncleanness internally? — Scripture said, 'therewith'[^fn_42b_41] which implies: Only therewith[^fn_42b_45] but not with any other.[^fn_42b_43] If so, why was it stated in Scripture, And he that eateth?[^fn_42b_46] To prescribe for one who touches or carries it the same size as that which was prescribed for one who eats of it: As one who eats of it incurs guilt on consuming the full size of an olive so also one who touches or carries it contracts uncleanness only if it is of the size of an olive.

Raba ruled: A man holding a dead creeping thing in a fold of his body[^fn_42b_47] is clean, but if he holds *nebelah* in a fold of his body he is unclean. 'A man holding a dead creeping thing in a fold of his body is clean', since a dead creeping thing conveys uncleanness by means of touch, while a concealed region of the body[^fn_42b_47] is not susceptible to the uncleanness of touch. 'If he holds *nebelah* in a fold of his body he is unclean' for, granted that he contracts no uncleanness through touch, he contracts it, at any rate, through carriage. If a man held a dead creeping thing in the fold of his body[^fn_42b_48] and he thus brought it into the air spaces[^fn_42b_49] of an oven[^fn_42b_50] the latter is unclean. Is not this obvious?[^fn_42b_51] — It might have been presumed that the All Merciful said, Into the inside of which,[^fn_42b_52] implying: [pg 43a]

But not the inside of its inside,[^fn_43a_1] hence we were informed \[that the oven is unclean\].[^fn_43a_2]

Resh Lakish ruled: If a reed was held in a fold of the body of a *zab* and he shook therewith a clean person the latter remains clean.[^fn_43a_3] If a reed was held in the fold of the body of a clean person and he shook therewith a *zab* the former is unclean.[^fn_43a_4] What is the reason?[^fn_43a_5] Because Scripture said, And whomsoever he that hath issue[^fn_43a_6] toucheth, without having rinsed his hands in water,[^fn_43a_7] and this[^fn_43a_8] refers to the shaking of a *zab*, a form of conveyance of uncleanness the like of which we do not find anywhere in all the Torah; and the All Merciful expressed this in the term of touching,[^fn_43a_9] in order to tell that shaking and touching must be performed with a part of the body which is like one's hands; as one's hands are exposed[^fn_43a_10] so must any other part of the body[^fn_43a_11] be exposed.

BUT A *ZAB* AND ONE WHO EMITTED SEMEN CONVEY NO UNCLEANNESS etc. A *ZAB*, because it is written in Scripture, When any man hath an issue out of his flesh,[^fn_43a_12] \[which implies that no uncleanness is conveyed\] unless his issue emerged 'out of his flesh'; ONE WHO EMITTED SEMEN, because It is written, And if the flow of seed go out from a man.[^fn_43a_13]

IF A MAN WAS EATING *TERUMAH* WHEN HE FELT etc. Was it not, however, taught: R. Eliezer stated, whoever holds his membrum when he makes water is as though he had brought a flood on the world?[^fn_43a_14] — Abaye replied: One does it with a thick rag.[^fn_43a_15] Raba stated: It may even be done with a soft rag, for once the semen has been detached the subsequent touch is of no consequence.[^fn_43a_16] And Abaye?[^fn_43a_17] — He takes into consideration the possibility of an additional discharge. And Raba? — He does not consider the possibility of an additional discharge. But does he not?[^fn_43a_18] Was it not in fact taught: 'To what may this be compared? To the putting of a finger upon the eye when, so long as the finger remains on it, the eye continues to tear'? Now Raba?[^fn_43a_19] — It is unusual to get heated twice in immediate succession.[^fn_43a_20]

Samuel ruled, Any semen the emission of which is not felt throughout one's body causes no uncleanness. What is the reason? — The All Merciful has said, The flow of seed,[^fn_43a_21] implying that the text[^fn_43a_22] deals only with such as is fit to produce seed. An objection was raised: If a man was troubled with unchaste thoughts in the night and when he rose up he found his flesh heated, he is unclean![^fn_43a_23] — R. Huna explained this to apply to a man who dreamt of indulging in sexual intercourse, it being impossible to indulge in the act without experiencing the sensation. Another rendering: Samuel ruled, Any semen which does not shoot forth like an arrow causes no uncleanness. What is the practical difference between the latter reading and the former reading? — The practical difference between them is the case where the detachment of the semen was perceived but the emergence was not felt.[^fn_43a_24] Now this ruling which was quite obvious to Samuel was a matter of enquiry for Raba. For Raba enquired: What is the law where the detachment of the semen was perceived but its emergence was not felt?[^fn_43a_25] — Come and hear: If a man who emitted semen performed immersion[^fn_43a_26] before he had made water, his uncleanness is resumed when he makes water![^fn_43a_27] — There it is different, since the emergence of most of the semen was perceived. Others have a different reading: Samuel ruled, Any semen which does not shoot forth like an arrow causes no fructification. It is only fructification that it does not cause but it does cause uncleanness, for it is said in Scripture. If there be among you any man, that is not clean by reason of that which chanceth him,[^fn_43a_28] which implies: Even a chance emission[^fn_43a_29] whatever its nature.[^fn_43a_30]

Raba enquired: What is the law where an idolater indulged in sexual thoughts,[^fn_43a_31] and then[^fn_43a_32] he went down and performed ritual immersion?[^fn_43a_33] If you were to find some case where we follow the time of detachment[^fn_43a_34] \[the question would arise\]. Does this apply only where the law is thereby restricted,[^fn_43a_35] but not here[^fn_43a_36] where the law would thereby be relaxed,[^fn_43a_37] or is it possible that no distinction is made? — This is undecided.

Raba enquired: What is the ruling where the urine of a zabah had been detached from the source[^fn_43a_38] and then she went down and performed ritual immersion?[^fn_43a_39] If you were to find some case where we follow the time of the detachment \[the question would arise\], Does this apply only to semen, since it cannot be restrained,[^fn_43a_40] but not to her urine which she is able to restrain,[^fn_43a_41] or is it possible that no distinction is made? — This is undecided.

Raba enquired: What is the law where the urine of an idolatress[^fn_43a_42] who was a zabah had been detached [pg 43b]

from the source, and then she[^fn_43b_1] went down and performed ritual immersion? If you were to find a case[^fn_43b_2] where we follow the time of the detachment even where the woman can restrain the discharge \[the question would arise\], Does this apply only to the Israelitish woman who is Pentateuchally unclean but not to an idolatress who was a zabah, since she is only Rabbinically unclean,[^fn_43b_3] or is it possible that no difference is made between them? — This is undecided.

AND THE DISCHARGES CONVEY UNCLEANNESS HOWEVER SMALL THE QUANTITY. Samuel ruled: \[the discharge of\] a *zab*[^fn_43b_4] must be such a quantity as would stop the orifice of the membrum, for it is said in Scriptures Or his flesh be stopped from his issue.[^fn_43b_5] But have we not learnt: AND THE DISCHARGES CONVEY UNCLEANNESS, HOWEVER SMALL THE QUANTITY? — He[^fn_43b_6] maintains the same view as R. Nathan. For it was taught: R. Nathan citing R. Ishmael ruled, \[the discharge of\] a *zab*[^fn_43b_4] must be such a quantity as would stop the orifice of the membrum; but \[the Rabbis\] did not agree with him.[^fn_43b_7] What is R. Ishmael's reason? — Because Scripture said, Or his flesh be stopped from his issue.[^fn_43b_5] And the Rabbis?[^fn_43b_8] — That text[^fn_43b_9] is required for the inference that the discharge conveys uncleanness only when in a state of fluidity[^fn_43b_10] but not when it is dry.[^fn_43b_11] And R. Ishmael?[^fn_43b_12] — That[^fn_43b_13] is inferred from run.[^fn_43b_14] And the Rabbis?[^fn_43b_15] — That text[^fn_43b_14] serves the purpose of indicating the number:[^fn_43b_16] His issue,[^fn_43b_9] implies once; His flesh run,[^fn_43b_9] implies twice; With his issue,[^fn_43b_9] implies three times; thus it was taught that a *zab* who observed three discharges is under an obligation to bring a sacrifice; Or his flesh be stopped from his issue, it is his uncleanness,[^fn_43b_9] implies that he is unclean even on account of a part of the number of his issues,[^fn_43b_17] this teaches that a *zab* who observed only two discharges conveys uncleanness to his couch and seat. As to R. Ishmael, however,[^fn_43b_18] whence does he deduce the number required?[^fn_43b_19] — He derives it from an exposition of R. Simai; for it was taught: R. Simai stated, Scripture enumerated two issues and described the man as unclean[^fn_43b_20] and it also enumerated three issues and described the man as unclean,[^fn_43b_21] how is this to be reconciled? Two observations subject a man to the restrictions of uncleanness, and three observations render him liable to bring a sacrifice. But according to the Rabbis[^fn_43b_22] who deduced both numbers from 'This shall be his uncleanness in his issue',[^fn_43b_23] what deduction do they make from the text 'when any man hath an issue out of his flesh'?[^fn_43b_24] — They require it for the deduction that uncleanness does not begin until the discharge emerged from one's flesh. What need, however, was there for 'His issue be unclean'?[^fn_43b_24] — 'This teaches that the issue itself[^fn_43b_25] is unclean.

R. Hanilai citing R. Eliezer son of R. Simeon ruled: Semen conveys uncleanness to the man who emitted it,[^fn_43b_26] however small its quantity, but as regards the man who touched it its quantity must be of the bulk of a lentil.[^fn_43b_27] But did we not learn, AND THE DISCHARGES CONVEY UNCLEANNESS, HOWEVER SMALL THE QUANTITY, which applies, does it not, to the case of one who touched semen? — No, it applies only to one who emitted it.[^fn_43b_26]

Come and hear: In one respect the law of semen is more restrictive than that of a dead creeping thing while in another respect the law of a dead creeping thing is more restrictive than that of semen. 'The law of a dead creeping thing is more restrictive' in that no distinction \[of age\] is made about its uncleanness,[^fn_43b_28] which is not the case with semen.[^fn_43b_29] 'The law of semen is more restrictive' in that uncleanness is conveyed by its smallest quantity, which is not the case with a creeping thing.[^fn_43b_30] Now does not this apply to one who touched the semen?[^fn_43b_31] — No, it applies only to one who emitted it.[^fn_43b_32] But was it not taught as being on a par with the creeping thing: As the latter is a case of touching so also the former?[^fn_43b_31] — R. Adda b. Ahabah replied: The ruling referred to a creeping thing in general[^fn_43b_33] and to semen in general.[^fn_43b_34] But does a creeping thing convey no uncleanness even when it is of the smallest bulk? Have we not in fact learnt: Members of the body[^fn_43b_35] have[^fn_43b_36] no prescribed minimum size \[and uncleanness is, therefore, conveyed\] by less than the size of an olive of corpse,[^fn_43b_37] by less than the size of an olive of *nebelah* or by less than the size of a lentil of a dead creeping thing?[^fn_43b_38] — It is different with a member of the body[^fn_43b_39] since the whole of it takes the place of the size of a lentil; for were any part of it[^fn_43b_40] missing,[^fn_43b_41] would the member[^fn_43b_42] have conveyed any uncleanness?[^fn_43b_43] What is meant by the 'distinction in uncleanness' in the case of semen? If it be suggested: The distinction between the semen of an Israelite and that of foreigners \[it could be objected\]: Is there not in this case also[^fn_43b_44] a distinction between a sea-mouse and a land-mouse?[^fn_43b_45] — The distinction rather is that between a minor and an adult.[^fn_43b_46]

R. Papa stated: This ruling[^fn_43b_47] is a point at issue between Tannas:[^fn_43b_48] \[For it was taught\] whence do we derive the inclusion in uncleanness of one who touched semen? From Scripture which explicitly stated, Or whosoever;[^fn_43b_49] and elsewhere Tannas differ on a relevant point,[^fn_43b_50] for there are those who hold that a deduction is carried through in all respects[^fn_43b_51] while others hold that a deduction is limited by its original basis.[^fn_43b_52] Now according to those who hold that a deduction is carried through in all respects[^fn_43b_51] it follows that as a dead creeping thing[^fn_43b_53] conveys uncleanness through touch so does semen convey uncleanness by touch and, consequently,[^fn_43b_54] as a dead creeping thing conveys uncleanness only when it is of the bulk of a lentil so does semen convey uncleanness only when it is of the bulk of a lentil; while according to him who maintained that a deduction is limited by its original basis[^fn_43b_55] it also follows that as a dead creeping thing conveys uncleanness through touch so does semen convey uncleanness through touch, but then, limiting it to its original basis, as semen conveys uncleanness to the man who emitted it, however small its quantity, so does it also convey uncleanness to the man who touched it, however small its quantity.[^fn_43b_56] Said[^fn_43b_57] R. Huna son of R. Nathan to R. Papa: Whence the proof that the inclusion in uncleanness of one who touched semen is deduced from the expression of 'Or whosoever occurring in the context dealing with the creeping thing?[^fn_43b_58] Is it not possible that the inclusion is derived from the expression of 'Or from whomsoever the flow of seed goeth out,[^fn_43b_59] and[^fn_43b_60] all may be of the opinion that a deduction is to be carried through in all respects?[^fn_43b_61] The Tannas[^fn_43b_62] were asked[^fn_43b_63] Some recited as R. Papa while others recited in agreement with R. Huna son of R. Nathan.

***MISHNAH***. A GIRL ONE DAY OLD IS SUBJECT TO THE UNCLEANNESS OF MENSTRUATION. ONE WHO IS TEN DAYS OLD IS SUBJECT TO THE UNCLEANNESS OF *ZIBAH*. A BOY ONE DAY OLD IS SUBJECT TO THE UNCLEANNESS OF *ZIBAH*, AND TO THE UNCLEANNESS OF LEPROSY AND THAT OF CORPSEUNCLEANNESS; HE SUBJECTS \[HIS DECEASED BROTHER'S WIDOW\] TO THE DUTY OF LEVIRATE MARRIAGE;[^fn_43b_64] HE EXEMPTS \[HIS MOTHER\] FROM THE LEVIRATE MARRIAGE,[^fn_43b_65] HE ENABLES HER[^fn_43b_66] TO EAT *TERUMAH* AND HE ALSO CAUSES HER TO BE DISQUALIFIED FROM EATING *TERUMAH*;[^fn_43b_67] [pg 44a] {¶=5.2}

HE INHERITS AND TRANSMITS;[^fn_44a_1] HE WHO KILLS HIM IS GUILTY OF MURDER, AND HE COUNTS TO HIS FATHER, TO HIS MOTHER AND TO ALL HIS RELATIVES AS[^fn_44a_1] A FULLY GROWN MAN.[^fn_44a_2]

***GEMARA***. Whence is this ruling[^fn_44a_3] deduced? — \[From the following\]. For our Rabbis taught: From the term woman[^fn_44a_4] I would only know that the laws[^fn_44a_5] are applicable to a grown-up woman, whence, however, the inference that a girl one day old is also subject to the uncleanness of menstruation? Since it was explicitly stated, And a woman.[^fn_44a_6]

ONE WHO IS TEN DAYS OLD IS SUBJECT TO THE UNCLEANNESS OF *ZIBAH*. Whence is this ruling deduced? \[From the following\]. For our Rabbis taught: From the term woman[^fn_44a_7] I would only know that the laws are applicable to a grown-up woman, whence, however, the inference that a girl who is ten days old is also subject to the uncleanness of *zibah*? Since it was explicitly stated, And a woman.[^fn_44a_8]

A BOY ONE DAY OLD etc. Whence is this ruling deduced? — \[From the following Scriptural text\]. For the Rabbis taught: When any man,[^fn_44a_9] what was the object of stating, 'When any man'?[^fn_44a_10] To include a boy one day old in the restrictions of the uncleanness of *zibah*; so R. Judah. R. Ishmael son of R. Johanan b. Beroka said, This deduction is not necessary, for surely it is stated in Scripture, And of them that have an issue, whether it be a man or a woman;[^fn_44a_11] 'whether it be a man' means one of any age, whether adult or minor, 'or a woman means one of any age, whether an adult or minor. But if so[^fn_44a_12] what need was there to state, 'When any man'?[^fn_44a_13] The Torah employed ordinary phraseology.[^fn_44a_14]

\[IS SUBJECT TO …\] THE UNCLEANNESS OF LEPROSY, since it is written, When a man shall have in the skin of his flesh,[^fn_44a_15] implying a man of any age.

\[IS SUBJECT TO …\] THAT OF CORPSE-UNCLEANNESS, because it is written, And upon the persons that were there,[^fn_44a_16] implying a person of any age.

HE SUBJECTS \[HIS DECEASED BROTHER'S WIDOW\] TO THE DUTY OF LEVIRATE MARRIAGE, for it is written, If brethren dwell together,[^fn_44a_17] implying brothers who are contemporaries.[^fn_44a_18]

HE EXEMPTS \[HIS MOTHER\] FROM THE LEVIRATE MARRIAGE, for the All Merciful has said, And have no child,[^fn_44a_17] but this man has one.

HE ENABLES HER TO EAT *TERUMAH*, for it is written, And such as are born in his house, they may eat[^fn_44a_19] of his bread,[^fn_44a_20] read it as, 'Shall cause to eat[^fn_44a_21] of his bread'.

AND HE ALSO CAUSES HER TO BE DISQUALIFIED FROM EATING *TERUMAH*. For the All Merciful has said, And have no child,[^fn_44a_22] but she has one. But what was the point of speaking of a 'child' seeing that the same applies even to an embryo, for it is written,[^fn_44a_23] As in her youth,[^fn_44a_22] which excludes[^fn_44a_24] one who is pregnant?[^fn_44a_25] Both texts were required. For if the All Merciful had only written, 'And have no child' \[it might have been presumed that the law[^fn_44a_26] applied to that case\] because originally there was but one body and now there are two bodies,[^fn_44a_27] but that in this case,[^fn_44a_28] where there was originally one body and now also there is only one body, it may be held that the woman may eat *terumah*, hence the All Merciful has written, 'As in her youth'.[^fn_44a_29] And if the All Merciful has only written, 'As in her youth' \[it might have been presumed that the law[^fn_44a_30] applied to that case alone\] since originally the woman's body was empty and now it is a full one, but that in this case,[^fn_44a_31] where her body was originally empty and is now also empty, the woman may well eat *terumah*. Hence the necessity for both texts. Now, the Scriptural texts have been well explained, but as regards our Mishnah, why just A BOY ONE DAY OLD, seeing[^fn_44a_32] that even an embryo also disqualifies its mother? — R. Shesheth replied: We are here dealing with the case of a priest who had two wives, one who had previously been a divorced woman[^fn_44a_33] and the other was not a divorced woman,[^fn_44a_34] and he had sons from the latter[^fn_44a_35] and one son from the former,[^fn_44a_36] so that the latter[^fn_44a_37] causes the slaves of his father[^fn_44a_38] to be disqualified from eating *terumah*;[^fn_44a_39] thus indicating that the law is contrary to the view[^fn_44a_40] of R. Jose. He having laid down that an embryo[^fn_44a_41] also causes disqualification we were informed here that only A BOY ONE DAY OLD causes disqualification but not an embryo.[^fn_44a_42]

HE INHERITS AND TRANSMITS. From whom does he INHERIT? Obviously from his father; and to whom does he TRANSMIT? Obviously to his paternal brothers;[^fn_44a_43] but could not these if they wished inherit from their father and, if they preferred, inherit from him?[^fn_44a_44] — R. Shesheth replied: The meaning is, He[^fn_44a_45] inherits the estate of his mother to transmit it[^fn_44a_46] to his paternal brothers;[^fn_44a_47] hence only then when he is ONE DAY OLD but not when he is an embryo. What is the reason? — Because it[^fn_44a_48] dies first,[^fn_44a_49] and no son may inherit from his mother [pg 44b]

in the grave[^fn_44b_1] to transmit the inheritance to his paternal brothers. But, surely, this[^fn_44b_2] is not? so, for was there not a case where an embryo made three convulsive movements?[^fn_44b_3] — Mar son of R. Ashi replied: \[Those were only reflexive movements\] like those of the tail of the lizard which moves convulsively \[even after it has been cut off\].[^fn_44b_4]

Mar son of R. Joseph citing Raba explained: This[^fn_44b_5] means to say that he causes a diminution in the portion of the birthright.[^fn_44b_6]

Mar son of R. Joseph citing Raba further ruled: A son born after the death of his father causes no diminution in the portion of the birthright.[^fn_44b_7] What is the reason?[^fn_44b_8] It is required that They shall have born to him.[^fn_44b_9] Thus[^fn_44b_10] it was taught at Sura; but at Pumbeditha it was taught as follows: Mar son of R. Joseph citing Raba ruled, A firstborn son that was born after the death of his father[^fn_44b_11] does not receive a double portion. What is the reason? It is necessary that He shall acknowledge,[^fn_44b_12] and \['he',\] surely, is not \[there to acknowledge\]. And the law is in agreement with all those versions which Mar son of R. Joseph cited in the name of Raba.

HE WHO KILLS HIM IS GUILTY OF MURDER, since it is written, And he that smiteth any man mortally,[^fn_44b_13] implying, whatever the age.[^fn_44b_14]

AND HE COUNTS TO HIS FATHER, TO HIS MOTHER AND TO ALL HIS RELATIVES AS A FULLY GROWN MAN, In respect of what law? — R. Papa replied: In respect of that of mourning.

In agreement with whose view \[is our Mishnah\]?[^fn_44b_15] It cannot be, can it, in agreement with[^fn_44b_16] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel who ruled: Any human[^fn_44b_17] child[^fn_44b_18] that survived for thirty days cannot be, regarded as a miscarriage,[^fn_44b_19] from which it follows that if he had not lived so long he would have been a doubtful case?[^fn_44b_20] — Here[^fn_44b_21] we are dealing with the case of a child concerning whom it is established that the months of his pregnancy were duly fulfilled.[^fn_44b_22]

***MISHNAH***. A GIRL OF THE AGE OF THREE YEARS AND ONE DAY MAY BE BETROTHED[^fn_44b_23] BY INTERCOURSE; IF THE YABAM[^fn_44b_24] HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HER, HE ACQUIRES HER THEREBY;[^fn_44b_25] THE GUILT[^fn_44b_26] OF ADULTERY[^fn_44b_27] MAY BE INCURRED THROUGH HER,[^fn_44b_28] AND SHE[^fn_44b_29] CAUSES UNCLEANNESS TO THE MAN WHO HAD INTERCOURSE WITH HER SO THAT HE IN TURN CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS TO THAT UPON WHICH HE LIES,[^fn_44b_30] AS TO A GARMENT WHICH HAS LAIN UPON \[A *ZAB*\].[^fn_44b_31] IF SHE WAS MARRIED TO A PRIEST, SHE MAY EAT *TERUMAH*. IF ANY OF THE INELIGIBLE PERSONS[^fn_44b_32] COHABITED WITH HER HE DISQUALIFIES HER FROM THE PRIESTHOOD.[^fn_44b_33] IF ANY OF THE FORBIDDEN DEGREES ENUMERATED IN THE TORAH COHABITED WITH HER HE IS TO BE EXECUTED ON HER ACCOUNT, BUT SHE[^fn_44b_34] IS EXEMPT \[FROM THE PENALTY\]. IF ONE WAS YOUNGER THAN THIS AGE INTERCOURSE WITH HER IS LIKE PUTTING A FINGER IN THE EYE. {¶=5.3}

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: A girl of the age of three years may be betrothed by intercourse; so R. Meir. But the Sages say: Only one who is three years and one day old. What is the practical difference between them? — The school of R Jannai replied: The practical difference between them is the day preceding the first day of the fourth year.[^fn_44b_35] R. Johanan, however, replied: The practical difference between them is the rule that thirty days of a year are counted as the full year.[^fn_44b_36]

An objection was raised: A girl of the age of three years and even one of the age of two years and one day may be betrothed by intercourse; so R. Meir. But the Sages say: Only one who is three years and one day old. [pg 45a]

Now, all is well according to R.
