Johanan, for just as there is a Tanna[^fn_45a_1] who holds[^fn_45a_2] that one day of a year is counted as a year so there may also be a Tanna who holds[^fn_45a_3] that thirty days of a year are counted as a full year; but, according to R. Jannai,[^fn_45a_4] does not this[^fn_45a_5] present a difficulty? — This is a difficulty.

IF ONE WAS YOUNGER THAN THIS AGE, INTERCOURSE WITH HER IS LIKE PUTTING A FINGER IN THE EYE. It was asked, Do the features of virginity[^fn_45a_6] disappear[^fn_45a_7] and reappear again[^fn_45a_8] or is it possible that they cannot be completely destroyed until after the third year of her age? In what practical respect could this matter? — In one, for instance, where her husband had intercourse with her before the age of[^fn_45a_9] three and found blood, and when he had intercourse after the age of three he found no blood. If you grant that they disappear and reappear again \[it might well be assumed\][^fn_45a_10] that[^fn_45a_11] there 'was not sufficient time for their reappearance, but if you maintain that they cannot be destroyed until after the age of three years it would be obvious that[^fn_45a_12] a stranger cohabited with her.[^fn_45a_13] Now what is your decision? — R. Hiyya son of R. Ika demurred: But who can tell us that a wound inflicted within the three years is not healed[^fn_45a_14] forthwith, seeing it is possible that it is immediately healed and it would thus be obvious[^fn_45a_12] that a stranger had cohabited with her?[^fn_45a_13] Rather the practical difference is the case, for instance, where her husband had intercourse with her while she was under[^fn_45a_15] three years of age and found blood and when he had intercourse after the age of three he also found blood. If you grant that the features disappear and reappear again the blood might well be treated as that of virginity, but if you maintain that they cannot be destroyed until after the age of three years, that[^fn_45a_16] must be the blood of menstruation. Now what is your decision? — R. Hisda replied, Come and hear: IF ONE WAS YOUNGER THAN THIS AGE, INTERCOURSE WITH HER IS LIKE PUTTING A FINGER IN THE EYE; what need was there to state, LIKE PUTTING A FINGER IN THE EYE' instead of merely saying: IF ONE WAS YOUNGER THAN THIS AGE, INTERCOURSE WITH HER IS of no consequence'? Does not this then teach us that as the eye tears and tears again so do the features of virginity disappear and reappear again.

Our Rabbis taught: It is related of Justinia[^fn_45a_17] the daughter of 'Aseverus son of Antonius that she once appeared before Rabbi 'Master', she said to him, 'at what age may a woman marry?'. 'At the age of three years and one day', he told her. 'And at what age is she capable of conception?' 'At the age of twelve years and one day', he replied. 'I', she said to him, 'married at the age of six and bore a child at the age of seven; alas for the three years that I have lost at my father's house'. But can a woman conceive at the age of six years? Did not R. Bibi recite in the presence of R. Nahman: Three classes of woman may use an absorbent[^fn_45a_18] in their marital intercourse:[^fn_45a_19] A minor, and an expectant and a nursing mother. The minor,[^fn_45a_20] because otherwise she might become pregnant and die. An expectant mother,[^fn_45a_20] because otherwise she might cause her foetus to degenerate into a sandal.[^fn_45a_21] A nursing mother,[^fn_45a_20] because otherwise she might have to wean her child prematurely,[^fn_45a_22] and this would result in his death. And what is the age of such a 'minor'?[^fn_45a_23] From the age of eleven years and one day to the age of twelve years and one day. One who is under[^fn_45a_24] or over this age[^fn_45a_25] must carry on her marital intercourse in a normal manner; so R. Meir. But the Sages ruled: The one as well as the other carries on her marital intercourse in a normal manner and mercy[^fn_45a_26] will be vouchsafed from heaven, for it is said in Scripture, The Lord preserveth the simple?[^fn_45a_27] — If you wish I might reply: Whose flesh is as the flesh of asses.[^fn_45a_28] And if you prefer I might reply: Whose mouth speaketh falsehood, and their right hand is a right hand of lying.[^fn_45a_29]

Our Rabbis taught: A story is told of a certain woman who came before R. Akiba and said to him, 'Master, intercourse has been forced upon me[^fn_45a_30] when I was under[^fn_45a_31] three years of age; what is my position towards the priesthood?'[^fn_45a_32] 'You are fit for the priesthood',[^fn_45a_33] he replied. 'Master', she continued, 'I will give you a comparison; to what may the incident be compared? To a babe whose finger was submerged[^fn_45a_34] in honey. The first time and the second time he cries about it, but the third time he sucks it'.[^fn_45a_35] 'If so', he replied, 'you are unfit for the priesthood'.[^fn_45a_36] Observing that the students were looking at each other,[^fn_45a_37] he said to them, 'Why do you find the ruling difficult?'[^fn_45a_38] 'Because', they replied, 'as all the Torah is a tradition that was handed to Moses at Sinai so is the law that a girl under the age of three years[^fn_45a_39] is fit for the priesthood one that was handed to Moses at Sinai'. R. Akiba too made his statement[^fn_45a_40] only for the purpose of exercising the wits of[^fn_45a_41] the students.[^fn_45a_42]

***MISHNAH***. IF A BOY OF THE AGE OF NINE YEARS AND ONE DAY COHABITED WITH HIS CHILDLESS BROTHER'S WIDOW, HE[^fn_45a_43] ACQUIRES HER THEREBY,[^fn_45a_44] BUT[^fn_45a_45] HE CANNOT DIVORCE HER UNTIL HE ATTAINS HIS MAJORITY. HE CONTRACTS UNCLEANNESS THROUGH INTERCOURSE WITH A MENSTRUANT AND HE IN TURN CONVEYS THE SAME DEGREE OF UNCLEANNESS TO THAT UPON WHICH HE LIES AS \[DOES A *ZAB*\] TO THAT WHICH HAS LAIN UPON HIM.[^fn_45a_46] HE[^fn_45a_47] DISQUALIFIES A WOMAN FROM THE PRIESTHOOD,[^fn_45a_48] BUT[^fn_45a_49] CANNOT CONFER UPON ONE[^fn_45a_50] THE RIGHT TO EAT *TERUMAH*.[^fn_45a_51] HE RENDERS A BEAST[^fn_45a_52] INVALID FOR THE ALTAR, AND IT IS STONED ON HIS ACCOUNT.[^fn_45a_53] IF HE HAD INTERCOURSE WITH ANY OF THE FORBIDDEN DEGREES THAT ARE ENUMERATED IN THE TORAH, SHE IS TO BE EXECUTED ON HIS ACCOUNT, THOUGH HE[^fn_45a_54] IS EXEMPT FROM PUNISHMENT. {¶=5.4}

***GEMARA***. But when HE ATTAINS HIS MAJORITY, is[^fn_45a_55] a divorce alone sufficient? Was it not taught: The cohabitation of a boy of nine years[^fn_45a_56] of age was given the same validity as that of a ma'amar[^fn_45a_57] by an adult; as a ma'amar by an adult requires[^fn_45a_58] a divorce in respect of his ma'amar and *halizah* in respect of his marital bond so does the cohabitation of a boy of nine years of age[^fn_45a_56] require[^fn_45a_58] a divorce in respect of his ma'amar[^fn_45a_59] and *halizah* in respect of his marital bond?[^fn_45a_60] — Rab replied: It is this that was meant:[^fn_45a_61] [pg 45b]

when HE ATTAINS HIS MAJORITY he shall cohabit with her[^fn_45b_1] and give her a divorce.[^fn_45b_2]

***MISHNAH***. THE VOWS OF A GIRL OF THE AGE OF ELEVEN YEARS AND ONE DAY MUST BE EXAMINED;[^fn_45b_3] THE VOWS OF ONE WHO IS OF THE AGE OF TWELVE YEARS AND ONE DAY ARE VALID;[^fn_45b_4] AND THROUGHOUT THE TWELFTH YEAR THEY ARE TO BE EXAMINED.[^fn_45b_3] THE VOWS OF A BOY OF THE AGE OF TWELVE YEARS AND ONE DAY MUST BE EXAMINED;[^fn_45b_5] THE VOWS OF ONE WHO IS OF THE AGE OF THIRTEEN YEARS AND ONE DAY ARE VALID; AND THROUGHOUT THE THIRTEENTH YEAR THEY ARE TO BE EXAMINED.[^fn_45b_5] PRIOR TO THIS AGE,[^fn_45b_6] EVEN THOUGH THEY SAID, 'WE KNOW IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR VOW' OR 'IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR DEDICATION', THEIR VOW[^fn_45b_7] IS NO VALID VOW AND THEIR DEDICATION IS NO VALID DEDICATION. SUBSEQUENT TO THIS AGE,[^fn_45b_8] EVEN THOUGH THEY SAID, 'WE DO NOT KNOW IN THE HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR VOW' OR 'IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR DEDICATION', THEIR VOW IS A VALID VOW AND THEIR DEDICATION IS A VALID DEDICATION. {¶=5.5}

***GEMARA***. But since it was stated, THE VOWS OF A GIRL OF THE AGE OF ELEVEN YEARS AND ONE DAY MUST BE EXAMINED,[^fn_45b_9] what need was there for stating, THE VOWS OF ONE WHO IS OF THE AGE OF TWELVE YEARS AND ONE DAY ARE VALID? — It might have been presumed that henceforth they must always be examined,[^fn_45b_10] hence we were informed that after the age of twelve years and a day the vows are invariably valid. But since it was stated, THE VOWS OF ONE WHO IS OF THE AGE OF TWELVE YEARS AND ONE DAY ARE VALID,[^fn_45b_11] what need was there for stating, AND THROUGHOUT THE TWELFTH YEAR THEY ARE TO BE EXAMINED?[^fn_45b_12] — It might have been presumed that, since a Master has laid down that 'Thirty days of a year are counted as a full year', where we examined her vows during a period of thirty days[^fn_45b_13] and she knew not how to express their significance,[^fn_45b_14] no further examinations[^fn_45b_15] should be held[^fn_45b_16] hence we were informed that her vows are to be examined all through the twelfth year. Then let the last two cases be stated, THE VOWS OF ONE WHO IS OF THE AGE OF TWELVE YEARS AND ONE DAY ARE VALID, AND THROUGHOUT THE TWELFTH YEAR THEY ARE TO BE EXAMINED, but[^fn_45b_17] what was the need for the statement, THE VOWS OF A GIRL OF THE AGE OF ELEVEN YEARS AND ONE DAY MUST BE EXAMINED? — It was required: Since it might have been suggested that as a rule examination was necessary in the twelfth year and unnecessary in the eleventh year, but that where we see that the girl is particularly bright she might also be examined in the eleventh year,[^fn_45b_18] we were informed that the period of examination invariably begins at the age of eleven years and one day. What was the need[^fn_45b_19] for stating, PRIOR TO THIS AGE and SUBSEQUENT TO THIS AGE? — It might have been presumed that the previous rulings[^fn_45b_20] applied only where the children themselves spontaneously say nothing[^fn_45b_21] but that where they do assert spontaneous opinion[^fn_45b_22] we may rely upon them, hence we were informed that even their own assertions do not affect the age limits.

Our Rabbis taught: These[^fn_45b_23] are the rulings of Rabbi. R. Simeon b. Eleazar stated, The age limits that were assigned to the girl apply to the boy while those assigned to the boy apply to the girl.[^fn_45b_24] R. Hisda stated: What is Rabbi's reason? Because it is written in Scripture, And the Lord God built[^fn_45b_25] the rib[^fn_45b_26] which teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, endowed the woman with more understanding[^fn_45b_27] than the man. And the other?[^fn_45b_28] — He requires that text[^fn_45b_25] for the same deduction as the one made by Resh Lakish, for Resh Lakish citing R. Simeon b. Menasya stated, And the lord God built the rib which he took from the man into a woman, and he brought her unto the man,[^fn_45b_29] teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, plaited Eve's hair and then brought her to Adam, for in the sea-towns they describe net-work as binyatha.[^fn_45b_30] But what is R. Simeon b. Eleazar's reason? — R. Samuel son of R. Isaac replied: As a boy frequents the house of his teacher his subtlety[^fn_45b_31] develops earlier.[^fn_45b_32]

It was asked: Is the intervening period[^fn_45b_33] regarded as that of under, or of over age?[^fn_45b_34] — In respect of what law could this matter: If in that of vows, it is neither regarded as that of under age nor as that of over age?[^fn_45b_35] — Rather in respect of punishments.[^fn_45b_36] Now what is the ruling? — Both Rab and R. Hanina replied: The intervening period is regarded as that of under age.[^fn_45b_37] Both R. Johanan and R. Joshua b. Levi replied: The intervening period is regarded as that of over age. Said R. Nahman b. Isaac: Your mnemonic[^fn_45b_38] is: Now this was the custom in former time in Israel.[^fn_45b_39]

R. Hamnuna raised an objection:[^fn_45b_40] SUBSEQUENT TO THIS AGE, EVEN THOUGH THEY SAID, WE DO NOT KNOW IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR VOW' OR 'IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR DEDICATION' THEIR VOW IS A VALID VOW AND THEIR DEDICATION IS A VALID DEDICATION. Thus[^fn_45b_41] it follows, does it not, that the intervening period is regarded as that of under age? Said Raba to him, Read then the first clause: PRIOR TO THIS AGE, EVEN THOUGH THEY SAID, 'WE KNEW IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR VOW' OR 'IN HONOUR OF WHOSE NAME WE HAVE MADE OUR DEDICATION', THEIR VOW IS NO VALID VOW AND THEIR DEDICATION IS NO VALID DEDICATION. Thus[^fn_45b_42] it follows, does it not, that the intervening period is regarded as that of over age? — This, however, is no argument, Raba having laboured under a misapprehension. He thought that R. Hamnuna drew his inference from a Mishnah redundancy,[^fn_45b_43] \[hence he argued that\] instead of drawing an inference from the final clause he might as well have drawn one from the first clause; but this was not the case. R. Hamnuna in fact drew his inference from the very wording[^fn_45b_44] of our Mishnah. How \[he reasoned\] is one to understand the expression of 'SUBSEQUENT TO THAT AGE'? If by that time one had not yet grown two hairs, one would, surely, still be a minor.[^fn_45b_45] Consequently it must refer to one who had grown two hairs, [pg 46a]

the reason for the ruling[^fn_46a_1] being that one was over age, when all requirements[^fn_46a_2] were satisfied.[^fn_46a_3] Thus it follows, does it not, that the intervening period[^fn_46a_4] is regarded as that of under age?[^fn_46a_5] A further objection was \[also\] raised by R. Zera: When … man … shall clearly utter a vow, the vow of …[^fn_46a_6] What was the purpose of stating 'man'? To include in the scope of the law a boy of the age of thirteen years and one day whose vows are valid, though he is unable to 'utter clearly'. Now how is this to be understood? If it be suggested that the reference is to a boy who had not yet grown two hairs, \[the objection could be raised:\] Such a boy would still have the status of a minor.[^fn_46a_7] The reference consequently must be to one who had grown two hairs, the reason being that he is thirteen years and one day old, when he is regarded as a 'man'. Thus[^fn_46a_8] it follows, does it not, that the intervening period is regarded as that of under age?[^fn_46a_9] — This is indeed a refutation.

R. Nahman stated, The question[^fn_46a_10] is a point at issue between Tannas:[^fn_46a_11] \[For it was taught:\] If a boy of the age of seven years grew two hairs they are attributed to a mole;[^fn_46a_12] from the age of nine years to that of twelve years and one day they are also to be attributed to a mole,[^fn_46a_12] but R. Jose son of R. Judah ruled: They[^fn_46a_13] are a sign of puberty; at the age of thirteen years and one day, all agree that they are a sign of puberty.[^fn_46a_14] Now is not this self-contradictory: You said, 'From the age of nine years to that of twelve years and one day they are also to be attributed to a mole', from which it follows that at the actual age of thirteen years they are a sign of puberty; but then it is stated, 'At the age of thirteen years and one day … they are a sign of puberty', from which it follows, does it not, that at the actual age of thirteen years they are to be attributed to a mole? Must you not concede then that this question[^fn_46a_15] is a point at issue between the Tannas, one Master[^fn_46a_16] holding that the intervening period is regarded as that of over age while the other Master maintains that the intervening period is regarded as that of under age?[^fn_46a_17] No; all may agree that the intervening period is regarded as that under age, but both clauses refer to a girl the first[^fn_46a_18] supporting the view of Rabbi[^fn_46a_19] while the latter[^fn_46a_20] represents that of R. Simeon b. Eleazar.[^fn_46a_21] And if you prefer I[^fn_46a_22] might reply: Both clauses refer to a boy, and the first represents the view of R. Simeon b. Eleazar while the latter represents the view of Rabbi.[^fn_46a_23] And if you prefer I[^fn_46a_24] might reply: Both clauses are the view of Rabbi, but one[^fn_46a_25] refers to a boy while the other[^fn_46a_26] refers to a girl. And if you prefer I[^fn_46a_24] might say: Both clauses are the view of R. Simeon b. Eleazar, but the one[^fn_46a_26] refers to a boy while the other[^fn_46a_25] refers to a girl.

'R. Jose son of R. Judah ruled: They are a sign of puberty.' R. Keruspedai son of R. Shabbethai explained: This applies only where they[^fn_46a_27] are still on him.[^fn_46a_28] So it was also taught: If a boy of the age of nine years and one day had grown two hairs they are to be attributed to a mole; from the age of nine years to that of twelve years and one day, though the hairs are still on him, they are to be attributed to a mole. R. Jose son of R. Judah ruled: They are a sign of puberty.

Raba stated: The law is that the intervening period is regarded as that of under age. R. Samuel b. Zutra taught Raba's tradition in the following form:[^fn_46a_29] Raba stated, A minor all through her twelfth year may make a declaration of *mi'un*[^fn_46a_30] and go away,[^fn_46a_31] but from that age upwards she may not make a declaration of *mi'un*[^fn_46a_32] but[^fn_46a_33] she may not submit to *halizah*.[^fn_46a_34] Is not this statement, however, self contradictory? You said, 'she may not make a declaration of mi'un' from which it is evident that[^fn_46a_35] she is regarded as one of age; but if she is of age why may she not submit to *halizah*? And were you to reply that he[^fn_46a_36] was in doubt,[^fn_46a_37] \[it could be retorted:\] Was he in doubt? Did not Raba in fact rule: A minor on attaining the age of majority need not be examined[^fn_46a_38] since there is presumption that she has grown the signs of puberty? — This[^fn_46a_39] applies only to general cases, but not here where an examination was held and no hairs were found. If so,[^fn_46a_40] why should she not be allowed to make a declaration of *mi'un*? The possibility is taken into consideration that they might have fallen off. This would be a satisfactory explanation according to him who holds that such a possibility is taken into consideration, but what explanation can be offered according to him who holds that such a possibility need not be taken into consideration? Was it not stated: R. Kahana[^fn_46a_41] ruled, There is no need to consider the possibility that they may have fallen off and R. Papi ruled, The possibility must be considered? — This[^fn_46a_42] applies only to the matter of *halizah*,[^fn_46a_43] but as regards *mi'un* the possibility is taken into consideration.[^fn_46a_44] Thus it follows that according to him who holds that the possibility[^fn_46a_45] is taken into consideration she may submit to *halizah*; but \[it may be objected:\] Did he not merely say that the possibility[^fn_46a_46] is taken into consideration?[^fn_46a_47] The fact is that this[^fn_46a_48] is a case where she was not examined,[^fn_46a_49] but the possibility[^fn_46a_50] is taken into consideration as regards *halizah*,[^fn_46a_51] and when Raba stated 'There is presumption' he meant it in regard to *mi'un*,[^fn_46a_52] but in regard to *halizah*[^fn_46a_53] an examination[^fn_46a_54] is a pre-requisite. R. Dimi of Nehardea stated: The law is that the possibility that the hairs may have fallen off is taken into consideration.[^fn_46a_55] This,[^fn_46a_56] however, applies only where one had betrothed her[^fn_46a_57] during the intervening period and cohabited after that period, since a Pentateuchal doubt is thereby involved,[^fn_46a_58] but not to the original betrothal alone.[^fn_46a_59]

R. Huna ruled: If \[a child\][^fn_46a_60] dedicated some food and then ate it, he[^fn_46a_61] is subject to flogging, for it is said in Scripture, When… man … shall clearly utter a vow,[^fn_46a_62] and He shall not break his word,[^fn_46a_63] which[^fn_46a_64] implies that whosoever is able to 'utter clearly'[^fn_46a_65] is subject to the prohibition of 'he shall not break his word'[^fn_46a_66] and only he who is not able to 'utter clearly' is not subject to the injunction of 'he shall not break his word'. R. Huna b. Judah addressed an objection to[^fn_46a_67] Raba[^fn_46a_68] in support of R. Huna: [pg 46b]

Since we find that Scripture has put a minor on a par with an adult[^fn_46b_1] as regards a presumptuous oath, a self-imposed prohibition[^fn_46b_2] and \[the injunction\] not to break his word, it might have been presumed that he should also incur the liability of a sacrifice for eating that which he had dedicated, hence it was explicitly stated,[^fn_46b_3] This is the thing.[^fn_46b_4] At any rate, was it not here stated that guilt was incurred for infringing a self imposed prohibition or \[the injunction\] not to break one's word?[^fn_46b_5] Read: The prohibition[^fn_46b_6] not to break his word.[^fn_46b_7] \[You say,\] 'The prohibition not to break his word'! Whatever your assumption may be \[a difficulty arises\]. If an intelligent minor[^fn_46b_8] approaching manhood is Pentateuchally forbidden to break his word, he should also incur the penalty of flogging;[^fn_46b_9] and if an intelligent minor approaching manhood is not Pentateuchally forbidden to do it, there should not be[^fn_46b_10] even a mere prohibition?[^fn_46b_11] — The prohibition[^fn_46b_12] applies to those who are responsible for him.[^fn_46b_13] May it then be inferred from this ruling[^fn_46b_14] that if a minor eats *nebelah*[^fn_46b_15] it is the duty of *Beth din* to take it away from him?[^fn_46b_16] Here we may be dealing with a case, for instance, where the minor dedicated the food and others[^fn_46b_17] ate it.[^fn_46b_18] This explanation is quite satisfactory according to him who laid down that if a minor dedicated some food and others[^fn_46b_17] ate it the latter are to be flogged, but what can be said in explanation according to him who ruled that they were not to be flogged; for it was stated: If a minor dedicated some food and others ate it, R. Kahana ruled, They are not to be flogged, while both R. Johanan and Resh Lakish ruled, They are to be flogged? — The prohibition[^fn_46b_19] is[^fn_46b_20] merely Rabbinical[^fn_46b_21] and the Scriptural text[^fn_46b_22] serves as a mere prop.

\[Reverting to\] the above text, 'If a minor dedicated some food and others ate it, R. Kahana ruled, They are not to be flogged, while both R. Johanan and Resh Lakish ruled, They are to be flogged'. On what principle do they differ? — The Masters[^fn_46b_23] are of the opinion that an intelligent minor approaching manhood is under a Pentateuchal obligation[^fn_46b_24] while the Master[^fn_46b_25] is of the opinion that an intelligent minor approaching manhood is only under a Rabbinical obligation.[^fn_46b_24] R. Jeremiah raised an objection: If a fatherless girl[^fn_46b_26] made a vow, her husband may disallow it for her. Now if you grant that an intelligent minor approaching manhood is only under a Rabbinical obligation[^fn_46b_24] one can well justify the ruling,[^fn_46b_27] since the force of a Rabbinical marriage[^fn_46b_28] may well annul a Rabbinical vow, but if you maintain that the obligation[^fn_46b_24] is Pentateuchal, could \[it may be objected\] the force of a Rabbinical marriage[^fn_46b_29] annul a Pentateuchal vow? — R. Judah citing Samuel replied: Her husband may disallow her vow for her whatever your assumption might be. If the minor's obligation[^fn_46b_24] is Rabbinical, the whole matter is a Rabbinical affair; and if the obligation is Pentateuchal, it is a case of a minor who eats *nebelah*[^fn_46b_30] where it is not the duty of the *Beth din* to take it away from him. But would she not be eating, in reliance upon the first disallowance,[^fn_46b_31] even when she attains her majority?[^fn_46b_32] — Rabbah b. Liwai replied: Her husband disallows her vow for her every now and then.[^fn_46b_33] This,[^fn_46b_34] however, applies only to one who cohabited with her.[^fn_46b_35] But, surely, no husband may disallow vows made prior to marriage?[^fn_46b_36] — This[^fn_46b_37] is in agreement with R. Phinehas who cited Raba,[^fn_46b_38] for R. Phinehas citing Raba stated: Any woman who vows acts in reliance on the opinion of her husband.[^fn_46b_39]

Said Abaye, Come and hear: If a minor has not yet grown two hairs, R. Judah ruled, his *terumah* is not[^fn_46b_40] valid; while R. Jose ruled, Before reaching the age when his vows are valid[^fn_46b_41] his *terumah* is not valid, but after reaching the age when his vows are valid[^fn_46b_42] his *terumah* is valid.[^fn_46b_43] Assuming[^fn_46b_44] that R. Jose is of the opinion that *terumah* at the present time is a Pentateuchal institution, his ruling would be well justified if you grant that an intelligent minor approaching manhood is under a Pentateuchal obligation,[^fn_46b_45] since a man under a Pentateuchal obligation may well render fit[^fn_46b_46] Pentateuchal *tebel*,[^fn_46b_47] but if you maintain that he is only under a Rabbinical obligation,[^fn_46b_48] could a man under a Rabbinical obligation render fit Pentateuchal *tebel*?[^fn_46b_49] — No, R. Jose is of the opinion that *terumah* at the present time is only a Rabbinical institution. But does R. Jose hold that *terumah* at the present time is only Rabbinical? Was it not in fact taught in Seder Olam:[^fn_46b_50] 'Which thy fathers possessed and thou shalt possess it,[^fn_46b_51] they had a first,[^fn_46b_52] and a second[^fn_46b_53] possession[^fn_46b_54] but they had no need for a third one';[^fn_46b_55] and R. Johanan stated, 'Who is the author of Seder Olam? R. Jose?'[^fn_46b_56] — R. Jose may well be its compiler[^fn_46b_57] but he himself does not uphold this view.[^fn_46b_58] This[^fn_46b_59] may also be supported by a process of reasoning. For it was taught: A dough[^fn_46b_60] that had become subject to the restrictions of *terumah*[^fn_46b_61] or became sour through a leaven of *terumah*, [pg 47a]

is subject to the obligation of the dough-offering[^fn_47a_1] and[^fn_47a_2] does not become unfit through contact with a tebul yom;[^fn_47a_3] so R. Meir and R. Judah, but R. Jose and R. Simeon exempt it from the obligation of the dough-offering. Assuming[^fn_47a_4] that he who holds that the institution of *terumah*[^fn_47a_5] is Pentateuchal also holds that of the dough-offering[^fn_47a_5] to be Pentateuchal and that he who holds that *terumah*[^fn_47a_5] is Rabbinical also holds the dough-offering[^fn_47a_5] to be Rabbinical, the ruling would be well justified if you grant that R. Jose[^fn_47a_6] is of the opinion that the dough offering at the present time is only Rabbinical, since the Rabbinic law which subjects the dough to the restrictions of *terumah* may well override the Rabbinical law of the dough-offering, but if you maintain that the institution of the dough-offering[^fn_47a_7] is Pentateuchal,[^fn_47a_8] could the Rabbinic law which subjects the dough to the restrictions of *terumah* override the institution of the dough offering which is Pentateuchal?[^fn_47a_9] — But is it not possible that R. Jose holds that *terumah* at the present time is a Pentateuchal institution while the dough offering is only a Rabbinical one, as in fact R. Huna son of R. Joshua stated in a reply?[^fn_47a_10] For R. Huna son of R. Joshua stated, I found the Rabbis of the college sitting at their studies and saying, 'Even according to him who holds that *terumah* at the present time is a Rabbinical institution, the dough offering is a Pentateuchal one, for during the seven years in which they[^fn_47a_11] conquered Canaan and during the seven years in which they divided it[^fn_47a_12] they were under the obligation of the dough offering though they were under no obligation to give tithe'; and I told them, 'Even according to him who holds that *terumah* at the present time is Pentateuchal, the dough offering is only Rabbinical, for it was taught: If Scripture had written, "when you come"13 it might have been presumed \[that the obligation of the dough-offering should come into force\] as soon as two or three spies had entered, hence it is said, In your coming,[^fn_47a_14] I have spoken[^fn_47a_15] only of the coming of all of you and not of the coming of a portion of you; but when Ezra brought them up not all of them went up with him.'[^fn_47a_16]

***MISHNAH***. THE SAGES SPOKE OF \[THE PHYSICAL DEVELOPMENT OF\] A WOMAN IN FIGURATIVE SPEECH: AN UNRIPE FIG, A FIG IN ITS EARLY RIPENING STAGE AND A RIPE FIG. SHE IS LIKE AN UNRIPE FIG' WHILE SHE IS YET A CHILD; A FIG IN ITS EARLY RIPENING STAGE' WHEN SHE IS IN THE AGE OF[^fn_47a_17] HER MAIDENHOOD. DURING BOTH THE LATTER AND THE FORMER AGES,[^fn_47a_18] THEY[^fn_47a_19] RULED, HER FATHER IS ENTITLED TO ANYTHING SHE FINDS AND TO HER HANDIWORK AND TO THE RIGHT OF INVALIDATING HER VOWS. 'A RIPE FIG' — AS SOON AS SHE BECOMES A BOGERETH, AND HER FATHER HAS NO LONGER ANY RIGHT OVER HER. {¶=5.6}

WHAT ARE THE MARKS \[OF A BOGERETH\]? R. JOSE THE GALILEAN SAYS: THE APPEARANCE OF[^fn_47a_20] THE WRINKLE BENEATH THE BREAST. R. AKIBA SAYS: THE HANGING DOWN OF[^fn_47a_21] THE BREASTS. BEN AZZAI SAYS: THE DARKENING OF THE RING AROUND THE NIPPLE. R. JOSE SAYS: \[THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE BREAST TO A STAGE\] WHEN ONE'S HAND BEING PUT ON THE NIPPLE IT SINKS AND ONLY SLOWLY RISES AGAIN.

***GEMARA***. SHE IS LIKE 'AN UNRIPE FIG'[^fn_47a_22] WHILE SHE IS YET A CHILD, as it is written in Scripture, The fig-tree putteth forth her green figs.[^fn_47a_23]

'A FIG IN ITS EARLY RIPENING STAGE',[^fn_47a_24] WHEN SHE IS IN THE AGE OF HER MAIDENHOOD, as we have learnt: Figs \[become subject to tithe\] as soon as they reach an early stage of ripening[^fn_47a_25] and Rabbah b. Bar Hana explained this to mean: As soon as their tips grow white. And if you prefer I might say that the meaning[^fn_47a_26] is derived from the following: For my soul became impatient of them, and their soul also loathed[^fn_47a_27] me.[^fn_47a_28]

A RIPE FIG',[^fn_47a_29] as one would say, 'It has come forth complete.'[^fn_47a_30]

WHAT ARE THE MARKS \[OF A BOGERETH\]? R. JOSE THE GALILEAN SAYS: THE APPEARANCE OF THE WRINKLE. Samuel explained: Not the actual appearance of the wrinkle, but it suffices if, when putting her hands behind her, the wrinkle beneath the breast seems to appear. Samuel[^fn_47a_31] examined his slave and paid her four *zuz* compensation for the indignity. Samuel thereby followed his principle, for Samuel stated: Of them[^fn_47a_32] may ye make bondmen[^fn_47a_33] for ever,[^fn_47a_34] I have given them to you for work[^fn_47a_35] but not to be subjected to indignities. Samuel assigned his female slaves to individual husbands.[^fn_47a_36] R. Nahman interchanged them.[^fn_47a_37] R. Shesheth entrusted them to Arabs[^fn_47a_38] but told them 'Be careful to have no intercourse with an Israelite'.

R. JOSE SAYS etc. What is the meaning of ukaz?[^fn_47a_39] — Samuel replied: The nipple of the breast.

Our Rabbis taught: What are the marks of bagruth? R. Eleazar son of R. Zadok stated, When the breasts begin to shake.[^fn_47a_40] R. Johanan b. Beroka stated, When the top of the nose[^fn_47a_41] grows white. But is not a woman when this grows white already old? — Rather said R. Ashi, when the top of the nose splits.[^fn_47a_42] R. Jose stated, When a ring is formed around the nipple. R. Simeon stated, When the mons veneris grows lower. [pg 47b]

So also did R. Simeon[^fn_47b_1] state: The Sages have indicated in \[the physical development of\] a woman three marks below and corresponding ones above. If, namely, she is like an unripe fig above, it may be taken for granted[^fn_47b_2] that she has not yet grown two hairs. If she is above like a fig in its early ripening, it may be taken for granted[^fn_47b_2] that she has already grown two hairs. If she is like a ripe fig above it may be taken for granted that the mons veneris has grown lower. What is meant by mons veneris? — R. Huna replied: There is a rounded eminence above that place,[^fn_47b_3] and as the girl grows in age it steadily grows lower.

Rabbi was asked:[^fn_47b_4] In agreement with whose view is the *halachah*? He sent word in reply: In agreement with all so as to restrict[^fn_47b_5] the law.[^fn_47b_6] R. Papa and R. Hinena son of R. Ika differ. One taught it[^fn_47b_7] in connection with this,[^fn_47b_8] while the other taught it in connection with the law of the Tyrian courtyard. For we have learnt: Which courtyard[^fn_47b_9] imposes the obligations of tithe?[^fn_47b_10] R. Simeon[^fn_47b_11] ruled: A Tyrian courtyard in which objects are safely kept.[^fn_47b_12] (Why is this described as a Tyrian courtyard? — Rabbah b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan replied: Since in Tyre they put a watchman at the door of a courtyard.) R. Akiba ruled: Any courtyard which one may open and another close[^fn_47b_13] is exempt from tithe.[^fn_47b_14] R. Nehemiah ruled: Any courtyard in which no one is ashamed to eat is subject to tithe.[^fn_47b_15] R. Jose ruled: Any courtyard into which people may enter and none is asked, 'What do you want?' is exempt.[^fn_47b_14] R. Judah ruled: If there were two courtyards, one within the other, the inner one is subject to tithe[^fn_47b_15] while the outer one is exempt.[^fn_47b_14] Rabbi was asked: In agreement with whose view is the *halachah*? He replied: The *halachah* is in agreement with all of them so as to restrict the law.[^fn_47b_16]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN AT THE AGE OF TWENTY DID NOT PRODUCE TWO HAIRS,[^fn_47b_17] SHE MUST BRING EVIDENCE THAT SHE IS TWENTY YEARS OF AGE AND SHE BECOMES CONFIRMED AS A WOMAN WHO IS INCAPABLE OF PROCREATION AND NEITHER PERFORMS *HALIZAH* NOR IS TAKEN IN LEVIRATE MARRIAGE. IF A MAN OF THE AGE OF TWENTY YEARS DID NOT PRODUCE TWO HAIRS,[^fn_47b_17] THEY[^fn_47b_18] MUST BRING EVIDENCE THAT HE IS TWENTY YEARS OLD AND HE BECOMES CONFIRMED[^fn_47b_19] AS A SARIS[^fn_47b_20] AND NEITHER SUBMITS TO *HALIZAH* NOR PERFORMS THE LEVIRATE MARRIAGE; SO BETH HILLEL. BETH SHAMMAI RULED: WITH THE ONE AS WELL AS WITH THE OTHER \[THIS TAKES PLACE AT\] THE AGE OF EIGHTEEN. R. ELIEZER RULED IN THE CASE OF THE MALE, IN AGREEMENT WITH BETH HILLEL, WHILE IN THAT OF THE FEMALE, IN AGREEMENT WITH BETH SHAMMAI, SINCE A WOMAN MATURES EARLIER THAN A MAN. {¶=5.7}

***GEMARA***. But I would point out an incongruity: The same law applies whether one is[^fn_47b_21] of the age of nine years and one day or whether one is of the age of twenty years but had not produced two hairs![^fn_47b_22] — R. Samuel son of R. Isaac citing Rab replied: This law[^fn_47b_23] applies only where other symptoms of a saris[^fn_47b_24] also appeared on him. Raba observed: This[^fn_47b_25] may also be arrived at by a deduction. For it was stated, AND HE BECOMES CONFIRMED AS A SARIS.[^fn_47b_26] This is conclusive.

Where, however, no other symptoms of a saris had developed, how long \[is one[^fn_47b_27] regarded as a minor\]? — R. Hiyya taught: Until he has passed middle age.[^fn_47b_28] Wherever people come with such a case[^fn_47b_29] before R. Hiyya,[^fn_47b_30] he used to tell them, if the youth was emaciated, 'Let him first be fattened'; and if he was stout, he used to tell them, 'Let him first be made to lose weight';[^fn_47b_31] for these symptoms[^fn_47b_32] appear[^fn_47b_33] sometimes as a result of emaciation and sometimes they appear as a result of stoutness.

Rab stated: It is the law throughout this chapter that age is calculated from one point of time to another point of time;[^fn_47b_34] but 'Ulla stated: This is the case only where we have explicitly learnt it.[^fn_47b_35] According to 'Ulla all is well since there is a satisfactory reason why in one case it was stated[^fn_47b_36] 'one day' while in the other this was not stated; but according to Rab, why was not this[^fn_47b_37] stated in all cases?[^fn_47b_38] Furthermore, it was taught: R. Jose b. Kipper stated in the name of R. Eliezer, If thirty days of the twentieth year have passed it is exactly the same as if the entire year had passed;[^fn_47b_39] and so also Rabbi at Lydda ruled, If thirty days of the eighteenth year have passed it is exactly the same as if the entire year had passed.[^fn_47b_40] Now one may well agree that there is no difficulty \[as regards the contradiction between the ruling\] of Rabbi and that of R. Jose b. Kipper, since the former[^fn_47b_41] is in agreement with Beth Shammai[^fn_47b_42] while the latter[^fn_47b_43] is in agreement with Beth Hillel;[^fn_47b_42] but does not this[^fn_47b_44] present a difficulty against Rab?[^fn_47b_45] — This[^fn_47b_46] is a question in dispute between Tannas.[^fn_47b_47] For it was taught: The year that is mentioned in connection with consecrated things;[^fn_47b_48] the year that is mentioned in connection with houses in walled cities;[^fn_47b_49] the two years[^fn_47b_50] in connection with a field of one's possession;[^fn_47b_51] the six years in connection with a Hebrew servant,[^fn_47b_52] and so also the years in the age of a son and a daughter[^fn_47b_53] are all to be calculated from one point of time to another point of time.[^fn_47b_54] Whence do we deduce the duration of the year that was mentioned in connection with consecrated things? R. Aha b. Jacob replied: Scripture said, A lamb of its[^fn_47b_55] year,[^fn_47b_56] which implies, Its own year and not a calendar year.[^fn_47b_57] Whence do we deduce the duration of the year that was mentioned in connection with the houses in walled cities? — Scripture said, Until the end of his year of sale[^fn_47b_58] which implies, Only his year of sale but not a calendar year.[^fn_47b_57] Whence do we deduce the duration of the two years in connection with a field of one's possession? — Scripture said, According unto the number of [pg 48a]

years of the crops he shall sell unto thee,[^fn_48a_1] which implies[^fn_48a_2] that one may sometimes sell three crops in two years.[^fn_48a_3] Whence do we deduce the duration of the six years in connection with a Hebrew servant? — Scripture said, Six years he shall serve, and in the seventh,[^fn_48a_4] which implies that in the seventh \[calendar\] year also he shall serve.[^fn_48a_5] In regard to what law was mention made of 'the years in the age of a son and a daughter'?[^fn_48a_6] — R. Giddal citing Rab replied: In regard to valuations.[^fn_48a_7] R. Joseph, however, replied: In regard to the ages[^fn_48a_8] given in our chapter of 'For a foetus born from its mother's side'.[^fn_48a_9] Said Abaye to him,[^fn_48a_10] 'Are you in disagreement?'[^fn_48a_11] — 'No', the other replied, 'he made one statement and I made another statement but there is no essential difference between us'. This is also logically right; for if it could be imagined that there is a radical difference between them and that the one[^fn_48a_12] who replied, 'In regard to valuations' does not accept the reply, 'In regard to our present chapter'[^fn_48a_13] \[the difficulty would arise:\] Did not Rab in fact state, 'It is the law throughout this chapter that age is calculated from one point of time to another point of time'?[^fn_48a_14] But, then, why did not the one[^fn_48a_15] who replied, 'In regard to valuations' also add, In regard to our chapter?[^fn_48a_16] — \[The reference[^fn_48a_17] must be to cases\] similar to those previously enumerated: As those[^fn_48a_18] were recorded in the Scriptures so must these[^fn_48a_17] be such as were recorded in the Scriptures.[^fn_48a_19] And the other?[^fn_48a_20] — \[If that were so\] it should have been said,[^fn_48a_17] instead of 'the age of a son and a daughter', the age of a male and a female.[^fn_48a_21]

R. Isaac b. Nahmani citing R. Eleazar[^fn_48a_22] stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with the ruling which R. Jose b. Kipper cited in the name of R. Eliezer.[^fn_48a_23] R. Zera observed: May I be worthy to go up[^fn_48a_24] and to learn the tradition[^fn_48a_25] from the Master's mouth. When he went up[^fn_48a_24] he met R. Eleazar and asked him, 'Did you say: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Jose b. Kipper?' — 'What I said was', the other replied, 'that it seemed to be reasonable. For since, throughout the chapter, "one day" was explicitly added[^fn_48a_26] while in this case[^fn_48a_27] it was not mentioned it may well be inferred that it seems reasonable \[that the *halachah* is\] in agreement with him'.

## CHAPTER VI

***MISHNAH***. IF THE LOWER MARK[^fn_48a_28] APPEARED BEFORE THE UPPER ONE[^fn_48a_29] HAD YET MADE ITS APPEARANCE, SHE MAY PERFORM *HALIZAH* OR CONTRACT LEVIRATE MARRIAGE.[^fn_48a_30] IF THE UPPER MARK[^fn_48a_29] APPEARED BEFORE THE LOWER ONE[^fn_48a_28] HAD MADE ITS APPEARANCE, THOUGH THIS IS IMPOSSIBLE,[^fn_48a_31] R. MEIR RULED, SHE MAY NEITHER PERFORM *HALIZAH* NOR CONTRACT THE LEVIRATE MARRIAGE; BUT THE SAGES RULED, SHE MAY EITHER PERFORM *HALIZAH* OR CONTRACT THE LEVIRATE MARRIAGE, BECAUSE THEY MAINTAIN: IT IS POSSIBLE FOR THE LOWER MARK TO APPEAR BEFORE THE UPPER ONE HAD YET MADE ITS APPEARANCE, BUT IT IS IMPOSSIBLE FOR THE UPPER MARK TO APPEAR BEFORE THE LOWER ONE HAD MADE ITS APPEARANCE.[^fn_48a_32] {¶=6.1}

***GEMARA***. 'THOUGH THIS IS IMPOSSIBLE'! But has it not in fact APPEARED?[^fn_48a_33] — 'APPEARED', according to R. Meir;[^fn_48a_34] 'THOUGH THIS IS IMPOSSIBLE' according to the Rabbis.[^fn_48a_35] Why then was it not stated: 'If the upper mark appeared, R. Meir ruled, She may neither perform *halizah* nor contract levirate marriage but the Sages ruled, She may either perform *halizah* or contract levirate marriage'. and I would well have known that their reason is that it is impossible?[^fn_48a_36] — If 'THOUGH THIS IS IMPOSSIBLE had not been stated, It might have been presumed that in most women the lower mark appears first and in that of a minority the upper mark appears first, and that R. Meir[^fn_48a_37] is guided by his principle according to which he takes even a minority into consideration,[^fn_48a_38] while the Rabbis[^fn_48a_39] are guided by their principle according to which they do not take a minority into consideration;[^fn_48a_40] and that this[^fn_48a_41] applies only to a general case, but where an examination was held and no \[lower mark\] was found the Rabbis, it might have been assumed, agree with R. Meir[^fn_48a_37] since the upper mark has appeared first, hence we were informed that this IS IMPOSSIBLE and that the lower mark[^fn_48a_42] had undoubtedly appeared earlier but merely fell off. According to R. Meir[^fn_48a_43] one may well justify the Scriptural text, Thy breasts[^fn_48a_44] were fashioned, and thy hair[^fn_48a_45] was grown,[^fn_48a_46] but according to the Rabbis,[^fn_48a_47] should not the order have been reversed?[^fn_48a_48] — It is this that was meant: As soon as the 'breasts are fashioned' it is known that 'thy hair was grown'. According to R. Meir[^fn_48a_49] one can well see the justification for the order of the Scriptural text, When they from Egypt bruised thy breasts[^fn_48a_44] for the bosom[^fn_48a_45] of thy youth.[^fn_48a_50] but according to the Rabbis,[^fn_48a_47] should not the order have been reversed?[^fn_48a_48] — It is this that was meant: As soon as 'thy breasts' appeared it is known that thy youth[^fn_48a_45] had appeared. And if you prefer I might reply: As to the meaning of[^fn_48a_51] shede,[^fn_48a_52] all the clause was written with regard to the breasts; and it is this that the Holy One, blessed be He, said in effect to Israel: [pg 48b]

'Thy breasts were swollen, yet thou didst not repent; yea, thy breasts were dried up, yet thou didst not repent'.[^fn_48b_1] All[^fn_48b_2] at any rate agree that[^fn_48b_3] we rely on the lower mark; whence do we deduce this? — Rab Judah citing Rab replied and so it was taught at the school of R. Ishmael: Scripture said, When a man or a woman shall commit any sin that men commit,[^fn_48b_4] Scripture[^fn_48b_5] compared the 'woman' to the 'man' in respect of all the punishments in the Torah; as a man is subject to punishments on the appearance of the one mark[^fn_48b_6] so is also a woman subject to punishments on the appearance of the one mark. Might it not be suggested: Either the one or the other?[^fn_48b_7] — Like the man: As with the man \[the determining factor\] is the lower mark and not the upper one so also with the woman it is the lower one that determines majority but not the upper one. So[^fn_48b_8] it was also taught: R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok stated, Thus did they explain and promulgate at Jamnia: As soon as the lower mark makes its appearance no attention need any longer be paid to the upper one.

It was taught: R. Simeon b. Gamaliel stated, Among towns-women the lower mark appears earlier because they are in the habit of taking baths; among village women the upper mark appears earlier because they grind with millstones.[^fn_48b_9] R. Simeon b. Eleazar stated: Among the daughters of the rich the right hand side develops earlier because it rubs against their scarves;[^fn_48b_10] among the daughters of the poor the left side develops earlier because they carry[^fn_48b_11] jars of water on them. And if you prefer I might say, Because they carry their brothers on their sides.

Our Rabbis taught: The left side develops earlier than the right side. R. Hanina the son of the brother of R. Joshua stated: The left side never developed earlier than the right side except in the case of one woman who lived in our neighbourhood whose left side developed earlier than the right one which later regained its normal strength.

Our Rabbis taught: All girls to be examined must be examined by women. So also R. Eliezer entrusted the examination to his wife, and R. Ishmael entrusted it to his mother. R. Judah ruled: Before the period[^fn_48b_12] and after the period,[^fn_48b_13] women examine them.[^fn_48b_14] During the period[^fn_48b_15] no woman may examine them, since in doubtful cases[^fn_48b_16] no woman is allowed to marry[^fn_48b_17] on the evidence of women. R. Simeon ruled, Even during the period[^fn_48b_15] women examine them. And a woman may be relied upon when by her evidence the law is restricted but not when it is relaxed thereby. How so? \[She may be relied upon when she states: 'The girl\] is of age', so that the latter should thereby be denied the right of *mi'un*, or 'She is a minor', so that she should thereby be denied the right of performing *halizah*; but she is not trusted when asserting, 'She is a minor', so that she should have the right of exercising *mi'un*, or 'She is of age', so that she should be entitled to perform *halizah*.

The Master said, 'R. Judah ruled: Before the period and after the period women examine them'. One can well concede that before the period an examination is required, for should \[the same hairs\][^fn_48b_18] be found after the period they would be regarded as a mole;[^fn_48b_19] but what need could there be for an examination after the period seeing that Raba has laid down that a minor who has attained the age of her majority need not be examined since there is presumption that she had by that time produced the marks of puberty? — When Raba stated, 'there is presumption', he meant it in respect of *mi'un*,[^fn_48b_20] but as regards *halizah*[^fn_48b_21] an examination is still required.[^fn_48b_22] 'During the period no women may examine them', because he is of the opinion \[that the presence of hairs\] during the period \[is a mark of majority\] as after the period;[^fn_48b_23] but after the period, when Raba's presumption is applicable, we rely upon women who may, therefore, conduct the examination,[^fn_48b_22] while during the period, when Raba's presumption is not applicable, we cannot rely upon women, and women, therefore, may not conduct the examination. 'R. Simeon ruled, Even during the period women examine them', for he is of the opinion \[that the presence of hairs\] during the period \[is no more a mark of puberty\] than it is before the period; and an examination is, therefore, required so that if \[the same hairs\][^fn_48b_24] should be found after the period they would be regarded as a mole.[^fn_48b_25] 'And a woman may be relied upon when by her evidence the law is restricted but not when it is relaxed thereby.' Who taught this? — If you wish I might say: R. Judah, and \[the reference is to evidence\] during the period.[^fn_48b_26] [pg 49a]

And if you prefer I might say: R. Simeon, and \[the reference is to evidence\] after the period,[^fn_49a_1] for he does not uphold the principle of Raba's presumption.

BECAUSE THEY MAINTAIN: IT IS POSSIBLE etc. What need again was there for this statement, seeing that it was already taught in the earlier clause? And were you to reply: Because it was desired to lay down an anonymous statement[^fn_49a_2] in agreement with the Rabbis \[it could be objected:\] Is not this obvious, since in a dispute between an individual authority and a number of authorities the *halachah* is in agreement with the majority? — It might have been presumed that R. Meir's reason is more acceptable because Scriptural texts[^fn_49a_3] provide support for his view, hence we were informed[^fn_49a_4] \[that the *halachah* is in agreement with the view of the Rabbis\]. And if you prefer I might reply: Because it was desired to state,[^fn_49a_5] 'Similarly'.[^fn_49a_6]

***MISHNAH***. SIMILARLY[^fn_49a_7] ANY \[HOLE IN\] AN EARTHEN VESSEL THAT LETS IN A LIQUID[^fn_49a_8] WILL[^fn_49a_9] LET IT OUT,[^fn_49a_10] BUT THERE MAY BE ONE THAT WILL LET IT OUT AND WILL NOT LET IT IN.[^fn_49a_11] ANY LIMB[^fn_49a_12] THAT GROWS A NAIL HAS ALSO A BONE IN IT[^fn_49a_13] BUT THERE MAY BE ONE THAT HAS A BONE IN IT BUT GROWS NO NAIL.[^fn_49a_14] WHATEVER CONTRACTS MIDRAS-UNCLEANNESS[^fn_49a_15] ALSO CONTRACTS CORPSE-UNCLEANNESS[^fn_49a_16] BUT THERE ARE SUCH AS CONTRACT CORPSE UNCLEANNESS[^fn_49a_17] AND DO NOT CONTRACT MIDRAS-UNCLEANNESS.[^fn_49a_18] {¶=6.2}

***GEMARA***. A vessel with a hole THAT LETS IN A LIQUID is unfit for the water of purification[^fn_49a_19] and is \[even more so\] unfit[^fn_49a_20] as a defective vessel;[^fn_49a_21] one with a hole THAT WILL LET IT OUT[^fn_49a_22] is fit for the water of purification[^fn_49a_23] but unfit as a defective vessel.[^fn_49a_24]

R. Assi stated, It was learnt,[^fn_49a_25] The minimum size \[of a hole to render\] an earthen vessel \[unfit for the consecration of the water of purification\] is one that will let a liquid in;[^fn_49a_26] and one that will let a liquid out[^fn_49a_22] was mentioned only in respect of a defective vessel.[^fn_49a_24] What is the reason?[^fn_49a_27] — Mar Zutra son of R. Nahman replied: Because people do not say,[^fn_49a_28] 'Bring a defective vessel for another defective vessel'.[^fn_49a_29]

Our Rabbis taught: How is an earthen vessel to be tested in order to ascertain whether its perforation is big enough to admit a liquid or not? One brings a tub full of water and puts the pot[^fn_49a_30] into it. If it absorbs any of the liquid, it may be taken for granted that it lets liquids in; and if not, it may be taken for granted that it only lets liquids out. [pg 49b]

R. Judah[^fn_49b_1] said: One inverts the handles of the pot into the tub[^fn_49b_2] and allows water to float over it. If it then absorbs any, it may be taken for granted that it will let liquids in; but if not, it may be taken for granted that it only lets liquids out. Or else, it[^fn_49b_3] may be put upon a fire. If the fire stops the leakage it is certain that the pot will only let liquids out; but if not it is certain that it also lets liquids in. R. Jose said: One does not put it upon the actual[^fn_49b_4] fire since the fire stops it,[^fn_49b_5] but it is put upon embers. If the embers stop it, it is certain that it only lets liquids out, but if not, it is certain that it also lets liquids in. If it drips drop after drop[^fn_49b_6] it is certain that it lets liquids in. What is the practical difference between the first Tanna[^fn_49b_7] and R. Judah? — 'Ulla replied: The practical difference between them is a case of absorption under pressure.[^fn_49b_8]

ANY LIMB THAT GROWS A NAIL etc. If it grows a nail[^fn_49b_9] it[^fn_49b_10] conveys uncleanness[^fn_49b_11] by means of touch, carriage and overshadowing. If it contains a bone but grows no nail it conveys uncleanness[^fn_49b_12] by means of touch and carriage but does not convey it by means of overshadowing.[^fn_49b_13]

R. Hisda stated: The following was said by our great Master,[^fn_49b_14] may the Omnipresent be his help. A redundant finger that contains a bone but grows no nail conveys uncleanness[^fn_49b_12] by means of touch and carriage but does not convey it by means of overshadowing. Rabbah b. Bar Hana explained: This is the case only when it[^fn_49b_15] is not counted in \[the row of the fingers of\] the hand.[^fn_49b_16]

WHATEVER CONTRACTS MIDRAS — UNCLEANNESS etc. Whatever object is fit for midras contracts corpse-uncleanness, but there are such as contract corpse-uncleanness and do not contract midras-uncleanness. What is this rule intended to include? — It is intended to include a *se'ah* measure and a *tarkab*;[^fn_49b_17] for it was taught: And he that sitteth on any thing;[^fn_49b_18] as it might have been presumed that if the *zab* inverted a *se'ah* measure and sat upon it or a *tarkab* measure and sat upon it, it shall be unclean,[^fn_49b_19] it was explicitly stated, Whereon he that hath the issue sat,[^fn_49b_18] implying[^fn_49b_20] that the text refers only to a thing that is appointed for sitting;[^fn_49b_21] but this one[^fn_49b_22] is excluded, since people would tell him, 'Get up that we may do our work with it'.[^fn_49b_23]

***MISHNAH***. WHOSOEVER IS FIT TO TRY CAPITAL CASES IS ALSO FIT TO TRY MONETARY SUITS, BUT ONE MAY BE FIT TO TRY MONETARY SUITS AND YET BE UNFIT TO TRY CAPITAL CASES. {¶=6.3}

***GEMARA***. Rab Judah stated: This[^fn_49b_24] was meant to include a bastard.[^fn_49b_25] Have we not, however, learnt this once before: 'All are eligible to try monetary suits but not all eligible to try capital cases';[^fn_49b_26] and when the question was raised, 'What was this intended to include?' Rab Judah replied, 'It was intended to include a bastard'?[^fn_49b_27] — One statement was intended to include a proselyte and the other to include a bastard. And both statements were necessary. For if we had been informed of the proselyte only it might have been presumed that it applied to him alone because he is eligible to enter the Assembly[^fn_49b_28] but not to a bastard who is not eligible to enter the Assembly.[^fn_49b_29] And if we had been informed of the bastard only it might have been presumed to apply to him alone because he issues from an eligible source[^fn_49b_30] but not to a proselyte who issues from an ineligible source.[^fn_49b_31] Hence the necessity for both rulings.

***MISHNAH***. WHOSOEVER IS ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS JUDGE IS[^fn_49b_32] ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS WITNESS, BUT ONE MAY BE ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS WITNESS AND NOT AS JUDGE. {¶=6.4}

***GEMARA***. What \[was this[^fn_49b_33] intended\] to include? — R. Johanan replied: To include one who is blind in one eye;[^fn_49b_34] and who is the author? [pg 50a]

— R. Meir.[^fn_50a_1] For it was taught: R. Meir used to say, What was the purport of the Scriptural text, According to their word shall every controversy and every leprosy be?[^fn_50a_2] What connection could controversies have with leprosies? But[^fn_50a_3] controversies were compared to leprosies, as leprosies must be examined by day, since it is written, And in the day when … appeareth in him,[^fn_50a_4] so must controversies be tried by day; and[^fn_50a_5] as leprosies are not to be examined by a blind man,[^fn_50a_6] since it is written, Wherever the priest looketh,[^fn_50a_7] so are controversies not to be tried by a blind man.[^fn_50a_6] And[^fn_50a_8] leprosies are further compared to controversies: As controversies are not to be tried by relatives, so are leprosies not to be examined by relatives. In case \[one were to argue:\] 'As controversies must be tried by three men so must leprosies also be examined by three men, this being logically arrived at a minori ad majus: If controversies affecting one's wealth must be tried by three men, how much more so matters affecting one's body', it was explicitly stated, When he shall be brought unto Aaron the priest or unto one of his sons the priests.[^fn_50a_9] Thus you have learnt that even a single[^fn_50a_10] priest may examine leprosies.[^fn_50a_11]

A certain blind man who lived in the neighbourhood of R. Johanan used to try lawsuits and the latter[^fn_50a_12] told him nothing against it. But how could he[^fn_50a_12] act in this manner, seeing that R. Johanan actually stated, 'The *halachah* is in agreement with an anonymous Mishnah', and we have learnt,[^fn_50a_13] WHOSOEVER IS ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS JUDGE IS ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS WITNESS, BUT ONE MAY BE ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS WITNESS AND NOT AS JUDGE, and when the question was raised, 'What was this intended to include?' R. Johanan replied, 'To include one who is blind in one eye'?[^fn_50a_14] — R. Johanan found another anonymous Mishnah.[^fn_50a_15] For we have learnt, Monetary suits must be tried by day and may be concluded by night.[^fn_50a_16] But why should this anonymous Mishnah[^fn_50a_17] be deemed more authoritative than the former?[^fn_50a_18] If you wish I might reply: An anonymous Mishnah which represents the view of a majority[^fn_50a_19] is preferable. And if you prefer I might reply: Because it[^fn_50a_20] was taught among the laws of legal procedure.[^fn_50a_21]

***MISHNAH***. WHATSOEVER IS SUBJECT TO TITHES IS SUSCEPTIBLE TO FOOD-UNCLEANNESS;[^fn_50a_22] BUT THERE IS A KIND OF FOODSTUFF[^fn_50a_23] THAT IS SUSCEPTIBLE TO FOOD-UNCLEANNESS AND IS NOT SUBJECT TO TITHES. {¶=6.5}

***GEMARA***. What was this[^fn_50a_24] intended to include? — To include flesh, fish and eggs.[^fn_50a_25]

***MISHNAH***. WHATSOEVER IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION OF *PE'AH*[^fn_50a_26] IS ALSO SUBJECT TO THAT OF TITHES; BUT THERE IS A KIND OF PRODUCE WHICH IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION OF TITHES AND IS NOT SUBJECT TO THAT OF *PE'AH*. {¶=6.6}

***GEMARA***. What was this[^fn_50a_24] intended to include? — To include the fig-tree and vegetables, which are not subject to the obligation of *pe'ah*.[^fn_50a_27] For we have learnt: They[^fn_50a_28] have laid down a general rule concerning *pe'ah*. Whatsoever is a foodstuff, is kept under watch, grows[^fn_50a_29] from the ground, is all harvested at the same time, and is taken in for storage, is subject to *pe'ah*.[^fn_50a_30] 'A foodstuff', excludes the after-growths of woad and madder;[^fn_50a_31] 'is kept under watch', excludes hefker; 'grows[^fn_50a_32] from the ground', excludes morils and truffles;[^fn_50a_33] 'is all harvested at the same time', excludes the fig-tree;[^fn_50a_34] and is taken in for storage', excludes vegetables. As regards tithes, however, we have learnt: Whatsoever is a foodstuff, is kept under watch and grows from the ground is subject to the obligation of tithes;[^fn_50a_35] whereas 'is all harvested at the same time[^fn_50a_36] and is taken in for storage'[^fn_50a_37] was not mentioned.[^fn_50a_38] But if garlic or onions[^fn_50a_39] grew among them[^fn_50a_40] they are subject \[to *pe'ah*\]. For we have learnt: As regards plots of onions between other vegetables, R. Jose ruled, *Pe'ah* must be left from each[^fn_50a_41] and the Sages ruled, From one for all.[^fn_50a_42]

Rabbah b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan ruled: If endives were originally sown for cattle-food and then \[the owner\] changed his mind[^fn_50a_43] to use them for human food, [pg 50b]

it is necessary[^fn_50b_1] that he should intend them for the purpose[^fn_50b_2] after they had been detached; he being of the opinion that intention[^fn_50b_2] concerning attached \[produce\] is no valid intention. Raba observed: We also have learnt a rule to the same effect: Thirteen things have been said about the carrion of a clean bird, (and the following is one of them).[^fn_50b_3] It is necessary[^fn_50b_4] that it should be intended for food but there is no need for it to be rendered[^fn_50b_5] susceptible to uncleanness.[^fn_50b_6] Thus it is clearly evident that[^fn_50b_7] an intention concerning a live being is no valid intention; so also here[^fn_50b_8] it must be said, that an intention concerning attached \[produce\][^fn_50b_9] is no valid intention.[^fn_50b_10] R. Zera said:[^fn_50b_11] We are dealing here[^fn_50b_12] with a \[flying\] pigeon that dropped from on high, so that it was not before us[^fn_50b_13] to enable one to have any intentions about it.[^fn_50b_14] Said Abaye to him:[^fn_50b_15] What can be said about the \[case of the\] hen of Jamnia?[^fn_50b_16] — That, the other[^fn_50b_15] replied, was a wild cock.[^fn_50b_17] They laughed at him: A wild cock is an unclean bird and an unclean bird does not convey uncleanness![^fn_50b_18] — 'When a great man', Abaye told them, 'said something, do not laugh at him. This was a case of a hen that ran away;[^fn_50b_19] and as to the meaning[^fn_50b_20] of "wild", it turned wild as far as its master was concerned'.[^fn_50b_21] R. Papa said: It was a field-hen.[^fn_50b_22] R. Papa thus followed his known view. For R. Papa ruled, A field-cock is forbidden and a field-hen is permitted; and your mnemonic is 'A male Ammonite[^fn_50b_23] but not a female Ammonite'. Amemar laid down in his discourse that a field-hen is forbidden.[^fn_50b_24] The Rabbis observed that it stamps on its prey[^fn_50b_25] when eating it;[^fn_50b_26] and it is this bird that is known as *girutha*.[^fn_50b_27]

Our Rabbis taught: If a pigeon[^fn_50b_28] fell into a winepress[^fn_50b_29] and it was intended to pick it up for a Samaritan,[^fn_50b_30] it is unclean;[^fn_50b_31] but if it was intended for a dog it is clean,[^fn_50b_32] R. Johanan b. Nuri[^fn_50b_33] ruled, Even if intended for a dog it is unclean.[^fn_50b_31] R. Johanan b. Nuri argued: This is arrived at a minori ad majus. If it[^fn_50b_34] conveys a major uncleanness,[^fn_50b_35] though there was no intention,[^fn_50b_36] should it not convey a minor uncleanness[^fn_50b_37] though there was no intention? They answered him: No; if you maintain your view in the case of a major uncleanness, which never descends to that,[^fn_50b_38] would you also maintain it in the case of a minor uncleanness which does descend to that?[^fn_50b_38] He replied: the hen of Jamnia proves my contention, for it descends to that and, though there was no intention, it was declared unclean. 'From there', they retorted, 'is your proof? In that place there were Samaritans and it was intended that they shall eat it.' Now with what case are we dealing here? If it be suggested with big cities \[the objection would arise\]: What need was there for intention, seeing that we have learnt: The carcass of a clean beast anywhere[^fn_50b_39] and the carcass of a clean bird and forbidden fat in large towns[^fn_50b_40] require neither intention nor to be rendered susceptible.[^fn_50b_41] If, however, it is suggested: Of villages, \[the difficulty arises:\] Is there any authority who maintains that in this case no intention is required, seeing that we have learnt: The carcass of an unclean beast[^fn_50b_42] anywhere[^fn_50b_43] and the carcass of a clean bird in villages[^fn_50b_44] require[^fn_50b_45] intention[^fn_50b_46] but need not be rendered susceptible?[^fn_50b_47] — R. Ze'ira b. Hanina replied: We are in fact dealing with an incident in a big city, but[^fn_50b_48] the winepress caused it[^fn_50b_49] to be objectionable[^fn_50b_50] and thus caused the town to be regarded as a village.

'R. Johanan b. Nuri argued: This is arrived at a minori ad majus. If it conveys a major uncleanness, though there was no intention, should it not convey a minor uncleanness though there was no intention? They answered him: No; if you maintain your view in the case of a major uncleanness which never descends to that.' What is meant by 'it never descends to that'? — Raba replied: It is this that they[^fn_50b_51] in effect said to him,[^fn_50b_52] 'No; if you maintain your view [pg 51a]

in the case of a major uncleanness which never causes an uncleanness of the same grade,[^fn_51a_1] would you also maintain it in the case of a minor uncleanness which does cause an uncleanness of the same grade?'[^fn_51a_2] Said Abaye to him: \[Should not this[^fn_51a_3] apply to the latter\] with even more reason: If a major uncleanness, concerning which the law has been relaxed in that it does not cause an uncleanness of the same grade,[^fn_51a_4] conveys uncleanness in the absence of intention, how much more then should a minor uncleanness, concerning which the law has been restricted in that it does cause uncleanness of the same grade,[^fn_51a_5] convey uncleanness even where there was no intention? — Rather, said R. Shesheth, It is this that they[^fn_51a_6] implied: 'No; if you maintain your view[^fn_51a_7] in the case of a major uncleanness, which need not be rendered susceptible,[^fn_51a_8] would you also maintain it[^fn_51a_7] in the case of a minor uncleanness which does require to be rendered susceptible?' But is it required to be rendered susceptible? Have we not in fact learnt:[^fn_51a_9] Three[^fn_51a_10] things have been said about the carrion of a clean bird,[^fn_51a_11] it is necessary that it should be intended for food, it conveys uncleanness through the oesophagus only,[^fn_51a_12] and there is no need for it to be rendered susceptible?[^fn_51a_13] — Granted that it is not required that a dead creeping thing shall render it susceptible,[^fn_51a_14] it is nevertheless necessary that it shall be rendered susceptible[^fn_51a_15] by means of water.[^fn_51a_16] Why[^fn_51a_17] is it not required that a dead creeping thing shall render it susceptible? In agreement with what the school of R. Ishmael taught. But then there should be no need for it to be rendered susceptible by means of water also in agreement with what the school of R. Ishmael taught; for the school of R. Ishmael taught: Upon any sowing seed which is to be sown,[^fn_51a_18] as seeds[^fn_51a_15] which do not eventually contract a major uncleanness[^fn_51a_19] must[^fn_51a_20] be rendered susceptible so must any other thing which does not eventually contract a major uncleanness be rendered susceptible; the carcass of a clean bird is excluded, in that it need not be rendered susceptible, since it eventually contracts a major uncleanness?[^fn_51a_21] — Rather, replied Raba, or as some say R. Papa, \[the reference[^fn_51a_22] is to\] a major uncleanness in general and to a minor uncleanness in general.[^fn_51a_23]

Raba stated: R. Johanan,[^fn_51a_24] however, agrees in regard to tithe that intention[^fn_51a_25] concerning attached \[produce\] is a valid intention.[^fn_51a_26] Raba explained, Whence do I derive this? From what we learnt: Savory,[^fn_51a_27] hyssop and calamint[^fn_51a_28] that are grown in a courtyard, if they are kept under watch,[^fn_51a_29] are subject to tithe.[^fn_51a_30] Now how are we to imagine the circumstances?[^fn_51a_31] If it be suggested that these herbs were originally sown for human consumption \[the difficulty would arise\]: Was it at all necessary to enunciate such a law?[^fn_51a_32] Consequently the circumstances must be such, must they not, that the herbs were originally sown for cattle food; and yet it was stated, 'if they are kept under watch'[^fn_51a_33] they 'are subject to tithe'.[^fn_51a_34] R. Ashi retorted: Here[^fn_51a_30] we are dealing with a courtyard in which the herbs grew spontaneously[^fn_51a_35] so that as a rule they are destined for human consumption, and[^fn_51a_36] it is this that was meant: If the courtyard affords protection for the produce it grows[^fn_51a_37] the herbs are subject to tithe; otherwise they are exempt.[^fn_51a_38]

R. Ashi objected:[^fn_51a_39] Whatsoever is subject to tithes is susceptible to food uncleanness.[^fn_51a_40] Now if that were so,[^fn_51a_41] would there not be the case of these[^fn_51a_42] which are liable to tithe[^fn_51a_43] and yet[^fn_51a_44] do not become susceptible to the uncleanness of food?[^fn_51a_45] — The fact is, said Raba, that it is this that was meant: Any species that is liable to tithe is susceptible to food uncleanness. This[^fn_51a_46] is also logically sound. For in the final clause[^fn_51a_47] it was stated, Whatsoever is subject to the law of the first of the fleece[^fn_51a_48] is also subject to that of the priestly gifts[^fn_51a_49] but there may be a beast[^fn_51a_50] that is subject to the law of the priestly gifts and is not subject to that of the first of the fleece.[^fn_51a_51] Now if it were so[^fn_51a_52] \[the objection would arise\]: Is there not also the case of the *terefah* which is subject to the law of the first of the fleece and yet is not subject to that of the priestly gifts?[^fn_51a_53] — Rabina retorted: This[^fn_51a_54] represents the view of[^fn_51a_55] R. Simeon. For it was taught:[^fn_51a_56] R. Simeon exempts the *terefah* from the law of the first of the fleece.[^fn_51a_57] R. Shimi b. Ashi replied,[^fn_51a_58] Come and hear: If a man declared his vineyard hefker[^fn_51a_59] and, rising early in the morning, he cut its grapes, he is liable[^fn_51a_60] to peret,[^fn_51a_61] 'oleloth,[^fn_51a_62] the forgotten sheaf[^fn_51a_63] and *pe'ah*[^fn_51a_64] but[^fn_51a_65] is exempt from tithe.[^fn_51a_66] But have we not learnt: WHATSOEVER IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION OF *PE'AH* IS ALSO SUBJECT TO THAT OF TITHES?[^fn_51a_67] Must you not then infer from this[^fn_51a_68] that the reference[^fn_51a_69] was[^fn_51a_70] to the whole species?[^fn_51a_71] This is conclusive.

Elsewhere we have learnt:[^fn_51a_72] The Sages agree with R. Akiba that if a man sowed dill or mustard seed in two or three different spots he must allow *pe'ah* from each.[^fn_51a_73] [pg 51b]

Now dill, surely, since it is liable to *pe'ah* is also liable[^fn_51b_1] to tithe, for we have learnt, WHATSOEVER IS SUBJECT TO THE OBLIGATION OF *PE'AH* IS ALSO SUBJECT TO THAT OF TITHES; and since it is liable to tithe it is also susceptible to food uncleanness. It is accordingly evident that anything that is used as a flavouring is susceptible to food uncleanness, since dill is used as a flavouring. But is not this incongruous with the following: 'Castus,[^fn_51b_2] amomum,[^fn_51b_3] and the principal spices, crowfoot, asafoetida, pepper and lozenges of bastard safron may be bought with second tithe money but they are not susceptible to food uncleanness; so R. Akiba. Said R. Johanan b. Nuri to him: If they may be bought with second tithe money why are they not susceptible to food uncleanness? And if they are not susceptible,[^fn_51b_4] they[^fn_51b_5] should not be bought with second tithe money',[^fn_51b_6] and in connection with this R. Johanan b. Nuri stated, 'A vote was taken and they decided that these are not to be bought with second tithe money and that they are not susceptible to food uncleanness'?[^fn_51b_7] — R. Hisda replied: When that Mishnah[^fn_51b_8] was taught the reference was to dill intended as an ingredient[^fn_51b_9] of kamak.[^fn_51b_10] R. Ashi stated, I submitted the following argument before R. Kahana:[^fn_51b_11] Do not say, 'The reference was to dill intended[^fn_51b_12] as an ingredient of kamak', from which it would follow that generally[^fn_51b_13] it is used as flavouring matter,[^fn_51b_14] but rather that dill is generally intended as an ingredient of kamak.[^fn_51b_15] For we have learnt: Dill,[^fn_51b_16] as soon as it has imparted some flavour to a dish, is no longer subject to the restrictions of *terumah*[^fn_51b_17] and it is no longer susceptible to food uncleanness.[^fn_51b_18] From which it follows that before it had imparted any flavour to a dish it is subject to the restrictions of *terumah* and is susceptible to food uncleanness.[^fn_51b_19] Now if you were to imagine that as a rule it is used for flavouring[^fn_51b_14] \[the difficulty would arise\]: Even if it had not imparted any flavour to a dish \[should it not be free from the restrictions of food since\] as a rule it is used for flavouring?[^fn_51b_20] Must you not then infer from this[^fn_51b_21] that generally it is used as an ingredient of kamak?[^fn_51b_15] This is conclusive.

***MISHNAH***. WHATSOEVER IS SUBJECT TO THE LAW OF THE FIRST OF THE FLEECE[^fn_51b_22] IS ALSO SUBJECT TO THAT OF THE PRIESTLY GIFTS,[^fn_51b_23] BUT THERE MAY BE \[A BEAST\][^fn_51b_24] THAT IS SUBJECT TO THE LAW OF THE PRIESTLY GIFTS AND NOT TO THAT OF THE FIRST OF THE FLEECE. WHATSOEVER IS SUBJECT TO THE LAW OF REMOVAL[^fn_51b_25] IS ALSO SUBJECT TO THE RESTRICTIONS OF THE SABBATICAL YEAR,[^fn_51b_26] BUT THERE IS \[A KIND OR PRODUCE\] THAT IS SUBJECT TO THE RESTRICTIONS OF THE SABBATICAL YEAR[^fn_51b_26] AND IS NOT SUBJECT TO THE LAW OF REMOVAL.[^fn_51b_25] {¶=6.7}

***GEMARA***. As, for instance, the leaves of arum and of miltwaste.[^fn_51b_27]

THERE IS A KIND OF PRODUCE THAT IS SUBJECT TO THE RESTRICTIONS OF THE SABBATICAL YEAR AND IS NOT SUBJECT TO THE LAW OF REMOVAL, the root of the arum and the root of miltwaste, since it is written in Scripture, And for thy cattle and for the beasts that are in thy land, shall all the increase thereof be for food,[^fn_51b_28] as long as 'the beasts' eat[^fn_51b_29] from the field you may feed 'thy cattle' in the house, but when the produce comes to an end for 'the beasts' in the field you must bring it to an end for 'thy cattle' which are in the house; but these,[^fn_51b_30] surely, have not come to an end.

***MISHNAH***. WHATSOEVER[^fn_51b_31] HAS SCALES HAS FINS BUT THERE ARE SOME THAT HAVE FINS AND NO SCALES. WHATSOEVER[^fn_51b_32] HAS HORNS HAS HOOFS BUT THERE ARE SOME THAT HAVE HOOFS AND NO HORNS. {¶=6.8}

***GEMARA***. WHATSOEVER HAS SCALES \[etc.\] \[viz.\] a clean fish;[^fn_51b_33] THERE ARE SOME THAT HAVE FINS AND NO SCALES, refers to an unclean fish.[^fn_51b_34] Now consider: Since we[^fn_51b_35] rely on the scales,[^fn_51b_36] what need then was there for the All Merciful to mention[^fn_51b_37] fins?[^fn_51b_38] — If the All Merciful had not written fins it might have been presumed that the written word kaskeseth[^fn_51b_39] meant[^fn_51b_40] fins and that even an unclean fish \[is, therefore, permitted\]. Hence has the All Merciful written 'fins' and 'scales'.[^fn_51b_41] But now that the All Merciful has written both 'fins' and 'scales', whence is it deduced that kaskeseth[^fn_51b_39] means the covering? Because it is written, And he was clad with a coat of mail.[^fn_51b_42] Then why[^fn_51b_43] did not the All Merciful write kaskeseth[^fn_51b_39] and there would be no need for the mention of fins?[^fn_51b_44] — R. Abbahu replied and so it was also taught at the school of R. Ishmael: To make the teaching great and glorious.[^fn_51b_45]

***MISHNAH***. WHATSOEVER REQUIRES A BENEDICTION AFTER IT REQUIRES ONE BEFORE IT, BUT THERE ARE THINGS THAT REQUIRE A BENEDICTION BEFORE THEM AND NOT AFTER THEM. {¶=6.9}

***GEMARA***. \[What was the last clause[^fn_51b_46] intended\] to include? — To include vegetables. But according to R. Isaac who did say a benediction[^fn_51b_47] after the eating of vegetables, what was this[^fn_51b_46] intended to include? — To include water. But according to R. Papa who said a benediction[^fn_51b_47] after he drank water, what was it[^fn_51b_46] intended to include? — To include the performance of commandments.[^fn_51b_48] But according to the Palestinians[^fn_51b_49] who after removing their tefillin say the benediction of ' … who hath sanctified us by his commandments, and hath commanded us to keep his statutes', what does this[^fn_51b_50] include? — It includes [pg 52a]

fragrant odours.[^fn_52a_1]

***MISHNAH***. IF A GIRL[^fn_52a_2] HAS GROWN TWO PUBIC HAIRS SHE[^fn_52a_3] MAY EITHER PERFORM *HALIZAH* OR CONTRACT LEVIRATE MARRIAGE, AND SHE IS UNDER AN OBLIGATION TO PERFORM ALL THE COMMANDMENTS THAT ARE ENUMERATED IN THE TORAH.  SO ALSO A BOY, IF HE HAS GROWN TWO PUBIC HAIRS, IS UNDER AN OBLIGATION TO PERFORM ALL THE COMMANDMENTS ENUMERATED IN THE TORAH. HE IS FURTHERMORE LIABLE TO THE PENALTY OF A STUBBORN AND REBELLIOUS SON[^fn_52a_4] AS SOON AS HE HAS GROWN TWO HAIRS UNTIL THE TIME WHEN HIS BEARD FORMS A CIRCLE.[^fn_52a_5] (THIS REFERS TO THE LOWER, AND NOT TO THE UPPER ONE, BUT[^fn_52a_6] THE SAGES USED A EUPHEMISM.)[^fn_52a_7] A GIRL WHO HAS GROWN TWO HAIRS[^fn_52a_8] MAY NO LONGER EXERCISE THE RIGHT OF *MI'UN*. R. JUDAH RULED: *MI'UN* MAY BE EXERCISED UNTIL THE BLACK[^fn_52a_9] PREDOMINATES.[^fn_52a_10] {¶=6.10}

***GEMARA***. But since we have learnt, SHE IS UNDER AN OBLIGATION TO PERFORM ALL THE COMMANDMENTS THAT ARE ENUMERATED IN THE TORAH, what need was there for stating, SHE MAY EITHER PERFORM *HALIZAH* OR CONTRACT LEVIRATE MARRIAGE?[^fn_52a_11] — To exclude a ruling of R. Jose who stated, 'In the Biblical section[^fn_52a_12] it is written man,[^fn_52a_13] but as regards a woman there is no difference between a major and a minor'.[^fn_52a_14] Hence we were informed that[^fn_52a_15] if she has grown two hairs she may perform *halizah*,[^fn_52a_16] but otherwise she may not. What is the reason? A woman is to be compared to man.[^fn_52a_17]

But since it was stated, SO ALSO A BOY, IF HE HAS GROWN TWO PUBIC HAIRS,[^fn_52a_18] what need was there for stating, HE IS UNDER AN OBLIGATION TO PERFORM ALL THE COMMANDMENTS ENUMERATED IN THE TORAH? And should you reply: Because it was desired to teach, HE IS FURTHERMORE LIABLE TO THE PENALTY OF A STUBBORN AND REBELLIOUS SON \[the objection would arise\]: Have we not learnt this once: 'When does one become liable to the penalty of a stubborn and rebellious son? As soon as one grows two hairs until the time the beard forms a circle. (By this was meant the lower, and not the upper one, but the Sages used a euphemism)'? — This is so indeed; only because details were specified about the girl those relating to the boy were also specified.

IF A GIRL HAS GROWN etc. R. Abbahu citing R. Eleazar stated, The *halachah* is in agreement with R. JUDAH. R. Judah, however, agrees that if she was subjected to cohabitation after she had grown two hairs,[^fn_52a_19] she may no longer exercise the right of *mi'un*.[^fn_52a_20] The colleagues of R. Kahana desired to give a practical decision[^fn_52a_21] in agreement with the ruling of R. Judah, although intercourse had taken place, but R. Kahana addressed them as follows: Did not such an incident happen with the daughter of R. Ishmael?[^fn_52a_22] She, namely, came to the schoolhouse to exercise the right of *mi'un* while her son was riding on her shoulder; and on that day were the views of R. Ishmael mentioned at the schoolhouse; and the Rabbis wept bitterly[^fn_52a_23] saying, 'Over a ruling which that righteous man[^fn_52a_24] had laid down should his offspring stumble!' For Rab Judah citing Samuel who had it from R. Ishmael stated: And she be not seized,[^fn_52a_25] \[then only\][^fn_52a_26] is she forbidden,[^fn_52a_27] but if she was seized she is permitted. There is, however, another class of woman who is permitted[^fn_52a_27] even if she was not seized. And who is that? A woman whose betrothal was a mistaken one,[^fn_52a_28] and who, even if her son sits riding on her shoulder, may exercise the right of *mi'un* and go away.[^fn_52a_29] Thereupon they took a vote and decided: Up to what age may a girl[^fn_52a_30] exercise the right of *mi'un*? Until that at which she grows two hairs. \[On hearing this incident\] they[^fn_52a_31] abstained and did not act as they first intended.[^fn_52a_32]

R. Isaac and the disciples of R. Hanina gave a practical decision in agreement with R. Judah, though the girl had been subjected to intercourse. R. Shamin b. Abba proceeded to tell it in the presence of R. Johanan; R. Johanan proceeded to tell it in the presence of R.
