Judah Nesi'ah[^fn_52a_33] and the latter sent a constable[^fn_52a_34] who took her away.[^fn_52a_35]

R. Hisda citing Mar Ukba stated: The meaning[^fn_52a_36] is not that the black must actually predominate but that it shall be such as, when two hairs lie flat, has the appearance[^fn_52a_37] of the black predominating over the white,[^fn_52a_38] Raba stated: Two hairs that reach from rim to rim.

R. Helbo citing R. Huna stated: The two hairs of which the Rabbis spoke[^fn_52a_39] must[^fn_52a_40] have follicles at their roots. R. Malkio citing R. Adda b. Ahabah ruled: Follicles suffice even in the absence of hairs. Said R. Hanina the son of R. Ika: The rulings concerning a spit,[^fn_52a_41] bondwomen[^fn_52a_42] and follicles[^fn_52a_43] were laid down by R. Malkio, but those concerning a forelock,[^fn_52a_44] wood-ash[^fn_52a_45] and cheese[^fn_52a_46] were laid down by R. Malkia. R. Papa, however, stated: If the statement was made on a Mishnah or a Baraitha the author is R. Malkia but if on reported traditions[^fn_52a_47] the author is R. Malkio. And the mnemonic[^fn_52a_48] is, 'The mathnitha[^fn_52a_49] is queen'.[^fn_52a_50] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_52a_51] — The practical difference between them is the statement on bondwomen.[^fn_52a_52] R. Ashi stated, Mar Zutra told me that R. Hanina of Sura felt about this the following difficulty: Would not a single Tanna[^fn_52a_53] go out of his way to teach[^fn_52a_54] us the law of the follicles? — If one[^fn_52a_55] had informed us of the law of the follicles it might have been presumed that \[puberty is not established\] unless there were two hairs in two follicles respectively, hence we were informed[^fn_52a_56] that even two hairs in one follicle are sufficient. But is there such a phenomenon?[^fn_52a_57] Is it not in fact written in Scripture, He that would break me with a tempest, and multiply my wounds without cause[^fn_52a_58] in connection with which Raba[^fn_52a_59] remarked: Job blasphemed with the mention of tempest and he was answered with a tempest. He 'blasphemed with the mention of tempest', saying to Him, 'Sovereign of the world, perhaps a tempest has passed before Thee, and caused Thee to confuse "Job"60 with "enemy"?'[^fn_52a_61] 'He was answered with a tempest': Then the Lord answered [pg 52b]

Job out of the whirlwind, and said[^fn_52b_1] to him, 'Most foolish man,[^fn_52b_2] I have created many hairs[^fn_52b_3] in a man's head and for every hair I have created a separate follicle, so that two should not suck from the same follicle, for if two were to suck from the same follicle they would impair the sight of man. I did not confuse one follicle with another, would I confuse "Job" and "enemy"?'[^fn_52b_4] — This is no difficulty since one[^fn_52b_5] refers to the body while the other[^fn_52b_6] refers to the head.

Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: The two hairs of which they spoke \[establish puberty\] even if one is on the crest and the other on the testes. So it was also taught: The two hairs of which they spoke \[establish puberty\] even if one grows on her back and the other on her belly, one on the joints of the fingers of her hand and the other on the joints of her toes; so R. Simeon b. Judah of Kefar Akko who cited it in the name of R. Ishmael.[^fn_52b_7] But Rab citing R. Assi ruled: puberty is not established unless two hairs grow in the same spot.

Our Rabbis taught: Up to what age may a girl exercise the right of *mi'un*? Until she grows two hairs; so R. Meir. R. Judah ruled: Until the black predominates.[^fn_52b_8] R. Jose ruled: Until a ring is formed around the nipple. Ben Shelakoth ruled: Until she grows her hair in profusion.[^fn_52b_9] In connection with this R. Simeon stated: Hanina b. Hakinai once met me at Zidon and said to me,[^fn_52b_10] 'When you arrive at R. Akiba's ask him "until what age may a girl exercise the right of *mi'un*". If he tells you, "Until she grows two hairs", ask him this: Did not Ben Shelakoth testify in the presence of all of you at Jamnia, "Until she grows her hair in profusion", and you did not say to him a word to the contrary?' When I arrived at R. Akiba's the latter told me, 'I do not know anything about the growing of hair in profusion, and I do not know Ben Shelakoth; a girl may exercise the right of *mi'un* until the age when she grows two hairs'.

***MISHNAH***. THE TWO HAIRS SPOKEN OF IN REGARD TO THE RED HEIFER[^fn_52b_11] AND IN REGARD TO LEPROSY[^fn_52b_12] AS WELL AS THOSE SPOKEN OF ANYWHERE ELSE[^fn_52b_13] MUST BE LONG ENOUGH FOR THEIR TIPS TO BE BENT TO THEIR ROOTS; SO R. ISHMAEL. R. ELIEZER RULED: LONG ENOUGH TO BE GRASPED BY A FINGER-NAIL, R. AKIBA RULED: LONG ENOUGH TO BE TAKEN OFF WITH SCISSORS. {¶=6.11}

***GEMARA***. R. Hisda citing Mar Ukba stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with the views of all these in that the law is thereby invariably restricted.[^fn_52b_14]

***MISHNAH***. A WOMAN WHO OBSERVED A BLOOD-STAIN[^fn_52b_15] IS IN AN UNSETTLED CONDITION[^fn_52b_16] AND MUST[^fn_52b_17] TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THE POSSIBILITY THAT IT WAS DUE TO *ZIBAH*; SO R. MEIR. BUT THE SAGES RULED: IN THE CASE OF BLOOD-STAINS THERE IS NO \[NEED TO CONSIDER THE POSSIBILITY OF THEIR BEING\] DUE TO *ZIBAH*. {¶=6.12}

***GEMARA***. Who are THE SAGES? — R. Hanina b. Antigonus. For it was taught: R. Hanina b. Antigonus ruled, In the case of blood-stains there is no \[need to consider the possibility of their being\] due to *zibah*, but sometimes blood-stains do lead to *zibah*. How so? If a woman[^fn_52b_18] put on three shirts that she had previously examined and then found a blood-stain on each of them, or if she[^fn_52b_19] observed a discharge[^fn_52b_20] on two days and \[a blood-stain on\] one shirt,[^fn_52b_21] these are the blood-stains that lead to *zibah*. But since in the case of three shirts, where she observed no direct discharge from her body, the possibility of *zibah* is taken into consideration, why was it necessary to mention[^fn_52b_22] that of 'two days and one shirt'? — It might have been presumed[^fn_52b_23] that in any instance like this[^fn_52b_24] the woman brings a sacrifice which may be eaten,[^fn_52b_25] hence we were informed \[that only the possibility[^fn_52b_26] of *zibah* is taken into consideration\].[^fn_52b_27] Raba observed: In this matter R. Hanina b. Antigonus vindicated his case against the Rabbis. For why is it \[that when a bloodstain\] less than three beans in size is in one spot we do not take into consideration the possibility of *zibah*? \[presumably\] because we assume that it is the result of observations on two days.[^fn_52b_28] But then why should we not, even if a stain of the size of three beans was in one spot, similarly assume that only to the extent of the size of two and a half beans the discharge was from her body while the rest is the blood of a louse due to the filth?[^fn_52b_29] — And the Rabbis?[^fn_52b_30] — Since the stain[^fn_52b_31] can be divided up into parts of the size of a bean and over for each day[^fn_52b_32] we do not ascribe it to any external cause. As to R. Hanina b. Antigonus, is it[^fn_52b_33] only when a stain of the size of three beans in one spot that we do not take the possibility of *zibah* into consideration, but if it is in three different places[^fn_52b_34] the possibility is taken into consideration? But did you not say[^fn_52b_35] that this[^fn_52b_36] applies only to stains on[^fn_52b_37] three shirts,[^fn_52b_38] from which it follows that it does not apply to stains[^fn_52b_39] in three spots?[^fn_52b_40] — He[^fn_52b_41] spoke to them on the line of the view of the Rabbis. As far as I am concerned, he said in effect, it[^fn_52b_42] applies only to three shirts[^fn_52b_38] and not to three spots;[^fn_52b_40] but according to your view, agree with me at least that, where she had observed a stain of the size of three beans in one spot, we assume that to the extent of two and a half beans the discharge came from her body while the rest is the blood of a louse due to the filth. And the Rabbis? — Since the stain[^fn_52b_43] can be divided up into parts of the size of a little more than a bean for each day,[^fn_52b_44] we do not ascribe it to any external cause,

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman observed a blood-stain, if it is big enough[^fn_52b_43] to be divided into parts corresponding respectively to three beans, each of which being slightly bigger than the size of a bean, she must take into consideration the possibility of *zibah*; otherwise, she need not take this possibility into consideration. R. Judah b. Agra citing R. Jose ruled: In the one case and in the other[^fn_52b_45] the possibility must be taken into consideration.[^fn_52b_46] [pg 53a]

Rabbi stated: R. Judah b. Agra's ruling is acceptable where she did not examine[^fn_53a_1] and the ruling of the Sages where she did examine. What is meant by 'she did examine' and by 'she did not examine'? — Raba replied: I found the Rabbis of the schoolhouse sitting at their studies and discoursing thus: 'Here[^fn_53a_2] we are dealing with the case of a woman who examined herself,[^fn_53a_3] but did not examine her shirt;[^fn_53a_4] and even her own body was examined by her only at the twilight of R. Judah,[^fn_53a_5] while at the twilight of R. Jose[^fn_53a_6] she did not examine herself. In such a case, the Rabbis being of the opinion that at the twilight of R. Jose it is already night, \[the question of *zibah* does not arise\] since she had examined herself at the twilight of R. Judah,[^fn_53a_7] and R. Jose follows his own view, he having stated that twilight is a doubtful time'.[^fn_53a_8] But I said to him: 'Had her hands been kept in her eyes[^fn_53a_9] throughout the twilight[^fn_53a_10] you would[^fn_53a_11] have spoken well,[^fn_53a_12] but now,[^fn_53a_13] is it not possible that she experienced a discharge[^fn_53a_14] as soon as she had removed her hands?'[^fn_53a_15] They then told me, 'We only spoke of a case where the woman had her hands in her eyes[^fn_53a_9] throughout the twilight'.

'Rabbi stated: R. Judah b. Agra's ruling[^fn_53a_16] is acceptable where she did not examine'. Now[^fn_53a_17] what is meant by 'she did not examine'? If it be suggested that she examined herself in the twilight of R. Judah but did not examine herself in the twilight of R. Jose \[the difficulty would arise\]: From this[^fn_53a_18] it follows that R. Judah holds[^fn_53a_19] that even where she examined herself both times,[^fn_53a_20] the possibility of *zibah* must be considered; \[but why should this be so\] seeing that she did examine herself?[^fn_53a_21] It is obvious then \[that the meaning[^fn_53a_22] is\] that she did not examine herself either in the twilight of R. Judah or in that of R. Jose;[^fn_53a_23] but if she had examined herself in R. Judah's twilight[^fn_53a_24] and did not examine herself in R. Jose's[^fn_53a_25] there is no need for her to consider the possibility \[of *zibah*\].[^fn_53a_26] It is thus clear that the twilight of R. Jose is according to Rabbi[^fn_53a_27] regarded as night.[^fn_53a_28] Now read the final clause: 'And the ruling of the Sages where she did examine' — What is meant by 'she did examine'? If it be suggested that she examined herself in the twilight of R. Judah but did not examine herself in that of R. Jose,[^fn_53a_29] it would follow[^fn_53a_30] that the Rabbis are of the opinion that even if she did not examine herself in either[^fn_53a_31] there is no need to consider the possibility of *zibah* \[but why should this be so\] seeing that she did not examine herself?[^fn_53a_32] It is obvious then that \[the meaning[^fn_53a_33] is\] that she examined herself both in the twilight of R. Judah and in that of R. Jose, but that if she had examined herself in the twilight of R. Judah and not in that of R. Jose the possibility of *zibah*[^fn_53a_34] must be considered.[^fn_53a_35] It is thus clear that the twilight of R. Jose is according to Rabbi[^fn_53a_36] regarded as doubtful time.[^fn_53a_37] Does not this then present a contradiction between two statements of Rabbi?[^fn_53a_38] — It is this that he[^fn_53a_39] meant: The view of R. Judah b. Agra[^fn_53a_40] is acceptable to the Rabbis[^fn_53a_41] when she did not examine herself at all either in R. Judah's twilight or in that of R. Jose's, for even the Sages differed from him[^fn_53a_42] only when she has examined herself in R. Judah's twilight[^fn_53a_43] and did not examine herself in that of R. Jose,[^fn_53a_44] but where she did not examine herself at all they agree with him,[^fn_53a_45] But does not the following show incongruity?[^fn_53a_46] \[For it was taught:\] If a woman observed a bloodstain, the observation being one of a large one,[^fn_53a_47] she must take into consideration the possibility of a discharge at twilight,[^fn_53a_48] but if the observation was one of a small stain[^fn_53a_49] she should not take the possibility into consideration. This is the ruling of R. Judah b. Agra who cited it in the name of R. Jose. Said Rabbi: I heard from him[^fn_53a_50] that in both cases must the possibility be taken into consideration; 'and', he said to me, 'it is for this reason: What if she had been a menstruant who did not[^fn_53a_51] make sure of her cleanness[^fn_53a_52] from the minha time[^fn_53a_53] and onwards, would she not[^fn_53a_54] have been regarded as being in a presumptive state of uncleanness?[^fn_53a_55] And his ruling is acceptable to me where she has examined herself. Now what is meant by 'she has examined herself'? If it be suggested that she has examined herself in the twilight of R. Judah and did not examine herself in that of R. Jose, it would follow that R. Judah b. Agra holds that even though she did not examine herself either in the twilight of R. Judah or in that of R. Jose the possibility need not be considered; but why should this be so seeing that she did not examine herself? It must be obvious then that she did examine herself both in the twilight of R. Judah and in that of R. Jose. Thus it follows that R. Judah b. Agra holds that if she examined herself in the twilight of R. Judah and not in that of R. Jose she need not consider the possibility. It is thus clear that the twilight of R. Jose is according to R. Judah b. Agra regarded as night. Does not this then present a contradiction between two rulings of R. Judah b. Agra?[^fn_53a_56] In the absence of Rabbi's interpretations[^fn_53a_57] there would well be no difficulty, since the former ruling might refer to a case where she has examined herself in R. Judah's twilight and not in that of R. Jose while here it is a case where she has examined herself in R. Jose's twilight as in that of R. Judah's; but with Rabbi's interpretations[^fn_53a_58] does not the contradiction arise? — Two Tannas expressed different views as to the opinion of R. Judah b. Agra. The first Tanna holds that the twilight of R. Judah ends first [pg 53b]

and then begins the twilight of R. Jose,[^fn_53b_1] while the second Tanna holds that the twilight of R. Jose is absorbed in that of R. Judah.[^fn_53b_2]

Our Rabbis taught: A woman who observes a bloodstain causes uncleanness to herself[^fn_53b_3] and to consecrated things retrospectively;[^fn_53b_4] so Rabbi. R. Simeon b. Eleazar ruled: She causes uncleanness[^fn_53b_5] to consecrated things but does not cause uncleanness to herself, since her bloodstain cannot be subject to greater restrictions than her observation.[^fn_53b_6] But[^fn_53b_7] do we not find that her bloodstain is subject to greater restrictions in regard to consecrated things? — Read rather thus: R. Simeon b. Eleazar ruled, Even to consecrated things she conveys no uncleanness,[^fn_53b_8] since her bloodstain should in no case be subject to greater restrictions than her observation.[^fn_53b_6]

Our Rabbis taught: If a woman observed first a bloodstain and then[^fn_53b_9] she observed a discharge of blood she may for a period of twenty-four hours ascribe her stain to her observation;[^fn_53b_10] so Rabbi. R. Simeon b. Eleazar ruled: Only during the same day.[^fn_53b_11] Said Rabbi: His view seems more acceptable than mine, since he improves[^fn_53b_12] her position while I make it worse. 'He improves it'! Does he not in fact[^fn_53b_13] make it worse? — Rabina replied: Reverse the statement,[^fn_53b_14] R. Nahman said: You need not really reverse it, \[the meaning being:\] Since he improves her position in regard to the laws of *zibah* while I make her position worse as regards the laws of *zibah*.[^fn_53b_15]

R. Zera enquired of R. Assi: Do stains[^fn_53b_16] necessitate an interval of cleanness[^fn_53b_17] or not? The other remained silent, answering him nothing at all. Once he[^fn_53b_18] found him[^fn_53b_19] as he was sitting at his studies and discoursing as follows: 'She may for twenty-four hours ascribe her stain to her observation. This is the ruling of Rabbi. In connection with this Resh Lakish explained that it applied only where she has examined herself,[^fn_53b_20] while R. Johanan explained: Even though she did not examine herself'.[^fn_53b_21] 'Thus it follows', he[^fn_53b_18] said to him,[^fn_53b_19] 'that[^fn_53b_22] stains necessitate an interval of cleanness'. 'Yes', the other[^fn_53b_19] replied. 'But did I not ask you this question many a time and you gave me no answer at all? It is likely that you recalled the tradition[^fn_53b_23] in the rapidity of your reviewing?'[^fn_53b_24] — 'Yes', the other replied, 'in the rapidity of my reviewing I recalled it'.

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN OBSERVED A DISCHARGE OF BLOOD ON THE ELEVENTH DAY[^fn_53b_25] AT TWILIGHT,[^fn_53b_26] AT THE BEGINNING OF A MENSTRUATION PERIOD AND AT THE END OF A MENSTRUATION PERIOD,[^fn_53b_27] AT THE BEGINNING OF A *ZIBAH* PERIOD AND AT THE END OF A *ZIBAH* PERIOD,[^fn_53b_27] ON THE FORTIETH DAY AFTER THE BIRTH OF A MALE[^fn_53b_28] OR ON THE EIGHTIETH DAY AFTER THE BIRTH OF A FEMALE,[^fn_53b_29] \[THE DISCHARGE HAVING BEEN OBSERVED\] AT TWILIGHT IN ALL THESE CASES,[^fn_53b_30] BEHOLD WOMEN IN SUCH CIRCUMSTANCES[^fn_53b_31] ARE IN A STATE OF PERPLEXITY.[^fn_53b_32] SAID R. JOSHUA: BEFORE YOU MAKE PROVISION FOR THE FOOLISH WOMEN[^fn_53b_33] COME AND MAKE PROVISION FOR THE WISE ONES.[^fn_53b_34] {¶=6.13}

***GEMARA***. AT THE BEGINNING OF A MENSTRUATION PERIOD AND AT THE END OF A MENSTRUATION PERIOD! Is it[^fn_53b_35] not rather the beginning of a menstruation period and the end of a *zibah* period?[^fn_53b_36] — R. Hisda replied: It is this that was meant: IF A WOMAN OBSERVED A DISCHARGE OF BLOOD ON THE ELEVENTH DAY AT TWILIGHT a time which is THE BEGINNING OF A MENSTRUATION PERIOD AND THE END OF A *ZIBAH* PERIOD, or on the seventh day of her menstruation when it is THE END OF A MENSTRUATION PERIOD AND THE BEGINNING OF A *ZIBAH* PERIOD.

SAID R. JOSHUA: BEFORE YOU MAKE PROVISION FOR THE FOOLISH WOMEN etc. But are these [pg 54a]

FOOLISH WOMEN? Are they not merely IN A STATE OF PERPLEXITY?[^fn_54a_1] — Rather read: Women who are in a state of perplexity. For[^fn_54a_2] it was taught: \[If a woman is alternately\] unclean on one day and clean on the next,[^fn_54a_3] she may perform her marital duty[^fn_54a_4] on the eighth day,[^fn_54a_5] the night following being included,[^fn_54a_6] and on four nights out of every eighteen days.[^fn_54a_7] If, however, she observed any issue in the evening,[^fn_54a_8] she performs her marital duty on the eighth day[^fn_54a_9] only.[^fn_54a_10] \[If she is alternately\] unclean[^fn_54a_11] for two days and clean for two days, she may perform her marital duty on the eighth,[^fn_54a_12] the twelfth,[^fn_54a_13] the sixteenth[^fn_54a_14] and the twentieth.[^fn_54a_15] But why is she not allowed to perform her marital duty on the nineteenth?[^fn_54a_16] — R. Shesheth replied: This[^fn_54a_17] proves that the 'gluttony'[^fn_54a_18] of which we have learnt[^fn_54a_19] is forbidden. R. Ashi[^fn_54a_20] replied: Granted that the eleventh day[^fn_54a_21] requires no safeguard,[^fn_54a_22] the tenth day[^fn_54a_23] at any rate does require a safeguard.[^fn_54a_24] If she is alternately unclean for three days and clean for three days, she may perform her marital duty on two days[^fn_54a_25] and may never again perform it.[^fn_54a_26] If she is alternately unclean for four days and clean for four days she performs her marital duty on one day,[^fn_54a_27] and may never again perform it.[^fn_54a_28] If she is alternately unclean for five days and clean for five days, she performs her marital duty on three days[^fn_54a_29] and may never again perform it.[^fn_54a_28] If she is alternately unclean for six days and clean for six days she performs her marital duty on five days[^fn_54a_30] and may never again perform it.[^fn_54a_28] If she is alternately unclean for seven days and clean for seven days, she may perform her marital duty during a quarter of her lifetime, \[seven days\][^fn_54a_31] out of each twenty-eight days.[^fn_54a_32] If she is alternately unclean for eight days and clean for eight days, she may perform her marital duty on fifteen days[^fn_54a_33] out of every forty-eight days.[^fn_54a_34] But is not the number[^fn_54a_35] fourteen?[^fn_54a_36] — R. Adda b. Isaac replied: This proves that the days of her menstruation in which she observes no discharge[^fn_54a_37] are reckoned in the counting[^fn_54a_38] prescribed for her *zibah*;[^fn_54a_39] for the question was raised: [pg 54b]

May the days succeeding childbirth[^fn_54b_1] on which the woman observes no discharge[^fn_54b_2] be reckoned in the counting prescribed for her *zibah*?[^fn_54b_3] R. Kahana replied, Come and hear: If a woman[^fn_54b_4] observed a discharge on two days, and on the third day she miscarried but was unaware what she miscarried, behold this is a case of doubtful *zibah* and doubtful birth[^fn_54b_5] and[^fn_54b_6] she must bring a sacrifice[^fn_54b_7] which may not be eaten[^fn_54b_8] while the days succeeding her childbirth[^fn_54b_9] on which she observes no discharge are reckoned in the counting prescribed for her *zibah*.[^fn_54b_10] R. Papa retorted: There[^fn_54b_11] the case is quite different,[^fn_54b_12] since it might be assumed[^fn_54b_11] that she gave birth to a male child,[^fn_54b_13] so that all the extra seven days that we impose upon her[^fn_54b_14] may well be reckoned in the counting prescribed for her *zibah*.[^fn_54b_15] Said R. Huna son of R. Joshua to R. Papa: Is there[^fn_54b_11] only the doubt of having given birth to a male child, and is there no doubt as to the possibility of the birth of a female child?[^fn_54b_16] But the fact is that[^fn_54b_17] you may well infer from here that they[^fn_54b_18] may be reckoned.[^fn_54b_19] This is conclusive.

If a woman is alternately unclean for nine days and clean for nine days she may have marital intercourse on eight days out of every eighteen days.[^fn_54b_20] If she is alternately unclean for ten days and clean for ten days, the days in which she is permitted marital intercourse are the same in number as the days of her *zibah*.[^fn_54b_21] And the same[^fn_54b_22] applies to cycles of a hundred[^fn_54b_23] and so also to cycles of a thousand.[^fn_54b_24]

## CHAPTER VII

***MISHNAH***. THE BLOOD OF A MENSTRUANT AND THE FLESH OF A CORPSE CONVEY UNCLEANNESS WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY. BUT THE ISSUE, PHLEGM AND SPITTLE OF A *ZAB*, A DEAD CREEPING THING, A CARCASS AND SEMEN CONVEY UNCLEANNESS WHEN WET BUT NOT WHEN DRY. IF, HOWEVER, ON BEING SOAKED, THEY ARE CAPABLE OF REVERTING TO THEIR ORIGINAL CONDITION THEY CONVEY UNCLEANNESS WHEN WET AND WHEN DRY. AND WHAT IS THE DURATION[^fn_54b_25] OF THEIR SOAKING?[^fn_54b_26] TWENTY-FOUR HOURS IN LUKEWARM WATER.[^fn_54b_27] R. JOSE RULED: IF THE FLESH OF A CORPSE IS DRY, AND ON BEING SOAKED CANNOT REVERT TO ITS ORIGINAL CONDITION, IT IS CLEAN.[^fn_54b_28] {¶=7.1}

***GEMARA***. Whence are these rulings[^fn_54b_29] deduced? — Hezekiah replied: From Scripture which says, And of her that is sick with her impurity,[^fn_54b_30] her impurity[^fn_54b_31] is like herself, as she conveys her uncleanness so does her impurity convey similar uncleanness. Thus we find the law concerning wet blood,[^fn_54b_32] whence the deduction concerning dry blood? — R. Isaac replied: Scripture said, Be,[^fn_54b_33] it shall retain its original force.[^fn_54b_34] But might it not be suggested that this[^fn_54b_35] applies only to blood that was wet and then dried up; whence, however, the deduction that it applies also to blood that was originally[^fn_54b_36] dry? And, furthermore, with reference to what we have learnt, 'If a woman aborted an object that was like a rind, like earth, like a hair, like red flies, let her put it in water and if it dissolves she is unclean', whence is this[^fn_54b_37] deduced? — 'Be'[^fn_54b_38] is an inclusive statement.[^fn_54b_39] If \[it be argued:\] As she causes couch and seat to convey uncleanness to man and to his garments[^fn_54b_40] so should her blood also cause couch and garment to convey uncleanness to man and his garments. \[it can be retorted:\] Is then her blood capable of using a couch or a seat?[^fn_54b_41] — But according to your argument[^fn_54b_42] \[it could also be objected\]: Is a leprous stone[^fn_54b_43] capable of using a couch or a seat that a text should be required to exclude it?[^fn_54b_44] For it was taught. 'It might have been presumed that a leprous stone should cause a couch and a seat to convey uncleanness to man and to his garments, this being arrived at logically, for if a *zab* who does not convey uncleanness by means of entry[^fn_54b_45] causes couch and seat to convey uncleanness to man and to his garments, how much more then should a leprous stone, which does convey uncleanness by means of entry,[^fn_54b_46] convey uncleanness to couch and seat to convey it to man and his garments, hence it was specifically stated, He that hath the issue,[^fn_54b_47] implying only 'he that hath the issue' \[is subject to the restriction\][^fn_54b_48] but not a leprous stone'. Now the reason[^fn_54b_49] is that Scripture has excluded it, but if that had not been the case it would have conveyed the uncleanness, would it not?[^fn_54b_50] — A reply may indeed be forthcoming from this very statement,[^fn_54b_51] for did you not say. 'He that hath the issue[^fn_54b_52] \[is subject to the restriction\] but not a leprous stone'? Well here also Scripture said, Whereon she sitteth,[^fn_54b_53] only she but not her blood. [pg 55a]

But might it not be suggested that[^fn_55a_1] as she conveys uncleanness to objects under a heavy stone[^fn_55a_2] so does her blood also convey uncleanness to objects under a heavy stone? — R. Ashi replied: Scripture said, And he that beareth those things,[^fn_55a_3] implying[^fn_55a_4] an exclusion.[^fn_55a_5]

AND THE FLESH OF A CORPSE. Whence is this deduced? — Resh Lakish replied: Scripture said, Whatsoever uncleanness he hath,[^fn_55a_6] implying all forms of uncleanness[^fn_55a_7] that emanate from him.[^fn_55a_8] R. Johanan replied: Or a bone of a man, or a grave,[^fn_55a_9] 'a man' is[^fn_55a_10] on a par with 'a bone'; as a bone \[conveys uncleanness when\] dry so does a man.[^fn_55a_11] What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_55a_12] — The practical difference between them is the case of flesh that[^fn_55a_13] crumbles.[^fn_55a_14]

An objection was raised: The flesh of a corpse that was crumbled is clean?[^fn_55a_15] — There it is a case where it was pulverised and turned into dust.

An objection was raised:[^fn_55a_16] Every part of a corpse conveys uncleanness except the teeth, the hair and the nails, but while they are attached \[to the corpse\] they are all unclean?[^fn_55a_17] — R. Adda b. Ahabah replied: It[^fn_55a_18] must be exactly like a bone; as a bone was created simultaneously with it[^fn_55a_19] so must every other part[^fn_55a_20] be such as was created with it.[^fn_55a_21] But are there not the hair and nails that were created with it[^fn_55a_19] and they are nevertheless clean? — Rather, said R. Adda b. Ahabah, It[^fn_55a_20] must be exactly like a bone; as a bone was created simultaneously with it[^fn_55a_19] and when cut[^fn_55a_22] does not grow again[^fn_55a_23] so must every other part[^fn_55a_20] be such as was created with it and when cut[^fn_55a_22] does not grow again. The teeth are, therefore, excluded since they were not created with it,[^fn_55a_19] and the hair and nails were excluded since, though they were created with it, they[^fn_55a_22] grow again. But skin surely \[is a part of the body\] that[^fn_55a_22] grows again, for[^fn_55a_24] we have learnt: A skinned animal,[^fn_55a_25] R. Meir declares, is ritually fit,[^fn_55a_26] and only the Sages declare it to be unfit.[^fn_55a_27] And even the Rabbis declare it to be unfit only because in the meantime[^fn_55a_28] the air affects it and it would die, but the skin[^fn_55a_29] would, as a matter of fact, grow again;[^fn_55a_30] and yet have we not learnt: In the case of the following their skins are on a par with their flesh,[^fn_55a_31] viz., the skin of a human being?[^fn_55a_32] — Surely in connection with this ruling it was stated: 'Ulla said, 'Pentateuchally the skin of a human being is clean, and what is the reason why they ruled it to be unclean? It is a preventive measure against the possibility that a person might use the skins of his father and mother as spreads for an ass.'

Others there are who read: Skin, surely, \[is a part of the body\] that[^fn_55a_33] does not grow again, for[^fn_55a_34] we have learnt: And the Sages declare it to be unfit.[^fn_55a_35] And even R. Meir declares it to be fit only because its flesh hardens and the animal recovers its health but it does not, as a matter of fact, grow again,[^fn_55a_36] and yet did not 'Ulla state, 'Pentateuchally the skin of a man is clean'? — When 'Ulla's statement was made it had reference to the final clause[^fn_55a_37] only: But all these,[^fn_55a_38] if they were dressed or trodden upon sufficiently to render them fit for dressing, are clean[^fn_55a_39] with the exception of a human skin.[^fn_55a_40] And it was in connection with this ruling that 'Ulla stated, 'Pentateuchally the human skin is clean if it had been dressed; and what is the reason why they ruled it to be unclean? It is a preventive measure against the possibility that a person might use the skins of his father and mother as spreads'. But does not flesh grow again and yet it is unclean? — Mar son of R. Ashi replied: The place of missing flesh becomes a scar.[^fn_55a_41]

BUT THE ISSUE. Whence is this[^fn_55a_42] deduced? — It was taught: His issue is unclean,[^fn_55a_43] teaches concerning an issue of a *zab* that it is unclean.[^fn_55a_44] But cannot this be arrived at by a process of reasoning: If it[^fn_55a_45] causes uncleanness to others[^fn_55a_46] would it not, with more reason, cause uncleanness to itself?[^fn_55a_47] The case of the scapegoat proves the contrary, since it causes uncleanness to others[^fn_55a_48] while it is itself clean. You also should not, therefore, be surprised in this case[^fn_55a_49] where, though the issue carries uncleanness to others,[^fn_55a_46] it is itself[^fn_55a_49] clean. Hence it was specifically stated, 'His issue is unclean'[^fn_55a_43] teaching thereby that the issue is unclean. But might it not be suggested that this[^fn_55a_50] applies only to contact \[uncleanness\] but not to carriage, this being a case similar to that of a dead creeping thing?[^fn_55a_51] — R. Bibi b. Abaye replied: There was no need for a Scriptural text as far as contact is concerned, since it[^fn_55a_50] is not inferior[^fn_55a_52] to semen, [pg 55b]

so that if a Scriptural text was required it was only in respect of carriage. But might it not be suggested that by means of carriage it conveys uncleanness to both man and his garments, while by means of contact it conveys uncleanness to man but not to his garments, this being a case similar to that of contact with a carcass?[^fn_55b_1] — This cannot be entertained, for it was taught: Others[^fn_55b_2] Say, Of them that have an issue, whether it be a man, or a woman,[^fn_55b_3] his 'issue' is compared[^fn_55b_4] to himself;[^fn_55b_5] as in his case you make no distinction between his contact and his carriage as regards the conveyance of uncleanness to man and to his garments,[^fn_55b_6] so also in that of his issue. But now that the law[^fn_55b_7] is deduced from 'Of them that have an issue',[^fn_55b_3] what need is there for 'His issue is unclean'?[^fn_55b_8] — R. Judah of Daskarta[^fn_55b_9] replied: It was required; since[^fn_55b_10] it might have been presumed that the case of the scapegoat proves the contrary,[^fn_55b_11] for it causes uncleanness to others[^fn_55b_12] while it itself is clean; and as to the deduction from[^fn_55b_13] 'Of them that have an issue' \[it might have been explained that\] it serves the purpose of indicating the number,[^fn_55b_14] viz., 'issue', one; 'his issue',[^fn_55b_15] two; while after the third issue the All Merciful compared him to the 'woman',[^fn_55b_16] hence the All Merciful has written, 'His issue is unclean'. And now that the All Merciful has also written, 'His issue is unclean'[^fn_55b_17] you may apply to the other text[^fn_55b_18] this exposition[^fn_55b_19] also.

AND SPITTLE. Whence do we deduce \[the uncleanness of\] spittle? — It was taught And if he[^fn_55b_20]  … spit.[^fn_55b_21] As this might be presumed to apply even if the spittle did not touch,[^fn_55b_22] it was explicitly stated, upon him that is clean,[^fn_55b_21] only if it touched him that is clean.[^fn_55b_23] Thus I know the law concerning his spittle only,[^fn_55b_24] whence could I deduce the uncleanness of his mucus, phlegm and nasal discharge? From the explicit statement, And[^fn_55b_25] if he … spit.[^fn_55b_26]

The Master said, 'As this might be presumed to apply even if the spittle did not touch',[^fn_55b_27] but whence could this uncleanness[^fn_55b_28] be deduced? — It might have been presumed that the expression of 'spit' here[^fn_55b_26] may be inferred from that of 'spit'[^fn_55b_29] mentioned in the case of a yebamah, as there the act[^fn_55b_30] is valid though the spittle does not touch \[the yabam\] so is the act[^fn_55b_31] valid here also even though the spittle did not touch the clean person, hence we were informed \[that actual contact is essential\]. But might it not be suggested that this[^fn_55b_31] applies only to touch[^fn_55b_32] but not to carriage, the law being similar to that of a dead creeping thing?[^fn_55b_33] — Resh Lakish replied: The school of R. Ishmael taught, Scripture said, 'upon that[^fn_55b_34] which is with the clean',[^fn_55b_26] implying, whatever is in the hand of him that is clean,[^fn_55b_35] I have declared it to be unclean to you.[^fn_55b_36] But might it not be suggested that by carriage it conveys uncleanness to the man and his garments while by contact it conveys uncleanness to man only but not to his garments, this law being similar to that of the touch of *nebelah*? — Resh Lakish replied and so it was also taught at the school of R. Ishmael: Scripture said, 'upon that which is with the clean'[^fn_55b_37] implying that that which I have declared to you as clean elsewhere I have declared to you as unclean here, and what is this? It is the touch of *nebelah*.[^fn_55b_38] But might it not be suggested that this[^fn_55b_39] refers to[^fn_55b_40] the carrying of a dead creeping thing?[^fn_55b_41] — If that were so, Scripture should have written, 'upon that which is with a man',[^fn_55b_42] why then did it write 'upon that which is with the clean'?[^fn_55b_43] Consequently the two deductions may be made.[^fn_55b_44]

'And nasal discharge'. What \[uncleanness\] is \[there in a\] nasal discharge?[^fn_55b_45] — Rab replied: This is the case where it was drawn and discharged through the mouth,[^fn_55b_46] since in the circumstances it is impossible for the nasal secretion to be free from particles of spittle. R. Johanan, however, stated that it is unclean even if it is drawn and discharged through the nose. It is thus clear that he is of the opinion that the nose is a source,[^fn_55b_47] the All Merciful[^fn_55b_48] having included it.[^fn_55b_49] As to Rab,[^fn_55b_50] why should not the tears of a zab's eyes[^fn_55b_51] be enumerated?[^fn_55b_52] For[^fn_55b_53] has not Rab stated, He who wishes to blind his eye shall have it painted by an idolater,[^fn_55b_54] and Levi stated, He who wishes to die shall have his eyes painted by an idolater, and in connection with this R. Hiyya b. Goria explained, 'What is Rab's reason for not saying "He who wishes to die \[etc.\]"? Because one might sniff them up and discharge them, through the mouth'.[^fn_55b_55] Now[^fn_55b_56] what is Rab's explanation?[^fn_55b_57] — Granted that the poison is discharged,[^fn_55b_58] the tears themselves are not so discharged.

Come and hear: 'There are nine fluids of[^fn_55b_59] a *zab*. His sweat, foul secretion and excrement are free from all uncleanness of *zibah*; the tears of his eye, the blood of his wound and the milk of a woman convey the uncleanness of liquids[^fn_55b_60] if they consist of a minimum quantity of a quarter of a *log*; but his *zibah*, his spittle and his urine[^fn_55b_61] convey major uncleanness';[^fn_55b_62] but nasal discharge was not mentioned. Now according to Rab[^fn_55b_63] one can well see why this was not mentioned, since it was not definite enough to be mentioned, for it is only sometimes that it is discharged through the mouth while at other times it is discharged through the nose;[^fn_55b_64] but according to R. Johanan[^fn_55b_65] why was it not mentioned? — But according to your view,[^fn_55b_66] was his mucus and phlegm[^fn_55b_67] mentioned?[^fn_55b_68] But the fact is that spittle was mentioned and the same law applies to all other secretions the law of whose uncleanness was derived from the Pentateuchal amplification,[^fn_55b_69] and so also here[^fn_55b_70] spittle was mentioned and all other secretions the law of whose uncleanness was derived from the amplification are also included. 'The tears of his eye' \[is legally a fluid\] since it is written in Scripture, And given them tears to drink in large measure,[^fn_55b_71] 'the blood of his wound', since it is written, And drink the blood of the slain,[^fn_55b_72] and there is no difference[^fn_55b_73] between striking one down outright or striking one down in part;[^fn_55b_74] 'the milk of a woman', since it is written, And she opened a bottle of milk, and gave him drink.[^fn_55b_75] Whence do we derive the law that 'his urine' \[is legally a fluid\]? — It was taught: His issue is unclean, and this[^fn_55b_76] includes his urine in respect of uncleanness. But may not this[^fn_55b_77] be arrived at by a logical argument? If spittle, that emanates from a region of cleanness, is unclean how much more so his urine that emanates [pg 56a]

from an unclean region?[^fn_56a_1] — The blood that issues from the orifice of the membrum[^fn_56a_2] could prove the contrary, for though it issues from an unclean region it is nevertheless clean; you also need not, therefore, be surprised at this that, though it issues from an unclean region, it should be clean. Hence it was explicitly stated, 'His issue is unclean and this', to include his urine in respect of uncleanness. Whence is it deduced that the blood that issues from the orifice of the membrum[^fn_56a_2] is clean? — From what was taught It might have been assumed that blood that issues from his[^fn_56a_2] mouth or from the orifice of the membrum is unclean,[^fn_56a_3] hence it was explicitly stated, As to his issue it is unclean,[^fn_56a_4] only 'it' is unclean, but blood that issues from his mouth or from his membrum is not unclean but clean.[^fn_56a_5] But might I not reverse the deductions?[^fn_56a_6] — R. Johanan citing R. Simeon b. Yohai replied: It[^fn_56a_7] must be similar to spittle; as spittle is formed in globules when it is discharged so must any other unclean fluid be one that is formed in globules when it is discharged; blood is, therefore, excluded since it is not formed in globules when it is discharged. But is not a woman's milk formed in globules when it is discharged and the Master nevertheless stated that 'a woman's milk conveys the uncleanness of liquids' which implies: Only[^fn_56a_8] the uncleanness of liquids but not major uncleanness? — Rather said R. Johanan citing R. Simeon b. Yohai: It[^fn_56a_7] must be similar to spittle, as spittle is formed in globules when discharged but[^fn_56a_9] may be re-absorbed, so must any other unclean fluid be one that is formed in globules when discharged and that[^fn_56a_10] may be re-absorbed; blood is, therefore, excluded since it is not formed in globules when it is discharged, and a woman's milk is excluded since, though it is formed in globules when discharged, it cannot be re-absorbed. But why should not deduction be made from the zab's issue: As his issue which is not formed in globules when it is discharged causes uncleanness so does any other fluid?[^fn_56a_11] — Raba replied: One cannot make a deduction from his issue, since it also causes uncleanness to others.[^fn_56a_12]

A DEAD CREEPING THING. Resh Lakish ruled: A dead creeping thing that dried up but whose shape was retained is unclean. But have we not learnt that they CONVEY UNCLEANNESS WHEN WET BUT NOT WHEN DRY? — R. Zera replied: This is no difficulty since the former[^fn_56a_13] refers to a whole[^fn_56a_14] while the latter[^fn_56a_15] refers to a part;[^fn_56a_16] for it was taught: R. Isaac son of R. Bisna citing R. Simeon b. Yohai stated, In them,[^fn_56a_17] one might presume that it is necessary[^fn_56a_18] to touch a whole, hence it was explicitly stated, Of them.[^fn_56a_19] If only 'Of them' had been written it might have been presumed that it suffices[^fn_56a_18] to touch a part, hence it was explicitly stated 'In them'.[^fn_56a_17] How then are the two to be reconciled? The one[^fn_56a_20] refers to a wet creeping thing while the other[^fn_56a_21] refers to a dry one. Raba ruled: The lizards of Mahuza,[^fn_56a_22] if their shapes are retained, are unclean.

Resh Lakish further stated: If a dead creeping thing was burnt while its shape was retained it is unclean. An objection was raised: If a burnt creeping thing was found upon olives and so also if a tattered rag[^fn_56a_23] was found upon them they are clean, because all questions of uncleanness are determined by the condition of the objects at the time they are found![^fn_56a_24] — R. Zera replied: This is no difficulty since the former[^fn_56a_25] refers to a whole[^fn_56a_26] while the latter[^fn_56a_27] refers to a part; for it was taught: R. Isaac son of R. Bisna citing R. Simeon b. Yohai stated, In them',[^fn_56a_28] one might presume that it is necessary[^fn_56a_29] to touch a whole, hence it was explicitly stated, Of them.[^fn_56a_30] If only 'of them' had been written it might have been presumed that it suffices[^fn_56a_29] to touch a part, hence it was explicitly stated, 'in them'. How then are the two to be reconciled? The one[^fn_56a_31] refers to a burnt creeping thing while the other refers to one that is not burnt.

CONVEY UNCLEANNESS WHEN WET. The ISSUE?[^fn_56a_32] Because it is written, His flesh run.[^fn_56a_33] His mucus, PHLEGM AND SPITTLE?[^fn_56a_32] Because it is written, If he that hath the issue spit[^fn_56a_34] implying[^fn_56a_35] any fluid like spittle. A DEAD CREEPING THING?[^fn_56a_32] The All Merciful said, When they are dead,[^fn_56a_36] implying when they have the appearance of being dead.[^fn_56a_37] SEMEN?[^fn_56a_32] Since it must be capable of causing fertilization. A CARCASS?[^fn_56a_32] Since it is written, If … die[^fn_56a_38] implying when they have the appearance of being dead.[^fn_56a_37]

IF, HOWEVER, ON BEING SOAKED THEY ARE CAPABLE. R. Jeremiah enquired: Is the soaking to be from beginning to end[^fn_56a_39] in LUKEWARM WATER,[^fn_56a_40] or only at the beginning although it is not so at the end?[^fn_56a_41] — Come and hear what was taught: For how long must they be soaked in lukewarm water? Judah b. Nakosa replied, For twenty-four hours, being lukewarm at the beginning though not at the end. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel replied, They must be lukewarm throughout the twenty-four hours.

R. JOSE RULED: THE FLESH OF A CORPSE etc. Samuel explained: It is CLEAN in so far only as not to convey uncleanness if it is of the bulk of an olive, but it does convey the uncleanness of corpse mould.[^fn_56a_42] So it was also taught: R. Jose ruled, The flesh of a corpse that is dry and, on being soaked, cannot return to its original condition is clean in so far only as not to convey uncleanness if it is of the bulk of an olive but it is subject to the uncleanness of corpse-mould.[^fn_56a_42]

***MISHNAH***. IF A DEAD CREEPING THING WAS FOUND IN AN ALLEY IT CAUSES UNCLEANNESS RETROSPECTIVELY TO SUCH TIME AS ONE CAN TESTIFY, 'I EXAMINED THIS ALLEY AND THERE WAS NO CREEPING THING IN IT', OR TO SUCH TIME AS IT WAS LAST SWEPT. SO ALSO A BLOODSTAIN, IF IT WAS FOUND ON A SHIRT, CAUSES UNCLEANNESS RETROSPECTIVELY TO SUCH TIME AS ONE CAN TESTIFY, 'I EXAMINED THIS SHIRT AND THERE WAS NO STAIN ON IT' OR TO SUCH TIME AS IT WAS LAST WASHED. AND IT[^fn_56a_43] CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS[^fn_56a_44] IRRESPECTIVE OF WHETHER IT IS WET OR DRY.[^fn_56a_45] R. SIMEON RULED: IF IT IS DRY[^fn_56a_45] IT CAUSES UNCLEANNESS RETROSPECTIVELY,[^fn_56a_46] BUT IF IT IS WET[^fn_56a_45] IT CAUSES UNCLEANNESS ONLY TO A TIME WHEN IT COULD STILL HAVE BEEN WET.[^fn_56a_47] {¶=7.2}

***GEMARA***. The question was raised: Is the alley TO SUCH TIME AS IT WAS LAST SWEPT in the presumptive state of having been duly examined,[^fn_56a_48] or is it possible that it is in the presumptive state of having been properly swept?[^fn_56a_49] And in what case could this[^fn_56a_50] matter? — In that where a person declared that he had swept the alley but did not examine it.[^fn_56a_51] If you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been duly examined'[^fn_56a_48] surely, he had not examined it;[^fn_56a_52] but if you say, 'it is in the presumptive state of having been properly swept'[^fn_56a_49] surely, at that time[^fn_56a_53] it was properly swept.[^fn_56a_54] [pg 56b]

Or also in the case where the creeping thing was found in a hole.[^fn_56b_1] If you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been duly examined', any one who examines the alley examines also any hole in it; but if you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been properly swept', a hole is not usually swept.[^fn_56b_2]

SO ALSO A BLOODSTAIN etc. The question was raised: Is the shirt TO SUCH TIME AS IT WAS LAST WASHED in the presumptive state of having been duly examined,[^fn_56b_3] or is it possible that it is in the presumptive state of having been properly washed?[^fn_56b_4] And in what case could this[^fn_56b_5] matter? — In that where a person declared that he had washed the shirt but did not examine it — If you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been duly examined', surely, he had not examined it,[^fn_56b_6] but if you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been properly washed', surely, it had been properly washed.[^fn_56b_7] Or also in the case where the stain was discovered in a fold.[^fn_56b_8] If you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been duly examined', anyone engaged in an examination examines also the folds,[^fn_56b_9] but if you say that 'it is in the presumptive state of having been properly washed', a stain in a fold may not have been washed out.[^fn_56b_10] Now what is the decision? — Come and hear: For it was taught: R. Meir stated, Why did they[^fn_56b_11] rule that if a dead creeping thing was found in an alley it causes uncleanness retrospectively to such time as one can testify, 'I examined this alley and there was no creeping thing in it', or to such time as it was last swept?[^fn_56b_12] Because there is presumption that the children of Israel examine their alleys at the time they are swept; but if they did not examine them, they impaired its presumptive cleanness retrospectively.[^fn_56b_13] And why did they[^fn_56b_11] rule that a bloodstain, if found on a shirt, causes uncleanness retrospectively to such time as one can testify, 'I examined this shirt and there was no stain on it', or to such time as it was last washed?[^fn_56b_14] Because there is presumption that the daughters of Israel examine their shirts at the time they are washing them; but if they did not examine them, they impair its presumptive cleanness retrospectively.[^fn_56b_15] R. Aha ruled: Let her[^fn_56b_16] wash it again. If its colour fades[^fn_56b_17] it may be taken for granted[^fn_56b_18] that it was made after the previous washing,[^fn_56b_19] but if it does not fade it may be taken for granted[^fn_56b_18] that it was made before the previous washing. Rabbi said, A stain after its washing is not like a stain before it had been washed, for the former penetrates into the material while the latter remains clotted on its surface. Thus it may be inferred[^fn_56b_20] that[^fn_56b_21] there is presumption that it was duly examined. This is conclusive.

AND IT CAUSES UNCLEANNESS IRRESPECTIVE OF WHETHER IT IS WET etc. R. Eleazar explained: This[^fn_56b_22] was learnt only concerning the dead creeping thing, but a wet bloodstain also causes uncleanness retrospectively,[^fn_56b_23] for it might be assumed that it was already dry but water had fallen upon it. But can it not be assumed in the case of a dead creeping thing also that it was already dry but water had fallen upon it? — If that were the case it would have been completely dismembered.[^fn_56b_24]

***MISHNAH***. ALL BLOODSTAINS[^fn_56b_25] THAT COME FROM REKEM[^fn_56b_26] ARE CLEAN.[^fn_56b_27] R. JUDAH DECLARES THEM UNCLEAN, BECAUSE THE PEOPLE WHO LIVE THERE ARE PROSELYTES[^fn_56b_28] THOUGH MISGUIDED.[^fn_56b_29] THOSE[^fn_56b_30] THAT COME FROM THE HEATHENS[^fn_56b_31] ARE CLEAN.[^fn_56b_32] THOSE THAT COME FROM ISRAELITES OR FROM SAMARITANS, R. MEIR DECLARES, ARE UNCLEAN, BUT THE SAGES DECLARED THEM CLEAN[^fn_56b_33] BECAUSE THEY ARE UNDER NO SUSPICION[^fn_56b_33] IN REGARD TO THEIR STAINS. {¶=7.3}

***GEMARA***. Since the statement[^fn_56b_34] was made categorically[^fn_56b_35] it follows, does it not, that it applies even to those from Tarmod?[^fn_56b_36] — R. Johanan replied: This proves that proselytes may be accepted from Tarmod.[^fn_56b_37] But can this be right[^fn_56b_38] seeing that both R. Johanan and Sabya ruled, No proselytes may be accepted from Tarmod? And should you reply that R. Johanan only said, 'This',[^fn_56b_39] but he himself[^fn_56b_40] does not hold this view \[it could be retorted\]: Did not R. Johanan lay down, 'The *halachah* is in accordance with an anonymous Mishnah'?[^fn_56b_41] — It is a question in dispute between Amoras as to what was actually R. Johanan's view.

FROM ISRAELITES etc. As to the Rabbis,[^fn_56b_42] if they declare the menstrual blood of Israelites clean, whose do they hold to be unclean? — Some words are missing from our Mishnah, this being the correct reading: FROM ISRAELITES are unclean, FROM SAMARITANS, R. MEIR DECLARES, ARE UNCLEAN, since Samaritans are true proselytes,[^fn_56b_43] BUT THE SAGES DECLARED THEM CLEAN because, in their opinion, Samaritans are merely lion-proselytes.[^fn_56b_44] If so, instead of saying, BECAUSE THEY ARE UNDER NO SUSPICION IN REGARD TO THEIR STAINS, It should have been said, Because they are lion-proselytes? — The fact rather is that it is this that was meant: FROM ISRAELITES OR FROM SAMARITANS they are unclean, since Samaritans are true proselytes; those that are found in Israelite cities[^fn_56b_45] are clean since they are not suspected of leaving their stains exposed, for they rather keep them in privacy; and those that are found[^fn_56b_45] in Samaritan cities, R. MEIR DECLARES, ARE UNCLEAN because they are suspected of leaving their stains exposed, BUT THE SAGES DECLARED THEM CLEAN BECAUSE THEY[^fn_56b_46] ARE UNDER NO SUSPICION IN REGARD TO THEIR STAINS.

***MISHNAH***. ALL BLOODSTAINS, WHERESOEVER THEY ARE FOUND,[^fn_56b_47] ARE CLEAN, EXCEPT THOSE THAT ARE FOUND INDOORS[^fn_56b_48] OR ROUND ABOUT A CHAMBER FOR[^fn_56b_49] UNCLEAN WOMEN.[^fn_56b_50] A CHAMBER FOR[^fn_56b_49] UNCLEAN SAMARITAN WOMEN CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BY OVERSHADOWING[^fn_56b_51] BECAUSE THEY BURY MISCARRIAGES THERE. R. JUDAH STATED, THEY DID NOT BURY THEM BUT THREW THEM AWAY AND THE WILD BEASTS DRAGGED THEM OFF. THEY[^fn_56b_52] ARE BELIEVED WHEN THEY DECLARE, 'WE BURIED MISCARRIAGES THERE', OR 'WE DID NOT BURY THEM'. THEY[^fn_56b_52] ARE BELIEVED WHEN THEY DECLARE CONCERNING — A BEAST WHETHER IT HAD GIVEN BIRTH TO A FIRSTLING[^fn_56b_53] OR HAD NOT GIVEN BIRTH TO ONE. THEY[^fn_56b_52] ARE BELIEVED WHEN GIVING INFORMATION ON THE MARKING OF GRAVES,[^fn_56b_54] BUT THEY ARE NOT BELIEVED EITHER IN REGARD TO OVERHANGING BRANCHES,[^fn_56b_55] OR PROTRUDING STONES[^fn_56b_55] OR A BETH HA-PERAS.[^fn_56b_55] THIS IS THE GENERAL RULE: IN ANY MATTER WHERE THEY ARE UNDER SUSPICION THEY ARE NOT BELIEVED. [pg 57a] {¶=7.4}

***GEMARA***. What exposition did they rely upon?[^fn_57a_1] — Thou shalt not remove they neighbour's landmark,[^fn_57a_2] which they of old time have set, in thine inheritance,[^fn_57a_3] whosoever has an 'inheritance'[^fn_57a_4] has also a 'landmark',[^fn_57a_2] but whosoever has no inheritance[^fn_57a_5] has no landmark.[^fn_57a_2]

THEY ARE BELIEVED WHEN THEY SAY, 'WE BURIED …' But,[^fn_57a_6] surely, they do not uphold, do they, the exposition of the injunction, Nor put a stumbling-block before the blind?[^fn_57a_7] — R. Abbahu replied: This[^fn_57a_8] is a case where a \[Samaritan\] priest stood there.[^fn_57a_9] But is it not possible that the priest was unclean?[^fn_57a_10] — It is a case where he holds *terumah* in his hand.[^fn_57a_11] But is it not possible that the *terumah* was unclean?[^fn_57a_10] — It is a case where he was eating of it.[^fn_57a_12] If so,[^fn_57a_13] what was the need of stating it?[^fn_57a_14] — It might have been presumed that they are not acquainted with the stages of formation,[^fn_57a_15] hence we were informed \[that we do rely upon them\].[^fn_57a_16]

THEY ARE BELIEVED WHEN THEY DECLARE CONCERNING A BEAST etc. But, surely, they do not uphold, the exposition of the injunction, Nor put a stumbling-block before the blind, do they?[^fn_57a_17] — R. Hiyya b. Abba citing R. Johanan replied: It is the case of a beast that is shorn and engaged in work.[^fn_57a_18] If so, what was the need of stating such a law?[^fn_57a_14] — It might have been presumed that they are not acquainted with the nature of a discharge \[from the womb\],[^fn_57a_19] hence we were informed \[that they are to be believed\].

THEY ARE BELIEVED WHEN GIVING INFORMATION ON THE MARKING OF etc. Although this[^fn_57a_20] is only a Rabbinical institution[^fn_57a_21] they are careful to observe it, since it is mentioned in Scripture. For it is written, And any seeth a man's bone, then shall he set up a sign by it.[^fn_57a_22]

BUT THEY ARE NOT BELIEVED EITHER IN REGARD TO OVERHANGING BRANCHES etc. 'OVERHANGING BRANCHES', as we have learnt: The following are regarded as overhanging branches. The foliage of a tree that affords a covering over the ground.[^fn_57a_23]

PROTRUDING STONES, as we have learnt: protruding stones that project from a wall.[^fn_57a_24]

BETH HA-PERAS. Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: A man[^fn_57a_25] may[^fn_57a_26] blow away the earth in a beth ha-peras[^fn_57a_27] and[^fn_57a_28] continue on his way. R. Judah b. Ammi citing Rab Judah ruled: A beth peras that had been trodden out is clean.[^fn_57a_29] One further taught: If one ploughs a graveyard he forms thereby a beth ha-peras.[^fn_57a_30] And to what extent does he form it? To that of a full length of a furrow of a hundred cubit \[squared, which covers an area of\] four beth *se'ah*.[^fn_57a_31] R. Jose ruled: Five beth *se'ah*. But are they[^fn_57a_32] not believed?[^fn_57a_33] Was it not in fact taught, 'Concerning a field in which a grave was lost[^fn_57a_34] a Samaritan is believed when he stated, "There is no grave there",[^fn_57a_35] since he gives his evidence only about the grave itself;[^fn_57a_36] concerning a tree whose foliage affords a covering over the ground[^fn_57a_37] he is believed when he stated, "There is no grave under it",[^fn_57a_38] since he renders evidence only about the grave itself'?[^fn_57a_36] — R. Johanan replied: This[^fn_57a_39] is a case where he walks backward and forward throughout all its area.[^fn_57a_40] If so,[^fn_57a_41] what was the need of stating it?[^fn_57a_42] — It might have been presumed that a narrow strip jutted out,[^fn_57a_43] hence we were informed that[^fn_57a_44] he is believed.[^fn_57a_45]

THIS IS THE GENERAL RULE etc. What is the expression THIS IS THE GENERAL RULE intended to include? — To include Sabbath boundaries[^fn_57a_46] and wine of libation.[^fn_57a_47] [pg 57b]

## CHAPTER VIII

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN OBSERVED A BLOODSTAIN ON HER BODY,[^fn_57b_1] IF IT WAS NEAR THE PUDENDA SHE IS UNCLEAN[^fn_57b_2] BUT IF IT WAS NOT NEAR THE PUDENDA SHE REMAINS CLEAN. IF[^fn_57b_3] IT WAS ON HER HEEL OR ON THE TIP OF HER GREAT TOE, SHE IS UNCLEAN.[^fn_57b_4] ON HER THIGH OR ON HER FEET, IF ON THE INNER SIDE, SHE IS UNCLEAN; IF ON THEIR OUTER SIDE, SHE REMAINS CLEAN; AND IF ON THE FRONT AND BACK SIDES[^fn_57b_5] SHE REMAINS CLEAN. IF SHE OBSERVED IT ON HER SHIRT BELOW THE BELT, SHE IS UNCLEAN,[^fn_57b_2] BUT IF ABOVE THE BELT, SHE REMAINS CLEAN. IF SHE OBSERVED IT ON THE SLEEVE OF HER SHIRT, SHE IS UNCLEAN IF IT[^fn_57b_6] CAN REACH AS LOW AS THE PUDENDA,[^fn_57b_2] BUT IF IT CANNOT, SHE REMAINS CLEAN. IF SHE TAKES IT OFF AND COVERS HERSELF WITH IT IN THE NIGHT, SHE IS UNCLEAN WHEREVER THE STAIN IS FOUND,[^fn_57b_7] SINCE IT CAN TURN ABOUT.[^fn_57b_8] AND THE SAME LAW[^fn_57b_9] APPLIES TO A PALLIUM.[^fn_57b_10] {¶=8.1}

***GEMARA***. Samuel ruled: If a woman examined the ground[^fn_57b_11] and after sitting on it, found on it some blood, she remains clean, for it is said, In her flesh,[^fn_57b_12] implying that she is not unclean unless she feels[^fn_57b_13] in her flesh. But the expression[^fn_57b_14] 'in her flesh' is required for the deduction that she conveys uncleanness within[^fn_57b_15] as without?[^fn_57b_16] — If so,[^fn_57b_17] Scripture could have said, 'In flesh', why then did it say' 'in her flesh'? It may, therefore, be deduced that she is not unclean 'unless she feels[^fn_57b_18] in her flesh'. But still, is not the expression required for the deduction, 'In her flesh, but not within a sac or within a lump of flesh'?[^fn_57b_19] — Both deductions may be made from it.

Come and hear: If a woman while attending to her needs[^fn_57b_20] observed a discharge of blood, R. Meir ruled: If she was standing at the time she is unclean,[^fn_57b_21] but if she was then sitting she remains clean.[^fn_57b_22] Now how is one to imagine the circumstance?[^fn_57b_23] If she felt the discharge, why should she be clean where she was sitting? Consequently this must be a case where she did not feel a discharge, and yet it was taught, was it not, that she was unclean?[^fn_57b_24] — This may in fact be a case where she did feel a discharge but[^fn_57b_25] it might be assumed that the feeling was that of the ejection of the urine. When she stands, the urine might well return to the interior of her womb[^fn_57b_26] and then carry out some blood with it, but if she sits,[^fn_57b_27] she remains clean.

Come and hear: If on a testing rag that was placed under a pillow some blood was found, it is regarded as clean if it[^fn_57b_28] was round,[^fn_57b_29] but if it was elongated it is unclean. Now how are we to understand the circumstances? If she felt a discharge, why should it be clean when round? Consequently it must be a case where she felt no discharge, and yet it was stated, was it not, that if it was elongated it is unclean?[^fn_57b_30] — No, it may in fact be a case where[^fn_57b_31] she felt the discharge, but it might be assumed that it was the feeling of the testing rag. Hence if it is elongated it must certainly have issued from her body.[^fn_57b_32] but if it is round[^fn_57b_33] it is clean.[^fn_57b_34]

Come and hear: If a vestige of blood is found on his rag they are both unclean and are also under the obligation of bringing a sacrifice. If any blood is found on her rag immediately after their intercourse they are both unclean and are also under the obligation of bringing a sacrifice. If, however, any blood is found on her rag after a time they are both unclean by reason of the doubt but exempt from the sacrifice.[^fn_57b_35] Now how are we to imagine the circumstance? If she has felt a discharge, why should they be exempt from the sacrifice where the blood is found after a time? Must it not then be a case where she did not feel any discharge, and yet it was taught, was it not, that 'if any blood is found on her rag immediately after their intercourse they are both unclean and are also under the obligation of bringing a sacrifice'?[^fn_57b_30] — No, she may in fact have felt the discharge, but it might be assumed that it was the feeling of the attendant.[^fn_57b_36]

Come and hear: You are thus in a position[^fn_57b_37] to say that three forms of doubt appertain to a woman. A bloodstain on her body, concerning which there is doubt whether it is unclean and clean, is regarded as unclean;[^fn_57b_38] on her shirt, when it is doubtful whether it is unclean or clean, is regarded as clean;[^fn_57b_38] and in regard to the laws of the uncleanness of contact and heset[^fn_57b_39] you follow the majority. Now what is meant by 'you follow the majority'? Is it not that if on most days she is unclean[^fn_57b_40] this is a cause of uncleanness[^fn_57b_41] even when she felt no discharge?[^fn_57b_30] — No, the meaning is that if on most days her observation of the blood is accompanied by a feeling of the discharge she is unclean since it might be assumed that she had felt it this time also but did not pay any attention to it.

The Master said, 'A bloodstain on her body, concerning which there is doubt whether it is unclean or clean, is regarded as unclean; on her shirt, when it is doubtful whether it is unclean or clean, is regarded as clean'. How is one to understand the circumstances? If it[^fn_57b_42] was below her belt, why, when on her shirt, is it regarded as clean seeing that we have learnt, BELOW THE BELT, SHE IS UNCLEAN; and if it was above her belt, why, when on her body is it regarded as unclean, seeing that we have learnt that if she observed blood on her body, IF IT WAS NOT NEAR THE PUDENDA, SHE REMAINS CLEAN? — If you wish I could reply that the stain was below the belt; and if you prefer I might reply that it was above the belt. 'If you wish I could reply that the stain was below the belt', in a case, for instance, where she passed through a butchers' market. If the stain was on her body it must have emanated from herself, for if it had emanated from an external source[^fn_57b_43] it should have been found on her shirt; but if it is found on her shirt, it must have emanated from an external source,[^fn_57b_43] for if it had emanated from herself it should have been found on her body. 'And if you prefer I might reply that it was above her belt', in a case, for instance, where she jumped backwards. If the stain is on her body it must undoubtedly have emanated from herself, for if it had emanated from an external source[^fn_57b_43] it should have been found on her shirt; but if it is found on her shirt, it must have emanated from an external source,[^fn_57b_43] for if it had emanated from herself, it should have been found on her body. At all events, it was stated, was it not, 'A bloodstain on her body, concerning which there is doubt whether it is unclean or clean, is regarded as clean', presumably even if she did not feel any discharge?[^fn_57b_44] Furthermore, we have learnt, IF A WOMAN OBSERVED A BLOODSTAIN ON HER BODY. IF IT WAS NEAR THE PUDENDA, SHE IS UNCLEAN. Does not this imply even where she did not feel any discharge?[^fn_57b_45] — R. Jeremiah of Difti replied: Samuel agrees that[^fn_57b_46] she is unclean [pg 58a]

according to Rabbinic law.[^fn_58a_1] R. Ashi[^fn_58a_2] replied: Samuel gave his ruling in accordance with the view of R. Nehemiah. For we learnt: R. Nehemiah ruled, Any thing that is not susceptible to uncleanness is not susceptible to stains.[^fn_58a_3] According to R. Ashi one can well see the reason why he[^fn_58a_4] mentioned 'ground',[^fn_58a_5] but according to R. Jeremiah of Difti,[^fn_58a_6] what was the point of mentioning 'ground', seeing that even in the case of a cloak[^fn_58a_7] the woman is subject to the same law? — This is a case of an implied climax:[^fn_58a_8] There is no question \[that the woman is clean where she sat on\] a cloak since it cannot be thoroughly examined and one may, therefore, well assume \[that the stain\] emanated from an external source,[^fn_58a_9] but even \[where she sat on\] the ground which can well be thoroughly examined,[^fn_58a_9] and where[^fn_58a_10] it might justifiably be assumed that it emanated from her body, she is nevertheless regarded as clean.

ON HER HEEL OR ON THE TIP OF HER GREAT TOE. SHE IS UNCLEAN etc. One can well concede that HER HEEL[^fn_58a_11] is likely[^fn_58a_12] to come in contact with that place,[^fn_58a_13] but what is the reason for the uncleanness in the case of a stain on THE TIP OF HER GREAT TOE? And should you reply: It might sometimes touch her heel \[the objection would arise\]: Do we \[as regards\] uncleanness presume transfer from place to place? Was it not in fact taught: If she[^fn_58a_14] had a wound on her neck in a position to which the blood stain might be attributed,[^fn_58a_15] she may so attribute it;[^fn_58a_16] if it was on her shoulder, in which case she cannot so attribute it,[^fn_58a_17] she must not so attribute it; and we do not suggest that it is possible that she had taken it[^fn_58a_18] with her hand and transferred it there?[^fn_58a_19] — The fact rather is that THE TIP OF HER TOE is in a different category.[^fn_58a_20] because \[direct dropping of blood\] might occur while she is walking. But do we not \[as regards\] uncleanness presume transfer from place to place? Was it not in fact taught: If it[^fn_58a_21] was found on her finger joints.[^fn_58a_22] she is unclean, because hands are active.[^fn_58a_23] Now what is the reason?[^fn_58a_24] Is it not this: That we assume that she had examined herself with one hand[^fn_58a_25] and then touched it with her other hand?[^fn_58a_26] — No, her hand is different[^fn_58a_20] since all of it might come in direct contact[^fn_58a_27] \[with the menstrual source\].

ON HER THIGH OR ON HER FEET, IF ON THEIR INNER SIDE etc. How far[^fn_58a_28] ON THEIR INNER SIDE?[^fn_58a_29] — The school of R. Jannai replied: As far as the place of hebek.[^fn_58a_30] The question was asked: Is the place of the hebek.[^fn_58a_31] regarded as the inner, or as the outer side? — Come and hear what R. Kattina learnt: As far as the place of the hebek, and the hebek itself is regarded as the inner side. R. Hiyya son of R. Iwya taught this[^fn_58a_32] explicitly: The School of R. Jannai ruled, As far as the place of the hebek and the hebek itself is regarded as in the inner side.

R. Jeremiah enquired: What is the ruling[^fn_58a_33] where a bloodstain had the shape of a ring, of a straight line of drops,[^fn_58a_34] or of a splash of drops.[^fn_58a_35] or where it runs across the breadth of her thigh? — Come and hear: 'A bloodstain on her body concerning which there is doubt whether it is unclean or clean, is regarded as unclean'. Now does not 'on her body' imply stains of such shapes? — No, it might only refer to one that is shaped like a stripe.[^fn_58a_36]

A woman once found blood on her web. When she came to R. Jannai[^fn_58a_37] he told her to experiment by repeating[^fn_58a_38] her forward and backward movements.[^fn_58a_39] But was it not taught: No repetition \[test is recognized\] in questions of cleanness?[^fn_58a_40] — We say that no repetition test is recognized only[^fn_58a_41] where the law would thereby[^fn_58a_42] be relaxed, but where it is thereby restricted we do recognize a test of repetition.[^fn_58a_43]

IF SHE TAKES IT OFF etc. It was taught: R. Eleazar son of R. Jose stated, In such a case[^fn_58a_44] I gave a ruling in the city of Rome imposing a prohibition,[^fn_58a_45] and when I came to the Sages of the South they said to me, 'You have given the right decision.

Our Rabbis taught: Where a tall woman put on the shirt[^fn_58a_46] of a short woman or if a short one put on the shirt[^fn_58a_46] of a tall one, if \[a blood stain\][^fn_58a_47] corresponds to the position of the pudenda of the tall one, they are both unclean, but if it does not correspond to it,[^fn_58a_48] the tall one is clean while the short one is unclean. Another Baraitha taught: If a woman examined her shirt[^fn_58a_49] and then[^fn_58a_50] lent it to her friend,[^fn_58a_51] she is clean, but her friend may attribute it[^fn_58a_52] to her. R. Shesheth explained: This[^fn_58a_53] was learnt only in regard to the civil law,[^fn_58a_54] but as regards the law of uncleanness the lender is clean while her friend is unclean. [pg 58b]

But why is this case different from the following where it was taught: If two women were engaged in the preparation of one bird which contained no more than one *sela'* of blood, and then a stain of the size of a *sela'* was found on each, they are both unclean?[^fn_58b_1] — There[^fn_58b_2] the law is different since there was an additional *sela'*.[^fn_58b_3]

Our Rabbis taught: Where a woman put on three shirts[^fn_58b_4] that she had previously examined[^fn_58b_5] \[and then found blood on one of them\]. if she is in a position to attribute \[the blood to an external source\][^fn_58b_6] she may do so even though \[the blood was found\] on the lowest shirt, but if she is not in a position to attribute \[it to an external cause\][^fn_58b_6] she may not do so even though \[the blood was found\] on the uppermost shirt. How so? If she passed through a butchers' market she may attribute the blood to it even though it was found on the lowest shirt, but if she did not pass through a butchers' market she may not attribute the blood to it even if it was found on the uppermost.

***MISHNAH***. \[A WOMAN\] MAY ATTRIBUTE \[A BLOODSTAIN\] TO ANY \[EXTERNAL\] CAUSE TO WHICH SHE CAN POSSIBLY ATTRIBUTE IT.[^fn_58b_7] IF \[FOR INSTANCE\] SHE HAD SLAIN A DOMESTIC BEAST, A WILD ANIMAL OR A BIRD, IF SHE WAS HANDLING BLOODSTAINS OR SAT BESIDE THOSE WHO HANDLED THEM. OR IF SHE KILLED A LOUSE. SHE MAY ATTRIBUTE THE BLOODSTAIN TO IT. HOW LARGE A STAIN MAY BE ATTRIBUTED TO A LOUSE?[^fn_58b_8] R. HANINA B. ANTIGONUS REPLIED: ONE UP TO THE SIZE[^fn_58b_9] OF A SPLIT BEAN; \[AND IT MAY BE ATTRIBUTED TO A LOUSE\] EVEN THOUGH SHE DID NOT KILL IT.[^fn_58b_10] SHE MAY ALSO ATTRIBUTE IT TO HER SON OR TO HER HUSBAND.[^fn_58b_11] IF SHE HERSELF HAD A WOUND THAT[^fn_58b_12] COULD OPEN AGAIN AND BLEED SHE MAY ATTRIBUTE IT TO IT. A WOMAN ONCE CAME TO R. AKIBA AND SAID TO HIM: I HAVE OBSERVED A BLOODSTAIN'. 'HAD YOU PERHAPS', HE SAID TO HER. 'A WOUND?' YES'. SHE REPLIED, 'BUT IT HAS HEALED'. IS IT POSSIBLE HE AGAIN ASKED HER, THAT IT COULD OPEN AGAIN AND BLEED?' 'YES', SHE REPLIED; AND R. AKIBA DECLARED HER CLEAN. OBSERVING THAT HIS DISCIPLES LOOKED AT EACH OTHER IN ASTONISHMENT. HE SAID TO THEM, 'WHY DO YOU FIND THIS DIFFICULT, SEEING THAT THE SAGES DID NOT LAY DOWN THE RULE[^fn_58b_13] IN ORDER TO IMPOSE RESTRICTIONS BUT RATHER TO RELAX THEM, FOR IT IS SAID IN SCRIPTURE, AND IF A WOMAN HAVE AN ISSUE, AND HER ISSUE IN HER FLESH BE BLOOD.[^fn_58b_14] ONLY BLOOD[^fn_58b_15] BUT NOT A BLOODSTAIN. IF ON A TESTING RAG THAT WAS PLACED UNDER A PILLOW SOME BLOOD WAS FOUND, IF THE STAIN IS ROUND IT IS CLEAN BUT IF IT IS ELONGATED IT IS UNCLEAN; SO R. ELIEZER SON OF R. ZADOK. {¶=8.2}

***GEMARA***. Thus we have here[^fn_58b_16] learnt what our Rabbis taught elsewhere: It once happened that R. Meir attributed it to collyrium, and Rabbi attributed it to the sap of a sycamore.[^fn_58b_17]

OR SAT. Only where SHE SAT[^fn_58b_18] but not \[where she believes that\] she did not sit.[^fn_58b_19] Thus[^fn_58b_20] we have here learnt what our Rabbis taught elsewhere: If a woman passed through a butchers' market, and it is a matter of doubt whether any blood was or was not squirted on her she may attribute \[any bloodstain on her to a possible contingency\]; but if it is doubtful whether she did or did not pass the market she[^fn_58b_21] is unclean.[^fn_58b_22]

IF SHE KILLED A LOUSE. Only where SHE KILLED[^fn_58b_18] but not where she did not kill any. Whose view then does our Mishnah[^fn_58b_23] represent? — That of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel. For it was taught: If she killed a louse she may attribute a bloodstain to it, but if she did not kill any she may not so attribute it; so R. Simeon b. Gamaliel. But the Sages ruled: In either case she may attribute the one to the other. Said R. Simeon b. Gamaliel: According to my view there is no limit[^fn_58b_24] and according to the view of my colleagues there is no end.[^fn_58b_24] 'According to my view there is no limit' since you could hardly find[^fn_58b_25] a woman who could be regarded as clean for her husband, seeing that there is hardly[^fn_58b_25] a bed that does not contain ever so many drops of louse blood.[^fn_58b_26] 'According to the view of my colleagues there is no end', since there is hardly[^fn_58b_25] a woman who could be regarded as unclean for her husband, seeing that there is hardly a sheet on which there are not ever so many drops of blood;[^fn_58b_27] but the view of R. Hanina b. Antigonus is more feasible than mine and theirs, for he has laid down, 'How large a stain may be attributed to a louse? One not bigger than the size of a split bean',[^fn_58b_28] and we rule in agreement with his view.[^fn_58b_29] But according to the Rabbis who ruled, SHE MAY ATTRIBUTE,[^fn_58b_30] how large may be the stain?[^fn_58b_31] — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: She may attribute it to a bed-bug even if it is as big as a lupine.[^fn_58b_32]

Our Rabbis taught: A[^fn_58b_33] bed-bug is of the same length and breadth and the taste of it is like its odour. Whosoever crushes it cannot help[^fn_58b_34] smelling it. It was stated to be of 'the same length and breadth' in regard to bloodstains.[^fn_58b_35] 'The taste of it is like its odour' has been stated in regard to *terumah*.[^fn_58b_36] For we have learnt: 'Or if he tasted the flavour of a bed-bug in his mouth he must spit it out.[^fn_58b_37] But how could he know this?[^fn_58b_38] Because 'the taste of it is like its odour'. But still, whence could he know this?[^fn_58b_39] \[Because\] 'whosoever crushes it cannot help[^fn_58b_34] smelling it'.

R. Ashi ruled: In a town in which there are pigs there is no need to consider the possibility of menstrual bloodstains.[^fn_58b_40] R. Nahman b. Isaac stated: The condition of[^fn_58b_41] Dokereth[^fn_58b_42] is[^fn_58b_43] like that of a town in which there are pigs.[^fn_58b_44]

HOW LARGE A STAIN MAY BE ATTRIBUTED etc. R. Huna explained: If the stain is equal in size to a split bean it may not be attributed to a louse; if it is smaller in size than a split bean it may be attributed to it. R. Hisda, however, explained: If it was of the same size as a split bean it may be attributed to it, but if it was bigger than the size of a split bean it may not be attributed to it. Must it be assumed that they[^fn_58b_45] differ on the question whether UP TO' is meant to include the terminus,[^fn_58b_46] R. Huna[^fn_58b_47] holding the opinion that 'up to' does not include the terminus[^fn_58b_48] while R. Hisda[^fn_58b_49] holds that 'up to' is inclusive of the terminus?[^fn_58b_50] — R. Huna can answer you: 'Up to' may sometimes include the terminus and sometimes exclude it, but in either case[^fn_58b_51] the meaning must be one that leads to a restriction,[^fn_58b_52] while R. Hisda can answer you: Elsewhere I agree with you[^fn_58b_53] that we adopt a meaning that leads to a restriction and not one that leads to a relaxation, but here the meaning must be in agreement with a ruling of R. Abbahu, R. Abbahu having ruled: All prescribed minima of the Sages are intended to impose restrictions, except the prescribed size of a split bean in the case of bloodstains which is intended to relax the law.[^fn_58b_54] There are others who give this tradition[^fn_58b_55] as an independent statement:[^fn_58b_56] R. Huna ruled, A bloodstain of the size of a split bean is treated as one bigger than the size of a split bean;[^fn_58b_57] while R. Hisda ruled, One of the size of a split bean is treated as one that is less than the size of a split bean;[^fn_58b_58] but they differ on the interpretation of UP TO here, as has just been explained.[^fn_58b_59]

An objection was raised: [pg 59a]

If a woman had drops of blood on her body below her belt[^fn_59a_1] and drops of blood above it, she may attribute \[the former to the blood that is assumed to be the cause of the drops\] on the latter[^fn_59a_2] up to the size of a split bean. Now does not this[^fn_59a_3] mean a stain of the size of a split bean below her belt?[^fn_59a_4] — No, a stain of the size of a split bean above the belt.[^fn_59a_5]

It was stated: If on the body of a woman[^fn_59a_6] was found a stain of the size of a split bean plus some addition,[^fn_59a_7] and to that addition clung a louse, R. Hanina ruled: She is unclean;[^fn_59a_8] and R. Jannai ruled: She is clean.[^fn_59a_9] 'R. Hanina ruled: She is unclean', since she may attribute a stain to a louse only where the former is of the size of a split bean but not where it is of the size of a split bean plus. 'R. Jannai ruled: She is clean', since this restriction[^fn_59a_10] applies only where no louse clings to the addition, but where a louse clings to it, it is quite evident that the addition is the blood of a louse, so that only a stain of the size of a split bean remains;[^fn_59a_11] and since such a size may elsewhere[^fn_59a_12] be attributed to a louse it may also here be so attributed.

R. Jeremiah enquired: What is the ruling where a woman handled some blood of the bulk of a split bean but on her body was found a bloodstain of the size of a split bean and a little more? This question arises according to R. Hanina and it also arises according to R. Jannai. 'This question arises according to R. Hanina', since R. Hanina may have maintained his view there[^fn_59a_13] that the woman was unclean, only because she did not handle any blood, but here, where she did handle some, she may well attribute \[the stain to an extraneous cause\].[^fn_59a_14] or is it possible that, even according to R. Jannai who ruled[^fn_59a_13] that she was clean, the ruling applies only where a louse clings to the stain, but where no louse clings to it, the stain may not be attributed to it? — Come and hear: If she was handling red stuff she may not attribute to it a black stain; if she was handling a small quantity[^fn_59a_15] she may not attribute to it a large stain.
