Now how is one to imagine the circumstances?[^fn_59a_16] Would you not agree that they were of the same nature?[^fn_59a_17] — No, this[^fn_59a_16] might be a case, for instance, where she handled a quantity of blood of the bulk of a split bean while on her body was found a stain of the size of two split beans and a little more in excess.[^fn_59a_18] But if so,[^fn_59a_19] what was the need of mentioning it?[^fn_59a_20] — It might have been presumed that one takes the part of the stain[^fn_59a_21] that may be attributed to the blood of the bird[^fn_59a_22] to be in the middle[^fn_59a_23] so that there remains less than the prescribed minimum on either of its sides,[^fn_59a_24] hence we were informed \[that the stain cannot be attributed to it[^fn_59a_25] at all\].

Raba ruled: If one kind of material[^fn_59a_26] was found upon a woman[^fn_59a_27] she may attribute to it any kind of stain.[^fn_59a_28] It was objected: If she was handling red stuff she may not attribute to it a black stain![^fn_59a_29] — A case where she had handled the stuff is different.[^fn_59a_30] There are some who say: Raba ruled, If a woman was handling one kind of material, she may attribute to it any kinds of stain.[^fn_59a_28] It was objected: If she was handling red stuff she may not attribute to it a black stain![^fn_59a_31] — When Raba laid down his ruling he referred to a woman who was handling a hen which contains several kinds of blood.

A WOMAN ONCE etc. But was it not taught: Seeing that the Sages did not lay down the rule in order to relax the law but rather to restrict it?[^fn_59a_32] — Rabina replied: The meaning is that they did not lay down the rule to relax Pentateuchal laws,[^fn_59a_33] but rather to add restrictions to them;[^fn_59a_34] but the uncleanness of bloodstains is altogether a Rabbinical enactment.[^fn_59a_35]

IF ON A TESTING RAG THAT WAS PLACED. The question was raised: Do the Rabbis differ from R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok or not? — Come and hear: A long stain is counted[^fn_59a_36] but scattered drops are not combined.[^fn_59a_37] Now whose view does this represent? If it be suggested: That of R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok \[the difficulty would arise:\] Why was there need[^fn_59a_38] for the combination, seeing that he ruled that even a stain that was only slightly elongated is unclean. Must we not then conclude that it represents the view of the Rabbis? Thus it follows, does it not, that they differ from his view? — No, this may indeed represent the view of R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok, for he laid down the law[^fn_59a_39] in regard to a testing rag[^fn_59a_40] but not in regard to a bloodstain.[^fn_59a_41]

Come and hear[^fn_59a_42] what Rab Judah citing Samuel stated: 'The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer son of R. Zadok'. Now since the *halachah* had to be declared it follows that they[^fn_59a_43] differ from him.[^fn_59a_44] This is conclusive. [pg 59b]

## CHAPTER IX

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN WHEN ATTENDING TO HER NEEDS[^fn_59b_1] OBSERVED AN ISSUE OF BLOOD, R. MEIR RULED: IF SHE WAS STANDING SHE IS UNCLEAN[^fn_59b_2] BUT IF SHE WAS SITTING SHE REMAINS CLEAN. R. JOSE RULED: IN EITHER CASE SHE REMAINS CLEAN. IF A MAN AND A WOMAN ATTENDED TO THEIR NEEDS[^fn_59b_1] IN THE SAME BOWL AND BLOOD WAS FOUND ON THE WATER, R. JOSE[^fn_59b_3] RULED THAT IT WAS CLEAN,[^fn_59b_4] WHILE R. SIMEON RULED THAT IT WAS UNCLEAN, SINCE IT IS NOT USUAL FOR A MAN TO DISCHARGE BLOOD, BUT THE PRESUMPTION IS THAT BLOOD ISSUES FROM THE WOMAN. {¶=9.1}

***GEMARA***. Wherein does the case where the woman WAS STANDING differ \[from that of sitting\]? \[Obviously\] in that we presume that the urine had returned to the source[^fn_59b_5] and brought back blood with it. But then, even where SHE WAS SITTING why should it not also be assumed that the urine had returned to the source and brought back blood with it? — Samuel replied: The reference is to a woman who discharges in a gush.[^fn_59b_6] But even where a discharge is gushing is it not possible that[^fn_59b_7] the blood issued[^fn_59b_8] after the water had ceased to flow?[^fn_59b_9] — R. Abba replied. The reference is to a woman who sat on the rim of a bowl, discharging into the bowl, and blood was found within the bowl, \[in which case it is obvious\] that if the blood had issued after the water had ceased to flow it[^fn_59b_10] should have been found on the rim of the bowl.[^fn_59b_11] Samuel ruled or, as some say, Rab Judah citing Samuel ruled: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Jose; and also R. Abba gave a ruling to Kala:[^fn_59b_12] The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Jose.

IF A MAN AND A WOMAN etc. The question was asked: Where both the man and the woman were standing.[^fn_59b_13] what, pray tell me, is the ruling of[^fn_59b_14] R. Meir?[^fn_59b_15] Did R. Meir maintain his view[^fn_59b_16] only where one doubt[^fn_59b_17] is involved, but where a double doubt[^fn_59b_18] is involved he does not hold the woman to be unclean, or is it possible that there is no difference? — Resh Lakish replied: His ruling[^fn_59b_19] is the same in both. Whence is this[^fn_59b_20] inferred? — Since it was not stated:[^fn_59b_21] R. Meir and R. Jose[^fn_59b_22] ruled that she remains clean'. If so,[^fn_59b_23] \[the difficulty arises:\] Now that R. Meir holds the woman to be unclean where a double doubt is involved,[^fn_59b_24] was there any need for his ruling[^fn_59b_25] where only one doubt is involved?[^fn_59b_26] — Yes, in order to inform you how far reaching is the ruling[^fn_59b_27] of R: Jose who laid down that the woman is clean even where only one doubt is involved. But, instead of disputing about such a case involving only one doubt in order to inform you how far reaching is the ruling of R. Jose, why should they not dispute about a case involving a double doubt in order to inform you how far reaching is the ruling of R. Meir?[^fn_59b_28] The power of a lenient view[^fn_59b_29] is preferred.[^fn_59b_30] R. Johanan, however, replied: R. Meir gave his ruling[^fn_59b_31] only where one doubt is involved, but where a double doubt is involved[^fn_59b_32] he did not maintain his view. But if so,[^fn_59b_33] why was it not stated:[^fn_59b_34] R. Meir and R. Jose[^fn_59b_35] ruled that she remains clean? — This should indeed have been done,[^fn_59b_36] but since he had just left R. Jose[^fn_59b_37] he also began[^fn_59b_38] With R. Jose. As to R. Jose, however, since he holds the woman clean where only one doubt is involved,[^fn_59b_39] was there any need for his ruling where a double doubt is involved?[^fn_59b_40] — As it might have been presumed that his ruling applied only ex post facto[^fn_59b_41] but not ab initio,[^fn_59b_42] we were informed[^fn_59b_43] that the ruling applied even ab initio. It was taught in agreement with R. Johanan: If a man and a woman attended to their needs in the same bowl and blood was found on the water, R. Meir and R. Jose declared it clean and R. Simeon declared it unclean.

The question was raised: Where a woman[^fn_59b_44] was sitting,[^fn_59b_45] what, pray tell me, is the ruling of[^fn_59b_46] R. Simeon? Did R. Simeon maintain his view only where she is standing, since her passage is then compressed.[^fn_59b_47] but not where she was sitting;[^fn_59b_48] or is it possible that there is no difference? — Come and hear what was taught: If she was sitting she may attribute \[any discharge of blood to an internal wound\], but if she was standing she may not attribute \[it to it\]; so R. Meir. R. Jose ruled: In either case she may attribute \[it to it\]. R. Simeon ruled: In either case she may not attribute \[it to it\].

The question was raised: Where a man and a woman were sitting.[^fn_59b_49] what, pray tell me, is the ruling of[^fn_59b_46] R. Simeon? Did R. Simeon maintain his view only where the woman was standing, since her passage is then compressed,[^fn_59b_50] or where she was sitting, since only one doubt is involved, but not where a double doubt is involved;[^fn_59b_51] or is it possible that there is no difference? — Come and hear: Since R. Simeon ruled, THE PRESUMPTION IS THAT BLOOD ISSUES FROM THE WOMAN,[^fn_59b_52] no distinction is to be made between an issue when they[^fn_59b_53] were standing and one when they were sitting.

***MISHNAH***. IF SHE LENT HER SHIRT TO A GENTILE WOMAN OR TO A MENSTRUANT SHE MAY ATTRIBUTE A STAIN[^fn_59b_54] TO EITHER.[^fn_59b_55] IF THREE WOMEN HAD WORN THE SAME SHIRT OR HAD SAT ON THE SAME WOODEN BENCH AND SUBSEQUENTLY BLOOD WAS FOUND ON IT, ALL ARE REGARDED AS UNCLEAN.[^fn_59b_56] IF THEY HAD SAT ON A STONE BENCH[^fn_59b_57] OR ON THE PROJECTION WITHIN THE COLONNADE OF A BATH HOUSE,[^fn_59b_57] R. NEHEMIAH RULES THAT THEY ARE CLEAN;[^fn_59b_58] FOR R. NEHEMIAH HAS LAID DOWN: ANY THING THAT IS NOT SUSCEPTIBLE TO UNCLEANNESS IS NOT SUSCEPTIBLE TO STAINS.[^fn_59b_59] {¶=9.2}

***GEMARA***. Rab explained: The reference[^fn_59b_60] is to a GENTILE WOMAN [pg 60a]

who once experienced a discharge.[^fn_60a_1] Whence is this derived? From the fact that she is placed on a par with A MENSTRUANT. As the menstruant is a woman who experienced a discharge[^fn_60a_1] so must the GENTILE WOMAN be one who experienced a discharge.[^fn_60a_1] R. Shesheth remarked, Rab must have made this statement when he was lying down and about to doze, for it was taught: 'She may attribute it[^fn_60a_2] to the gentile woman.[^fn_60a_3] R. Meir said, To the gentile woman who is capable of a menstrual discharge',[^fn_60a_4] Now even R. Meir[^fn_60a_5] only spoke of one who is 'capable of a menstrual discharge' but did not require one who actually experienced a discharge.[^fn_60a_6] Raba retorted: But do you understand R. Meir to restrict the law?[^fn_60a_7] R. Meir in fact relaxes it. For it was taught: 'She may not attribute it[^fn_60a_8] to the gentile woman. R. Meir ruled: She may attribute it to her'.[^fn_60a_9] But, then, does not a difficulty arise[^fn_60a_10] from the former?[^fn_60a_11] — Explain thus:[^fn_60a_12] Only when she[^fn_60a_13] experienced a discharge once before; and R. Meir said, If she is capable of a menstrual discharge even though she never yet experienced one.[^fn_60a_14]

Our Rabbis taught: A woman may attribute a stain[^fn_60a_15] to another woman[^fn_60a_16] who was awaiting a day for a day, if it[^fn_60a_17] was the latter's second day,[^fn_60a_18] and[^fn_60a_19] to a woman[^fn_60a_16] who counted seven days[^fn_60a_20] before she had performed ritual immersion.[^fn_60a_21] Hence she is at an advantage[^fn_60a_22] while her friend is at a disadvantage;[^fn_60a_23] so R. Simeon b. Gamaliel. Rabbi ruled, She[^fn_60a_24] may not so attribute it.[^fn_60a_25] Hence both are at a disadvantage. They[^fn_60a_26] agree, however, that she may attribute a stain to a woman who was awaiting a day for a day if it[^fn_60a_27] was the latter's first day,[^fn_60a_28] and to a woman who was abiding in her clean blood,[^fn_60a_29] and to a virgin whose blood is clean.[^fn_60a_30] Why was it necessary to state the 'hence' of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel?[^fn_60a_31] — On account of the ruling of Rabbi.[^fn_60a_32] Why was it necessary to state the 'hence' of Rabbi?[^fn_60a_33] — It might have been presumed that only the woman on whom the stain was found shall be at a disadvantage while the other shall not be disadvantaged, hence we were informed that both are at a disadvantage.

R. Hisda stated: If a clean and an unclean person walked respectively in two paths one of which was clean and the other unclean,[^fn_60a_34] we arrive at the dispute between Rabbi and R. Simeon b. Gamaliel.[^fn_60a_35] R. Adda demurred: Rabbi may have maintained his view only[^fn_60a_36] there, because both are in similar conditions,[^fn_60a_37] but what difference \[to the unclean person in this case\] could our assumption make?[^fn_60a_38] And R. Hisda?[^fn_60a_39] — After all[^fn_60a_40] she has yet to perform the immersion.[^fn_60a_41] It was stated:[^fn_60a_42] R. Jose son of R. Hanina ruled, If a clean and an unclean person, and even if a clean, and a doubtfully clean person walked respectively in two paths one of which was unclean and the other clean, it may be assumed, according to the opinion of all,[^fn_60a_43] that the unclean path was taken by the doubtfully clean person and the clean path by the clean one.

R. Johanan enquired of R. Judah b. Liwai: May a stain[^fn_60a_44] be attributed to \[another woman[^fn_60a_45] who was unclean on account of\] a stain? So far as Rabbi's view is concerned the question does not arise; for, since in that case[^fn_60a_46] where the woman had observed a discharge from her own body[^fn_60a_47] you said \[that the other woman's stain\] may not be attributed \[to her\], how much less then may this be done in this case where the stain may have originated from an external cause.[^fn_60a_48] The question arises only in connection with the view of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel: Is it only in that case,[^fn_60a_46] where the woman had observed a discharge from her own body,[^fn_60a_47] that the other woman's stain may be attributed to her, but here, where the stain may have originated from an external cause,[^fn_60a_48] she may not so attribute it,[^fn_60a_49] or is it possible that no difference is made between the two cases? — The other replied: One may not so attribute it. What is the reason? — Because \[there is a tradition that\][^fn_60a_50] one may not so attribute it.[^fn_60a_51]

He pointed out to him the following objection: 'Is it not permissible to attribute a stain[^fn_60a_52] to \[another woman[^fn_60a_53] who was unclean on account of\] a stain. If a woman[^fn_60a_54] had lent her shirt to a gentile woman or to one who continued unclean by reason of a stain, she may attribute its to her.[^fn_60a_55] (But is not this Baraitha self contradictory: In the first clause you stated, 'it is not permissible to attribute' while in the final clause you stated that it was permissible to attribute? — This is no difficulty: The former is the view of Rabbi while the latter is that of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel. There are some who read: The latter as well as the former represents the view of Rabbi, but[^fn_60a_56] the latter[^fn_60a_57] applies to her first day[^fn_60a_58] while the former[^fn_60a_59] applies to her second day.[^fn_60a_60] R. Ashi replied: The former[^fn_60a_61] as well as the latter[^fn_60a_57] represents the view of R; Simeon b. Gamaliel and yet there is no difficulty, [pg 60b]

for the former applies to retrospective uncleanness[^fn_60b_1] while the latter applies to future uncleanness.)2 At all events does not a difficulty arise?[^fn_60b_3] — Rabina replied: This is no difficulty for it is this that was meant:[^fn_60b_4] If she had lent her shirt to a gentile woman,[^fn_60b_5] she who discovered[^fn_60b_6] the stain[^fn_60b_7] may attribute it to her.[^fn_60b_8] But was it not stated, 'or to one who continued unclean by reason of a stain'?[^fn_60b_9] — It is this that was meant: Or to one who continued clean owing to clean blood,[^fn_60b_10] she who discovered[^fn_60b_11] the stain may attribute it to her.[^fn_60b_12]

IF THREE WOMEN HAD WORN etc. FOR R. NEHEMIAH HAS etc. R. Mattenah stated: What is R. Nehemiah's reason? That it is written, And clean[^fn_60b_13] she shall sit upon the ground,[^fn_60b_14] provided she sat on the ground she is clean.[^fn_60b_15] R. Huna citing R. Hanina stated: R. Nehemiah rules that they are clean if they sat even on the back of an earthenware vessel. But is not this obvious?[^fn_60b_16] — It might have been presumed that a restriction shall be imposed on its back as a preventive measure against the possible relaxation of the law in regard to its inside,[^fn_60b_17] hence we were informed that on the back of an earthenware vessel they are clean. Abaye stated: R. Nehemiah holds them to be clean if they sat on strips of cloth that were less than three by three fingerbreadths, since such are unsuitable for use either by the poor or the rich.[^fn_60b_18]

R. Hiyya son of R. Mattenah citing Rab stated in his discourse: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Nehemiah. Said R. Nahman to him: Abba[^fn_60b_19] learnt, 'A case was once submitted to the Sages and they declared the woman concerned to be unclean' and you state, 'the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Nehemiah'? — What was that case? — The one concerning which it was taught: If two women were grinding with a hand mill and blood was found under the inner one,[^fn_60b_20] both are unclean.[^fn_60b_21] If it was found under the outer one,[^fn_60b_22] the outer one is unclean[^fn_60b_23] but the inner one remains clean.[^fn_60b_24] If it was found between the two, both are unclean.[^fn_60b_25] It once happened that blood was found on the edge of a bath,[^fn_60b_26] and on an olive leaf while they were making a fire in an oven, and when the case was submitted to the Sages they declared them to be unclean.[^fn_60b_27] This[^fn_60b_28] is a point at issue between Tannas. For it was taught: R. Jacob[^fn_60b_29] ruled that they were unclean and R. Nehemiah ruled that they were clean, and the Sages[^fn_60b_30] ruled in agreement with R. Nehemiah.

***MISHNAH***. IF THREE WOMEN SLEPT IN ONE BED AND BLOOD WAS FOUND UNDER ONE OF THEM, THEY ARE ALL UNCLEAN. IF ONE OF THEM EXAMINED HERSELF AND WAS FOUND TO BE UNCLEAN, SHE ALONE IS UNCLEAN WHILE THE TWO OTHERS ARE CLEAN. THEY MAY ALSO ATTRIBUTE THE BLOOD TO ONE ANOTHER.[^fn_60b_31] AND IF THEY WERE NOT LIKELY[^fn_60b_32] TO OBSERVE A DISCHARGE,[^fn_60b_31] THEY MUST BE REGARDED AS THOUGH THEY WERE LIKELY TO OBSERVE ONE. {¶=9.3}

***GEMARA***. Rab Judah citing Rab explained: But this[^fn_60b_33] applies only where she examined herself immediately \[after the discovery of the blood\],[^fn_60b_34] He is of the same opinion as Bar Pada who laid down: Whenever her husband is liable to a sin-offering,[^fn_60b_35] her clean things[^fn_60b_36] are[^fn_60b_37] to be unclean;[^fn_60b_38] where her husband is liable to a suspensive guilt-offering,[^fn_60b_39] her clean things[^fn_60b_40] are regarded as being in a suspended state of uncleanness;[^fn_60b_41] and where her husband is exempt,[^fn_60b_42] her clean things[^fn_60b_43] remain clean. But R. Oshaia[^fn_60b_44] ruled: Even where her husband is liable to a sin-offering,[^fn_60b_45] her clean things are[^fn_60b_46] deemed to be in a suspended state.[^fn_60b_47] One can see the reason[^fn_60b_48] there, since it might well be assumed that the waiter[^fn_60b_49] had caused the obstruction of the blood; but, in this case,[^fn_60b_50] if it were a fact that the blood was there,[^fn_60b_51] what could have caused its obstruction?[^fn_60b_52] R. Jeremiah observed: As to R. Oshaia's metaphor[^fn_60b_53] to what may this be compared? To an old man and a child who were walking together on a road. While they are underway the child restrains his gait.[^fn_60b_54] but after they enter the town[^fn_60b_55] the child accelerates his pace.[^fn_60b_56] Abaye on the other hand observed: As to the metaphor of R. Oshaia, to what may this be compared? To a man who puts his finger on his eye. While the finger is on the eye the tears are held back, but as soon as the finger is removed the tears quickly come forth.[^fn_60b_56]

THEY MAY ALSO ATTRIBUTE THE BLOOD TO ONE ANOTHER. Our Rabbis taught: In what manner do they attribute it to one another? If one was a pregnant woman[^fn_60b_54] and the other was not pregnant, the former may attribute the blood to the latter. If one was a nursing woman[^fn_60b_57] and the other was not a nursing woman, the former may attribute the blood to the latter. If one was an old woman[^fn_60b_57] and the other was not an old woman, the former may attribute the blood to the latter. If one was a virgin[^fn_60b_58] and the other was no virgin, the former may attribute the blood to the latter. If both were pregnant, nursing, old or virgins — it is \[a case like\] this concerning which we have learnt, IF THEY WERE NOT LIKELY TO OBSERVE A DISCHARGE, THEY MUST BE REGARDED [pg 61a]

AS THOUGH THEY WERE LIKELY TO OBSERVE ONE.

***MISHNAH***. IF THREE WOMEN SLEPT IN ONE BED, AND BLOOD WAS FOUND UNDER THE MIDDLE ONE, THEY ARE ALL UNCLEAN. IF IT WAS FOUND UNDER THE INNER ONE,[^fn_61a_1] THE TWO INNER ONES[^fn_61a_2] ARE UNCLEAN WHILE THE OUTER ONE IS CLEAN. IF IT WAS FOUND UNDER THE OUTER ONE,[^fn_61a_3] THE TWO OUTER ONES[^fn_61a_4] ARE UNCLEAN WHILE THE INNER ONE[^fn_61a_5] IS CLEAN. WHEN[^fn_61a_6] IS THIS THE CASE?[^fn_61a_7] WHEN THEY PASSED[^fn_61a_8] BY WAY OF THE FOOT OF THE BED,[^fn_61a_9] BUT IF THEY PASSED ACROSS IT,[^fn_61a_10] THEY ARE ALL UNCLEAN.[^fn_61a_11] IF ONE OF THEM EXAMINED HERSELF AND WAS FOUND CLEAN, SHE REMAINS CLEAN WHILE THE TWO OTHERS ARE UNCLEAN. IF TWO, EXAMINED THEMSELVES AND WERE FOUND TO BE CLEAN THEY REMAIN CLEAN WHILE THE THIRD IS UNCLEAN. IF THE THREE EXAMINED THEMSELVES AND WERE FOUND TO BE CLEAN, THEY ARE ALL UNCLEAN. TO WHAT MAY THIS BE COMPARED? TO AN UNCLEAN HEAP[^fn_61a_12] THAT WAS MIXED UP WITH TWO CLEAN HEAPS, WHERE, IF THEY EXAMINED ONE OF THEM AND FOUND IT TO BE CLEAN, IT IS CLEAN WHILE THE TWO OTHERS ARE UNCLEAN; IF THEY EXAMINED TWO OF THE HEAPS AND FOUND THEM TO BE CLEAN, THEY ARE CLEAN WHILE THE THIRD ONE IS UNCLEAN; AND IF THEY EXAMINED THE THREE AND THEY WERE FOUND TO BE CLEAN, THEY ARE ALL UNCLEAN; SO R. MEIR, FOR R. MEIR RULED: ANY OBJECT THAT IS IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF UNCLEANNESS ALWAYS REMAINS UNCLEAN UNTIL IT IS KNOWN TO YOU WHERE THE UNCLEANNESS IS. BUT THE SAGES RULED: ONE CONTINUES THE EXAMINATION OF THE HEAP UNTIL ONE REACHES BEDROCK OR VIRGIN SOIL.[^fn_61a_13] {¶=9.4}

***GEMARA***. Why is it that in the first clause[^fn_61a_14] no distinction is made[^fn_61a_15] while in the final clause[^fn_61a_16] a distinction is made? — R. Ammi replied: The former is a case where the women were interlocked.[^fn_61a_17]

IF ONE OF THEM EXAMINED HERSELF etc. What need was there for stating, 'TO WHAT MAY THIS BE COMPARED'? — It is this that R. Meir in effect said to the Rabbis: Why is it that in the case of blood you do not differ from me[^fn_61a_18] while in that of a heap you differ?[^fn_61a_19] — And the Rabbis?[^fn_61a_20] — There \[the heap may be regarded as clean\] since it might well be assumed that a raven had carried away the piece of corpse, but here, whence[^fn_61a_21] could the blood have come?[^fn_61a_22]

It was taught: R. Meir stated, It once happened that a sycamore tree at Kefar Saba, held to be in a presumptive state of uncleanness, was examined and no object of uncleanness was found. After a time the wind blew upon it and uprooted it when the skull of a corpse was found stuck in its root.[^fn_61a_23] They[^fn_61a_24] answered him: 'Do you adduce proof from there? It might be suggested that the examination was not thorough enough'.[^fn_61a_25]

It was taught: R. Jose stated, It once happened that a cave at Shihin, held to be in a presumptive state of uncleanness, was examined until ground, that was as smooth as a finger nail[^fn_61a_26] was reached, but no unclean object was found. After a time labourers entered it to shelter from[^fn_61a_27] rain, and chopping with their axes found a mortar full of bones.[^fn_61a_28] They[^fn_61a_29] answered him: 'Do you adduce proof from there? It might be suggested that the examination was not thorough enough'.[^fn_61a_30]

It was taught: Abba Saul stated, It once happened that a clod at Beth Horon was held in a presumptive state of uncleanness, and the Sages could not properly examine it because its area was extensive.[^fn_61a_31] But there was an old man in the place[^fn_61a_32] whose name was R. Joshua b. Hananiah and he said to them, 'Bring me some sheets'. They brought to him sheets and he soaked them in water and then spread them over the clod.[^fn_61a_33] The clean area[^fn_61a_34] remained dry while the unclean area[^fn_61a_35] became moist. And, having examined the latter, they found a large pit full of bones. One taught: That was the pit which Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had filled with slain bodies, as it is written, Now the pit wherein Ishmael cast all the dead bodies of the men whom he had slain by the hand[^fn_61a_36] of Gedaliah.[^fn_61a_37] But was it Gedaliah that killed them? Was it not in fact Ishmael that killed them?[^fn_61a_38] — But owing to the fact that he[^fn_61a_39] should have taken note of the advice of Johanan the son of Kareah[^fn_61a_40] and did not do so Scripture regards him as though he had killed them.

Raba observed: As to slander, though one should not believe[^fn_61a_41] it one should nevertheless take note of it. There were certain Galileans about whom a rumour was spread that they killed a person. They came to R. Tarfon and said to him, 'Will the Master hide us?' 'How', he replied, 'should I act? Should I not hide you, they[^fn_61a_42] would see you.[^fn_61a_43] Should I hide you, I would be acting contrary to the statement of the Rabbis,[^fn_61a_44] "As to slander, though one should not believe[^fn_61a_45] it, one should take note of it".[^fn_61a_46] Go you and hide yourselves'.

And the Lord said unto Moses: Fear him not'.[^fn_61a_47] Consider: Sihon and Og were brothers, for a Master stated, 'Sihon and Og were the sons of Ahijah the son of Shamhazai',[^fn_61a_48] then why was it that he feared Og while he did not fear Sihon? R. Johanan citing R. Simeon b. Yohai replied: From the answer that was given[^fn_61a_49] to[^fn_61a_50] that righteous man[^fn_61a_51] you may understand what was in his mind.[^fn_61a_52] He thought: Peradventure the merit of our father Abraham will stand him[^fn_61a_53] by, for it is said, And there came one that had escaped, and told Abram the Hebrew,[^fn_61a_54] in connection with which R. Johanan explained: This refers to Og who escaped the fate of the generation of the flood.[^fn_61a_55]

Our Rabbis taught:[^fn_61a_56] If a \[woman's\] bloodstain was lost in a garment[^fn_61a_57] one must apply to it[^fn_61a_58] seven substances[^fn_61a_59] and thus neutralize it. R. Simeon b. Eleazar ruled: [pg 61b]

One must examine it in small sections.[^fn_61b_1] If semen was lost in it, when new it should be examined with a needle,[^fn_61b_2] and when worn out it should be examined in sunlight.[^fn_61b_3] One taught: No section need be smaller than three fingerbreadths.

Our Rabbis taught: A garment in which kil'ayim[^fn_61b_4] was lost[^fn_61b_5] may not be sold to an idolater,[^fn_61b_6] nor may one make of it a packsaddle for an ass, but it may be made into[^fn_61b_7] a shroud for a corpse. R. Joseph observed: This[^fn_61b_8] implies that the commandments will be abolished in the Hereafter.[^fn_61b_9] Said Abaye (or as some say R. Dimi) to him: But did not R. Manni[^fn_61b_10] in the name of R. Jannai state, 'This[^fn_61b_8] was learnt only in regard to the time of the lamentations[^fn_61b_11] but for burial[^fn_61b_12] this is forbidden'?[^fn_61b_13] — The other replied: But was it not stated in connection with it, 'R. Johanan ruled: Even for burial'? And thereby R. Johanan followed his previously expressed view, for R. Johanan stated: 'What is the purport of the Scriptural text, Free[^fn_61b_14] among the dead?[^fn_61b_15] As soon as a man dies he is free from the commandments'.

Rafram b. Papa citing R. Hisda ruled: A garment in which kil'ayim was lost may be dyed[^fn_61b_16] and[^fn_61b_17] it is then permitted to be worn.[^fn_61b_18] Said Raba to Rafram b. Papa: Whence does the old man derive this?[^fn_61b_19] The other replied: It is in our Mishnah, for we have learnt, ONE CONTINUES THE EXAMINATION OF THE HEAP UNTIL ONE REACHES BEDROCK; and if it[^fn_61b_20] is not there, it is obviously assumed that a raven had carried it away. Here too, dye does not have the same effect on wool and flax and, since no \[difference could be\] discerned,[^fn_61b_21] it may well be assumed \[that the compromising threads\] had dropped out.

R. Aha son of R. Yeba citing Mar Zutra ruled: If a man inserted flaxen threads in his woollen garment and then pulled them out but is not sure whether he pulled them \[all\] out or not, it is quite proper \[for him to wear the garment\]. What is the reason? — Pentateuchally, since it is written sha'atnez[^fn_61b_22] the prohibition does not apply unless the material was hackled, spun and woven,[^fn_61b_23] but it is only the Rabbis who imposed a prohibition on it,[^fn_61b_24] and since the man is not quite sure about the pulling out of the threads the garment is permitted. R. Ashi demurred: Might it not be suggested that it[^fn_61b_25] must be either hackled or spun or woven? — The law, however, is in agreement with Mar Zutra, because the All Merciful expressed them in one word.[^fn_61b_23]

Our Rabbis taught: A dyed garment is susceptible to the uncleanness of a bloodstain. R. Nathan b. Joseph ruled: It is not susceptible to the uncleanness of a stain, for dyed garments were ordained for women only in order to relax the law in regard to their bloodstains. 'Were ordained'! Who[^fn_61b_26] ordained them? — Rather read: For dyed garments were permitted to women only in order to relax the law in regard to their bloodstains. 'Were permitted'! Does this then imply that they were once forbidden? — Yes, for we have learnt: At the time of the Vespasian invasion they[^fn_61b_27] prohibited the wearing of garlands by bridegrooms and the beating of drums at weddings. They also desired to prohibit dyed garments, but felt that it was better not to do so,[^fn_61b_28] in order to relax the law in regard to their bloodstains.

***MISHNAH***. SEVEN SUBSTANCES MUST BE APPLIED TO A STAIN:[^fn_61b_29] TASTELESS SPITTLE,[^fn_61b_30] THE LIQUID OF CRUSHED BEANS, URINE, NATRON, LYE, [pg 62a] {¶=9.5}

CIMOLIAN EARTH, AND LION'S LEAF. IF ONE IMMERSED IT[^fn_62a_1] AND, HAVING HANDLED CLEAN THINGS ON IT, APPLIED TO IT THE SEVEN SUBSTANCES AND THE STAIN DID NOT FADE AWAY IT MUST BE A DYE; AND THE CLEAN THINGS REMAIN CLEAN AND THERE IS NO NEED TO IMMERSE IT[^fn_62a_2] AGAIN. IF THE STAIN FADED AWAY OR GREW FAINTER,[^fn_62a_3] IT MUST BE A BLOODSTAIN AND THE CLEAN THINGS ARE UNCLEAN AND IT IS NECESSARY[^fn_62a_4] TO PERFORM IMMERSION AGAIN.[^fn_62a_5] WHAT IS MEANT BY TASTELESS SPITTLE'? THAT OF A MAN WHO ON THAT DAY[^fn_62a_6] TASTED NOTHING. THE LIQUID OF CRUSHED BEANS'? PASTE MADE OF CRUSHED BEANS THAT WERE NATURALLY[^fn_62a_7] PEELED OFF. URINE'? THIS REFERS TO SUCH AS HAS FERMENTED. ONE MUST SCOUR THE STAIN THREE TIMES WITH EACH OF THE SUBSTANCES. IF THEY WERE NOT APPLIED IN THE PRESCRIBED ORDER, OR IF THE SEVEN SUBSTANCES WERE APPLIED SIMULTANEOUSLY, NOTHING USEFUL HAS THEREBY BEEN DONE.[^fn_62a_8]

***GEMARA***. One taught:[^fn_62a_9] The Alexandrian natron and not the Antipatrian one.

BORITH.[^fn_62a_10] Rab Judah stated: This means ahala.[^fn_62a_11] But was it not taught: The borith and the ahal?[^fn_62a_12] — The fact is that borith means sulphur. An incongruity was pointed out: They[^fn_62a_13] added to them[^fn_62a_14] the bulb of ornithogalum[^fn_62a_15] and garden-orache,[^fn_62a_16] the borith and the ahal. Now if 'borith' means sulphur \[the objection would arise:\] Is it subject to the restrictions of the Sabbatical year, seeing that it was taught:[^fn_62a_17] This is the general rule, Whatsoever has a root[^fn_62a_18] is subject to the restrictions of the Sabbatical year and whatsoever has no root is not subject to the restrictions of the Sabbatical year? — What then do you suggest: That borith means ahala? But was it not taught: 'The borith and the ahal'?[^fn_62a_19] — There are two kinds of ahala.

KIMONIA.[^fn_62a_20] Rab Judah explained: Shelof-doz.[^fn_62a_21]

And eshlag.[^fn_62a_22] Samuel stated: I enquired of the seamen and they told me that its name was eshlaga, that it was to be found between the cracks of pearls and that it was extracted with an iron nail.

IF ONE IMMERSED IT AND, HAVING HANDLED etc. Our Rabbis taught: If one applied to it[^fn_62a_23] the seven substances[^fn_62a_24] and it did not fade away and then applied to it soap and it disappeared, one's clean things are unclean.[^fn_62a_25] But does not soap remove dye also?[^fn_62a_26] — Rather read: If one applied to it[^fn_62a_23] six of the substances and it did not fade away and when soap had been applied it disappeared, his clean things are unclean, since it is possible that if one had first applied to it the seventh substance it might also have disappeared.[^fn_62a_27] Another \[Baraitha\] taught: If one applied to it[^fn_62a_23] the seven substances and it did not fade away but when one applied them a second time it disappeared, one's clean things remain clean.[^fn_62a_28] R. Zera stated: This[^fn_62a_29] was taught only in regard to clean things that were handled between the first and the second wash;[^fn_62a_29] but the clean things that were handled after the second wash[^fn_62a_30] are unclean, since the person was particular about it[^fn_62a_31] and it had disappeared.[^fn_62a_32] [pg 62b]

Said R. Abba to R. Ashi: Does then the uncleanness[^fn_62b_1] depend on whether one is particular? — Yes, the other replied, for it was taught, 'R. Hiyya ruled: To that which is certain menstrual blood one may apply the seven substances and[^fn_62b_2] thereby[^fn_62b_3] neutralize it'.[^fn_62b_4] But why should this be so,[^fn_62b_5] seeing that it is menstrual blood? It is obvious then[^fn_62b_6] that uncleanness[^fn_62b_1] depends[^fn_62b_7] on whether one is particular. Here also[^fn_62b_8] then uncleanness[^fn_62b_1] may depend on whether one is particular.

Elsewhere we learnt: If potsherds which a *zab* has used[^fn_62b_9] absorbed liquids and then fell into the air-space of an oven,[^fn_62b_10] and the oven[^fn_62b_11] was heated, the oven becomes unclean, because the liquid[^fn_62b_12] would[^fn_62b_13] ultimately emerge.[^fn_62b_14] Resh Lakish stated: This[^fn_62b_15] was learnt only in regard to liquids of a minor uncleanness[^fn_62b_16] but in the case of liquids of a major uncleanness[^fn_62b_17] the oven becomes unclean even though it was not heated.[^fn_62b_18] R. Johanan stated: Whether the liquids were subject to a minor or a major uncleanness the oven is unclean only if it was heated but not otherwise.[^fn_62b_19]

R. Johanan raised an objection against Resh Lakish: IF ONE IMMERSED IT AND, HAVING HANDLED CLEAN THINGS ON IT, APPLIED TO IT THE SEVEN SUBSTANCES AND THE STAIN DID NOT FADE AWAY, IT MUST BE A DYE; AND THE CLEAN THINGS REMAIN CLEAN AND THERE IS NO NEED TO IMMERSE IT AGAIN.[^fn_62b_20] The other replied: Leave alone the laws of stains[^fn_62b_21] which are merely Rabbinical.[^fn_62b_22] But \[R. Johanan objected\] did not R. Hiyya teach, 'To that which is certain menstrual blood one may apply the seven substances and thereby neutralize it'?[^fn_62b_23] — The other replied: If Rabbi[^fn_62b_24] has not taught[^fn_62b_25] it,[^fn_62b_26] whence could R. Hiyya[^fn_62b_27] know it?[^fn_62b_28]

R. Johanan pointed out another objection against Resh Lakish: 'If a quarter of a *log* of blood[^fn_62b_29] was absorbed in the floor of a house \[all[^fn_62b_30] that is in\] the house becomes unclean,[^fn_62b_31] but others say: \[All that is in\] the house remains clean. These two versions, however, do not essentially differ, since the former refers to vessels that were there originally[^fn_62b_32] while the latter refers to vessels that were brought in subsequently.[^fn_62b_33] Where 'blood was absorbed in a garment, and on being washed, a quarter of a *log* of blood would emerge from it, it is unclean, but otherwise it is clean![^fn_62b_34] — R. Kahana replied: Here they have learnt some of the more lenient rulings concerning quarters of a *log* \[both referring to a mixture of clean and unclean blood\]; \[and the law of\] mixed blood[^fn_62b_35] is different[^fn_62b_36] since it[^fn_62b_37] is only Rabbinical.[^fn_62b_38] Resh Lakish raised an objection against R. Johanan: Any absorbed uncleanness that cannot emerge is regarded as clean.[^fn_62b_39] Thus it follows, does it not, that if it can emerge it is unclean even though it had not yet emerged?[^fn_62b_40] — R. Papa replied: Wherever it[^fn_62b_41] cannot emerge[^fn_62b_42] and the owner did not mind absorption,[^fn_62b_43] all agree that it is regarded as clean. If it can emerge and the owner does mind the absorption, all agree that it is unclean. They only differ where it can emerge but the owner does not mind its absorption. One Master[^fn_62b_44] holds the view that since it can emerge \[it is unclean\], though the owner did not mind its absorption;[^fn_62b_45] and the other Master[^fn_62b_46] holds that although it can emerge [pg 63a]

it is unclean only if the owner minds the absorption, but not otherwise.[^fn_63a_1]

WHAT IS MEANT BY 'TASTELESS SPITTLE'. One taught:[^fn_63a_2] That of a man who tasted nothing since the previous evening. R. Papa intended to explain before Raba \[that this bears the same meaning\] as when one says that he had tasted nothing in the evening.[^fn_63a_3] But Raba[^fn_63a_4] pointed out to him: Does it say 'in the evening'?[^fn_63a_3] It only says, 'Since the previous evening',[^fn_63a_5] thus excluding only the case of one who got up early[^fn_63a_6] and ate.[^fn_63a_7] Rabbah b. Bar Hana citing R. Johanan stated: What is meant by tasteless spittle? \[That of a person\] who spent half a night in sleep.[^fn_63a_8] This then implies that the quality of spittle[^fn_63a_9] depends on sleep. But have we not learnt:[^fn_63a_10] If a man slept all day his is no tasteless spittle and if he was awake all night it is tasteless spittle?[^fn_63a_11] — There[^fn_63a_12] it is a case, where one was in a state of drowsiness.[^fn_63a_13] What state of drowsiness is hereby to be understood? — R. Ashi replied: Where a man is half asleep and half awake;[^fn_63a_14] when addressed he answers but is unable to give any rational reply, and when he is reminded of any thing he can recall it.

One taught: If a man rose up early in the morning and studied his lesson, his is no tasteless spittle.[^fn_63a_15] But for how long?[^fn_63a_16] — R. Judah b. Shila citing R. Ashi who had it from R. Eleazar replied: For a period during 'which[^fn_63a_17] can be uttered the greater part of one's usual talk in the course of three hours.

THE LIQUID OF CRUSHED BEANS? — PASTE MADE OF CRUSHED BEANS etc. May it be suggested that this[^fn_63a_18] provides support for Resh Lakish; for Resh Lakish said: There must be tasteless spittle with each of the substances? — It is possible that the heat of one's mouth suffices.[^fn_63a_19] Our Mishnah[^fn_63a_20] is not in agreement with R. Judah. For it was taught: R. Judah explained,[^fn_63a_21] Boiling liquid of crushed beans before \['ober\] salt is put into it.[^fn_63a_22] What is the proof that the expression[^fn_63a_23] 'ober' means 'before'? — R. Nahman b. Isaac replied: Since Scripture says, Then Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain, and overran \[wa-ya'abor\][^fn_63a_24] the Cushite.[^fn_63a_25] Abaye replied, The proof comes from here: And he himself passed over \['abar\][^fn_63a_24] before them.[^fn_63a_26] And if you prefer I might reply that the proof comes from here: And their king is passed on \[wa-ya'abor\][^fn_63a_24] before them, and the Lord before them.[^fn_63a_27]

URINE? THIS REFERS TO SUCH AS HAS FERMENTED. One taught: What must be the duration of[^fn_63a_28] their fermentation? Three days. R. Johanan observed, All the standards of the Sages in respect of bloodstains need additional standards to define them:[^fn_63a_29] \[Is the urine that\] of a child or of an old man,[^fn_63a_30] of a man or of a woman,[^fn_63a_30] covered[^fn_63a_30] or uncovered, of the summer season[^fn_63a_30] or of the winter season?

ONE MUST SCOUR THE STAIN THREE TIMES. R. Jeremiah enquired: Does the forward and backward movement[^fn_63a_31] count as one or is it possible that it counts as two? Now what is the decision? — This stands undecided.[^fn_63a_32]

IF THEY WERE NOT APPLIED IN THE PRESCRIBED ORDER. Our Rabbis taught: If the latter[^fn_63a_33] were applied before the former,[^fn_63a_34] one Baraitha teaches, 'The latter[^fn_63a_35] are counted[^fn_63a_36] and the former[^fn_63a_37] are not counted,'[^fn_63a_38] while another \[Baraitha\] teaches, 'The former are counted and the latter are not counted'![^fn_63a_39] — Abaye replied: According to both statements the latter[^fn_63a_35] are counted, and the former[^fn_63a_40] are not; but 'former'[^fn_63a_41] refers to those that are[^fn_63a_42] first in the prescribed order[^fn_63a_43] though second in the process of application.

***MISHNAH***. FOR EVERY WOMAN THAT HAS A SETTLED PERIOD IT SUFFICES \[TO RECKON HER PERIOD OF UNCLEANNESS FROM\] HER SET TIME. AND THESE ARE THE SYMPTOMS OF SETTLED PERIODS: \[IF THE WOMAN\][^fn_63a_44] YAWNS, SNEEZES, FEELS PAIN AT THE TOP OF[^fn_63a_45] HER STOMACH OR THE BOTTOM OF HER BOWELS, DISCHARGES,[^fn_63a_46] OR IS SEIZED BY A KIND OF SHIVERING, OR ANY OTHER SIMILAR SYMPTOMS.[^fn_63a_46] ANY WOMAN WHO ESTABLISHED FOR HERSELF \[ONE OF THE SYMPTOMS\][^fn_63a_44] THREE TIMES MAY BE DEEMED TO HAVE[^fn_63a_47] A SETTLED PERIOD. {¶=9.6}

***GEMARA***. Have we not learnt once before, 'For any woman who has a settled period it suffices \[to reckon her period of uncleanness from\] her set time'?[^fn_63a_48] — There the reference is to settled periods \[that are determined by the number\] of days[^fn_63a_49] while here the reference is to settled periods \[that are determined by conditions\] of the body; as it was actually taught, 'The following are the symptoms of settled periods: If a woman yawns, sneezes, feels pain at the top of her stomach or the bottom of her bowels or discharges'. 'Discharges'! Is she not then[^fn_63a_50] constantly discharging?[^fn_63a_51] — 'Ulla son of R. Elai replied: [pg 63b]

This is a case where she discharges unclean blood as a result of a discharge[^fn_63b_1] of clean blood.[^fn_63b_2]

OR … A KIND OF SHIVERING etc. What was the expression, OR ANY OTHER SIMILAR SYMPTOMS, intended to include? — Rabbah b. 'Ullah replied: To include a woman who feels a heaviness in her head[^fn_63b_3] or a heaviness in her limbs, who shivers or belches. R. Huna b. Hiyya citing Samuel observed: Behold \[the Sages\] have ruled that 'for settled periods \[that are determined by the number\] of days two \[occurrences are required\],[^fn_63b_4] for settled periods \[that are determined by the condition\] of the body one occurrence suffices,[^fn_63b_5] for settled periods \[that are determined by conditions\] which the Sages did not enumerate three occurrences are required;[^fn_63b_6] But \[I do not know\] what the expression, 'for settled periods that are determined by conditions which the Sages did not enumerate intended to include? — R. Joseph replied: To include a woman who feels a heaviness in the head,[^fn_63b_3] a heaviness in her limbs, who shivers or belches. Said Abaye to him:[^fn_63b_7] What does he teach us thereby,[^fn_63b_8] seeing that this is actually a ruling in our Mishnah,[^fn_63b_9] Rabbah b. 'Ulla having thus[^fn_63b_10] explained it? — Rather, said Abaye, it[^fn_63b_8] was intended to include one who ate garlic and observed a discharge, one who ate onions and observed a discharge, and one who chewed pepper and observed a discharge. R. Joseph observed: I have not heard this tradition.[^fn_63b_11] Said Abaye to him: You yourself have told it to us, and it was in connection with the following that you told it to us:[^fn_63b_12] If a woman was in the habit of observing a discharge on the fifteenth day of the month and this was changed to the twentieth day, intercourse is forbidden to her on both days.[^fn_63b_13] If she observed a discharge on three consecutive months[^fn_63b_14] on the twentieth day, intercourse on the fifteenth becomes permitted[^fn_63b_15] and she establishes the twentieth day as her settled period: for no woman can establish for herself a settled period unless the discharge had appeared three times on the same date.[^fn_63b_16] And in connection with this you told us: Rab Judah citing Samuel stated, This is the view of R. Gamaliel son of Rabbi who cited it in the name of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel,[^fn_63b_17] but the Sages ruled: If she observed a discharge once[^fn_63b_18] she need not[^fn_63b_19] repeat it a second time and a third time. And when we asked you, 'Since you said, "She need not repeat it a second time" was there any need to state that she need not repeat it a third time'? you replied' She need not repeat it a second time in the case of settled periods \[that are determined by the condition\] of her body and she need not repeat it a third time in the case of settled periods \[determined by the number\] of days. But why did he not simply say, 'This is the view of R. Simeon b. Gamaliel'?[^fn_63b_17] — It is this that Samuel informed us: That R. Gamaliel the son of Rabbi holds the same view as R. Simeon b. Gamaliel.

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN HAD THE HABIT OF OBSERVING HER MENSTRUAL DISCHARGES AT THE ONSET OF THE SYMPTOMS[^fn_63b_20] OF HER SETTLED PERIODS, ALL CLEAN THINGS[^fn_63b_21] THAT SHE HANDLED WHILE THE SYMPTOMS WERE IN PROGRESS[^fn_63b_22] ARE UNCLEAN; BUT IF SHE HAD THE HABIT OF OBSERVING THEM AT THE END OF THE SYMPTOMS, ALL CLEAN THINGS[^fn_63b_21] THAT SHE HANDLED WHILE THE SYMPTOMS LASTED[^fn_63b_22] REMAIN CLEAN. R. JOSE RULED: SETTLED PERIODS MAY ALSO BE DETERMINED BY DAYS AND HOURS.[^fn_63b_23] IF[^fn_63b_24] SHE HAD THE HABIT OF OBSERVING HER MENSTRUAL DISCHARGES AT SUNRISE SHE IS FORBIDDEN INTERCOURSE AT SUNRISE ONLY.[^fn_63b_25] R. JUDAH RULED: SHE[^fn_63b_26] IS PERMITTED IT DURING ALL THAT DAY.[^fn_63b_27] {¶=9.7}

***GEMARA***. One taught: What[^fn_63b_28] did R. Jose mean by 'Settled periods may also be determined by days and hours'? If a woman had the habit of observing her discharge on the twentieth day of the month[^fn_63b_29] and at the sixth hour of the day,[^fn_63b_30] and the twentieth day arrived and she observed no discharge, she is forbidden intercourse during all the first six hours;[^fn_63b_31] so R. Judah. R. Jose, however, permits it until the beginning of the sixth hour[^fn_63b_32] but during the sixth hour she must take into consideration \[the possibility of a discharge\].[^fn_63b_33] If the sixth hour has passed and she observed no discharge, she is still forbidden intercourse all that day; so R. Judah, R. Jose, however, permits it from the time of the afternoon service[^fn_63b_34] onwards.

IF SHE HAD THE HABIT \[etc.\]. But was it not taught: R. Judah ruled, She[^fn_63b_35] is permitted intercourse all night?[^fn_63b_36] — This is no contradiction. The Baraitha deals with the case of[^fn_63b_37] one who had the habit of observing the discharge at the beginning of the day[^fn_63b_38] while the Mishnah deals with one who had the habit of observing the discharge at the end of the night.[^fn_63b_39]

One \[Baraitha\] taught: R. Judah forbids intercourse before her settled period, and permits it after the period while another \[Baraitha\] taught: \[R. Judah\] forbids it after her settled period and permits it before the period. This,[^fn_63b_40] however, represents no difficulty, since the former is a case where she usually observes her discharge at the end of the night while the latter is a case where she usually observes it at the beginning of the day.[^fn_63b_41]

Raba stated: The *halachah* is in agreement with R. Judah. But could Raba have said this, seeing that it was taught: Thus shall ye separate the children of Israel from their uncleanness;[^fn_63b_42] from this, R. Jeremiah[^fn_63b_43] observed, follows a warning to the children of Israel that they shall separate from their wives near their periods. And for how long? Raba[^fn_63b_44] replied: One 'onah.[^fn_63b_45] Now does not this mean: An additional 'onah?[^fn_63b_46] — No; the same 'onah. But then, what need is there for the two statements?[^fn_63b_47] — Both are required. For, if he had informed us of the former statement only, it might have been presumed that it applied only to the law relating to clean things but not to that relating to a woman's permissibility to her husband. Hence we were informed \[of the latter statement\]. And if \[our information were to be derived\] from the latter statement only it might have been presumed that near her settled period an additional 'onah is required, hence we were informed that only one 'onah is necessary.

***MISHNAH***. IF SHE WAS ACCUSTOMED TO OBSERVE A FLOW OF MENSTRUAL BLOOD ON THE FIFTEENTH DAY[^fn_63b_48] AND THIS WAS CHANGED[^fn_63b_49] TO THE TWENTIETH DAY,[^fn_63b_48] MARITAL INTERCOURSE IS FORBIDDEN ON BOTH DAYS.[^fn_63b_50] IF THIS WAS TWICE CHANGED TO THE TWENTIETH INTERCOURSE IS AGAIN FORBIDDEN ON BOTH DAYS.[^fn_63b_50] IF THIS WAS CHANGED THREE TIMES TO THE TWENTIETH DAY, INTERCOURSE IS NOW PERMITTED ON THE FIFTEENTH[^fn_63b_51] AND THE TWENTIETH IS ESTABLISHED AS HER SETTLED PERIOD. FOR A WOMAN MAY NOT REGARD HER MENSTRUAL PERIODS AS SETTLED UNLESS THE RECURRENCE HAS BEEN REGULAR THREE TIMES; NOR IS SHE RELEASED FROM THE RESTRICTIONS OF A SETTLED PERIOD UNLESS IT HAS VARIED[^fn_63b_52] THREE TIMES. [pg 64a] {¶=9.8}

***GEMARA***. It was stated: If a woman observed a discharge on the fifteenth day of one month, on the sixteenth of the next month and on the seventeenth of the third month, Rab ruled: She has thereby established for herself a settled period in arithmetical progression,[^fn_64a_1] but Samuel ruled: No settled period can be established unless the progression is repeated three times.[^fn_64a_2] Must it be conceded that Rab and Samuel differ on the same principle as that on which Rabbi and R. Simeon b. Gamaliel differ? For it was taught: If a woman was married to one man who died and to a second one who also died, she may not be married to a third one; so Rabbi. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: She may be married to a third but may not be married to a fourth?[^fn_64a_3] — No, all[^fn_64a_4] may concede that the law is in agreement with R. Simeon b. Gamaliel but it is this principle on which they[^fn_64a_5] differ here: Rab holds that the fifteenth day is included in the number while Samuel holds that the fifteenth, since the observation on it was not in arithmetic progression, is not included in the number.[^fn_64a_6]

He raised an objection against him: If a woman had been accustomed to observe her discharge on the fifteenth day[^fn_64a_7] and this was changed[^fn_64a_8] to the sixteenth, intercourse is forbidden[^fn_64a_9] on both days.[^fn_64a_10] If this was changed[^fn_64a_11] to the seventeenth day, intercourse[^fn_64a_12] on the sixteenth is again permitted[^fn_64a_13] but on the fifteenth[^fn_64a_14] and the seventeenth[^fn_64a_15] it is forbidden. If[^fn_64a_12] this was changed to the eighteenth intercourse[^fn_64a_12] is again permitted on all the former dates;[^fn_64a_16] and[^fn_64a_17] is forbidden only on the day after[^fn_64a_18] the eighteenth and onwards.[^fn_64a_19] Now does not this[^fn_64a_20] present an objection against Rab?[^fn_64a_21] — Rab can answer you: Where a woman was accustomed to observe her discharge on a certain date[^fn_64a_22] the law is different.[^fn_64a_23] But as to him who raised the objection, on what possible ground did he raise it?[^fn_64a_24] — \[He assumed that the case of\] one who was accustomed to a settled period had to be stated:[^fn_64a_25] As it might have been presumed that since she was accustomed to observe her discharge on a settled date and this was changed, the change is effective[^fn_64a_26] even if this[^fn_64a_27] occurred only twice, hence we had to be informed \[that[^fn_64a_28] the change must have recurred three times\].

An objection was raised: If she observed a discharge on the twenty-first day of one[^fn_64a_29] month, on the twenty-second of the next month and on the twenty-third of the third month, she has thereby established for herself a settled period. If she skipped over[^fn_64a_30] to the twenty-fourth[^fn_64a_31] day of the month, she has not established for herself a settled period.[^fn_64a_32] Does not this[^fn_64a_33] present an objection against Samuel?[^fn_64a_34] — Samuel can answer you: Here we are dealing with the case of a woman, for instance, who was accustomed to observe her discharge on the twentieth day and this[^fn_64a_35] was changed to the twenty-first.[^fn_64a_36] An inference from the wording also justifies this view;[^fn_64a_37] for the twentieth day was left out[^fn_64a_38] and the twenty-first was mentioned.[^fn_64a_39] This is conclusive.

FOR A WOMAN MAY NOT REGARD HER MENSTRUAL PERIOD AS SETTLED UNLESS THE RECURRENCE HAS BEEN REGULAR etc. R. Papa explained: This[^fn_64a_40] was said only in regard to the establishment of a settled period,[^fn_64a_41] but as regards taking the possibility of a discharge into consideration[^fn_64a_42] one occurrence suffices.[^fn_64a_43] But what[^fn_64a_44] does he[^fn_64a_45] teach us, seeing that we have learnt: IF SHE WAS ACCUSTOMED TO OBSERVE A FLOW OF MENSTRUAL BLOOD ON THE FIFTEENTH DAY AND THIS WAS CHANGED TO THE TWENTIETH DAY, MARITAL INTERCOURSE IS FORBIDDEN ON BOTH DAYS?[^fn_64a_46] — If the inference had to be made from there,[^fn_64a_47] it might have been presumed that the ruling[^fn_64a_48] applied only where the woman was still[^fn_64a_49] within her menstruation period,[^fn_64a_50] but where she is not within her menstruation period[^fn_64a_51] she[^fn_64a_52] need not consider the possibility of a discharge,[^fn_64a_53] hence we were informed[^fn_64a_54] \[that even in the latter case the possibility of a discharge must be taken into consideration\].

NOR IS SHE RELEASED FROM THE RESTRICTIONS OF A SETTLED PERIOD etc. R. Papa explained: This, that it is necessary for the change to recur three times before a settled period can be abolished, was said only where a settled period had been established by three regular occurrences, but one that was established by two recurrences only may be abolished by one change. But what[^fn_64a_55] does he[^fn_64a_56] teach us, seeing that we learnt: A WOMAN MAY NOT REGARD HER MENSTRUAL PERIODS AS SETTLED UNLESS THE RECURRENCE HAS BEEN REGULAR THREE TIMES?[^fn_64a_57] — It might have been presumed[^fn_64a_58] that one occurence[^fn_64a_59] is required for the abolition of one,[^fn_64a_60] two[^fn_64a_61] for two[^fn_64a_62] and three[^fn_64a_61] for three,[^fn_64a_62] hence we were informed[^fn_64a_63] \[that even for two occurrences[^fn_64a_64] only ones is required\].[^fn_64a_65] It was taught in agreement with R. Papa:[^fn_64a_66] If a woman had a habit of observing her menstrual discharge on the twentieth day,[^fn_64a_67] and this was changed to the thirtieth, intercourse is forbidden[^fn_64a_68] on both days. If the twentieth day[^fn_64a_68] arrived and she observed no discharge, she is permitted intercourse until the thirtieth but must consider the possibility of a discharge on the thirtieth day itself.[^fn_64a_69] If the thirtieth day arrived and she observed a discharge, the twentieth[^fn_64a_68] arrived and she observed none, the thirtieth arrived and she observed none and the twentieth[^fn_64a_68] arrived and she observed one, the thirtieth[^fn_64a_68] becomes a permitted day[^fn_64a_70] [pg 64b]

and the twentieth[^fn_64b_1] becomes a forbidden one, because the guest[^fn_64b_2] comes in his usual time.

***MISHNAH***. WOMEN IN REGARD TO THEIR VIRGINITY ARE LIKE VINES. ONE VINE MAY HAVE RED WINE[^fn_64b_3] WHILE ANOTHER HAS BLACK WINE, ONE VINE MAY YIELD MUCH WINE WHILE ANOTHER YIELDS LITTLE.[^fn_64b_4] R. JUDAH STATED: EVERY NORMAL VINE YIELDS[^fn_64b_5] WINE,[^fn_64b_6] AND ONE THAT YIELDS NO WINE IS BUT A DORKETAI.[^fn_64b_7] {¶=9.9}

***GEMARA***. One taught:[^fn_64b_8] A generation cut off.[^fn_64b_9] R. Hiyya taught: As leaven is wholesome for the dough so is \[menstrual\] blood wholesome for a woman. One taught in the name of R. Meir: Every woman who has an abundance of \[menstrual\] blood has many children.

## CHAPTER X

***MISHNAH***. IF A YOUNG GIRL, WHOSE AGE OF MENSTRUATION[^fn_64b_10] HAS NOT ARRIVED, MARRIED, BETH SHAMMAI RULED: SHE IS ALLOWED[^fn_64b_11] FOUR NIGHTS,[^fn_64b_12] AND BETH HILLEL RULED: UNTIL THE WOUND IS HEALED.[^fn_64b_13] IF THE AGE OF HER MENSTRUATION HAS ARRIVED[^fn_64b_14] AND SHE MARRIED, BETH SHAMMAI RULED: SHE IS ALLOWED[^fn_64b_11] THE FIRST NIGHT, AND BETH HILLEL RULED: FOUR NIGHTS, UNTIL THE EXIT OF THE SABBATH.[^fn_64b_15] IF SHE HAD OBSERVED A DISCHARGE WHILE SHE WAS STILL IN HER FATHER'S HOUSE,[^fn_64b_16] BETH SHAMMAI RULED: SHE IS ONLY ALLOWED THE OBLIGATORY MARITAL INTERCOURSE,[^fn_64b_17] AND BETH HILLEL RULED: ALL THAT[^fn_64b_18] NIGHT. {¶=10.1}

***GEMARA***. R. Nahman b. Isaac explained:[^fn_64b_19] Even if she already observed a discharge.[^fn_64b_20] Whence is this inferred? — Since in the final clause[^fn_64b_21] a distinction is drawn between one who did and one who did not observe a discharge it follows that in the case in the first clause no distinction is made between the one and the other.[^fn_64b_22] So it was also taught: Beth Hillel ruled: Intercourse is allowed until the wound is healed irrespective of whether she already[^fn_64b_23] did or did not observe a discharge.

UNTIL THE WOUND IS HEALED. For how long?[^fn_64b_24] — Rab Judah replied: Rab said, 'So long as it discharges matter', but when I mentioned this in the presence of Samuel the latter said to me, 'I do not know what that "discharging" exactly means; rather explain.[^fn_64b_25] So long as spittle is engendered in the mouth[^fn_64b_26] on account of intercourse'.[^fn_64b_27] How is one to understand the 'discharging' of which Rab spoke? — R. Samuel son of R. Isaac replied. This was explained to me by Rab: If when standing she observes a discharge and when sitting she does not observe one, it may be known that the wound has not healed; if when lying on the ground she observes a discharge and when lying on cushions and bolsters she does not observe one, it may be known that the wound had not healed; and if when lying on any of these she either observes a discharge or does not observe one, it may be known that the wound is healed.

IF THE AGE OF HER MENSTRUATION HAS ARRIVED etc. It was stated: If she had intercourse in the day time,[^fn_64b_28] Rab ruled, She has not lost thereby the right to intercourse during the nights. but Levi ruled, She has thereby lost the right to intercourse in the nights. Rab ruled, 'She has not lost thereby the right to intercourse during the nights', because we learnt, UNTIL THE EXIT OF THE SABBATH.[^fn_64b_29] 'But Levi ruled, She has thereby lost the right to intercourse in the nights', for the meaning of[^fn_64b_30] FOUR NIGHTS mentioned is four 'onahs.[^fn_64b_31] But according to Rab[^fn_64b_32] what was the purpose of mentioning FOUR NIGHTS? — We were thereby informed of what is regarded as good manners, viz., that intercourse should take place at night.[^fn_64b_33] But according to Levi[^fn_64b_34] it should only have been stated FOUR NIGHTS, what was the purpose of saying, UNTIL THE EXIT OF THE SABBATH? — It is this that we were informed:[^fn_64b_35] That it is permitted to perform the first marital intercourse[^fn_64b_36] on the Sabbath,[^fn_64b_37] in agreement with a ruling of Samuel; for Samuel ruled: It is permissible to enter through a narrow breach[^fn_64b_38] on the Sabbath although one causes pebbles to fall.[^fn_64b_39]

It was stated: If a man had marital intercourse[^fn_64b_40] and found no blood but, having repeated the act,[^fn_64b_41] he found blood, R. Hanina ruled: The woman is unclean;[^fn_64b_42] but R. Assi ruled: She is clean. 'R. Hanina ruled: The woman is unclean', for if it were the case that the blood was that of virginity it would have issued on the first occasion. 'But R. Assi ruled: She is clean', because it is possible that something unusual may have happened to her, in accordance with a statement of Samuel; for Samuel stated, 'I could perform a number of acts of intercourse without causing any bleeding'. And the other?[^fn_64b_43] — Samuel is different from ordinary people since his capability[^fn_64b_44] was great.

Rab stated: A woman who has reached her maturity[^fn_64b_45] is[^fn_64b_46] allowed[^fn_64b_47] all the first night.[^fn_64b_48] But this applies only to a woman who had never yet observed a discharge, but if she did observe one she is permitted the obligatory act of intercourse only and no more. An objection was raised: It once happened that Rabbi allowed a woman intercourse on four nights in twelve months.[^fn_64b_49] Now how is one to understand his ruling? If it be suggested that he allowed her all these nights[^fn_64b_50] during the period of her minority [pg 65a]

the objection would arise: Have we not learnt, UNTIL THE WOUND IS HEALED?[^fn_65a_1] If, however, it is suggested that he allowed her all the nights during the period of her na'aruth[^fn_65a_2] the difficulty would arise: Does na'aruth ever extend over twelve months, seeing that Samuel had stated: The period intervening between the commencement of na'aruth and maturity is only six months? And should you suggest that the meaning is that the period is not shorter but may be longer[^fn_65a_3] it could be retorted: Did he not in fact state 'only'?[^fn_65a_4] If, however, it is suggested that he allowed her two nights during the days of her minority and two during her na'aruth, the difficulty would arise: Did not R. Hinena b. Shelemya once ask Rab, 'what is the ruling where her age of menstruation arrived when she was already under the authority of her husband?' and the other replied: All acts of intercourse which one performs[^fn_65a_5] are regarded as one act only and the other[^fn_65a_6] make up the four nights?[^fn_65a_7] Consequently this must be a case where he allowed her one night during her minority, two nights during her na'aruth period and one night during the days of her maturity. Now if you grant that a woman of mature age generally is allowed[^fn_65a_8] more than one night[^fn_65a_9] one can well see the justification for the ruling;[^fn_65a_10] for, as intercourse during minority has the effect of reducing one night[^fn_65a_11] during her na'aruth period, so intercourse during the na'aruth period has the effect of reducing one night[^fn_65a_12] during her maturity;[^fn_65a_13] but if you maintain[^fn_65a_14] that a woman of mature age generally[^fn_65a_8] is not allowed more than one night, should he[^fn_65a_15] not have allowed her[^fn_65a_16] but one act of the obligatory marital intercourse and no more?[^fn_65a_17] — The fact is that he[^fn_65a_15] allowed her one night during her minority and three nights during her na'aruth period,[^fn_65a_18] but[^fn_65a_19] it was not as you think[^fn_65a_20] that every three months represented a period; every two months rather represented a period.

Menjamin of Saksanah was embarking on a journey[^fn_65a_21] to the locality of Samuel where he intended to act[^fn_65a_22] according to the ruling of Rab,[^fn_65a_23] even where the woman had observed a discharge, assuming that Rab drew no distinction between one who did and one who did not observe a discharge, but he died while he was underway. Samuel accordingly applied to Rab[^fn_65a_24] the Scriptural text, There shall no mischief befall the righteous.[^fn_65a_25]

R. Hinena b. Shelemya observed: As soon as a person's teeth fall out[^fn_65a_26] his means[^fn_65a_27] of a livelihood are reduced; for it is said: And I also have given you cleanness of teeth[^fn_65a_26] in all your cities, and want of bread in all your places.[^fn_65a_28]

IF SHE OBSERVED A DISCHARGE WHILE SHE WAS STILL etc. Our Rabbis taught: If a girl observed a discharge while she was still in her father's house, Beth Hillel ruled: She is permitted marital intercourse all the night[^fn_65a_29] and, moreover, she is allowed a full 'onah. And how long is a full 'onah?[^fn_65a_30] — R. Simeon b. Gamaliel explained: A night and half a day. But do we require an 'onah to be so long?[^fn_65a_31] Is not \[such a requirement\] rather incongruous with the following: If a person's winepresses or oil-presses were unclean and he desired to prepare his wine and oil respectively[^fn_65a_32] in conditions of cleanness, how is he to proceed? He rinses the boards,[^fn_65a_33] the twigs[^fn_65a_34] and the troughs; [pg 65b]

and as for the wickerwork, if it is made of willows and hemp it must be scoured, and if of bast or reeds it must remain unused;[^fn_65b_1] and for how long must they remain unused? For twelve months. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: One must leave them from one period of wine-pressing to another[^fn_65b_2] and from one period of oil-pressing to another.[^fn_65b_2] (But is not this ruling[^fn_65b_3] identical with that of the first Tanna?[^fn_65b_4] — The practical difference between them arises in the case of early or late ripening fruit.)[^fn_65b_5] R. Jose stated: If a person desires to obtain cleanness forthwith he pours over them boiling water or scalds them with olive water. R. Simeon b. Gamaliel citing R. Jose ruled: He puts them under a pipe through which runs a continuous stream of water or in a fountain with flowing water. And for how long? For one 'onah. (As these provisions were applied to yen nesek so were they applied to matters of cleanness. But is not the order[^fn_65b_6] reversed, seeing that we are here dealing with the laws of cleanness? — Rather say: As these provisions were applied to matters of cleanness so were they applied to yen nesek.) And how long is an 'onah? R. Hiyya b. Abba citing R. Johanan replied: Either a day or a night. R. Hana She'una or, as some say, R. Hana b. She'una citing Rabbah b. Bar Hana who had it from R. Johanan replied: Half a day and half a night. And in connection with this R. Samuel b. R. Isaac explained: There is no real difference between them,[^fn_65b_7] the former referring to the spring and autumn equinoxes[^fn_65b_8] and the latter to the summer and winter solstices?[^fn_65b_9] — Here also, in the case of the menstruant woman,[^fn_65b_10] read: Half a day and half a night. But did he not say 'a night and half a day'? — Rather say: Either 'a night' in the spring or autumn equinox or 'half a day and half a night' in the winter or summer solstice. And if you prefer I might reply: The case involving a *kethubah*[^fn_65b_11] is different[^fn_65b_12] since protracted negotiations take place[^fn_65b_13] before it is signed.[^fn_65b_14]

Both Rab and Samuel laid down: The *halachah* is that[^fn_65b_15] one performs the obligatory marital act and withdraws forthwith. R. Hisda raised an objection: It once happened that Rabbi allowed a woman intercourse on four nights in twelve months![^fn_65b_16] — Said Rabbah[^fn_65b_17] to him: What need have you[^fn_65b_18] for repeating the same objection? Rather raise one from our Mishnah?[^fn_65b_19] — But he was of the opinion that a practical decision[^fn_65b_20] is weightier.[^fn_65b_21] At all events,[^fn_65b_22] does not a difficulty arise against Rab and Samuel?[^fn_65b_23] They acted in agreement with our Masters; for it was taught: Our Masters decided by a second count of votes[^fn_65b_24] that one only performs the obligatory marital act and withdraws forthwith.

'Ulla stated: When R. Johanan and Resh Lakish were engaged in the discussions of the chapter on the 'Young Girl'[^fn_65b_25] they carried away from it only what a fox carries away from a ploughed field,[^fn_65b_26] and concluded it[^fn_65b_27] with this statement: One performs the obligatory marital act and withdraws forthwith. Said R. Abba to R. Ashi: Now then,[^fn_65b_28] should a scrupulous man[^fn_65b_29] not even finish his act? — The other replied: If that were to be the rule[^fn_65b_30] one would be ill at ease[^fn_65b_31] and would withdraw altogether.

Our Rabbis taught: But all these women if they[^fn_65b_32] were continually discharging blood during[^fn_65b_33] the four nights and after the four nights or[^fn_65b_34] during the night and after it, must without exception[^fn_65b_35] examine themselves;[^fn_65b_36] and in the case of all these R. Meir imposes restrictions in agreement with the view of Beth Shammai.[^fn_65b_37] In regard, however, to other observations of blood,[^fn_65b_38] concerning which a difference of opinion exists between Beth Shammai[^fn_65b_39] and Beth Hillel,[^fn_65b_40] he is guided[^fn_65b_41] by the colour of the blood; for R. Meir ruled: The colours of the various kinds of blood are different from one another. In what manner? Menstrual blood is red, the blood of virginity is not so red; menstrual blood is turbid, the blood of virginity is not turbid; menstrual blood issues from the source, the blood of virginity issues from the sides. R. Isaac son of R. Jose citing R. Johanan stated: This is the ruling of R. Meir alone, but the Sages maintain: All the colours of the various kinds of blood are the same.

Our Rabbis taught: A woman who observes a discharge of blood[^fn_65b_42] as a result of marital intercourse may perform her marital duty the first, second and third time. Henceforward,[^fn_65b_43] however, she may not perform it until she is divorced [pg 66a]

and marries another man.[^fn_66a_1] If she was married to another man and again observed a discharge of blood as a result of her marital intercourse, she may perform her marital duty the first, second and third time. Henceforward, however, she may not perform it until she is divorced and marries another man. If she was married to another man and again observed a discharge of blood as a result of her intercourse she may perform her marital duty the first, second and third time. Henceforward, however, she may not perform it unless she first examines herself. How does she examine herself? She inserts a tube within which rests a painting stick to the top of which is attached an absorbent. If blood is found on the top of the absorbent it may be known that it[^fn_66a_2] emanated from the source[^fn_66a_3] and if no blood is found on the top, it may be known that it[^fn_66a_2] emanated from the sides.[^fn_66a_4] If, however, she has a wound in that place she may attribute the blood to her wound.[^fn_66a_4] If she has a fixed period[^fn_66a_5] she may attribute it to her fixed period,[^fn_66a_6] but if the nature of the blood of her wound is different from that of the blood of her observation she may not so attribute it. A woman, furthermore, is believed when she says, 'I have a wound in the source from which blood is discharged';[^fn_66a_4] so Rabbi.[^fn_66a_7] R. Simeon b. Gamaliel ruled: The blood of a wound that is discharged through the source is unclean. Our Masters, however, testified that the blood of a wound that is discharged through the source is clean. What is the point at issue between them?[^fn_66a_8] — 'Ulla replied: The point at issue between them is the question whether the interior of the uterus is unclean.[^fn_66a_9] Would not a tube[^fn_66a_10] bruise her?[^fn_66a_11] — Samuel replied: The examination is performed with a leaden tube whose edge[^fn_66a_12] is bent inwards. But, said Resh Lakish to R. Johanan, why should she not[^fn_66a_13] examine herself[^fn_66a_14] after the third intercourse with her first husband?[^fn_66a_15] — The other replied: Because not all fingers[^fn_66a_16] are alike.[^fn_66a_17] But, the former said, why should she not[^fn_66a_18] have to examine herself[^fn_66a_14] after the first intercourse with her third husband? — Because not all ejections[^fn_66a_19] are of equal force.[^fn_66a_20]

A certain woman once came to Rabbi \[with such a complaint\].[^fn_66a_21] Go, he said to Abdan, and frighten her. As the latter approached and frightened her a clot of blood dropped from her. This woman, Rabbi exclaimed, is now cured. A certain woman \[with a similar complaint\][^fn_66a_21] once came to the Master Samuel. Go, he said to R. Dimi b. Joseph, and frighten her. The latter approached and frightened her but nothing dropped from her. This woman, Samuel pronounced, is one full of blood which she scatters,[^fn_66a_22] and any woman who is full of blood which she scatters[^fn_66a_22] has no cure. Once there came to R. Johanan a certain woman who, whenever she emerged from her ritual immersion, observed a discharge of blood. It is possible, he said to her, that the gossip of your townspeople[^fn_66a_23] has caused the affliction;[^fn_66a_24] arrange[^fn_66a_25] for your intercourse with him to take place near the river side.[^fn_66a_26] There is one who says: He[^fn_66a_27] said to her, Reveal your affliction to your friends so that, as they were astounded in one way,[^fn_66a_28] they may also be astounded in the other.[^fn_66a_29] There is also one who says: He[^fn_66a_30] said to her, Announce your trouble to your friends so that they may offer prayers for mercy to be vouchsafed to you. For it was taught: And shall cry, 'Unclean, unclean',[^fn_66a_31] he must announce his trouble to the public so that they may pray for mercy to be vouchsafed to him. R. Joseph stated: Such an incident once occurred at Pumbeditha and the woman was cured.

R. Joseph citing Rab Judah who had it from Rab stated: Rabbi ordained at Sadoth,[^fn_66a_32] If a woman observed a discharge on one day she[^fn_66a_33] must wait[^fn_66a_34] six days in addition to it.[^fn_66a_35] If she observed discharges on two days she[^fn_66a_33] must wait[^fn_66a_34] six days in addition to these.[^fn_66a_36] If she observed a discharge on three days she[^fn_66a_33] must wait[^fn_66a_34] seven clean days.[^fn_66a_37] R. Zera stated: The daughters of Israel have imposed upon themselves the restriction that even if they observe a drop of blood of the size of a mustard seed they wait on account of it seven clean days.

Raba took R. Samuel out for a walk[^fn_66a_38] when he discoursed as follows: If a woman[^fn_66a_39] was in protracted labour[^fn_66a_40] for two days and on the third she miscarried she must wait seven clean days; he being of the opinion that the law relating to protracted labour[^fn_66a_41] does not apply to miscarriages and that it is impossible for the uterus[^fn_66a_42] to open without bleeding. Said R. Papa to Raba: What is the point in speaking of one who was in protracted labour for two days seeing that the same applies even where there was the minutest discharge, since R. Zera stated, The daughters of Israel have imposed upon themselves the restriction that even where they observe only a drop of blood of the size of a mustard seed they wait on account of it seven clean days? — The other replied: I am speaking to you of a prohibition,[^fn_66a_43] and you talk of a custom which applies only where the restriction has been adopted.[^fn_66a_44]

(Mnemonic. Had an offer, natron, In warm water, to perform immersion, folds upon a haven.)[^fn_66a_45] Raba stated: If a woman had an offer of marriage and she accepted it she[^fn_66a_46] must allow seven clean days to pass.[^fn_66a_47]

Rabina was engaged in preparations for the marriage of his son at R. Hanina's.[^fn_66a_48] 'Does the Master', the latter said to him, 'intend writing the *kethubah* four days hence?' 'Yes', the other replied; but when the fourth day arrived he waited for another four days and thus caused a delay of seven days after the day in question.[^fn_66a_49] 'Why', the first asked, 'all this delay?'[^fn_66a_50] 'Does not the Master', the other replied, 'hold the opinion of Raba, Raba having ruled: If a woman had an offer of marriage and she accepted she must allow seven clean days to pass?' 'It is possible', the first suggested, that Raba spoke only of one of mature age who is likely to discharge menstrual blood,[^fn_66a_51] but did he speak of a minor who is unlikely to discharge menstrual blood?' 'Raba', the other replied, 'has explicitly stated: There is no difference between one of mature age and a minor. For what is the reason why one of mature age is subject to the restriction? Because her passions are excited;[^fn_66a_52] well, those of a minor also are excited.

Raba ruled: A woman [pg 66b]

must not wash her head either with natron or with ohal.[^fn_66b_1] 'With natron', because it plucks out the hair;[^fn_66b_2] and 'with ohal' because it causes the hairs to cling to one another.[^fn_66b_3]

Amemar also citing Raba ruled: A woman[^fn_66b_4] must wash her head in warm water only and she may do it even with such as was warmed by the sun[^fn_66b_5] but not with cold water. Why not with cold water? — Because cold water[^fn_66b_6] loosens[^fn_66b_7] the hair.[^fn_66b_8]

Raba further ruled: A man should always give instructions to his household that a woman[^fn_66b_9] should wash the folds of her body[^fn_66b_10] with water. An objection was raised: It is not necessary for the water[^fn_66b_11] to penetrate into the folds of the body[^fn_66b_12] or to its concealed parts![^fn_66b_13] — Granted that it is not necessary for the water to penetrate,[^fn_66b_14] it is necessary nevertheless that it be capable of penetration to every part;[^fn_66b_15] in agreement with a ruling of R. Zera. For R. Zera ruled: Wherever proper mingling[^fn_66b_16] is possible actual mingling is not essential,[^fn_66b_17] but where proper mingling is not possible[^fn_66b_18] the actual mingling is indispensable.[^fn_66b_19]

Rabin son of R. Adda citing R. Isaac stated: It once happened that a bondmaid of Rabbi performed immersion and when she ascended \[from the water\] a bone constituting an interposition was found between her teeth, and[^fn_66b_20] Rabbi required her to perform a second immersion.[^fn_66b_21]

Raba further ruled: If a woman performed immersion, and when she ascended \[from the water\] an object that caused an interposition was found upon her, she need not wash her head or perform immersion again if her immersion was performed immediately after the washing of her head;[^fn_66b_22] otherwise, she must wash her head and perform immersion again. There are others who say: If she performed her immersion on the same day on which she washed her head, she need not wash her head or perform immersion again, otherwise she must wash her head and perform immersion again. What is the practical difference between them?[^fn_66b_23] — The practical difference between them is the question whether immersion must follow immediately upon the washing of the head,[^fn_66b_24] and whether a woman may wash her head during the day and perform her immersion at night.

Raba ruled: A woman may not stand upon an earthenware when she is to perform ritual immersion. R. Kahana intended to say, 'What is the reason? Because a preventive measure has been enacted against the possibility of using[^fn_66b_25] bath-houses,[^fn_66b_26] but that it is quite proper to stand upon a block of wood'. Said R. Hanan of Nehardea to him, 'What is the reason[^fn_66b_27] there?[^fn_66b_28] Because she is frightened;[^fn_66b_29] on a chip of wood she is also frightened'.[^fn_66b_29]

R. Samuel b. R. Isaac ruled: A woman shall not perform immersion [pg 67a]

in a harbour;[^fn_67a_1] although there may be no \[mud\][^fn_67a_2] now[^fn_67a_3] it may well be assumed that it had fallen off with the drippings.[^fn_67a_4] Samuel's father made ritual baths for his daughters in the days of Nisan[^fn_67a_5] and mats[^fn_67a_6] in the days of Tishri.[^fn_67a_7]

R. Giddal citing Rab ruled: If a woman gave to her child some cooked food and then performed her ritual immersion and ascended from the water,[^fn_67a_8] her immersion has no validity,[^fn_67a_9] because, though there may be no food[^fn_67a_10] now,[^fn_67a_11] it may well be assumed that it had fallen off with the drippings.[^fn_67a_12]

Rami b. Abba[^fn_67a_13] ruled: Scars[^fn_67a_14] constitute no interposition[^fn_67a_15] during the first[^fn_67a_16] three days;[^fn_67a_17] henceforth they constitute an interposition.
