Mar Ukba ruled: Pus within the eye constitutes no interposition when it is moist, but when it is dry it constitutes one. When is it called 'dry'? — From the time it begins to turn yellow.

Samuel ruled: Stibium within the eye constitutes no interposition but on the outside of the eye it constitutes one. If a woman's eyes were twitching it constitutes no interposition even if it is on the outside of the eye.[^fn_67a_18]

R. Johanan ruled: If a woman[^fn_67a_19] opened her eyes too wide[^fn_67a_20] or shut them too closely,[^fn_67a_21] her immersion has no validity.

Resh Lakish ruled: A woman must perform immersion only when standing in her natural position;[^fn_67a_22] as we have learnt:[^fn_67a_23] A man[^fn_67a_24] is inspected[^fn_67a_25] in the same position as when he hoes[^fn_67a_26] or[^fn_67a_27] gathers olives;[^fn_67a_28] and a woman[^fn_67a_24] is inspected[^fn_67a_25] in the same position as when she weaves[^fn_67a_29] or[^fn_67a_27] suckles her child.[^fn_67a_28]

Rabbah b. R. Huna[^fn_67a_30] stated, 'One knotted hair constitutes an interposition,[^fn_67a_31] [pg 67b]

three hairs[^fn_67b_1] constitute no interposition;[^fn_67b_2] but I do not know the ruling in the case of two'. R. Johanan, however, stated, 'We have only this one principle: R. Isaac said, According to traditional law[^fn_67b_3] an interposition on its[^fn_67b_4] major part[^fn_67b_5] to which a man objects constitutes an interposition but one which he does not mind constitutes no interposition; but the Rabbis ruled that an interposition on its[^fn_67b_4] greater part shall constitute an interposition, even when the man does not mind it, as a preventive measure against the possibility of allowing an interposition on its major part to which the man does object; and they also ruled that an interposition on its minor part to which a man objects shall constitute an interposition as a preventive measure against the possibility of allowing an interposition on its major part to which a man objects.[^fn_67b_6] But why should no prohibition be enacted also against an interposition on its lesser part, to which one does not object, as a preventive measure against the possibility of allowing an interposition over the lesser part to which one does object?[^fn_67b_7] — This ruling itself[^fn_67b_8] is but a preventive measure, shall we go so far[^fn_67b_9] as to institute a preventive measure against the possibility of infringing a preventive measure?[^fn_67b_10]

Rab ruled: If a menstruant performs immersion at 'the proper time[^fn_67b_11] she may do it only at night[^fn_67b_12] but if she performs it after the proper time[^fn_67b_13] she may do it either in the day time or at night.[^fn_67b_14] R. Johanan ruled: Whether at the proper time or after the proper time a menstruant may perform immersion only at night, on account of the possibility of her daughter's following her lead.[^fn_67b_15] Rab, moreover, also withdrew his ruling; for R. Hiyya b. Ashi citing Rab laid down: Whether at the proper time or after the proper time[^fn_67b_13] a menstruant may perform immersion only at night on account of the possibility of her daughter's following her lead.[^fn_67b_15] R. Idi ordained at Narash that immersion shall be performed on the eighth day[^fn_67b_16] on account of lions.[^fn_67b_17] R. Aha b. Jacob issued a similar ordinance at Papunia on account of thieves.[^fn_67b_17] Rab Judah did the same at Pumbeditha on account of the cold. Rabbah[^fn_67b_18] acted similarly at Mahoza on account of the guards of the city gates.[^fn_67b_19] Said R. Papa[^fn_67b_20] to Raba,[^fn_67b_21] Consider: At the present time the Rabbis have put all menstruants on the same level as zabahs,[^fn_67b_22] why then should they not allow them[^fn_67b_23] to perform immersion in the daytime of the seventh day?[^fn_67b_24] — This cannot be allowed on account of the following ruling of R. Simeon. For it was taught: After that she shall be clean,[^fn_67b_25] 'after' means after all of them, implying that no uncleanness may intervene between them; but R. Simeon stated: After that she shall be clean[^fn_67b_24] implies that after the act[^fn_67b_26] she shall[^fn_67b_27] be clean, but the Sages have ruled that it was forbidden to do so in case she might thereby land in a doubtful situation.[^fn_67b_28]

R. Huna ruled: A woman[^fn_67b_29] may wash her head on a Sunday[^fn_67b_30] and perform immersion on the following Tuesday,[^fn_67b_31] since similarly she[^fn_67b_32] is allowed to wash her head[^fn_67b_33] on a Friday[^fn_67b_34] and undergo immersion on the following Saturday night.[^fn_67b_35] A woman may wash her head on a Sunday and undergo immersion on the following Wednesday, since similarly she[^fn_67b_36] is allowed to wash her head[^fn_67b_37] on a Friday[^fn_67b_34] and undergo immersion in the night following a festival that occurred on a Sunday. A woman may wash her head on a Sunday and undergo immersion on the following Thursday, since similarly she may wash her head on a Friday and undergo immersion in the night following the two festival days of the New Year that happened to fall immediately after a Saturday. R. Hisda, however, stated: In all these cases[^fn_67b_38] we rule as mentioned[^fn_67b_39] but we do not draw the inference of 'since similarly'; for where \[the avoidance of an interval\] is possible an interval must be avoided,[^fn_67b_40] and only where this is impossible[^fn_67b_41] may an interval be allowed.[^fn_67b_42] R. Yemar, however, stated: We may even draw the inferences of 'since similarly'[^fn_67b_43] except in the case where a woman is permitted to wash her head on a Sunday and undergo immersion on the following Thursday, for the parallel of the night following the two festival days of the New Year that happened to fall immediately after a Saturday does not hold, since it is possible for the woman to wash her head and undergo immersion in the same night.[^fn_67b_44] Meremar in his discourse laid down: The law is in agreement with R. Hisda[^fn_67b_45] but[^fn_67b_46] in accordance with the interpretation of R. Yemar.[^fn_67b_47]

The question was raised: May a woman wash her head at night[^fn_67b_48] and perform immersion the same night?[^fn_67b_49] — Mar Zutra forbids this, but R. Hinena of Sura permits it. Said R. Adda to R. Hinena of Sura:[^fn_67b_50] Did not the following incident[^fn_67b_51] actually occur[^fn_67b_52] to the wife of the exilarch Abba Mari? She having had some quarrel[^fn_67b_53] R. Nahman b. Isaac proceeded to pacify her, and when she said to him, 'What is the hurry now?[^fn_67b_54] [pg 68a]

There will be time enough to-morrow', he understood what she meant[^fn_68a_1] and retorted, 'Are you short of kettles? Are you short of buckets?[^fn_68a_2] Are you short of servants?'[^fn_68a_3]

Raba delivered the following discourse: A woman may wash her head on the Sabbath eve[^fn_68a_4] and perform immersion at the termination of the Sabbath.[^fn_68a_5] Said R. Papa to Raba: But did not Rabin send in his letter the message that 'a woman must not wash her head on the Sabbath eve and perform immersion at the termination of the Sabbath'? And, furthermore, is it not surprising to yourself that a woman should be allowed to[^fn_68a_6] wash her head in the day time and perform immersion at night seeing that it is required that immersion should follow immediately after the washing of the head, which is not the case here? Raba subsequently appointed an amora[^fn_68a_7] in connection with this matter and delivered the following discourse: The statement I made to you is an erroneous one,[^fn_68a_8] but in fact it was this that was reported in the name of R. Johanan, 'A woman may not wash her head on the Sabbath eve and perform immersion at the termination of the Sabbath'; and, furthermore, it would be surprising that a woman should be allowed to[^fn_68a_6] wash her head in the day time and perform immersion at night seeing that it is required that immersion should closely follow the washing of the head, which would not be the case here. But the law is that a woman may wash her head in the day time and perform immersion at night. And the law is that a woman may wash her head at night only.[^fn_68a_9] But does not a contradiction arise between the one law and the other? — There is no contradiction: The former refers to a case where washing in the day time is possible while the latter refers to one where this is impossible.[^fn_68a_10]

***MISHNAH***. IF A MENSTRUANT EXAMINED HERSELF ON THE SEVENTH DAY[^fn_68a_11] IN THE MORNING AND FOUND HERSELF TO BE CLEAN, AND AT TWILIGHT[^fn_68a_12] SHE DID NOT ASCERTAIN HER SEPARATION,[^fn_68a_13] AND AFTER SOME DAYS SHE EXAMINED HERSELF AND FOUND THAT SHE WAS UNCLEAN, BEHOLD SHE IS[^fn_68a_14] IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS.[^fn_68a_15] IF SHE EXAMINED HERSELF ON THE SEVENTH DAY[^fn_68a_16] IN THE MORNING AND FOUND THAT SHE WAS UNCLEAN, AND AT TWILIGHT[^fn_68a_17] SHE DID NOT ASCERTAIN HER SEPARATION,[^fn_68a_13] AND AFTER A TIME SHE EXAMINED HERSELF AND FOUND THAT SHE WAS CLEAN, BEHOLD SHE IS[^fn_68a_14] IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF UNCLEANNESS.[^fn_68a_18] SHE[^fn_68a_19] CONVEYS, HOWEVER, UNCLEANNESS FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS RETROSPECTIVELY OR DURING THE TIME BETWEEN THE LAST AND THE PREVIOUS EXAMINATION, BUT IF SHE HAD A SETTLED PERIOD, IT SUFFICES FOR HER TO BE DEEMED UNCLEAN FROM THE TIME OF HER DISCHARGE. R.[^fn_68a_20] JUDAH RULED: ANY WOMAN WHO DID NOT,[^fn_68a_21] FOLLOWING THE AFTERNOON, ASCERTAIN HER SEPARATION TO A STATE OF CLEANNESS IS REGARDED AS BEING IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF UNCLEANNESS.[^fn_68a_22] BUT THE SAGES RULED: EVEN IF SHE EXAMINED HERSELF ON THE SECOND DAY OF HER MENSTRUATION AND FOUND THAT SHE WAS CLEAN, AND AT TWILIGHT SHE DID NOT ASCERTAIN HER SEPARATION, AND AFTER A TIME SHE EXAMINED HERSELF AND FOUND THAT SHE WAS UNCLEAN, SHE IS REGARDED AS BEING IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS.[^fn_68a_23] {¶=10.2}

***GEMARA***. It was stated: Rab ruled: She[^fn_68a_24] is a certain zabah, but Levi ruled: She is a doubtful zabah. What do they refer to? If it be suggested: To the first clause \[it could be objected\]: Was it not stated, BEHOLD SHE IS IN A PRESUMPTIVE STATE OF CLEANNESS? If, on the other hand, they refer[^fn_68a_25] to the final clause,[^fn_68a_26] one can well see the logic of regarding the woman[^fn_68a_27] as a doubtful zabah,[^fn_68a_28] but why also[^fn_68a_29] a certain zabah seeing that she has examined herself and found that she was clean?[^fn_68a_30] The fact is that when the statements of Rab and Levi were made they were given as independent rulings:[^fn_68a_31] If a menstruant examined herself on the seventh day in the morning and found that she was unclean, and at twilight she did not ascertain her separation, and after some days she examined herself and found that she was unclean, Rab ruled: She is a certain zabah, but Levi ruled: She is a doubtful zabah. 'Rab ruled: she is a certain zabah', since she was previously found to be unclean and now also she was found to be unclean, she must be definitely unclean. 'But Levi ruled: She is a doubtful zabah', because it might be assumed that the discharge may have been discontinued in the intervening time. [pg 68b]

Levi also taught the same ruling in a Baraitha: After these days[^fn_68b_1] irrespective of whether she examined herself and found that she was clean or whether she examined herself and found that she was unclean, behold she is to be regarded as a doubtful zabah.

SHE CONVEYS, HOWEVER, UNCLEANNESS FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS RETROSPECTIVELY. Must it be conceded that this[^fn_68b_2] represents an objection against a view of Raba, since Raba stated: This[^fn_68b_3] tells that[^fn_68b_4] a woman during the days of her *zibah* does not[^fn_68b_5] cause twenty-four hours retrospective uncleanness? — But was not an objection against Raba raised once before?[^fn_68b_6] — It is this that we meant: Must it be conceded that an objection may be raised against Raba from this Mishnah also? — Raba can answer you: When it was stated, SHE CONVEYS, HOWEVER, UNCLEANNESS FOR TWENTY-FOUR HOURS RETROSPECTIVELY, the reference was to the beginning of this chapter, viz., to a girl who observed a discharge while she was still in her father's house.[^fn_68b_7] As it might have been presumed that, since clean days intervened, the discharge should be regarded as one at the beginning of her menstruation and she[^fn_68b_8] should in consequence convey no retrospective uncleanness for twenty-four hours, hence we were informed \[that she does\].

BUT IF SHE HAS A SETTLED PERIOD. Must it be conceded that this[^fn_68b_9] presents an objection against the view of R. Huna b. Hiyya cited in the name of Samuel, since R. Huna b. Hiyya citing Samuel stated: This[^fn_68b_10] tells that a woman cannot establish for herself a regular period[^fn_68b_11] during the days of her *zibah*? — R. Huna b. Hiyya can answer you: When we ruled that 'a woman cannot establish for herself a regular period during the days of her zibah' we meant that it is not necessary for her[^fn_68b_12] to have a change of period three times for the purpose of abolishing a settled period because we maintain that her blood is suspended; and, since her blood is suspended, IT SUFFICES FOR HER TO BE DEEMED UNCLEAN FROM THE TIME OF HER DISCHARGE.

R. JUDAH RULED. It was taught: They said to R. Judah, Had her hands been lying in her eyes[^fn_68b_13] throughout twilight you would have spoken well, but now, since it might be assumed that she experienced a discharge as soon as she removed her hands, what practical difference is there between the case where she ascertained her separation to a state of cleanness on the seventh day following the afternoon and that where she has ascertained her separation to a state of cleanness on the first day? 'On the first day'! Is there any authority who holds such a view?[^fn_68b_14] — Yes; and so it was taught: Rabbi stated, 'I once asked R. Jose and R. Simeon when they were underway: What is the law where a menstruant examined herself on the seventh day in the morning and found that she was clean, and at twilight she did not ascertain her separation,[^fn_68b_15] and after some days she examined herself and found that she was unclean? And they replied:[^fn_68b_16] Behold such a woman is in a presumptive state of cleanness. What, I asked, is the law where she examined herself on the sixth, fifth, fourth, third or second? And they replied: There is no difference. As regards an examination on the first day I did not ask, but it was a mistake on my part that I did not ask. For is she not on all these days in a state of presumptive uncleanness and yet as soon as the discharge ceased it is deemed to have completely ceased, so also in regard to the first day as soon as the discharge ceased it may be deemed to have ceased completely'.[^fn_68b_17] What view, however, did he[^fn_68b_18] hold at first?[^fn_68b_19] — \[That the woman is unclean\] since there is[^fn_68b_20] the presumption of an open source.

***MISHNAH***. IF A *ZAB* AND A ZABAH[^fn_68b_21] EXAMINED THEMSELVES ON THE FIRST DAY[^fn_68b_22] AND FOUND THEMSELVES CLEAN AND ON THE SEVENTH DAY[^fn_68b_22] ALSO AND FOUND THEMSELVES CLEAN, BUT DID NOT EXAMINE THEMSELVES DURING THE OTHER, INTERVENING, DAYS, R. ELIEZER RULED: BEHOLD THESE ARE IN A PRESUMPTIVE CONDITION OF CLEANNESS. R. JOSHUA RULED: THEY ARE ENTITLED \[TO RECKON AS CLEAN\] ONLY THE FIRST DAY AND THE SEVENTH DAY. R. AKIBA RULED: THEY ARE ENTITLED TO RECKON AS CLEAN THE SEVENTH DAY ALONE.[^fn_68b_23] {¶=10.3}

***GEMARA***. It was taught: Said R. Eliezer to R. Joshua, According to your view[^fn_68b_24] you would be counting with interruptions; but did not the Torah state, After that she shall be clean,[^fn_68b_25] 'after' meaning 'after all of them', implying that no uncleanness may intervene between them?[^fn_68b_26] — Said R. Joshua to him: But do you not agree that a *zab* who[^fn_68b_27] observed an emission of semen[^fn_68b_28] or a nazirite who[^fn_68b_29] walked under overshadowing branches or mural projections[^fn_68b_30] counts with interruptions though the Torah said,[^fn_68b_31] But the former days shall be void?[^fn_68b_32] And R. Eliezer?[^fn_68b_33] — All is well there[^fn_68b_34] since the All Merciful has said,[^fn_68b_35] So that he is unclean thereby,[^fn_68b_36] implying that it renders void one day only.[^fn_68b_37] And if the imposition of a restriction[^fn_68b_38] be suggested, on account of the possibility of mistaking one uncleanness for another,[^fn_68b_39] it could be retorted: A *zab* would not be mistaken for one who emitted semen. All is also well[^fn_68b_40] with a nazirite who walked under overshadowing branches or mural projections, since Pentateuchally it is necessary[^fn_68b_41] that the \[overshadowing\] tent shall be a proper one and it is only the Rabbis who enacted the ruling[^fn_68b_42] as a preventive measure, and no one would mistake a Rabbinic law for a Pentateuchal one; but here,[^fn_68b_43] if we were to take into consideration the possibility of a doubtful observation,[^fn_68b_44] one might mistake this case for one of a certain observation.[^fn_68b_45]

It was taught: R. Jose and R. Simeon stated, The view of R. Eliezer is more feasible than that of R. Joshua, and the view of R. Akiba is more acceptable than those of all of them, but the *halachah* is in agreement with R. Eliezer.

The question was raised: If a *zab* or a zabah examined themselves on the first day[^fn_68b_46] and on the eighth day[^fn_68b_47] and found that they were clean while on the other days they did not examine themselves, [pg 69a]

what is the law according to R. Eliezer.[^fn_69a_1] Is it necessary[^fn_69a_2] that an examination should take place both at the beginning and at the end of the prescribed days[^fn_69a_3] \[hence this case is excluded\][^fn_69a_4] since there was one at the beginning only[^fn_69a_5] but not at the end,[^fn_69a_6] or is it possible that an examination at the beginning[^fn_69a_5] suffices although there was none at the end?[^fn_69a_6] — Rab replied: The law is the same in either case,[^fn_69a_7] an examination at the beginning sufficing although there was none at the end. R. Hanina, however, replied: It is necessary[^fn_69a_2] that there be an examination both at the beginning and at the end[^fn_69a_8] \[hence this case is excluded\] since there was one at the beginning only but not at the end.

An objection was raised: But both hold the same opinion,[^fn_69a_9] where a *zab* and a zabah examined themselves on the first day and on the eighth day and found themselves clean, that they may count the eighth day only as clean.[^fn_69a_10] Now who are referred to in the expression 'both hold the same opinion'? Is it not R. Eliezer and R. Joshua?[^fn_69a_11] — No; R. Joshua and R. Akiba.[^fn_69a_12]

R. Shesheth citing R. Jeremiah b. Abba who had it from Rab stated: If a menstruant has ascertained her separation to a state of cleanness on her third day,[^fn_69a_13] she may count it in the number of the seven clean days.[^fn_69a_14] 'A menstruant'! What need has she for counting?[^fn_69a_15] — Rather read: If a zabah has ascertained her separation to a state of cleanness on her third day,[^fn_69a_13] she may count it in the number of the seven clean days.[^fn_69a_14] Said R. Shesheth to R. Jeremiah b. Abba: Did then Rab pronounce his ruling in agreement with the view of the Samaritans who ruled that the day on which a woman ceases to have her discharge may be counted by her in the number of the prescribed seven days?[^fn_69a_16] — When Rab spoke he meant: Exclusive of the third day.[^fn_69a_17] But if 'exclusive of the third day' is not the ruling obvious? — The ruling was necessary only in a case, for instance, where the woman[^fn_69a_18] did not examine herself until the seventh day,[^fn_69a_19] so that[^fn_69a_20] we were informed there[^fn_69a_21] that an examination at the beginning[^fn_69a_22] suffices although there was none at the end,[^fn_69a_23] while here[^fn_69a_24] we were informed that an examination at the end[^fn_69a_23] suffices[^fn_69a_25] even though there was none at the beginning.[^fn_69a_22] As it might have been presumed that only where there was an examination at the beginning,[^fn_69a_22] though there was none at the end,[^fn_69a_23] do we assume \[the days to be clean\], because we regard them as remaining in their presumptive state,[^fn_69a_26] but not where the examination was held at their conclusion[^fn_69a_23] and[^fn_69a_27] not at their beginning,[^fn_69a_22] hence we were informed \[that in either case the days are regarded as clean\]. But can this[^fn_69a_28] be correct seeing that[^fn_69a_29] when Rabin came[^fn_69a_30] he stated, 'R. Jose b. Hanina raised an objection \[from a Baraitha dealing with\] a forgetful[^fn_69a_31] woman but I do not know what his objection was', and[^fn_69a_32] we have an established rule that during the first week of her appearance before us we require her to undergo immersion in the nights[^fn_69a_33] but we do not require her to undergo immersion in the day time. Now if it could be entertained that it is not necessary that the days[^fn_69a_34] be counted in our presence, she[^fn_69a_35] should have been made to undergo immersion in the day time also, since it is possible that she gave birth during a *zibah* period and had completed the counting on that day. Must it not consequently be inferred from the ruling that it is necessary for the counting to take place in our presence?[^fn_69a_36] — But have we not explained this ruling to be in agreement with the view of R. Akiba who ruled that it was necessary for the counting to take place in our presence?[^fn_69a_37] — And whence do you infer that according to the Rabbis it is not necessary for the counting to take place in our presence? — From what was taught:[^fn_69a_38] 'If a forgetful[^fn_69a_39] woman stated, "I observed some uncleanness on a certain day",[^fn_69a_40] she[^fn_69a_41] is expected to undergo nine immersions, seven[^fn_69a_42] in respect of menstruation[^fn_69a_43] and two[^fn_69a_44] in respect of *zibah*.[^fn_69a_45] If she states, "I observed some uncleanness at twilight", she is to undergo eleven immersions'. 'Eleven'! For what purpose?[^fn_69a_46] — R. Jeremiah of Difti replied: This is a case, for instance, where the woman[^fn_69a_47] actually appeared before us at twilight,[^fn_69a_48] so that provision has to be made for[^fn_69a_49] eight immersions in respect of menstruation[^fn_69a_50] and for three in respect of *zibah*.[^fn_69a_51] 'If she states, "I observed no discharge whatsoever", she is to undergo fifteen immersions'.[^fn_69a_52] Raba observed: 'This kind of law that is a negation of all reason[^fn_69a_53] is in vogue at Galhi where there is a law that one who owns a bull must feed the town's cattle one day while one who owns no bull must feed them on two days. Once they had occasion to deal with[^fn_69a_54] an orphan the son of a widow. Having been entrusted with the bulls \[to feed\] he proceeded to kill them, saying to the people, "He who owned a bull shall receive one hide and he who owned no bull shall receive two hides". "What", they said to him, "is this that you say?" "The conclusion of this process", he answered them, "follows the same principle as the beginning of the process. Was it not the case with the beginning of this process that one who owned nothing was better off? Well, at the conclusion of the process too, one who owned nothing is better off". Here also: If where a woman states, "I observed a discharge", it suffices for her to undergo either nine immersions or eleven immersions,[^fn_69a_55] should it be necessary for her, where she states, "I observed no discharge whatsoever", to undergo fifteen immersions?' — Rather read thus: If she states, 'I observed a discharge and I do not know how long it continued[^fn_69a_56] and whether I observed it during a menstruation period or a *zibah* one', she is to undergo fifteen immersions. For if she appeared before us in the day-time we allow her seven days in respect of menstruation[^fn_69a_55] [pg 69b]

and eight in respect of *zibah*;[^fn_69b_1] and if she appeared before us at night we allow her eight in respect of menstruation[^fn_69b_2] and seven in respect of *zibah*.[^fn_69b_3] But does not menstruation require eight days?[^fn_69b_4] — Rather say: In either case[^fn_69b_5] seven in respect of menstruation and eight in respect of *zibah*. But if she appeared at night, does she not require[^fn_69b_4] eight in respect of menstruation?[^fn_69b_6] — In respect of *zibah* where the number of immersions is fixed, since it does not vary whether she appeared before us in the day time or at night, \[the eighth immersion\] was counted, but in respect of menstruation where the number is not fixed, for only where she appeared before us at night does she require eight immersions while if she appeared before us in the day time she does not require eight \[the eighth immersion\] was not counted. Now, if it could be entertained that it is necessary for all the counting to take place in our presence, what need is there[^fn_69b_7] for all these immersions?[^fn_69b_8] Should she not rather count the seven days and then undergo immersion?[^fn_69b_9] Consequently it may be inferred from here that[^fn_69b_10] it is the Rabbis[^fn_69b_11] who hold that it is not necessary for the counting to take place in our presence.[^fn_69b_12] Said R. Aha son of R. Joseph to R. Ashi, Have we not had recourse to explanations of this ruling?[^fn_69b_13] Explain it then in the following manner and read thus: If a woman states, 'I counted[^fn_69b_14] and know not how many days I counted and whether I counted them during the period of menstruation or during that of zibah', she is to undergo fifteen immersions.[^fn_69b_15] But if she stated, 'I counted and know not how many days I counted', it is at any rate impossible that she should not have counted one day, at least, is she then not short of one immersion?[^fn_69b_16] Rather read: If she states, 'I know not whether I did or did not count'.[^fn_69b_17]

***MISHNAH***. IF A *ZAB*, A ZABAH, A MENSTRUANT, A WOMAN AFTER CHILDBIRTH OR A LEPER HAVE DIED \[THEIR CORPSES\] CONVEY UNCLEANNESS BY CARRIAGE[^fn_69b_18] UNTIL THE FLESH HAS DECAYED. IF AN IDOLATER HAS DIED HE CONVEYS NO UNCLEANNESS.[^fn_69b_19] BETH SHAMMAI RULED: ALL WOMEN DIE AS MENSTRUANTS;[^fn_69b_18] BUT BETH HILLEL RULED: A WOMAN[^fn_69b_20] CANNOT BE REGARDED AS A MENSTRUANT UNLESS SHE DIED WHILE SHE WAS IN MENSTRUATION. {¶=10.4}

***GEMARA***. What is the meaning of BY CARRIAGE? If it be suggested: By actual carriage, \[the objection would arise:\] Does not in fact every corpse convey uncleanness by carriage?[^fn_69b_21] — Rather say that BY CARRIAGE means[^fn_69b_22] through a heavy[^fn_69b_23] stone,[^fn_69b_24] for[^fn_69b_25] it is written, And a stone was brought, and laid[^fn_69b_26] upon the mouth of the den.[^fn_69b_27] What is the reason?[^fn_69b_28] — Rab replied: This[^fn_69b_29] is a preventive measure against the case where they[^fn_69b_30] swoon.[^fn_69b_31] One taught: In the name of R. Eliezer it was stated, This possibility must be taken into consideration until his stomach bursts.

IF AN IDOLATER HAS DIED etc. It was taught: Rabbi stated, On what ground did they rule that if an idolater has died he conveys no uncleanness by carriage? Because his uncleanness when alive[^fn_69b_32] is not Pentateuchal, but Rabbinical.

Our Rabbis taught: Twelve questions did the Alexandrians address to R. Joshua b. Hananiah.[^fn_69b_33] Three were of a scientific nature,[^fn_69b_34] three were matters of aggada, three were mere nonsense and three were matters of conduct.[^fn_69b_35]

'Three were of a scientific nature': If a *zab*, a zabah, a menstruant, a woman after childbirth or a leper have died, how long do their corpses convey uncleanness by carriage? He replied: Until the flesh has decayed. Is the daughter of a woman that was divorced and remarried by her first husband[^fn_69b_36] allowed to marry a priest? Do we say that this might be inferred a minori ad majus: If the son of a widow who was married to a High priest, who is not forbidden to all,[^fn_69b_37] is nevertheless tainted,[^fn_69b_38] how much more so the offspring of her[^fn_69b_39] who is forbidden to all;[^fn_69b_40] or is it possible to refute the argument, thus: The case of a widow married to a High Priest is different because she herself is profaned?[^fn_69b_41] He replied: [pg 70a]

She is an abomination,[^fn_70a_1] but her children are no abomination. If the sacrifices of two lepers were mixed up and after the sacrifice of one of them was offered[^fn_70a_2] one of them died, what is to be done about the other?[^fn_70a_3] He replied: He assigns[^fn_70a_4] his possessions to others so that he becomes a poor man and then[^fn_70a_5] brings a bird sin-offering which may be brought[^fn_70a_6] even in a case of doubt. But is there not also a guilt-offering?[^fn_70a_7] — Samuel replied: This[^fn_70a_8] applies only where his guilt-offering had been duly offered.[^fn_70a_9] R. Shesheth observed: A great man like Samuel should say such a thing! In agreement with whose view \[could his answer[^fn_70a_10] have been given)? If in agreement with that of R. Judah[^fn_70a_11] \[the difficulty arises:\] Did he not state that[^fn_70a_12] the guilt-offering[^fn_70a_13] determines a person's status,[^fn_70a_14] so that since the guilt-offering determined for him[^fn_70a_15] a status of wealth he could no longer bring a sin-offering in the state of poverty? For we have learnt, 'If a leper brought the sacrifice of a poor man[^fn_70a_16] and then[^fn_70a_17] became rich or if he brought that of a rich man[^fn_70a_18] and became poor, all depends[^fn_70a_19] on[^fn_70a_20] the sin-offering;[^fn_70a_21] so R. Simeon. R.[^fn_70a_22] Judah ruled: All depends on the guilt-offering.[^fn_70a_23] R. Eliezer b. Jacob ruled: All depends on the birds'.[^fn_70a_24] And if \[Samuel has given his answer\] in agreement with the view of R. Simeon who ruled that the sin-offering[^fn_70a_25] determines the man's status,[^fn_70a_26] why should he not bring another sacrifice[^fn_70a_27] even where the guilt-offering had not been offered,[^fn_70a_28] for, surely, we have heard R. Simeon say, 'Let him bring one and make his stipulation'; for it was taught: R. Simeon ruled,[^fn_70a_29] On the morrow[^fn_70a_30] he brings his guilt-offering and its *log*[^fn_70a_31] with it, places it at the Nikanor gate[^fn_70a_32] and pronounces over it the following stipulation: If he is a leper, behold his guilt-offering and its *log*[^fn_70a_31] with it, and if he is not, let this guilt-offering be a freewill peace-offering. Now this guilt-offering[^fn_70a_33] is [pg 70b]

to be slain[^fn_70b_1] in the north[^fn_70b_2] and is subject to the requirements of application[^fn_70b_1] in the thumbs,[^fn_70b_3] leaning,[^fn_70b_4] drink-offerings, waving[^fn_70b_5] and the presentation of the breast and shoulder to the priest.[^fn_70b_5] It may also be eaten by the priestly males on the same day and the following night;[^fn_70b_1] but the Sages did not agree with R. Simeon because[^fn_70b_6] one might[^fn_70b_7] cause holy things[^fn_70b_8] to be brought into the place of disqualified sacrifices.[^fn_70b_9] — Samuel may hold the same view as R. Simeon in one respect[^fn_70b_10] while differing from him in another.[^fn_70b_11]

'Three were matters of aggada'; One verse says, For I have no pleasure in the death of him that dieth,[^fn_70b_12] but another verse says, Because the Lord would slay them?[^fn_70b_13] — The former refers to those who are penitents while the latter refers to those who are not penitent. One verse says, who regardeth not persons,[^fn_70b_14] nor taketh reward,[^fn_70b_15] but another verse says, The Lord lift up his countenance upon thee?[^fn_70b_16] — The former refers to the time before sentence is passed while the latter refers to the time after the sentence has been passed. One verse says, For the Lord hath chosen Zion,[^fn_70b_17] but another verse says, For this city[^fn_70b_18] hath been to me a provocation of Mine anger and of My fury from the day that they built it even unto this day?[^fn_70b_19] The former applied to the time before Solomon married the daughter of Pharaoh while the latter applied to the time after Solomon married the daughter of Pharaoh.

'Three were mere nonsense': Does the wife of Lot[^fn_70b_20] convey uncleanness? He replied: A corpse conveys uncleanness but no pillar of salt conveys uncleanness. Does the son of the Shunamite[^fn_70b_21] convey uncleanness?[^fn_70b_22] He replied: A corpse conveys uncleanness but no live person conveys uncleanness. Will the dead in the hereafter[^fn_70b_23] require to be sprinkled upon[^fn_70b_24] on the third and the seventh[^fn_70b_25] or will they not require it? He replied: When they will be resurrected we shall go into the matter.[^fn_70b_26] Others say: When our Master Moses will come with them.

'Three were concerned with matters of conduct': What must a man do that he may become wise? He replied: Let him engage much in study[^fn_70b_27] and a little in business. Did not many, they said, do so and it was of no avail to them? — Rather, let them pray for mercy from Him to whom is the wisdom, for it is said, For the Lord giveth wisdom, out of His mouth cometh knowledge and discernment.[^fn_70b_28] R. Hiyya taught: This[^fn_70b_29] may be compared to the action of a mortal king who prepared for his servants a banquet but to his friends he sent from that which he had before himself. What then[^fn_70b_30] does he[^fn_70b_31] teach us?[^fn_70b_32] That one without the other[^fn_70b_33] does not suffice. What must a man do that he may become rich? He replied: Let him engage much in business[^fn_70b_34] and deal honestly. Did not many, they said to him, do so but it was of no avail to them? — Rather, let him pray for mercy from Him to whom are the riches, for it is said, Mine is the silver, and Mine the gold.[^fn_70b_35] What then[^fn_70b_36] does he[^fn_70b_37] teach us?[^fn_70b_38] — That one without the other[^fn_70b_39] does not suffice. What must a man do that he may have male children? He replied: He shall marry a wife that is worthy of him [pg 71a]

and conduct himself in modesty[^fn_71a_1] at the time of marital intercourse. Did not many, they said to him, act in this manner but it did not avail them? — Rather, let him pray for mercy from Him to whom are the children, for it is said, Lo, children are a heritage of the Lord; the fruit of the womb is a reward.[^fn_71a_2] What then[^fn_71a_3] does he teach us? That one without the other does not suffice. What is exactly meant by 'the fruit of the womb is a reward'? — R. Hama son of R. Hanina replied: As a reward for containing oneself during intercourse in the womb, in order that one's wife may emit the semen first, the Holy One, blessed be He, gives one the reward of the fruit of the womb.

BETH SHAMMAI RULED etc. What is Beth Shammai's reason? If it be suggested: Because it is written, And the queen was exceedingly pained,[^fn_71a_4] and Rab explained, 'This teaches that she had experienced a menstrual discharge', so that here also,[^fn_71a_5] owing to the fright of the angel of death, she experiences a discharge \[it could be retorted\]: Have we not in fact learnt that fear causes blood to disappear?[^fn_71a_6] — This is no difficulty since fear[^fn_71a_6] detains it while sudden fright[^fn_71a_7] loosens it. But \[then what of\] that which was taught,[^fn_71a_8] 'Beth Shammai stated: All men die as zabs and Beth Hillel stated: No dying man is deemed to be a *zab* unless he died when he was actually one', why[^fn_71a_9] should not one apply here[^fn_71a_10] the text, Out of his flesh[^fn_71a_11] but not on account of a mishap?[^fn_71a_12] — Beth Shammai's reason is rather as it was taught: Formerly they were wont to subject to ritual immersion all utensils that had been used by dying menstruants,[^fn_71a_13] but as living menstruants felt ashamed in consequence[^fn_71a_14] it was enacted that utensils used by all dying women should be subject to immersion,[^fn_71a_15] out of a deference to the living menstruants. Formerly they were wont to subject to ritual immersion utensils used by dying zabs,[^fn_71a_16] but as living zabs felt ashamed in consequence it was enacted that utensils used by all dying men[^fn_71a_17] should be subject to ritual immersion, out of deference to the living zabs.[^fn_71a_18]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN DIED AND A QUARTER OF A *LOG* OF BLOOD ISSUED FROM HER, IT[^fn_71a_19] CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS AS A BLOODSTAIN[^fn_71a_20] AND IT[^fn_71a_21] ALSO CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS BY OVERSHADOWING.[^fn_71a_22] R. JUDAH RULED: IT DOES NOT CONVEY UNCLEANNESS AS A STAIN, SINCE IT WAS DETACHED AFTER SHE HAD DIED.[^fn_71a_23] R. JUDAH, HOWEVER, AGREES THAT WHERE A WOMAN SITTING ON THE TRAVAILING STOOL DIED AND A QUARTER OF A *LOG* OF BLOOD ISSUED FROM HER, IT[^fn_71a_24] CONVEYS UNCLEANNESS AS A BLOODSTAIN.[^fn_71a_20] R. JOSE RULED: HENCE[^fn_71a_24] IT CONVEYS NO UNCLEANNESS BY OVERSHADOWING.[^fn_71a_25] {¶=10.5}

***GEMARA***. Does it then follow[^fn_71a_26] that the first Tanna[^fn_71a_27] holds that even though blood was detached after she died[^fn_71a_28] it conveys uncleanness as a bloodstain?[^fn_71a_29] — Ze'iri[^fn_71a_30] replied: The difference between them[^fn_71a_31] is[^fn_71a_32] the question whether the interior of the uterus is unclean.[^fn_71a_33]

R. JUDAH, HOWEVER, AGREES. Does it then follow that the first Tanna[^fn_71a_34] holds that it conveys uncleanness by overshadowing also?[^fn_71a_35] — Rab Judah replied: The difference between them[^fn_71a_36] is[^fn_71a_37] the question of mingled blood;[^fn_71a_38] for it was taught: What is meant by 'mingled blood'?[^fn_71a_39] R. Eleazar son of R. Judah explained: If blood issued from a slain man both while he was still alive and when he was dead and it is doubtful whether \[a full quarter of a *log*\] issued while he was still alive or when he was already dead or whether it partly issued while he was alive and partly while he was dead, such is mingled blood.[^fn_71a_39] But the Sages[^fn_71a_40] ruled: In a private domain such a case of doubt is unclean while in a public domain such a case of doubt is clean. What then is meant by 'mingled blood'?[^fn_71a_39] If a quarter of a *log* of blood issued from a slain man both while he was still alive and when he was dead and the flow had not yet ceased[^fn_71a_41] and[^fn_71a_42] it is doubtful whether the greater part[^fn_71a_43] issued while he was alive and the lesser part when he was dead or whether the lesser part issued while he was alive and the greater part when he was dead, such is mingled blood.[^fn_71a_44] R. Judah ruled: The blood of a slain man, from whom a quarter of a *log* of blood issued while he was lying in a bed with his blood dripping into a hole, is unclean, because the drop of death is mingled with it, but the Sages hold it to be clean[^fn_71a_45] because[^fn_71a_46] [pg 71b]

each single drop[^fn_71b_1] is detached from the other.[^fn_71b_2] But did not the Rabbis speak well to R. Judah?[^fn_71b_3] — R. Judah follows his own principle, for he laid down that no blood can neutralize other blood.[^fn_71b_4] R. Simeon ruled: If the blood of a man crucified upon the beam was flowing slowly[^fn_71b_5] to the ground, and a quarter of a *log* of blood was found under him, it is unclean.[^fn_71b_6] R. Judah declared it clean, since it might be held[^fn_71b_7] that the drop of death remained on the beam. But why should not R. Judah say to himself[^fn_71b_8] 'Since it might be held[^fn_71b_7] that the drop of death remained on the bed'? — \[The case of blood\] in a bed is different[^fn_71b_9] since it percolates.[^fn_71b_10]

***MISHNAH***. FORMERLY IT WAS RULED: A WOMAN WHO ABIDES IN CLEAN BLOOD[^fn_71b_11] MAY POUR OUT[^fn_71b_12] WATER[^fn_71b_13] FOR \[WASHING OF\] THE PASCHAL LAMB.[^fn_71b_14] SUBSEQUENTLY THEY CHANGED THEIR VIEW: IN RESPECT OF CONSECRATED FOOD SHE IS LIKE ONE WHO CAME IN CONTACT WITH A PERSON THAT WAS SUBJECT TO CORPSE UNCLEANNESS.[^fn_71b_15] THIS ACCORDING TO THE VIEW OF BETH HILLEL. BETH SHAMMAI RULED: EVEN AS ONE WHO IS SUBJECT TO CORPSE UNCLEANNESS.[^fn_71b_16] {¶=10.6}

***GEMARA***. 'SHE MAY POUR OUT' only, but may not touch it.[^fn_71b_17] It is thus evident[^fn_71b_18] that unconsecrated foodstuffs prepared in conditions of holiness[^fn_71b_19] are treated as holy. But then read the final clause: SUBSEQUENTLY THEY CHANGED THEIR VIEW: IN RESPECT OF CONSECRATED FOOD SHE IS LIKE ONE WHO CAME IN CONTACT WITH A PERSON THAT WAS SUBJECT TO CORPSE UNCLEANNESS. Thus only[^fn_71b_20] IN RESPECT OF CONSECRATED FOOD but not in respect of unconsecrated food.[^fn_71b_21] It is thus evident, is it not, that unconsecrated foodstuffs prepared in conditions of holiness[^fn_71b_19] are not treated as holy? — Who is the author of our Mishnah?[^fn_71b_22] It is Abba Saul; for it was taught: Abba Saul ruled, A tebul yom is unclean in the first grade in respect of consecrated food to cause two further grades of uncleanness[^fn_71b_23] and one grade of disqualification.[^fn_71b_24]

***MISHNAH***. BUT THEY[^fn_71b_25] AGREE THAT SHE[^fn_71b_26] MAY EAT[^fn_71b_27] SECOND TITHE; SHE MAY SET ASIDE HER[^fn_71b_28] DOUGH-OFFERING,[^fn_71b_29] BRING IT NEAR[^fn_71b_30] TO THE DOUGH[^fn_71b_31] AND DESIGNATE IT AS SUCH;[^fn_71b_32] AND THAT IF ANY OF HER SPITTLE OR OF THE BLOOD OF HER PURIFICATION[^fn_71b_33] FELL ON A LOAF OF *TERUMAH* THE LATTER REMAINS CLEAN. BETH SHAMMAI RULED: SHE REQUIRES IMMERSION AT THE END \[OF HER DAYS OF PURIFICATION\],[^fn_71b_34] AND BETH HILLEL RULED: SHE REQUIRES NO IMMERSION AT THE END. {¶=10.7}

***GEMARA***. Because[^fn_71b_35] a Master ruled: If a person performed immersion and came up \[from his bathing\] he may[^fn_71b_36] eat of second tithe.

SHE MAY SET ASIDE HER DOUGH-OFFERING. For unconsecrated dough that is *tebel*[^fn_71b_37] in respect of the dough-offering[^fn_71b_38] is not treated like the dough-offering.[^fn_71b_39]

BRING IT NEAR. Because a Master stated: It is a religious duty to set aside the offering from dough that is in close proximity to that for which it is set aside.

AND DESIGNATE IT AS SUCH. Since it might have been presumed that this should be forbidden as a preventive measure against the possibility of her touching the dough[^fn_71b_40] from the outside,[^fn_71b_41] we were informed \[that this is permitted\].

AND IF ANY OF HER SPITTLE … FELL. For we have learnt: The liquid \[issues\] of a tebul yom[^fn_71b_42] are like the liquids that he touches, neither of them conveying uncleanness. The exception is the liquid issue of a *zab*[^fn_71b_43] which is a father of uncleanness.

BETH SHAMMAI. What is the point at issue between them?[^fn_71b_44] — R. Kattina replied: The point at issue between them is the necessity for immersion[^fn_71b_45] at the end of a long day.[^fn_71b_46]

***MISHNAH***. IF A WOMAN OBSERVED A DISCHARGE ON THE ELEVENTH DAY[^fn_71b_47] AND PERFORMED IMMERSION IN THE EVENING AND THEN HAD MARITAL INTERCOURSE, BETH SHAMMAI RULED: THEY[^fn_71b_48] CONVEY UNCLEANNESS[^fn_71b_49] TO COUCH AND SEAT[^fn_71b_50] AND THEY ARE LIABLE TO A SACRIFICE,[^fn_71b_51] [pg 72a] {¶=10.8}

BUT BETH HILLEL[^fn_72a_1] RULED: THEY ARE EXEMPT FROM THE SACRIFICE.[^fn_72a_2] IF SHE PERFORMED IMMERSION ON THE NEXT DAY[^fn_72a_3] AND THEN HAD MARITAL INTERCOURSE AND AFTER THAT OBSERVED A DISCHARGE, BETH SHAMMAI RULED: THEY[^fn_72a_4] CONVEY UNCLEANNESS[^fn_72a_5] TO COUCH AND SEAT[^fn_72a_6] AND ARE EXEMPT FROM THE SACRIFICE,[^fn_72a_7] BUT BETH HILLEL RULED: SUCH A PERSON[^fn_72a_8] IS A GLUTTON,[^fn_72a_9] THEY[^fn_72a_10] AGREE, HOWEVER, THAT, WHERE A WOMAN OBSERVED A DISCHARGE DURING THE ELEVEN DAYS[^fn_72a_11] AND PERFORMED IMMERSION IN THE EVENING AND THEN HAD INTERCOURSE, BOTH[^fn_72a_12] CONVEY UNCLEANNESS TO COUCH AND SEAT[^fn_72a_13] AND ARE LIABLE TO A SACRIFICE.[^fn_72a_14] IF SHE PERFORMED IMMERSION ON THE NEXT DAY[^fn_72a_15] AND THEN HAD INTERCOURSE, SUCH AN ACT IS IMPROPER[^fn_72a_16] CONDUCT,[^fn_72a_17] BUT THE UNCLEANNESS OF THEIR TOUCH AND THEIR LIABILITY TO A SACRIFICE ON ACCOUNT OF THEIR INTERCOURSE ARE IN SUSPENSE.[^fn_72a_18]

***GEMARA***. Our Rabbis taught: And both[^fn_72a_19] agree[^fn_72a_20] that if a woman performs immersion at night after a *zibah*[^fn_72a_21] the immersion is invalid, for both agree that if a woman who observed a discharge during the eleven days[^fn_72a_21] and performed immersion in the evening and then had intercourse she conveys uncleanness to couch and seat and both are liable to a sacrifice. They[^fn_72a_19] only differ where a discharge occurred on the eleventh day in which case Beth Shammai ruled: They[^fn_72a_22] convey uncleanness to couch and seat and are liable to a sacrifice, and Beth Hillel exempt them from the sacrifice. Said Beth Shammai to Beth Hillel: Why should in this respect the eleventh day differ from one of the intermediate of the eleven days; seeing that the former is like the latter in regard to uncleanness, why should it not also be like it in regard to the sacrifice? Beth Hillel answered Beth Shammai: No; if you ruled that a sacrifice is due after a discharge in the intermediate of the eleven days because the following day[^fn_72a_23] combines with it in regard to *zibah*, would you also maintain the same ruling in regard to the eleventh day which[^fn_72a_24] is not followed by one that we could combine with it in regard to *zibah*? Said Beth Shammai to them: You must be consistent;[^fn_72a_25] if the one is like the other in regard to uncleanness it should also be like it in regard to the sacrifice, and if it is not like it in regard to the sacrifice it should not be like it in regard to uncleanness either. Said Beth Hillel to them: If we impose upon a man[^fn_72a_26] uncleanness in order to restrict the law[^fn_72a_27] we cannot on that ground impose upon him the obligation of a sacrifice which might[^fn_72a_28] lead to a relaxation of the law.[^fn_72a_29] And, furthermore, you stand refuted[^fn_72a_30] Out of your own rulings. For, since you rule that if she performed immersion on the next day and having had intercourse she observed a discharge, uncleanness is conveyed to couch and seat and she is exempt from a sacrifice, you also must be consistent.[^fn_72a_31] If the one is like the other in regard to uncleanness it should also be like it in regard to the sacrifice and if it is not like it in regard to the sacrifice it should not be like it in regard to uncleanness either. The fact, however, is that they are like one another only where the law is thereby restricted but not where it would thereby be relaxed; well, here also, they are like one another where the law is thereby restricted but not where it is thereby relaxed.

R. Huna stated: Couches and seats[^fn_72a_32] which she occupies on the second day[^fn_72a_33] are held to be unclean[^fn_72a_34] by Beth Shammai even though she performed immersion[^fn_72a_35] and even though she observed no discharge.[^fn_72a_35] What is the reason? — Because if she had observed a discharge she would have been unclean,[^fn_72a_36] she is therefore now[^fn_72a_37] also unclean.[^fn_72a_34] Said R. Joseph: What new law does he[^fn_72a_38] teach us,[^fn_72a_39] seeing that we have learnt, IF SHE PERFORMED IMMERSION ON THE NEXT DAY[^fn_72a_40] AND THEN HAD MARITAL INTERCOURSE AND AFTER THAT OBSERVED A DISCHARGE, BETH SHAMMAI RULED: THEY[^fn_72a_41] CONVEY UNCLEANNESS TO COUCH AND SEAT[^fn_72a_42] AND ARE[^fn_72a_41] EXEMPT FROM THE SACRIFICE?[^fn_72a_43] R. Kahana objected:[^fn_72a_44] Where she observed a discharge[^fn_72a_45] the case is different.[^fn_72a_46] Said R. Joseph: But what matters it that she observed a discharge[^fn_72a_47] seeing that it is one of menstruation?[^fn_72a_48] — Abaye answered R. Joseph: R. Kahana[^fn_72a_49] had this difficulty: Where the woman did observe a discharge one can well see the reason why uncleanness has been imposed since[^fn_72a_50] an observation of menstruation had to be declared unclean as a preventive measure against the possibility of an observation of a discharge of *zibah*, but where one observed no discharge[^fn_72a_51] what possibility was there to be provided against? And, furthermore, we have learnt:[^fn_72a_52] If a man observed one discharge of *zibah*, Beth Shammai ruled: He is like a woman who waits a day for a day[^fn_72a_53] and Beth Hillel ruled: Like a man who emitted semen,[^fn_72a_54] [pg 72b]

and it was taught:[^fn_72b_1] If a man[^fn_72b_2] caused the shaking of the \[first\] observed discharge, Beth Shammai ruled: The man must be held in suspense,[^fn_72b_3] and Beth Hillel declared him clean.[^fn_72b_4] As to couches and seats occupied between a first and a second discharge, Beth Shammai hold them in suspense and Beth Hillel declare them clean. Now in the first clause it was stated, 'If a man observed one discharge of *zibah*, Beth Shammai ruled: He is like a woman who waits a day for a day', from which it is evident, is it not, that in the case of a woman who waits a day for a day the uncleanness is held in suspense?[^fn_72b_5] — Do not read, 'A woman who waits a day for a day' but read: Like a man who had intercourse with one who waits a day for a day.[^fn_72b_6] But why is it that he[^fn_72b_7] does not convey uncleanness to couch and seat,[^fn_72b_8] while she does convey uncleanness to them?[^fn_72b_9] — About him, since he does not usually bleed, the Rabbis enacted no preventive measure,[^fn_72b_10] but in her case, since she does usually bleed, the Rabbis enacted a preventive measure. But[^fn_72b_11] why is it that she conveys uncleanness to couch and seat and does not convey uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her? — To couch and seat which are in common use she conveys uncleanness but to the man who had intercourse, which in such circumstances is an unusual occurrence, no uncleanness is conveyed.

We learnt, IF SHE PERFORMED IMMERSION ON THE NEXT DAY AND THEN HAD INTERCOURSE, SUCH AN ACT IS IMPROPER CONDUCT, BUT THE UNCLEANNESS OF THEIR TOUCH AND THEIR LIABILITY TO A SACRIFICE ON ACCOUNT OF THEIR INTERCOURSE ARE IN SUSPENSE. Does not this represent the general view?[^fn_72b_12] — No, it is only the view of Beth Hillel. For it was taught: Said R. Judah to Beth Hillel: Do you then call such an act improper conduct, seeing that this man only intended to have intercourse with a menstruant? — 'A menstruant'! How could such an idea be entertained? — Rather read: To have intercourse with a zabah. 'A zabah'! How could this idea be entertained? — Rather read: To have intercourse with one who waits a day for a day.

It was stated: As to the tenth day,[^fn_72b_13] R. Johanan ruled, The tenth is on a par with the ninth; as the ninth[^fn_72b_14] must be followed[^fn_72b_15] by observation[^fn_72b_16] so must the tenth[^fn_72b_17] be followed by observation.[^fn_72b_18] Resh Lakish ruled: The tenth is on a par with the eleventh; as the eleventh[^fn_72b_19] need not be followed by observation[^fn_72b_20] so the tenth need not be followed by observation.

Some there are who teach this[^fn_72b_21] in connection with the following. R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah said to R. Akiba, Even if you were all day to draw inferences from[^fn_72b_22] the repetition of 'with oil'[^fn_72b_23] I would not listen to you, the fact being that the prescribed quantities of half a *log* of oil for a thanksgiving-offering, and a quarter of a *log* of wine for a nazirite, and the eleven days that intervene between one menstruation period and the next are the *halachah* of Moses handed down from Sinai. What is the '*halachah*' referred to? — R. Johanan replied: The one *halachah* applicable to the eleventh day.[^fn_72b_24] Resh Lakish replied: The halachahs[^fn_72b_25] applicable to the eleventh day. 'R. Johanan replied: The one *halachah* applicable to the eleventh day' i.e., the eleventh day[^fn_72b_26] only need not be followed[^fn_72b_27] by a day of observation[^fn_72b_28] but for the other days[^fn_72b_29] it[^fn_72b_30] does serve as a day of observation. But 'Resh Lakish replied: The halachahs applicable to the eleventh day', i.e., neither need the eleventh be followed by one of observation nor does it serve as one of observation for the tenth.[^fn_72b_31] But are these[^fn_72b_32] halachahs? Are they not in fact derived from Scriptural texts? For it was taught: As it might have been presumed that if a woman observes a discharge on three consecutive days at the beginning of a menstruation period she shall be a zabah,[^fn_72b_33] and that the text[^fn_72b_34] 'If a woman have an issue and her issue in her flesh be blood'[^fn_72b_35] applies[^fn_72b_36] to one who observed a discharge on one day only[^fn_72b_37] it was, therefore, explicitly stated, [pg 73a]

Not in the time of her menstruation,[^fn_73a_1] implying,[^fn_73a_2] close to the time of her menstruation.[^fn_73a_3] Thus I only know about[^fn_73a_4] the three days that immediately follow[^fn_73a_5] the period of her menstruation, whence is it deduced that the same restrictions apply where the three days are separated from the period of her menstruation by one day? It was explicitly stated, Or if she have an issue.[^fn_73a_6] Thus I only know about an interval of one day, whence is it deduced that the restrictions extend \[where the day or the days on which the discharge appeared were\] separated \[from the menstruation period\] by two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine or ten days? You may reason thus: As we find in the case of the fourth day[^fn_73a_7] that[^fn_73a_8] it is suitable for the counting[^fn_73a_9] and[^fn_73a_10] is also appropriate as one for *zibah*[^fn_73a_11] so may I also introduce[^fn_73a_12] the tenth day[^fn_73a_13] since it is both suitable for the prescribed counting[^fn_73a_14] and appropriate as one for *zibah*.[^fn_73a_15] But whence is it deduced that the eleventh day[^fn_73a_16] is also included?[^fn_73a_17] It was explicitly stated, Not in the time of her menstruation.[^fn_73a_18] Might I also[^fn_73a_19] include[^fn_73a_17] the twelfth day?[^fn_73a_7] You must admit that this cannot be done.[^fn_73a_20] But what reason do you see for including[^fn_73a_17] the eleventh and for excluding the twelfth? I include the eleventh since it is suitable for being counted \[as one of the seven clean days following the one[^fn_73a_21] that is deduced[^fn_73a_22] from\] 'or if she have an issue'[^fn_73a_23] and I exclude the twelfth since it is not suitable for being counted as one of the seven clean days following the one that is deduced from 'or if she have an issue'.[^fn_73a_24] But so far I only know that *zibah*[^fn_73a_25] is established after a discharge on[^fn_73a_26] three days, whence is it deduced that the restrictions apply to a discharge on two days? It was explicitly stated, Days.[^fn_73a_27] Whence the deduction that the same applies also to a discharge on one day? It was explicitly stated, All the days.[^fn_73a_27] 'Unclean',[^fn_73a_27] implies that she conveys uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her like a menstruant. 'She',[^fn_73a_27] implies that only she conveys uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her but that the *zab* conveys no uncleanness to the woman with whom he had intercourse. But is there not an argument \[a minori ad majus\]: If she, who does not contract uncleanness on account of observation[^fn_73a_28] as on account of days,[^fn_73a_29] does convey uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her, is there not more reason that the man who does contract uncleanness on account of observation as on account of days[^fn_73a_30] should convey uncleanness to the woman with whom he had intercourse? It was expressly stated, 'she',[^fn_73a_27] implying that only she conveys uncleanness to the man who had intercourse with her but that a *zab* does not convey uncleanness to the woman with whom he had intercourse. But whence is it deduced that he conveys uncleanness to couch and seat? It was expressly stated, As the bed of her menstruation.[^fn_73a_31] From this,[^fn_73a_31] however, I would only know the case of a man who experienced a discharge on three days, whence the deduction that the restrictions apply to a discharge on two days? It was explicitly stated, 'Days'. But whence the deduction that the same applies to a discharge on one day? It was stated, 'All the days' — And whence do we infer that the woman must count one day to correspond to one day?[^fn_73a_32] It was stated, She shall be.[^fn_73a_33] As it might have been presumed that she should count seven days after a discharge has appeared on two days only, this being arrived at by the following argument, 'If the man who does not count one day to correspond to one day[^fn_73a_34] counts seven days after a discharge on two days, how much more reason is there that she who does count one day to correspond to one day[^fn_73a_32] should count seven days after a discharge on two days', it was explicitly stated, She shall be,[^fn_73a_33] implying that she counts one day only. It is thus evident,[^fn_73a_35] is it not, that these[^fn_73a_36] are derived from Scriptural texts?[^fn_73a_37] — According to R. Akiba they are derived from Scriptural texts, but according to R. Eleazar b. 'Azariah they are traditional halachahs.

Said R. Shemaiah[^fn_73a_38] to R. Abba:[^fn_73a_39] Might it be suggested that on account of a discharge in the day time[^fn_73a_40] a woman is a zabah, and that on account of one in the night[^fn_73a_41] she is a menstruant? — For your sake,[^fn_73a_42] the other replied, Scripture stated, By[^fn_73a_43] the time of her menstruation,[^fn_73a_44] implying[^fn_73a_45] a discharge close to the time of her menstruation. Now which is a discharge that is close to the time of her menstruation? One that occurred in the night;[^fn_73a_46] and yet Scripture called her a zabah.[^fn_73a_47]

The Tanna debe Eliyahu[^fn_73a_48] \[teaches\]: Whoever repeats[^fn_73a_49] *halachahs* every day may rest assured that he will be a denizen of the world to come, for it is said, Halikoth — *the world is his*;[^fn_73a_50] read not *halikoth*[^fn_73a_51] but *halakoth*.[^fn_73a_52]

[^fn_73a_52]: Or 'halachahs' (the Mishnah, Baraitha, and the oral laws that were handed down through Moses from Sinai). If a man studies these 'halachahs, the world (to come) is his'.

[^fn_2a_1]: In respect of menstrual uncleanness.

[^fn_2a_2]: It being assumed that up to that moment there was no vestige of blood even in the ante-chamber (cf. Mishnah *infra* 40a). Hence only objects that were touched by the woman after the discovery become ritually unclean. All objects touched prior to that moment remain clean.

[^fn_2a_3]: When she discovered the discharge. If the last, for instance, took place at 5 p.m. on a Thursday and the previous one at 8 a.m. on the preceding Sunday, all objects touched since the Sunday examination are deemed to be ritually unclean because it is assumed that some blood, prevented from leaving the body by the walls of the womb, may have made its way into the ante-chamber immediately after that examination.

[^fn_2a_4]: Shammai, whose ruling is too lenient.

[^fn_2a_5]: Hillel, who is too restrictive, since blood could not well be retained in the ante-chamber for a very long time.

[^fn_2a_6]: Me'eth le'eth, lit., 'from time to time'.

[^fn_2a_7]: An interval of more than twenty-four hours having intervened between the two examinations.

[^fn_2a_8]: The two examinations having taken place within twenty-four hours.

[^fn_2a_9]: Before and after.

[^fn_2a_10]: Lit., 'behold this'.

[^fn_2a_11]: In the case of 'ANY WOMAN WHO HAS A SETTLED PERIOD (*supra*).

[^fn_2a_12]: In the preparation, for instance, of foodstuffs.

[^fn_2a_13]: The bed, and the foodstuffs which she handled.

[^fn_2a_14]: The Sages.

[^fn_2a_15]: A woman who had no settled period.

[^fn_2a_16]: From the time she observed the flow.

[^fn_2a_17]: Prescribed in Lev. XV, 19.

[^fn_2a_18]: For his ruling in the first clause of our Mishnah.

[^fn_2a_19]: About whom it is uncertain when her flow began.

[^fn_2a_20]: Lit., 'cause to stand … upon'.

[^fn_2a_21]: Spoken of in our Mishnah.

[^fn_2a_22]: Since she was occupied with ritually clean things.

[^fn_2a_23]: How, in view of Shammai's reason, can he maintain his ruling.

[^fn_2a_24]: Which might impair its status.

[^fn_2a_25]: But is due to some external cause. MS.M. adds, 'as, for instance, when it is doubtful whether one did, or did not touch (an unclean object)'.

[^fn_2b_1]: The case of the menstruant.

[^fn_2b_2]: Both according to Shammai and Hillel.

[^fn_2b_3]: Which must contain a minimum of forty *se'ah* of water.

[^fn_2b_4]: Where a case of doubtful uncleanness is elsewhere regarded as clean.

[^fn_2b_5]: Where a doubtful case is regarded as unclean (cf. prev. n.).

[^fn_2b_6]: Since the bath is now ritually invalid.

[^fn_2b_7]: Mik. II, 2.

[^fn_2b_8]: Who ruled that the period of uncleanness of menstruant women begins FROM THE TIME OF THEIR DISCOVERY OF THE FLOW and not retrospectively.

[^fn_2b_9]: According to the Sages; or the interval between her last and previous examinations according to Hillel (v. our Mishnah).

[^fn_2b_10]: V.

[^fn_2b_11]: As explained *infra* 6a.

[^fn_2b_12]: In the case of the ritual bath, where it is categorically stated 'are retrospectively unclean'.

[^fn_2b_13]: And the *terumah* must be burned.

[^fn_2b_14]: For the restrictions.

[^fn_2b_15]: The case of the ritual bath.

[^fn_2b_16]: Of uncleanness, which before valid immersion is a certainty.

[^fn_2b_17]: On account of the discovered invalidity of the ritual bath he used.

[^fn_2b_18]: Since the invalidity may have begun at the time the immersion took place.

[^fn_2b_19]: At the time of the immersion.

[^fn_2b_20]: That of the menstruant.

[^fn_2b_21]: Hence there is no need to assume that the flow began any earlier.

[^fn_2b_22]: Ritual bath.

[^fn_2b_23]: As far as is known.

[^fn_2b_24]: Why then should it be assumed to have been lacking earlier?

[^fn_2b_25]: Lit., 'thus, now'.

[^fn_2b_26]: So that the presumptive state of validity has long ago been impaired. And since it is not known when the process began the restrictive ruling given is well justified.

[^fn_2b_27]: Obviously not. Hence it may well be assumed that the flow began only at the moment when it was discovered.

[^fn_2b_28]: While in fact a particle of it which is quite sufficient to cause uncleanness (cf. *infra* 40) may have been in the antechamber long before she was aware of any flow.

[^fn_2b_29]: That of the ritual bath.

[^fn_2b_30]: The assumption that the unclean person was in his confirmed status of uncleanness and the lacking condition of the bath.

[^fn_2b_31]: The case of the menstruant.

[^fn_2b_32]: The present observation of the blood. Since against this factor there is the favourable one of the woman's previous condition of confirmed cleanness it may well be assumed that the flow began not earlier than the moment when it was observed.

[^fn_2b_33]: According to Shammai.

[^fn_2b_34]: What follows is a Baraitha (Tosef. Ter. IV) and is quoted here as Mishnah. This is not an isolated instance. V. Higger Ozar ha Beraitoth, pp. 37ff.

[^fn_2b_35]: Either by tasting some of its contents (Rashi) the *terumah* and tithe having been duly taken from it (Rashb. B.B. 96a) or by smelling it (Tosaf. l.c.).

[^fn_2b_36]: In order that he might be allowed to use the wine in the other jugs he keeps this one jug for the purpose of taking from it daily, or whenever required, the appropriate quantity of wine as *terumah* or tithe for the wine in the other jugs.

[^fn_2b_37]: After a month or two, for instance.

[^fn_2b_38]: A liquid which (according to Rabbi, B.B. 84b) may not be used as *terumah* for wine.

[^fn_2b_39]: So MS.M. and Rashal. Cur. edd. in parenthesis insert 'the first'.

[^fn_2b_40]: V. following note.

[^fn_2b_41]: Tosef. Ter. IV. The meaning according to R. Johanan (B.B. 96a) is that during the first three days after the test the contents of the jug are regarded as 'certain' wine because in less than three days wine cannot turn into vinegar. Even if it be assumed that it began to turn sour immediately after the test it could not be called 'vinegar' until full three days had elapsed. The *terumah* given within these three days must inevitably have been wine and consequently have exempted the wine in the other jugs. After three days the contents are regarded as 'doubtful wine' since it is possible that the wine began to deteriorate only three days before it was found to be vinegar, into which it may have turned just at that moment. As the *terumah* is accordingly of a doubtful nature another portion must be set aside for the purpose. The meaning according to R. Joshua b. Levi (ibid.) is that during the last three days prior to the discovery that it had turned into vinegar, it is regarded as 'certain' vinegar because, in his opinion, the contents are deemed to be vinegar as soon as the wine begins to deteriorate in odour though its taste may still be that of wine. Since it is now proper vinegar the deterioration must have commenced at least three days earlier. Prior to the three days it is regarded as 'doubtful' because it is unknown when the deterioration had set in.

[^fn_2b_42]: The ruling in the Baraitha cited according to which where unfavourable factors exist restrictions are applied retrospectively.

[^fn_2b_43]: Who ruled in our Mishnah that menstruants are not deemed to have been unclean for any length of time retrospectively, but reckon their period of uncleanness only from the moment OF THEIR DISCOVERING THE FLOW.

[^fn_2b_44]: In the Baraitha cited.

[^fn_2b_45]: The untithed wine, v.

[^fn_2b_46]: Sc. that the priestly and levitical dues have not been duly set aside for it.

[^fn_2b_47]: Of being wine.

[^fn_2b_48]: That of the menstruant.

[^fn_2b_49]: That of the jug of wine.

[^fn_2b_50]: So that it lost its status long before it completely turned into vinegar.

[^fn_2b_51]: Of course not. Hence the assumption that the flow began the moment it was discovered.

[^fn_2b_52]: The confirmed status of the wine as *tebel* and its present sour condition.

[^fn_2b_53]: The present observation of the blood.

[^fn_2b_54]: Cited *supra* from Tosef. Ter. IV.

[^fn_2b_55]: Mik. II, 2, also cited *supra*.

[^fn_2b_56]: In both of which (as stated *supra*) there are equally two unfavourable factors.

[^fn_2b_57]: Mik. II, 2.

[^fn_2b_58]: Cited *supra* from Tosef. Ter. IV.

[^fn_2b_59]: So marg. gl. Cur. edd. 'we learnt'.

[^fn_2b_60]: *Supra* q.v. notes.

[^fn_2b_61]: Tosef. Mik. I; the reason is discussed *infra*.

[^fn_3a_1]: R. Simeon and the first Tanna.

[^fn_3a_2]: Each his respective rulings in the Baraitha just cited.

[^fn_3a_3]: V. , in connection with whom Scripture speaks of uncleanness or defilement (cf. Num. V, 13).

[^fn_3a_4]: Sc. the first Tanna (cf. *supra* n. 7).

[^fn_3a_5]: A sotah, until her innocence is proved by the test (cf. Num. V, 15-28), being definitely forbidden to her husband.

[^fn_3a_6]: The case of the ritual bath under discussion.

[^fn_3a_7]: Where no privacy is possible.

[^fn_3a_8]: Lit., 'thus, now'.

[^fn_3a_9]: Sotah.

[^fn_3a_10]: Of the woman's uncleanness or prohibition to her husband.

[^fn_3a_11]: Of the woman with the suspected stranger.

[^fn_3a_12]: Hence the ruling that in such a case the woman is deemed clean.

[^fn_3a_13]: Of uncleanness.

[^fn_3a_14]: Of the water in the bath.

[^fn_3a_15]: Nothing. Hence the Rabbis' ruling that all purifications effected, irrespective of domain, are deemed to be unclean.

[^fn_3a_16]: As pointed out *supra* 2b.

[^fn_3a_17]: The case of the ritual bath under discussion.

[^fn_3a_18]: Lit., 'thus, now'.

[^fn_3a_19]: Sotah.

[^fn_3a_20]: Lit., 'there are feet for the thing'

[^fn_3a_21]: Her husband.

[^fn_3a_22]: In the case of the bath. As there is no basis whatever for the assumption that this deficiency occurred before the purifications had been effected it may well be assumed that it occurred afterwards immediately before the bath was measured. It has thus been shown, as R. Hanina replied *supra*, that according to R. Simeon all cases of doubtful uncleanness in a private domain where there is no basis for the affirmation of the uncleanness, are regarded as being in suspense.

[^fn_3a_23]: For holding doubtful cases of uncleanness in a public domain to be clean.

[^fn_3a_24]: Sc. ritual immersion which takes place when the period of uncleanness is concluded.

[^fn_3a_25]: I.e., uncleanness contracted from coming in contact with an unclean object.

[^fn_3a_26]: How, in view of R. Simeon's inference, could they maintain (v. *supra* 2b ad fin.) that 'all purifications … whether it was in a public or in a private domain, are unclean'?

[^fn_3a_27]: Lit., 'thus, now'.

[^fn_3a_28]: The case of the inception of uncleanness.

[^fn_3a_29]: In a case of termination of uncleanness.

[^fn_3a_30]: The case of the menstruant in our Mishnah.

[^fn_3a_31]: According to Shammai.

[^fn_3a_32]: To all clean objects that were in the alley prior to its discovery.

[^fn_3a_33]: Sc. only clean objects that were in the alley prior to that examination are ritually clean since the examination has established that during that time there was no creeping thing in the alley.

[^fn_3a_34]: *Infra* 56a; and no creeping thing was found. The sweeping, which is presumably accompanied by a search for any unclean things, has the same force as a direct examination. Hence (cf. prev. n.) only objects that were in the alley prior to the sweeping are clean while those that were there after the sweeping, since a creeping thing may have fallen into the alley immediately after the sweeping was over, are regarded as unclean. Now seeing that here uncleanness in a doubtful case is caused retrospectively, why does Shammai in our Mishnah restrict the period of uncleanness to the time of THEIR DISCOVERING only?

[^fn_3a_35]: The case of the alley in the Mishnah just cited.

[^fn_3a_36]: To the objection raised against Shammai.

[^fn_3a_37]: For his ruling that menstruants begin their period of uncleanness from the time OF THEIR DISCOVERING OF THE FLOW only and not, as in the case of the alley, retrospectively.

[^fn_3a_38]: As she did not feel any prior to her present discovery it may be safely assumed that previously there had not been any.

[^fn_3a_39]: How, in view of this argument, can he maintain that a menstruant's uncleanness is RECKONED RETROSPECTIVELY?

[^fn_3a_40]: Of the menstrual flow.

[^fn_3a_41]: When the woman is unconscious of it. As this is quite possible, why does not Shammai extend the period of uncleanness retrospectively?

[^fn_3a_42]: In Shammai's opinion.

[^fn_3a_43]: Of the flow.

[^fn_3a_44]: As she did not awake, it may well be presumed that the flow began just before its discovery.

[^fn_3a_45]: Who is incapable of distinguishing the first appearance of a flow.

[^fn_3a_46]: That the period of uncleanness extends retrospectively.

[^fn_3a_47]: Which presumably includes the imbecile also.

[^fn_3a_48]: Omitting 'ALL'.

[^fn_3a_49]: *Infra* 7a.

[^fn_3a_50]: Shammai.

As the uncleanness that is conveyed to vessels by liquids is merely Rabbinical, and as it was desired to make a distinction between Pentateuchal and Rabbinical uncleanness, it was enacted that, in such a case, only the outsides of vessels and not their insides shall contract the uncleanness.

Hence whatever its colour the woman cannot be regarded as a menstruant. R. Judah, however, maintains that the uterus never opens without some bleeding though this may sometimes escape observation. The woman is, therefore, unclean on account of the inevitable discharge of the blood of labour even though the object was green or white and no blood whatsoever had been observed. The Rabbis, on the other hand, maintain that the uterus sometimes opens without any accompanying bleeding and the woman is, therefore, clean whenever no discharge is observed.

[^fn_44b_6]: If, for instance, there were two brothers other than the boy in question, and one of them was the firstborn, the estate is divided, not into three portions (two for the ordinary portions of the two brothers and one for the birthright), but into four portions. Each brother, including the young child, receives one such portion and the firstborn receives the additional fourth portion as his birthright. The firstborn thus receives, as the portion of his birthright, a quarter of the estate, and not (as would have been the case if the child were excluded) a third.

[^fn_44b_7]: Though he receives his due portion in the estate. In the case mentioned as an instance in the prev. n. the estate would first be divided into three portions (as if the embryo did not exist) and the firstborn would receive, as his birthright, one of these, which represents a third of the estate. The remaining two thirds would then be divided into three equal shares, each of the three brothers receiving one, I.e., two ninths of the estate. The full portion of the firstborn would accordingly amount to (1/3 + 2/9 = 5/9) five ninths of the estate, while, where the child was one day old, the firstborn's full portion would only amount to half the estate, i.e., (5/9 — 1/2 = 1/18) one eighteenth less.

[^fn_54a_7]: Again counting from the day of the first discharge (cf. prev. n. but one). As she never discharges on three consecutive days she can never become a major zabah (who must allow seven clean days to pass before she can attain cleanness). When she discharges on the ninth day (one of the alternate unclean days) she, as a minor zabah (the discharge having taken place within the eleven days of the *zibah* period which began on the eighth), must allow one clean day (the tenth) to pass and may perform her marital duty in the night following it. Observing a discharge on the eleventh day (one of the alternate unclean days) she allows the twelfth day to pass and performs her duty in the night that follows. Similarly she may perform her marital duty on the nights following respectively the fourteenth and the sixteenth. By the time eighteen days have passed with the sunset of the eighteenth day she has, in addition to the eighth day and night following it, the four nights that follow respectively the tenth, twelfth, fourteenth and sixteenth day. The night following the eighteenth day is again one in which performance of marital duty is permitted, but it belongs to the next cycle. On the nineteenth, the seven days of menstruation begin again and the cycle is repeated.

[^fn_54a_8]: Of the alternate unclean days.

[^fn_54a_9]: After her first discharge, sc. the day and the night preceding it. On the day she is definitely clean since her discharge does not appear until evening, and in the previous night she is also clean since with the day preceding it (the seventh) her unclean menstruation period had come to an end.

[^fn_54a_10]: During the first seven days she is unclean as a menstruant and in the night following the eighth (one of the alternate unclean nights) she is unclean as a minor zabah (the *zibah* period having commenced on the eighth) and must consequently allow one day, the ninth, to pass. On the night following the ninth (another of the alternate unclean nights) she is again unclean as a minor zabah and must again allow a day, the tenth, to pass, and so on until the termination of eighteen days when a new cycle of the same number of days begins in which again she is allowed marital duty on the eighth day and the night preceding it only.

[^fn_54a_21]: Of the *zibah* period (the eighteenth in the cycle).

Hence it is that marital intercourse cannot in this case be permitted before the twentieth.

[^fn_54a_25]: The eleventh and twelfth after her first discharge. [^fn_54a_26]: Since after the twelfth day she will never attain cleanness. [^fn_54a_28]: Cf. prev. n, but one mut. mut.

[^fn_54a_29]: The eighth, ninth and tenth (immediately following the first menstruation period) being the last three of the first group of five clean days.

[^fn_54a_31]: That follow the unclean seven days of the menstruation period.

[^fn_54a_32]: Made up as follows: Seven unclean days of menstruation, seven days of cleanness (in which marital intercourse is permitted), seven days of uncleanness in which the woman becomes a major zabah and seven days that must be counted after the confirmed *zibah*; and so on with each cycle of twenty-eight days.

[^fn_54a_33]: The tenth to the sixteenth (seven days), the twenty-sixth to the thirty-second (seven days) and the forty-eighth (7 + 7 + 1 = 15 days). Cf. foll. n.

[^fn_54a_34]: Composed as follows: Eight unclean days (the last of which being the first of the eleven days of *zibah* turns the woman into a minor zabah); one day (the first of the second group of eight days) that must be allowed to pass by a minor zabah before cleanness is attained, and seven clean days in which marital intercourse is permitted; two days (the first of the third group of eight days) of *zibah* (being the last two of the eleven days of the first *zibah* period) and six days of the second menstruation period; one day (the first of the fourth group of eight days) completing the seventh day of menstruation, and seven days in which marital intercourse is permitted; eight days of uncleanness (the fifth group of eight days during the first three of which she becomes a major zabah); seven days (the first of the sixth group) that serve as the number of days prescribed for a major zabah and one day (the last of the sixth group and the forty-eighth day in the cycle) in which marital intercourse is permitted.

[^fn_54a_38]: Sc. of the seven days.

It is also possible that the birth was a proper one and that it was accompanied by bleeding in which case it is both a valid birth and a proper *zibah*. On the second day of her arrival she again undergoes immersion for a similar reason, since it is possible that the day on which her discharge had appeared was not the previous one but the day of her arrival. On the third day no immersion is necessary since it is certain that on the second there was no discharge.

[^fn_69a_51]: She performs the first two immersions for the same reason as in the former case, since it is possible that her discharge in *zibah* took place on the day prior to her arrival (so that immersion must be performed immediately at the twilight when she arrived) or on that day (so that immersion has to be performed on the following day). She must also undergo immersion on the third day since it is possible that the discharge occurred at the twilight at which she arrived and that that time was a part of the night, so that she was unclean on the day following, and having waited the second day she becomes clean on the third when the immersion is performed.
