[^fn_72a_30]: Noshekin, lit., 'you bite'. Golds. suggests the reading mushabin, 'you are answered'.

[^fn_72a_31]: Lit., 'make your measures equal'.

[^fn_72a_32]: So MS.M. and Rashi. Cur. edd. 'her couch and seat'.

[^fn_72a_33]: Sc. the day following one of the intermediate days of the *zibah* period on which she experienced a discharge.

[^fn_72a_34]: Rabbinically.

[^fn_72a_35]: On the second day.

[^fn_72a_36]: Retrospectively, in accordance with Pentateuchal law, since the discharge on the second day is joined to that on the first to constitute a continuous *zibah*.

[^fn_72a_37]: As a preventive measure.

[^fn_72a_38]: R. Huna.

[^fn_72a_39]: By his statement.

[^fn_72a_40]: The day following the eleventh of a *zibah* period, which is the first of the following menstruation period, and a discharge on which cannot be treated as a continuation of the *zibah* discharge of the previous day.

[^fn_72a_41]: Cur. edd. use here the fem. sing.

[^fn_72a_42]: In cur. edd., the plural is here used.

[^fn_72a_43]: Now, since a discharge on the twelfth day cannot be treated as a continuation of that on the eleventh (cf. prev. n. but two) and since it does not invalidate the immersion on that day, that discharge, as far as *zibah* is concerned, might well be regarded as if it had never occurred. The case is consequently similar to that of R. Huna where a discharge on an intermediate day in the *zibah* period was followed by a day on which none had occurred. As in the Mishnah, where the second discharge occurred on the twelfth, uncleanness has been imposed Rabbinically as a preventive measure against the possibility of a second discharge occurring on the eleventh so also in the case of R. Huna uncleanness must be imposed where no discharge occurred on the second day as a preventive measure against the possibility of a discharge occurring on the second day. What need then was there for R. Huna to make a statement which is implicit in the ruling of our Mishnah?

[^fn_72a_44]: Against R. Huna.

[^fn_72a_45]: The case dealt with in our Mishnah though that discharge could not be attributed to *zibah*.

[^fn_72a_46]: From one where there was no discharge at all. How then could R. Huna maintain his statement?

[^fn_72a_47]: The case in our Mishnah.

[^fn_72a_48]: Which cannot be attributed to *zibah*; and consequently (cf. p. 501, n. 13) might be regarded (as in the case of R. Huna) as if no discharge had taken place. What then is the basis of R. Kahana's objection?

[^fn_72a_49]: Who advanced the opinion that 'where she observed a discharge the case is different'.

[^fn_72a_50]: The ruling concerning one discharge being likely to be misunderstood for that of another discharge.

[^fn_72a_51]: And since the absence of a discharge is not likely to be misunderstood for a discharge.

[^fn_72a_52]: Contrary to the view of R. Huna.

[^fn_72a_53]: Sc. who must allow one clean day to pass for every day on which she experienced a discharge before she may be regarded as clean. As the uncleanness of the touch of such a woman on the second day after she performed immersion is left in suspense to provide against the possibility of a discharge appearing later in the day, so must also be the uncleanness of such a person if after experiencing the discharge he performed immersion. If, e.g., he touches tithe its uncleanness must remain in suspense in case he observes a second discharge which would continue his former *zibah*.

[^fn_72a_54]: Sc. he is clean in regard to tithe immediately after his immersion. At all events it was here stated that, according to Beth Shammai, a woman who waits a day for a day is on a par with a man who experienced a first discharge of *zibah*.

[^fn_72b_1]: Regarding a *zab* who experienced one discharge.

[^fn_72b_2]: Who was clean.

[^fn_72b_3]: Until evening. If the *zab* experienced a second discharge on that day he becomes a confirmed *zab* retrospectively and the man who shook the discharge becomes unclean.

[^fn_72b_4]: As is the case with one who caused the shaking of semen who remains clean.

[^fn_72b_5]: And if she experiences no second discharge she is clean.

[^fn_72b_6]: Because R. Huna agrees in the case of the man that, if the intercourse took place on the second day after the woman's immersion, the question of his uncleanness must he held in suspense and that before a second discharge appears he is even Rabbinically free from certain uncleanness.

[^fn_72b_7]: The man who had the intercourse.

[^fn_72b_8]: Which he alone occupied.

[^fn_72b_9]: To couch and seat that have been occupied by her.

[^fn_72b_10]: That, even where the woman observed no discharge after their intercourse, he shall convey uncleanness to couch and seat.

[^fn_72b_11]: Since a preventive measure was enacted in her case on account of her tendency to bleed.

[^fn_72b_12]: Even that of Beth Shammai who accordingly hold that on the day following a discharge during the intermediate days of the *zibah* period the woman's touch causes only a suspended uncleanness. An objection thus arises against R. Huna who maintained that according to Beth Shammai couch and seat in such circumstances are held to be unclean.

[^fn_72b_13]: Sc. a first discharge on the tenth day of the *zibah* period. Such a discharge can never develop into a major *zibah* (by being repeated on three consecutive days) since the tenth day is followed by one day only of the *zibah* period (the eleventh) the twelfth being the first of the next menstruation period.

[^fn_72b_14]: Since a discharge on it may develop (if it is repeated on the tenth and the eleventh) into a major *zibah*.

[^fn_72b_15]: Lit., 'requires'.

[^fn_72b_16]: On the next day.

[^fn_72b_17]: If it was the first day in the *zibah* period on which a discharge appeared.

[^fn_72b_18]: On the eleventh; though a repeated discharge on the latter day would not constitute a major *zibah*.

[^fn_72b_19]: Which is the last day of the *zibah* period.

[^fn_72b_20]: According to Beth Hillel the day following being one of menstruation.

[^fn_72b_21]: The dispute between R. Johanan and Resh Lakish.

[^fn_72b_22]: Lit., increase, i.e., to regard every Scriptural mention of 'with oil', in connection with the thanksgiving-offering, as implying an addition to the quantity specified. Any two additions imply a reduction (cf. Zeb. 82a, 89a).

[^fn_72b_23]: Lit., 'with oil, with oil,' (cf. Rashal and BaH.).

[^fn_72b_24]: Of a *zibah* period.

[^fn_72b_25]: Two.

[^fn_72b_26]: If a discharge was observed on it.

[^fn_72b_27]: As any other of the eleven days must.

[^fn_72b_28]: Since the next day is the first of the menstruation period.

[^fn_72b_29]: The tenth.

[^fn_72b_30]: The eleventh.

[^fn_72b_31]: This is the Pentateuchal law. Rabbinically, however, even the eleventh day must be followed by one of observation before the woman may be regarded as clean.

[^fn_72b_32]: The rules regarding the eleventh day.

[^fn_72b_35]: Lev. XV, 19, which implies that neither the counting of seven days nor any sacrifice is required.

[^fn_72b_36]: Cf. prev. n. but one.

[^fn_72b_37]: Cf. Rashal. Cur. edd. in parenthesis, 'but she who observes on three days at the beginning shall be a zabah'.

[^fn_73a_1]: Lev. XV, 25. E.V., 'of her impurity'.

[^fn_73a_2]: Cur. edd. in parenthesis, 'beyond the time of her menstruation'.

[^fn_73a_3]: Sc. the three consecutive days on which a discharge appears and which subject the woman to the restrictions of a major zabah must be close to (not within) the seven days of the menstruation period, viz., the first three days of the period of *zibah*.

[^fn_73a_4]: Lit., 'and I have not but'.

[^fn_73a_5]: Lit., 'near to'.

[^fn_73a_6]: Lev. XV, 25.

[^fn_73a_7]: After the menstruation period.

[^fn_73a_8]: Where the discharge appeared on the first three days following menstruation and then ceased.

[^fn_73a_9]: Of the prescribed seven days beginning with it.

[^fn_73a_10]: As has just been deduced from Lev. XV, 25: Or if she have an issue.

[^fn_73a_11]: If the discharge first appeared on the second day following menstruation and was repeated on the third and fourth.

[^fn_73a_12]: Under the *zibah* restrictions.

[^fn_73a_13]: And, much more so, the other days enumerated.

[^fn_73a_14]: Where the discharge appeared on the first three days after menstruation.

[^fn_73a_15]: If the discharge occurred on it as well as on the preceding two days.

[^fn_73a_16]: Which, if the discharge appeared on the first three days, cannot be counted among the seven days prescribed.

[^fn_73a_17]: In the restrictions, so that if a discharge appeared on it and on the preceding two days *zibah* is established.

[^fn_73a_18]: Lev. XV, 25. E.V. 'of her impurity'.

[^fn_73a_19]: As a deduction from the text just cited.

[^fn_73a_20]: A discharge on the twelfth being regarded as one of menstruation that cannot be added to the *zibah*.

[^fn_73a_21]: The fourth day.

[^fn_73a_22]: *Supra*.

[^fn_73a_23]: The seven days following a discharge on the fourth terminating on the eleventh.

[^fn_73a_24]: It being the first day of menstruation.

[^fn_73a_25]: That conveys uncleanness to couch and seat.

[^fn_73a_26]: Lit., 'and I have not but'.

[^fn_73a_27]: Lev. XV, 25.

[^fn_73a_28]: If, e.g., she experienced three discharges on one day she is not regarded as a major zabah (v. foll. n.) to incur the obligation of a sacrifice.

[^fn_73a_29]: A discharge that appeared on three consecutive days confirms a woman as a major zabah (cf. prev. n.).

[^fn_73a_30]: A man is confirmed as a *zab* irrespective of whether he observed three discharges on three consecutive days respectively or all the three discharges on the same day (cf. B.K. 24a).

[^fn_73a_31]: Lev. XV, 16.

[^fn_73a_32]: Sc. if she experienced a discharge on one day she must allow one clean day to pass before she may be regarded as clean.

[^fn_73a_33]: Lit., 'shall be to her', Lev. XV, 25.

[^fn_73a_34]: After one discharge on one day he performs immersion in the evening and resumes his cleanness.

[^fn_73a_35]: The argument begun on 72b ad fin. is now resumed and concluded.

[^fn_73a_36]: The laws regarding the intervals between the menstruation periods, viz., that each interval extends over eleven days; that a discharge on three consecutive days of these eleven subjects the woman to the restrictions of a major zabah; that after a discharge on only one or two of these days no more than one clean day need be allowed to pass; that after the eleven days' period the menstruation period begins, and that a discharge on the first of these causes the woman to be unclean on that day and on the following six days.

[^fn_73a_37]: How then could it be stated *supra* that these laws were halachahs?

[^fn_73a_39]: *Var. lec*., Raba (MS.M.).
